question:
The density of a material in SI unit is $128 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. In certain units in which the unit of length is 25 cm and the unit of mass is 50 g , the numerical value of density of the material is:

$
solution:
\item  Density of material in SI unit,

$=\frac{128 \mathrm{~kg}}{\mathrm{~m}^{3}}$

Density of material in new system

$=\frac{128(50 \mathrm{~g})(20)}{(25 \mathrm{~cm})^{3}(4)^{3}}=\frac{128}{64}(20)=40$ units

question: A metal sample carrying a current along X -axis with density $\mathrm{J}_{\mathrm{x}}$ is subjected to a magnetic field $\mathrm{B}_{\mathrm{z}}$ (along z -axis). The electric field $\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{y}}$ developed along Y -axis is directly proportional to $\mathrm{J}_{\mathrm{x}}$ as well as $\mathrm{B}_{\mathrm{Z}}$. The constant of proportionality has SI unit
solution:
\item  According to question

$\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{y}} \propto \mathrm{J}_{\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{B}_{\mathrm{Z}}$

$\therefore$ Constant of proportionality

$K=\frac{E_{y}}{B_{Z} J_{x}}=\frac{C}{J_{x}}=\frac{m^{3}}{A s}$

[As $\frac{E}{B}=C$ (speed of light) and $J=\frac{I}{\text { Area }}$ ]

question: The quantities $x=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}}, y=\frac{E}{B}$ and $z=\frac{1}{C R}$ are defined where $C$-capacitance, $R$-Resistance, $l$-length, $E$-Electric field, $B$-magnetic field and $\varepsilon_{0}, \mu_{0}$, - free space permittivity and permeability respectively. Then :
options: a) $x, y$ and $z$ have the same dimension.
b) Only $x$ and $z$ have the same dimension.
c) Only $x$ and $y$ have the same dimension.
d) Only $y$ and $z$ have the same dimension.
solution:
\item  We know that

Speed of light, $c=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}}=x$

Also, $c=\frac{E}{B}=y$

Time constant, $\tau=R c=t$

$\therefore z=\frac{l}{R c}=\frac{l}{t}=$ Speed

Thus, $x, y, z$ will have the same dimension of speed.

question: Dimensional formula for thermal conductivity is (here $K$ denotes the temperature :
A quantity $x$ is given by $\left(I F v^{2} / W L^{4}\right)$ in terms of moment of inertia $I$, force $F$, velocity $v$, work $W$ and Length $L$. The dimensional formula for $x$ is same as that of :
solution:
\item  Dimension of Force $F=\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}$

Dimension of velocity $V=\mathrm{L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}$

Dimension of work $=\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}$

Dimension of length $=\mathrm{L}$

Moment of inertia $=\mathrm{ML}^{2}$

$\therefore x=\frac{I F v^{2}}{W L^{4}}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{\left(\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{2}\right)\left(\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right)\left(\mathrm{L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right)^{2}}{\left(\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right)\left(\mathrm{L}^{4}\right)} \\
& =\frac{\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}}{\mathrm{~L}^{3}}=\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}=\text { Energy density }
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Amount of solar energy received on the earth's surface per unit area per unit time is defined a solar constant. Dimension of solar constant is :
solution:
\item  Solar constant $=\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Time Area }}$

Dimension of Energy, $E=\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}$

Dimension of Time $=\mathrm{T}$

Dimension of Area $=\mathrm{L}^{2}$

$\therefore$ Dimension of Solar constant

$=\frac{\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}}{\mathrm{TL}^{2}}=\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{-3}$.

question:
If speed V , area A and force F are chosen as fundamental units, then the dimension of Young's modulus will be :


$
solution:
\item  Young's modulus, $Y=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}$

$\Rightarrow Y=\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{A}} / \frac{\Delta \ell}{\ell_{0}}=\mathrm{FA}^{-1} \mathrm{~V}^{0}$

question: If momentum (P), area (A) and time (T) are taken to be the fundamental quantities then the dimensional formula for energy is :
solution:
\item  Energy, $E \propto A^{a} T^{b} P^{c}$


\begin{equation*}
\text { or, } \quad E=k A^{a} T^{b} P^{c} \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


where $k$ is a dimensionless constant and $a, b$ and $c$ are the exponents.

Dimension of momentum, $P=M^{1} L^{1} T^{-1}$

Dimension of area, $A=L^{2}$

Dimension of time, $T=T^{1}$

Putting these value in equation (i), we get

$M^{1} L^{2} T^{-2}=M^{c} L^{2 a+c} T^{b-c}$

by comparison

$c=1$

$2 a+c=2$

$b-c=-2$

$c=1, a=1 / 2, b=-1$

$\therefore E=A^{1 / 2} T^{-1} P^{1}$

question: Which of the following combinations has the dimension of electrical resistance ( $\epsilon_{0}$ is the permittivity of vacuum and $\mu_{0}$ is the permeability of vacuum)?
solution:
\item  $\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}}{\varepsilon_{0}}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0}^{2}}{\varepsilon_{0} \mu_{0}}}=\mu_{0} c \quad\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}}=c\right)$

$\mu_{0} c \rightarrow \mathrm{MLT}^{-2} \mathrm{~A}^{-2} \times \mathrm{LT}^{-1}$

$\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-3} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}$

Dimensions of resistance

question: In the formula $\mathrm{X}=5 \mathrm{YZ}^{2}, \mathrm{X}$ and Z have dimensions of capacitance and magnetic field, respectively. What are the dimensions of Y in SI units ?
solution:
\item  $\mathrm{X}=5 \mathrm{YZ}^{2}$

$\Rightarrow Y \propto \frac{X}{Z^{2}}$\\
$X=$ Capacitance $=\frac{Q}{\mathrm{~V}}=\frac{Q^{2}}{W}=\frac{\left[A^{2} T^{2}\right]}{\left[M L^{2} T^{-2}\right]}$

$\mathrm{X}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^{4} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]$

$Z=B=\frac{F}{I L}$

$[\because F=I L B]$

$\mathrm{Z}=\left[\mathrm{MT}^{-2} \mathrm{~A}^{-1}\right]$

$Y=\frac{\left[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^{4} A^{2}\right]}{\left[M T^{-2} A^{-1}\right]^{2}}$

$\mathrm{Y}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-3} \mathrm{~L}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^{8} \mathrm{~A}^{4}\right]$

(Using (i))

question: In SI units, the dimensions of $\sqrt{\frac{\epsilon_{0}}{\mu_{0}}}$ is:
solution:
\item  $\left[\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{\mu_{0}}}\right]=\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_{0}^{2}}{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}}=\left[\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}}\right]=\varepsilon_{0} C\left[L T^{-1}\right] \times\left[\varepsilon_{0}\right]$

$$
\left[\because \frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}}=C\right]
$$

$\because F=\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}$

$\Rightarrow\left[\varepsilon_{0}\right]=\frac{[A T]^{2}}{\left[M L T^{-2}\right] \times\left[L^{2}\right]}=\left[A^{2} M^{-1} L^{-3} T^{4}\right]$

$\therefore\left[\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{\mu_{0}}}\right]=\left[L T^{-1}\right] \times\left[A^{2} M^{-1} L^{-3} T^{4}\right]$

$=\left[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^{3} A^{2}\right]$

question: Let $l, r, c$ and $v$ represent inductance, resistance, capacitance and voltage, respectively. The dimension of $\frac{\ell}{r c v}$ in SI units will be :
solution:
\item  As we know,

$\left[\frac{\ell}{\mathrm{r}}\right]=[\mathrm{T}]$ and $[\mathrm{cv}]=[\mathrm{AT}]$

$\therefore\left[\frac{\ell}{\mathrm{rcv}}\right]=\left[\frac{\mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{AT}}\right]=\left[\mathrm{A}^{-1}\right]$

question: The force of interaction between two atoms is given by $F=\alpha \beta \exp \left(-\frac{x^{2}}{\alpha k T}\right)$; where $x$ is the distance, k is the Boltzmann constant and T is temperature and $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are two constants. The dimensions of $\beta$ is: $
solution:
\item  Force of interaction between two atoms,

$\mathrm{F}=\alpha \beta \mathrm{e}^{\left(\frac{-\mathrm{x}^{2}}{\alpha \mathrm{kT}}\right)}$

Since exponential terms are dimensionless

$\therefore\left[\frac{\mathrm{x}^{2}}{\alpha \mathrm{kT}}\right]=\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}$

$\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{L}^{2}}{[\alpha] \mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}}=\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}$

$\Rightarrow[\alpha]=\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{2}$

$[F]=[\alpha][\beta]$

$\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}=\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{2}[\beta]$

$\Rightarrow[\beta]=\mathrm{M}^{2} \mathrm{LT}^{-4}$

question: If speed (V), acceleration (A) and force (F) are considered as fundamental units, the dimension of Young's modulus will be :
solution:
\item  $\operatorname{Let}[\mathrm{Y}]=[\mathrm{V}]^{a}[\mathrm{~F}]^{b}[\mathrm{~A}]^{\mathrm{c}}$

$\left[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]^{\mathrm{a}}\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{b}}\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{c}}$

$\left[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]=\left[\mathrm{M}^{\mathrm{b}} \mathrm{L}^{\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b}+\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{T}^{-\mathrm{a}-2 \mathrm{~b}-2 \mathrm{c}}\right]$

Comparing power both side of similar terms we get, $\mathrm{b}=1, \mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b}+\mathrm{c}=-1,-\mathrm{a}-2 \mathrm{~b}-2 \mathrm{c}=-2$

solving above equations we get:

$\mathrm{a}=-4, \mathrm{~b}=1, \mathrm{c}=2$

so $[\mathrm{Y}]=\left[\mathrm{V}^{-4} \mathrm{FA}^{2}\right]=\left[\mathrm{V}^{-4} \mathrm{~A}^{2} \mathrm{~F}\right]$

question:
A quantity $f$ is given by $f=\sqrt{\frac{h c^{5}}{G}}$ where c is speed of light, G universal gravitational constant and $h$ is the Planck's constant. Dimension of $f$ is that of :\\





$]
Expression for time in terms of $G$ (universal gravitational constant), h (Planck's constant) and c (speed of light) is proportional to:
solution:
\item  Let $\mathrm{t} \propto \mathrm{G}^{\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{h}^{\mathrm{y}} \mathrm{C}^{\mathrm{z}}$

Dimensions of $\mathrm{G}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]$,

$\mathrm{h}=\left[\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]$ and $\mathrm{C}=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]$

$[\mathrm{T}]=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{x}}\left[\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]^{\mathrm{y}}\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]^{\mathrm{z}}$

$\left[M^{0} L^{0} T^{1}\right]=\left[M^{-x+y} L^{3 x+2 y+z} T^{-2 x-y-z}\right]$

By comparing the powers of $\mathrm{M}, \mathrm{L}, \mathrm{T}$ both the sides

$-x+y=0 \Rightarrow x=y$

$3 x+2 y+z=0 \Rightarrow 5 x+z=0$

$-2 x-y-z=1 \quad \Rightarrow 3 x+z=-1$

Solving eqns. (i) and (ii),

$\mathrm{x}=\mathrm{y}=\frac{1}{2}, \mathrm{z}=-\frac{5}{2} \therefore \mathrm{t} \propto \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{Gh}}{\mathrm{C}^{5}}}$

question: The dimensions of stopping potential $V_{0}$ in photoelectric effect in units of Planck's constant ' $h$ ', speed of light ' $c$ ' and Gravitational constant ' $G$ ' and ampere $A$ is:
solution:
\item 

Stopping potential $\left(V_{0}\right) \propto h^{x} I^{y} G^{Z} C^{r}$

Here, $h=$ Planck's constant $=\left[M L^{2} T^{-1}\right]$

$I=$ current $=[A]$

$G=$ Gravitational constant $=\left[M^{-1} L^{3} T^{-2}\right]$

and $c=$ speed of light $=\left[L T^{-1}\right]$

$V_{0}=$ potential $=\left[M L^{2} T^{-3} A^{-1}\right]$

$\therefore\left[M L^{2} T^{-3} A^{-1}\right]=\left[M L^{2} T^{-1}\right]^{x}[A]^{y}\left[M^{-1} L^{3} T^{2}\right]^{2}\left[L T^{-1}\right] r$ $M^{x-z} ; L^{2 x+3 z+r} ; T^{-x-2 z-r} ; A^{y}$

Comparing dimension of $\mathrm{M}, \mathrm{L}, \mathrm{T}, \mathrm{A}$, we get

$\mathrm{y}=-1, \mathrm{x}=0, \mathrm{z}=-1, \mathrm{r}=5$

$\therefore V_{0} \propto h^{0} I^{-1} G^{-1} C^{5}$

question: The dimensions of $\frac{B^{2}}{2 \mu_{0}}$, where $B$ is magnetic field and $\mu_{0}$ is the magnetic permeability of vacuum, is:
solution:
\item  The quantity $\frac{B^{2}}{2 \mu_{0}}$ is the energy density of magnetic field.

$\Rightarrow\left[\frac{B^{2}}{2 \mu_{0}}\right]=\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Volume }}=\frac{\text { Force } \times \text { displacement }}{(\text { displacement })^{3}}$

$$
=\left[\frac{M L^{2} T^{-2}}{L^{3}}\right]=M L^{-1} T^{-2}
$$

question: The characteristic distance at which quantum gravitational effects are significant, the Planck length, can be determined from a suitable combination of the fundamental physical constants $\mathrm{G}, \mathrm{h}$ and c . Which of the following correctly gives the Planck length?
solution: \item  Plank length is a unit of length, $l_{p}=1.616229 \times 10^{-35} \mathrm{~m}$ $l_{p}=\sqrt{\frac{h G}{c^{3}}}$

question: Time (T), velocity (C) and angular momentum (h) are chosen as fundamental quantities instead of mass, length and time. In terms of these, the dimensions of mass would be :
solution:
\item  Let mass, related as $M \propto \mathrm{T}^{x} \mathrm{C}^{y} h^{z}$


$\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}=\left(\mathrm{T}^{1}\right)^{x}\left(\mathrm{~L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right)^{y}\left(\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right)^{z}$

$\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}=\mathrm{M}^{z} \mathrm{~L}^{y+2 z}+\mathrm{T}^{\mathrm{x}-\mathrm{y}-\mathrm{z}}$

$\mathrm{z}=1$

$y+2 z=0$

$x-y-z=0$

$y=-2$

$x+2-1=0$

$x=-1$

$\mathrm{M}=\left[\mathrm{T}^{-1} \mathrm{C}^{-2} \mathrm{~h}^{1}\right]$

question: $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}, \mathrm{C}$ and D are four different physical quantities having different dimensions. None of them is dimensionless. But we know that the equation $\mathrm{AD}=\mathrm{C} \ln (\mathrm{BD})$ holds true. Then which of the combination is not a meaningful quantity?
solution: \item  Dimension of $\mathrm{A} \neq$ dimension of (C) Hence $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{C}$ is not possible.

question: In the following 'I' refers to current and other symbols have their usual meaning, Choose the option that corresponds to the dimensions of electrical conductivity:
solution:
\item  We know that resistivity


$\rho=\frac{R A}{\ell}$

Conductivity $=\frac{1}{\text { resistivity }}=\frac{\ell}{\mathrm{RA}}$

$=\frac{\ell \mathrm{I}}{\mathrm{VA}}(\because \mathrm{V}=\mathrm{RI})$

$=\frac{[\mathrm{L}][\mathrm{I}]}{\left[\frac{\left[\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right.}{[\mathrm{I}][\mathrm{T}]}\right] \times\left[\mathrm{L}^{2}\right]} \because \mathrm{V}=\frac{\mathrm{W}}{\mathrm{q}}=\frac{\mathrm{W}}{\mathrm{it}}$

$=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{3}\right]\left[\mathrm{I}^{2}\right]=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{3} \mathrm{I}^{2}\right]$

question: If electronic charge $e$, electron mass $m$, speed of light in vacuum c and Planck's constant h are taken as fundamental quantities, the permeability of vacuum $\mu_{0}$ can be expressed in units of :
solution:
\item  Let $\mu_{0}$ related with $e, m, c$ and $h$ as follows.

$\mu_{0}=k e^{a} m^{b} c^{c} h^{d}$

$$
\left[M L T^{-2} A^{-2}\right]=[A T]^{a}[M]^{b}\left[L T^{-1}\right]^{c}\left[M L^{2} T^{-1}\right]^{d}
$$

$=\left[M^{b+d} L^{c+2 d} T^{a-c-d} A^{a}\right]$

On comparing both sides we get

$a=-2$

$b+d=1$

$c+2 d=1$

$a-c-d=-2$

By equation (i), (ii), (iii) \& (iv) we get,

$a=-2, b=0, c=-1, d=1$

$\therefore\left[\mu_{0}\right]=\left[\frac{h}{c e^{2}}\right]$

question: If the capacitance of a nanocapacitor is measured in terms of a unit ' $u$ ' made by combining the electric charge ' $e$ ', Bohr radius ' $a_{0}$ ', Planck's constant ' $h$ ' and speed of light ' $c$ ' then
solution:
\item  Let unit ' $u$ ' related with $e, a_{0}, h$ and $c$ as follows.

$[u]=[e]^{a}\left[a_{0}\right]^{b}[h]^{c}[C]^{d}$

Using dimensional method,

$\left[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^{+4} A^{+2}\right]=\left[A^{1} T^{1}\right]^{a}[L]^{b}\left[M L 2 T^{-1}\right]^{c}\left[L T^{-1}\right]^{d}$

$\left[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^{+4} A^{+2}\right]=\left[M^{c} L^{b+2 c+d} T^{a-c-d} A^{a}\right]$

$a=2, b=1, c=-1, d=-1$

$\therefore \quad u=\frac{e^{2} a_{0}}{h c}$

question: From the following combinations of physical constants (expressed through their usual symbols) the only combination, that would have the same value in different systems of units, is:
solution:
\item  The dimensional formulae of

$e=\left[M^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{1} \mathrm{~A}^{1}\right]$ $\varepsilon_{0}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{4} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]$

$\mathrm{G}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]$ and $\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{e}}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\right]$

Now, $\frac{\mathrm{e}^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \mathrm{Gm}_{\mathrm{e}}^{2}}$

$=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{1} \mathrm{~A}^{1}\right]^{2}}{2 \pi\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{4} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\right]^{2}}$

$=\frac{\left[\mathrm{T}^{2} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]}{2 \pi\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1-1+2} \mathrm{~L}^{-3+3} \mathrm{~T}^{4-2} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]}$

$=\frac{\left[\mathrm{T}^{2} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]}{2 \pi\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{2} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]}=\frac{1}{2 \pi}$

$\because \frac{1}{2 \pi}$ is dimensionless thus the combination $\frac{\mathrm{e}^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \mathrm{Gm}_{\mathrm{e}}^{2}}$

would have the same value in different systems of units

question: In terms of resistance R and time T , the dimensions of ratio $\frac{\mu}{\varepsilon}$ of the permeability $\mu$ and permittivity $\varepsilon$ is:
solution:
\item  Dimensions of $\mu=\left[M L T^{-2} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}\right]$

Dimensions of $\epsilon=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{4} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]$

Dimensions of $\mathrm{R}=\left[\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-3} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}\right]$

$\therefore \quad \frac{\text { Dimensions of } \mu}{\text { Dimensions of } \epsilon}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{4} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]}$

$=\left[\mathrm{M}^{2} \mathrm{~L}^{4} \mathrm{~T}^{-6} \mathrm{~A}^{-4}\right]=\left[\mathrm{R}^{2}\right]$

question: Let $\left
solution:
\item  As we know, $\mathrm{F}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{\mathrm{q}_{1} \mathrm{q}_{2}}{\mathrm{R}^{2}}$

$\Rightarrow \varepsilon_{0}=\frac{\mathrm{q}_{1} \mathrm{q}_{2}}{4 \pi \mathrm{FR}^{2}}$

Hence, $\varepsilon_{0}=\frac{\mathrm{C}^{2}}{\mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{2}}=\frac{[\mathrm{AT}]^{2}}{\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}\right]\left[\mathrm{L}^{2}\right]}$

$$
=\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{4} \mathrm{~A}^{2}\right]
$$

question: If the time period $t$ of the oscillation of a drop of liquid of density $d$, radius $r$, vibrating under surface tension $s$ is given by the formula $t=\sqrt{r^{2 b} s^{c} d^{a / 2}}$. It is observed that the time period is directly proportional to $\sqrt{\frac{d}{s}}$. The value of $b$ should therefore be :
solution: \item

question: The dimensions of angular momentum, latent heat and capacitance are, respectively.
solution:
\item  Angular momentum $=\mathrm{m} \times \mathrm{v} \times \mathrm{r}=\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}$


Latent heat $\mathrm{L}=\frac{\mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{m}}=\frac{\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}}{\mathrm{M}}=\mathrm{L}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}$

Capacitance $\mathrm{C}=\frac{\text { Charge }}{\text { P.d. }}=\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^{4} \mathrm{~A}^{2}$

question: Given that $K=$ energy, $V=$ velocity, $T=$ time. If they are chosen as the fundamental units, then what is dimensional formula for surface tension?
solution:
\item  Surface tension, $T=\frac{F}{\ell}=\frac{F}{\ell} \cdot \frac{\ell}{\ell} \cdot \frac{T^{2}}{T^{2}}$

(As, $F \cdot \ell=K$ (energy); $\frac{T^{2}}{\ell^{2}}=V^{-2}$ )

Therefore, surface tension $=\left[K V^{-2} T^{-2}\right]$

question: The dimensions of magnetic field in $\mathrm{M}, \mathrm{L}, \mathrm{T}$ and C (coulomb) is given as
solution:
\item  Magnitude of Lorentz formula $F=q v B \sin \theta$

$B=\frac{F}{q v}=\frac{M L T^{-2}}{C \times L T^{-1}}=\left[M T^{-1} C^{-1}\right]$

question: Which of the following units denotes the dimension $\frac{\mathrm{ML}^{2}}{\mathrm{Q}^{2}}$, where $Q$ denotes the electric charge?
solution:
\item  Mutual inductance $=\frac{\phi}{I}=\frac{B A}{I}$

$[$ Henry $]=\frac{\left[M T^{-1} Q^{-1} L^{2}\right]}{\left[Q T^{-1}\right]}=M L^{2} Q^{-2}$

question: Out of the following pair, which one does NOT have identical dimensions ?
options: b) Angular momentum and planck's constant
d) Moment of inertia and moment of a force
solution:
\item  Moment of Inertia, $I=M R^{2}$

$[I]=\left[M L^{2}\right]$

Moment of force, $\vec{\tau}=\vec{r} \times \vec{F}$

$\vec{\tau}=[L]\left[M L T^{-2}\right]=\left[M L^{2} T^{-2}\right]$

question: Which one of the following represents the correct dimensions of the coefficient of viscosity?
solution:
\item  According to, Stokes law,

$F=6 \pi \eta r v \Rightarrow \eta=\frac{F}{6 \pi r v}$

$\eta=\frac{\left[M L T^{-2}\right]}{[L]\left[L T^{-1}\right]} \Rightarrow \eta=\left[M L^{-1} T^{-1}\right]$

question: Dimensions of $\frac{1}{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}$, where symbols have their usual meaning, are
solution:
\item  As we know, the velocity of light in free space is given by

$c=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{o} \varepsilon_{o}}} \therefore \frac{1}{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}=e^{2}=Z_{1}^{2} T^{2}$

$\frac{1}{\mu_{o} \varepsilon_{o}}=C^{2}[\mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}]^{2}$

$=\left[L T^{-1}\right]^{2}$

$=\left[M^{0} L^{2} T^{-2}\right]$

question: The physical quantities not having same dimensions are
solution:
\item  Momentum, $=m v=\left[M L T^{-1}\right]$

Planck's constant,

$h=\frac{E}{v}=\frac{\left[M L^{2} T^{-2}\right]}{\left[T^{-1}\right]}=\left[M L^{2} T^{-1}\right]$

question: Identify the pair whose dimensions are equal
solution:
\item  Work $W=\vec{F} \cdot \vec{s}=F s \cos \theta$

$\because \vec{A} \cdot \vec{B}=A B \cos \theta$

$=\left[M L T^{-2}\right][L]=\left[M L^{2} T^{-2}\right]$;

Torque, $\vec{\tau}=\vec{r} \times \vec{F} \Rightarrow \tau=r F \sin \theta$

$\because \vec{A} \times \vec{B}=A B \sin \theta$

$=[L]\left[M L T^{-2}\right]=\left[M L^{2} T^{-2}\right]$

question: A screw gauge has 50 divisions on its circular scale. The circular scale is 4 units ahead of the pitch scale marking, prior to use. Upon one complete rotation of the circular scale, a displacement of 0.5 mm is noticed on the pitch scale. The nature of zero error involved, and the least count of the screw gauge, are respectively :
solution:
\item  Given:No. ofdivision on circular scale ofscrew gauge $=50$

Pitch $=0.5 \mathrm{~mm}$

Least count of screw gauge

$=\frac{\text { Pitch }}{\text { No. of division on circular scale }}$

$=\frac{0.5}{50} \mathrm{~mm}=1 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~m}=10 \mu \mathrm{m}$

And nature of zero error is positive.

question: The density of a solid metal sphere is determined by measuring its mass and its diameter. The maximum error in the density of the sphere is $\left(\frac{x}{100}\right) \%$. If the relative errors in measuring the mass and the diameter are $6.0 \%$ and $1.5 \%$ respectively, the value of $x$ is $\qquad$ .]
solution:
\item 

Density, $\rho=\frac{M}{V}=\frac{M}{\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(\frac{D}{2}\right)^{3}} \Rightarrow \rho=\frac{6}{\pi} M D^{-3}$ $\therefore \%\left(\frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho}\right)=\frac{\Delta m}{m}+3\left(\frac{\Delta D}{D}\right)=6+3 \times 1.5=10.5 \%$

$\%\left(\frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho}\right)=\frac{1050}{100} \%=\left(\frac{x}{100}\right) \%$

$\therefore x=1050.00$

question: A student measuring the diameter of a pencil of circular cross-section with the help of a vernier scale records the following four readings $5.50 \mathrm{~mm}, 5.55 \mathrm{~mm}, 5.45 \mathrm{~mm}$, 5.65 mm , The average of these four reading is 5.5375 mm and the standard deviation of the data is 0.07395 mm . The average diameter of the pencil should therefore be recorded as :
solution:
\item  Average diameter, $d_{\mathrm{av}}=5.5375 \mathrm{~mm}$

Deviation of data, $\Delta d=0.07395 \mathrm{~mm}$

As the measured data are upto two digits after decimal, therefore answer should be in two digits after decimal.

$\therefore d=(5.54 \pm 0.07) \mathrm{mm}$

question:
A physical quantity $z$ depends on four observables $a, b, c$ and $d$, as $z=\frac{a^{2} b^{\frac{2}{3}}}{\sqrt{c} d^{3}}$. The percentages of error in the measurement of $a, b, c$ and $d$ are $2 \%, 1.5 \%, 4 \%$ and $2.5 \%$ respectively. The percentage of error in $z$ is :

$
solution:
\item  Given: $Z=\frac{a^{2} b^{2 / 3}}{\sqrt{c} d^{3}}$

Percentage error in $Z$,

$=\frac{\Delta Z}{Z}=\frac{2 \Delta a}{a}+\frac{2}{3} \frac{\Delta b}{b}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{\Delta c}{c}+\frac{3 \Delta d}{d}$

$=2 \times 2+\frac{2}{3} \times 1.5+\frac{1}{2} \times 4+3 \times 2.5=14.5 \%$.

question: Using screw gauge of pitch 0.1 cm and 50 divisions on its circular scale, the thickness of an object is measured. It should correctly be recorded as :
solution:
\item  Thickness $=$ M.S. Reading + Circular Scale Reading (L.C.)

Here $\mathrm{LC}=\frac{\text { Pitch }}{\text { Circular scale division }}=\frac{0.1}{50}=0.002 \mathrm{~cm}$ per division

So, correct measurement is measurement of integral multiple of L.C.

question: The least count of the main scale of a vernier callipers is 1 mm . Its vernier scale is divided into 10 divisions and coincide with 9 divisions of the main scale. When jaws are touching each other, the $7^{\text {th }}$ division of vernier scale coincides with a division of main scale and the zero of vernier scale is lying right side of the zero of main scale. When this vernier is used to measure length of a cylinder the zero of the vernier scale betwen 3.1 cm and 3.2 cm and $4^{\text {th }}$ VSD coincides with a main scale division. The length of the cylinder is : (VSD is vernier scale division)
solution:
\item  L.C. of vernier callipers $=1 \mathrm{MSD}-1 \mathrm{VSD}$

$=\left(1-\frac{9}{10}\right) \times 1=0.1 \mathrm{~mm}=0.01 \mathrm{~cm}$

Here $7^{\text {th }}$ division of vernier scale coincides with a division of main scale and the zero of vernier scale is lying right side of the zero of main scale.

Zero error $=7 \times 0.1=0.7 \mathrm{~mm}=0.07 \mathrm{~cm}$.

Length of the cylinder $=$ measured value - zero error

$=(3.1+4 \times 0.01)-0.07=3.07 \mathrm{~cm}$.

question: If the screw on a screw-gauge is given six rotations, it moves by 3 mm on the main scale. If there are 50 divisions on the circular scale the least count of the screw gauge is:
solution:
\item  When screw on a screw-gauge is given six rotations, it moves by 3 mm on the main scale

$\therefore \quad$ Pitch $=\frac{3}{6}=0.5 \mathrm{~mm}$

$\therefore \quad$ Least count L.C. $=\frac{\text { Pitch }}{C S D}=\frac{0.5 \mathrm{~mm}}{50}$

$=\frac{1}{100} \mathrm{~mm}=0.01 \mathrm{~mm}=0.001 \mathrm{~cm}$

question: For the four sets of three measured physical quantities as given below. Which of the following options is correct?

A simple pendulum is being used to determine the value of gravitational acceleration $g$ at a certain place. The length of the pendulum is 25.0 cm and a stop watch with 1 s resolution measures the time taken for 40 oscillations to be 50 s . The accuracy in $g$ is:
solution:
\item  Given, Length of simple pendulum, $l=25.0 \mathrm{~cm}$ Time of 40 oscillation, $T=50 \mathrm{~s}$

Time period of pendulum

$T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{g}}$

$\Rightarrow T^{2}=\frac{4 \pi^{2} \ell}{g} \Rightarrow g=\frac{4 \pi^{2} \ell}{T^{2}}$

$\Rightarrow$ Fractional error in $\mathrm{g}=\frac{\Delta g}{g}=\frac{\Delta l}{l}+\frac{2 \Delta T}{T}$

$\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta g}{g}=\left(\frac{0.1}{25.0}\right)+2\left(\frac{1}{50}\right)=0.044$

$\therefore$ Percentage error in $g=\frac{\Delta g}{g} \times 100=4.4 \%$

question: In the density measurement of a cube, the mass and edge length are measured as $(10.00 \pm 0.10) \mathrm{kg}$ and $(0.10 \pm 0.01)$ m , respectively. The error in the measurement of density is:
solution:
\item  $\delta=\frac{M}{V}=\frac{M}{l^{3}}=M l^{-3}$

$\frac{\Delta \delta}{\delta}=\frac{\Delta M}{M}+3 \frac{\Delta l}{l}=\frac{0.10}{10.00}+3\left(\frac{0.01}{0.10}\right)=0.31 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$.

question: The area of a square is $5.29 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$. The area of 7 such squares taking into account the significant figures is:
solution:
\item  $A=7 \times 5.29=37.03 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$

The result should have three significant figures, so $A=37.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$

question: In a simple pendulum experiment for determination of acceleration due to gravity $(g)$, time taken for 20 oscillations is measured by using a watch of 1 second least count. The mean value of time taken comes out to be 30 s . The length of pendulum is measured by using a meter scale of least count 1 mm and the value obtained is 55.0 cm . The percentage error in the determination of $g$ is close to :
solution:
\item  We have

$T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{g}}$ or $g=4 \pi^{2} \frac{\ell}{T^{2}}$

$\frac{\Delta g}{g} \times 100=\frac{\Delta R}{Q} \times 100+2 \frac{\Delta T}{T} \times 100$

$=\frac{0.1}{55} \times 100+2\left(\frac{1}{30}\right) \times 100$

$=0.18+6.67=6.8 \%$

question: The least count of the main scale of a screw gauge is 1 mm . The minimum number of divisions on its circular scale required to measure $5 \mu \mathrm{m}$ diameter of a wire is:
solution:
\item  Least count of main scale of screw gauge $=1 \mathrm{~mm}$ Least count of screw gauge

$=\frac{\text { Pitch }}{\text { Number of division on circular scale }}$

$5 \times 10^{-6}=\frac{10^{-3}}{\mathrm{~N}}$

$\Rightarrow \mathrm{N}=200$

question: The diameter and height of a cylinder are measured by a meter scale to be $12.6 \pm 0.1 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $34.2 \pm 0.1 \mathrm{~cm}$, respectively. What will be the value of its volume in appropriate significant figures?
solution: \item

question:
The pitch and the number of divisions, on the circular scale for a given screw gauge are 0.5 mm and 100 respectively. When the screw gauge is fully tightened without any object, the zero of its circular scale lies 3 division below the mean line.

The readings of the main scale and the circular scale, for a thin sheet, are 5.5 mm and 48 respectively, the thickness of the sheet is:
solution:
\item  Least count of screw gauge,


$\mathrm{LC}=\frac{\text { Pitch }}{\text { No. of division }}$

$=0.5 \times 10^{-3}=0.5 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mm}+$ ve error $=3 \times 0.5 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mm}$

$=1.5 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mm}=0.015 \mathrm{~mm}$

Reading $=$ MSR + CSR $-(+$ ve error $)$

$=5.5 \mathrm{~mm}+\left(48 \times 0.5 \times 10^{-2}\right)-0.015$

$=5.5+0.24-0.015=5.725 \mathrm{~mm}$\\

question: The density of a material in the shape of a cube is determined by measuring three sides of the cube and its mass. If the relative errors in measuring the mass and length are respectively $1.5 \%$ and $1 \%$, the maximum error in determining the density is:

The percentage errors in quantities $\mathrm{P}, \mathrm{Q}, \mathrm{R}$ and S are $0.5 \%$, $1 \%, 3 \%$ and $1.5 \%$ respectively in the measurement of a physical quantity $\mathrm{A}=\frac{\mathrm{P}^{3} \mathrm{Q}^{2}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{RS}}}$.

The maximum percentage error in the value of $A$ will be
solution:
\item  Maximum percentage error in A

$=3(\%$ error in P$)+2(\%$ error in Q$)$

$+\frac{1}{2}(\%$ error in R$)+1(\%$ error in S$)$

$=3 \times 0.5+2 \times 1+\frac{1}{2} \times 3+1 \times 1.5$

$=1.5+2+1.5+1.5=6.5 \%$

question: The relative uncertainty in the period of a satellite orbiting around the earth is $10^{-2}$. If the relative uncertainty in the radius of the orbit is negligible, the relative uncertainty in the mass of the earth is
solution:
\item  From Kepler's law, time period of a satellite,

$\mathrm{T}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{r}^{3}}{\mathrm{Gm}}} \quad \mathrm{T}^{2}=\frac{4 \pi^{2}}{\mathrm{GM}} \mathrm{r}^{3}$

Relative uncertainty in the mass of the earth

$\left|\frac{\Delta \mathrm{M}}{\mathrm{M}}\right|=2 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{T}}=2 \times 10^{-2} \quad(\because 4 \pi \& \mathrm{G}$ constant and

relative uncertainty in radius $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{r}}{\mathrm{r}}$ negligible)

question: The relative error in the determination of the surface area of a sphere is $\alpha$. Then the relative error in the determination of its volume is
solution:
\item  Relative error in Surface area, $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{s}}{\mathrm{s}}=2 \times \frac{\Delta \mathrm{r}}{\mathrm{r}}=\alpha$ and relative error in volume, $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{v}}{\mathrm{v}}=3 \times \frac{\Delta \mathrm{r}}{\mathrm{r}}$

$\therefore$ Relative error in volume w.r.t. relative error in area, $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{v}}{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{3}{2} \alpha$

question: In a screw gauge, 5 complete rotations of the screw cause it to move a linear distance of 0.25 cm . There are 100 circular scale divisions. The thickness of a wire measured by this screw gauge gives a reading of 4 main scale divisions and 30 circular scale divisions. Assuming negligible zero error, the thickness of the wire is:
solution:
\item  Least count $=\frac{\text { Value of } 1 \text { part on main scale }}{\text { Number of parts on vernier scale }}$

$=\frac{0.25}{5 \times 100} \mathrm{~cm}=5 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~cm}$

Reading $=4 \times 0.05 \mathrm{~cm}+30 \times 5 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~cm}$

$=(0.2+0.0150) \mathrm{cm}=0.2150 \mathrm{~cm}$ (Thickness of wire)

question:
The following observations were taken for determining surface tensiton T of water by capillary method :

Diameter of capilary, $\mathrm{D}=1.25 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}$

rise of water, $\mathrm{h}=1.45 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}$

Using $\mathrm{g}=9.80 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ and the simplified relation

$T=\frac{r h g}{2} \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$, the possible error in surface tension is closest to :
solution:
\item  Surface tension, $T=\frac{r h g}{2} \times 10^{3}$

Relative error in surface tension,

$\frac{\Delta T}{T}=\frac{\Delta r}{r}+\frac{\Delta h}{h}+0\left(\because \mathrm{g}, 2 \& 10^{3}\right.$ are constant $)$

Percentage error

$100 \times \frac{\Delta T}{T}=\left(\frac{10^{-2} \times 0.01}{1.25 \times 10^{-2}}+\frac{10^{-2} \times 0.01}{1.45 \times 10^{-2}}\right) 100$

$=(0.8+0.689)$

$=(1.489)=1.489 \% \cong 1.5 \%$

question:
A physical quantity P is described by the relation

$\mathrm{P}=a^{1 / 2} b^{2} \mathrm{c}^{3} d^{-4}$

If the relative errors in the measurement of $a, b, c$ and $d$ respectively, are $2 \%, 1 \%, 3 \%$ and $5 \%$, then the relative error in P will be :
solution:
\item  Given, $\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{a}^{1 / 2} \mathrm{~b}^{2} \mathrm{c}^{2} \mathrm{~d}^{-4}$, Maximum relative error,

$\frac{\Delta \mathrm{P}}{\mathrm{P}}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\Delta \mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{a}}+2 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{b}}{\mathrm{b}}+3 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{c}}{\mathrm{c}}+4 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}}$

$=\frac{1}{2} \times 2+2 \times 1+3 \times 3+4 \times 5=32 \%$

question: A screw gauge with a pitch of 0.5 mm and a circular scale with 50 divisions is used to measure the thickness of a thin sheet of Aluminium. Before starting the measurement, it is found that wen the two jaws of the screw gauge are brought in contact, the $45^{\text {th }}$ division coincides with the main scale line and the zero of the main scale is barely visible. What is the thickness of the sheet if the main scale reading is 0.5 mm and the 25 th division coincides with the main scale line?
solution:
L.C. $=\frac{0.5}{50}=0.01 \mathrm{~mm}$

Zero error $=5 \times 0.01=0.05 \mathrm{~mm}$ (Negative)

Reading $=(0.5+25 \times 0.01)+0.05=0.80 \mathrm{~mm}$

question: A student measures the time period of 100 oscillations of a simple pendulum four times. The data set is $90 \mathrm{~s}, 91 \mathrm{~s}, 95$ s , and 92 s . If the minimum division in the measuring clock is 1 s , then the reported mean time should be:
solution:
\item  $\Delta \mathrm{T}=\frac{\left|\Delta \mathrm{T}_{1}\right|+\left|\Delta \mathrm{T}_{2}\right|+\left|\Delta \mathrm{T}_{3}\right|+\left|\Delta \mathrm{T}_{4}\right|}{4}$

$=\frac{2+1+3+0}{4}=1.5$

As the resolution of measuring clock is 1.5 therefore the mean time should be $92 \pm 1.5$

question: The period of oscillation of a simple pendulum is $\mathrm{T}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{L}}{\mathrm{g}}} \cdot$ Measured value of L is 20.0 cm known to 1 mm accuracy and time for 100 oscillations of the pendulum is found to be 90 s using a wrist watch of 1 s resolution. The accuracy in the determination of $g$ is :
solution:
\item  As, $g=4 \pi^{2} \frac{L}{T^{2}}$

So, $\frac{\Delta g}{g} \times 100=\frac{\Delta L}{L} \times 100+2 \frac{\Delta T}{T} \times 100$

$=\frac{0.1}{20} \times 100+2 \times \frac{1}{90} \times 100=2.72 \simeq 3 \%$

question: Diameter of a steel ball is measured using a Vernier callipers which has divisions of 0.1 cm on its main scale (MS) and 10 divisions of its vernier scale (VS) match 9 divisions on the main scale. Three such measurements for a ball are given as:

The current voltage relation of a diode is given by $\mathrm{I}=\left(\mathrm{e}^{1000 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{T}}-1\right) \mathrm{mA}$, where the applied voltage V is in volts and the temperature T is in degree kelvin. If a student makes an error measuring $\pm 0.01 \mathrm{~V}$ while measuring the current of 5 mA at 300 K , what will be the error in the value of current in mA ?
solution:
\item  The current voltage relation of diode is

$I=\left(e^{1000 V / T}-1\right) \mathrm{mA}$ (given)

When, $I=5 m A, e^{1000 \mathrm{~V} / T}=6 \mathrm{~mA}$

Also, $d I=\left(e^{1000 V / T}\right) \times \frac{1000}{T}$

Error $= \pm 0.01$ (By exponential function)

$=(6 \mathrm{~mA}) \times \frac{1000}{300} \times(0.01)=0.2 \mathrm{~mA}$

question: A student measured the length of a rod and wrote it as 3.50 cm . Which instrument did he use to measure it?
options: b) A vernier calliper where the 10 divisions in vernier scale matches with 9 division in main scale and main scale has 10 divisions in 1 cm .
c) A screw gauge having 100 divisions in the circular scale and pitch as 1 mm .
d) A screw gauge having 50 divisions in the circular scale and pitch as 1 mm .
solution:
\item  Measured length of rod $=3.50 \mathrm{~cm}$

For Vernier Scale with 1 Main Scale Division $=1 \mathrm{~mm}$ 9 Main Scale Division $=10$ Vernier Scale Division, Least count $=1 \mathrm{MSD}-1 \mathrm{VSD}=0.1 \mathrm{~mm}$

question: Match List-I(Event) with List-II (Order of the time interval for happening of the event) and select the correct option from the options given below the lists:
solution:
\item  Rotation period of earth is about $24 \mathrm{hrs} \simeq 10^{5} \mathrm{~s}$ Revolution period of earth is about 365 days $\simeq 10^{7} \mathrm{~s}$

Speed of light wave $\mathrm{C}=3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$

Wavelength of visible light of spectrum

$\lambda=4000-7800 \AA$

$\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{f} \lambda\left(\right.$ and $\left.\mathrm{T}=\frac{1}{\mathrm{f}}\right)$

Therefore period of light wave is $10^{-15} \mathrm{~s}$ (approx)

question: In the experiment of calibration of voltmeter, a standard cell ofe.m.f. 1.1 volt is balanced against 440 cm of potential wire. The potential difference across the ends of resistance is found to balance against 220 cm of the wire. The corresponding reading of voltmeter is 0.5 volt. The error in the reading of volmeter will be:
solution:
\item  In a voltmeter

$\mathrm{V} \propto l$

$\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{k} l$

Now, it is given $\mathrm{E}=1.1$ volt for $l_{1}=440 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $\mathrm{V}=0.5$ volt for $l_{2}=220 \mathrm{~cm}$

Let the error in reading of voltmeter be $\Delta \mathrm{V}$ then, $1.1=400 \mathrm{~K}$ and $(0.5-\Delta \mathrm{V})=220 \mathrm{~K}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1.1}{440}=\frac{0.5-\Delta \mathrm{V}}{220} \\
& \therefore \quad \Delta \mathrm{V}=-0.05 \text { volt }
\end{aligned}
$$

question: An experiment is performed to obtain the value of acceleration due to gravity $g$ by using a simple pendulum of length L . In this experiment time for 100 oscillations is measured by using a watch of 1 second least count and the value is 90.0 seconds. The length L is measured by using a meter scale of least count 1 mm and the value is 20.0 cm . The error in the determination of $g$ would be:
solution:
\item  According to the question.

$t=(90 \pm 1)$ or, $\frac{\Delta t}{t}=\frac{1}{90}$

$l=(20 \pm 0.1)$ or, $\frac{\Delta l}{l}=\frac{0.1}{20}$

$\frac{\Delta g}{g} \%=?$

As we know,

$t=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}} \Rightarrow g=\frac{4 \pi^{2} l}{t^{2}}$

or, $\frac{\Delta g}{g}= \pm\left(\frac{\Delta l}{l}+2 \frac{\Delta t}{t}\right)=\left(\frac{0.1}{20}+2 \times \frac{1}{90}\right)=0.027$

$\therefore \frac{\Delta g}{g} \%=2.7 \%$

question: Resistance of a given wire is obtained by measuring the current flowing in it and the voltage difference applied across it. If the percentage errors in the measurement of the current and the voltage difference are $3 \%$ each, then error in the value of resistance of the wire is
solution:
\item  According to ohm's law, $\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{IR}$

$\mathrm{R}=\frac{V}{I}$

$\therefore$ Percentage error $=\frac{\text { Absolute error }}{\text { Measurement }} \times 10^{2}$

where, $\frac{\Delta V}{V} \times 100=\frac{\Delta I}{I} \times 100=3 \%$

then, $\frac{\Delta R}{R} \times 100=\frac{\Delta V}{V} \times 10^{2}+\frac{\Delta I}{I} \times 10^{2}$

$=3 \%+3 \%=6 \%$

question:
A spectrometer gives the following reading when used to measure the angle of a prism.

Main scale reading : 58.5 degree

Vernier scale reading : 09 divisions

Given that 1 division on main scale corresponds to 0.5 degree. Total divisions on the Vernier scale is 30 and match with 29 divisions of the main scale. The angle of the prism from the above data is
solution:
\item  $\because$ Reading of Vernier $=$ Main scale reading + Vernier scale reading $\times$ least count.

Main scale reading $=58.5$

Vernier scale reading $=09$ division

least count of Vernier $=0.5^{\circ} / 30$

Thus, $\mathrm{R}=58.5^{\circ}+9 \times \frac{0.5^{\circ}}{30}$

$\mathrm{R}=58.65^{\circ}$

question: $N$ divisions on the main scale of a vernier calliper coincide with $(N+1)$ divisions of the vernier scale. If each division of main scale is ' $a$ ' units, then the least count of the instrument is
solution:
\item  No. of divisions on main scale $=N$

No. of divisions on vernier scale $=N+1$

size of main scale division $=a$

Let size of vernier scale division be $b$ then we have

$a N=b(N+1) \Rightarrow \mathrm{b}=\frac{a N}{N+1}$

Least count is $\mathrm{a}-\mathrm{b}=\mathrm{a}-\frac{a N}{N+1}$

$=a\left[\frac{N+1-N}{N+1}\right]=\frac{a}{N+1}$

question: A student measured the diameter of a wire using a screw gauge with the least count 0.001 cm and listed the measurements. The measured value should be recorded as
solution:
\item  The least count (L.C.) of a screw guage is the smallest length which can be measured accurately with it.

As least count is $0.001 \mathrm{~cm}=\frac{1}{1000} \mathrm{~cm}$

Hence measured value should be recorded upto 3 decimal places i.e., 5.320 cm

question:
A screw gauge gives the following reading when used to measure the diameter of a wire.

Main scale reading : 0 mm

Circular scale reading : 52 divisions

Given that 1 mm on main scale corresponds to 100 divisions of the circular scale. The diameter of wire from the above data is
solution:
\item  Least count, L.C. $=\frac{1}{100} \mathrm{~mm}$

Diameter of wire $=M S R+C S R \times L . C$.

$\because 1 \mathrm{~mm}=0.1 \mathrm{~cm}$

$=0+\frac{1}{100} \times 52=0.52 \mathrm{~mm}=0.052 \mathrm{~cm}$

question: The respective number of significant figures for the numbers $23.023,0.0003$ and $2.1 \times 10^{-3}$ are
solution:
\item  Number of significant figures in $23.023=5$

Number of significant figures in $0.0003=1$

Number of significant figures in $2.1 \times 10^{-3}=2$

So, the radiation belongs to X-rays part of the spectrum.

question: In an experiment the angles are required to be measured using an instrument, 29 divisions of the main scale exactly coincide with the 30 divisions of the vernier scale. If the smallest division of the main scale is half- a degree $\left(=0.5^{\circ}\right)$, then the least count of the instrument is:
solution:
\item  30 Divisions of V.S. coincide with 29 divisions of M.S.

$\therefore 1$ V.S.D $=\frac{29}{30}$ MSD

L.C. $=1 \mathrm{MSD}-1 \mathrm{VSD}$

$=1 \mathrm{MSD}-\frac{29}{30} \mathrm{MSD}$ $=\frac{1}{30} \mathrm{MSD}$

$=\frac{1}{30} \times 0.5^{\circ}=1$ minute.

question:
A body of mass $\mathrm{m}=3.513 \mathrm{~kg}$ is moving along the x -axis with a speed of $5.00 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$. The magnitude of its momentum is recorded as


$
solution:
\item  Momentum, $p=m \times v$

Given, mass of a body $=3.513 \mathrm{~kg}$ speed of body

$=(3.513) \times(5.00)=17.565 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$

$=17.6$ (Rounding off to get three significant figures)

question: Two full turns of the circular scale of a screw gauge cover a distance of 1 mm on its main scale. The total number of divisions on the circular scale is 50 . Further, it is found that the screw gauge has a zero error of -0.03 mm . While measuring the diameter of a thin wire, a student notes the main scale reading of 3 mm and the number of circular scale divisions in line with the main scale as 35 . The diameter of the wire is
solution:
\item  Least count of screw gauge $=0.01 \mathrm{~mm}$

$\because \frac{0.5}{50} \mathrm{~mm}$

Reading $=[$ M.S.R. + C.S.R. $\times$ L.C. $]-($ zero error $)$

$=[3+35 \times 0.01]-(-0.03)=3.38 \mathrm{~mm}$


\end{document}

question: A particle moving in the $x y$ plane experiences a velocity dependent force $\vec{F}=k\left(v_{y} \hat{i}+v_{x} \hat{j}\right)$, where $v_{x}$ and $v_{y}$ are $x$ and $y$ components of its velocity $\vec{v}$. if $\vec{a}$ is the acceleration of the particle, then which of the following statements is true for the particle?
options: a) quantity $\vec{v} \times \vec{a}$ is constant in time
b) $\vec{F}$ arises due to a magnetic field
c) kinetic energy of particle is constant in time
d) quantity $\vec{v} \cdot \vec{a}$ is constant in time
solution: Given  $$ \begin{aligned} & \vec{F}=k\left(v_{y} \hat{i}+v_{x} \hat{j}\right) \\ & \therefore F_{x}=k v_{y} \hat{i}, F_{y}=k v_{x} \hat{j} \\ & \frac{m d v_{x}}{d t}=k v_{y} \Rightarrow \frac{d v_{x}}{d t}=\frac{k}{m} v_{y} \end{aligned} $$  Similarly, $\frac{d v_{y}}{d t}=\frac{k}{m} v_{x}$  $\frac{d v_{y}}{d v_{x}}=\frac{v_{x}}{v_{y}} \Rightarrow \int v_{y} d v_{y}=\int v_{x} d v_{x}$  $v_{y}^{2}=v_{x}^{2}+C$  $v_{y}^{2}-v_{x}^{2}=$ constant  $\vec{v} \times \vec{a}=\left(v_{x} \hat{i}+v_{y} \hat{j}\right) \times \frac{k}{m}\left(v_{y} \hat{i}+v_{x} \hat{j}\right)$  $$ =\left(v_{x}^{2} \hat{k}-v_{y}^{2} \hat{k}\right) \frac{k}{m}=\left(v_{x}^{2}-v_{y}^{2}\right) \frac{k}{m} \hat{k}=\text { constant } $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A spaceship in space sweeps stationary interplanetary dust.

As a result, its mass increases at a rate $\frac{d M(t)}{d t}=b v^{2}(t)$, where $v(t)$ is its instantaneous velocity. The instantaneous acceleration of the satellite is :
solution: From the Newton's second law,   \begin{equation*} F=\frac{d p}{d t}=\frac{d(m v)}{d t}=v\left(\frac{d m}{d t}\right) \tag{i} \end{equation*}   We have given, $\frac{d M(t)}{d t}=b v^{2}(t)$  Thrust on the satellite,  $F=-v\left(\frac{d m}{d t}\right)=-v\left(b v^{2}\right)=-b v^{3}$ [Using (i) and (ii)]  $\Rightarrow F=M(t) a=-b v^{3} \Rightarrow a=\frac{-b v^{3}}{M(t)}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A small ball of mass $m$ is thrown upward with velocity $u$ from the ground. The ball experiences a resistive force $m k v^{2}$ where $v$ is its speed. The maximum height attained by the ball is :
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-128}   $\vec{F}=m k v^{2}-m g \quad\left(\because m g\right.$ and $m k v^{2}$ act opposite to each other)  $$ \vec{a}=\frac{\vec{F}}{m}=-\left[k v^{2}+g\right] $$  $\Rightarrow v \cdot \frac{d v}{d h}=-\left[k v^{2}+g\right]$  $\left(\because a=v \frac{d v}{d h}\right)$  $\Rightarrow \int_{u}^{0} \frac{v \cdot d v}{k v^{2}+g}=\int_{0}^{h} d h$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2 k} \ln \left[k v^{2}+g\right]_{u}^{0}=-h$ $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2 k} \ln \left[\frac{k u^{2}+g}{g}\right]=h$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A ball is thrown upward with an initial velocity $\mathrm{V}_{0}$ from the surface of the earth. The motion of the ball is affected by a drag force equal to $m \gamma v^{2}$ (where $m$ is mass of the ball, $v$ is its instantaneous velocity and $\gamma$ is a constant). Time taken by the ball to rise to its zenith is :
solution: Net acceleration  $\frac{\mathrm{dv}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\mathrm{a}=-\left(\mathrm{g}+\gamma \mathrm{v}^{2}\right)$  Let time $t$ required to rise to its zenith $(\mathrm{v}=0)$ so,  $\int_{v_{0}}^{0} \frac{-d v}{g+\gamma v^{2}}=\int_{0}^{t} d t \quad\left[\right.$ for $\left.H_{\max ,} v=0\right]$  $\therefore \mathrm{t}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\gamma \mathrm{g}}} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\sqrt{\gamma} \mathrm{v}_{0}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{g}}}\right)$    \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle of mass m is moving in a straight line with momentum p . Starting at time $\mathrm{t}=0$, a force $\mathrm{F}=k t$ acts in the same direction on the moving particle during time interval T so that its momentum changes from p to 3 p . Here $k$ is a constant. The value of T is :
solution: From Newton's second law  $\frac{\mathrm{dp}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{kt}$  Integrating both sides we get,  $\int_{\mathrm{p}}^{3 \mathrm{p}} \mathrm{dp}=\int_{0}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{ktdt} \Rightarrow[\mathrm{p}]_{\mathrm{p}}^{3 \mathrm{p}}=\mathrm{k}\left[\frac{\mathrm{t}^{2}}{2}\right]_{0}^{\mathrm{T}}$  $\Rightarrow 2 \mathrm{p}=\frac{\mathrm{kT}^{2}}{2} \Rightarrow \mathrm{T}=2 \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{p}}{\mathrm{k}}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle of mass $m$ is acted upon by a force F given by the empirical law $F=\frac{R}{t^{2}} v(t)$. If this law is to be tested experimentally by observing the motion starting from rest, the best way is to plot:
solution: From $F=\frac{R}{t^{2}} v(t) \Rightarrow m \frac{d v}{d t}=\frac{R}{t^{2}} v(t)$  Integrating both sides $\int \frac{\mathrm{dv}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\int \frac{\mathrm{Rdt}}{\mathrm{mt}^{2}}$  In $\mathrm{v}=-\frac{\mathrm{R}}{\mathrm{mt}}$  $\therefore \ln v \propto \frac{1}{\mathrm{t}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A large number ( n ) of identical beads, each of mass m and radius $r$ are strung on a thin smooth rigid horizontal rod of length L ( $\mathrm{L}>\mathrm{r}$ ) and are at rest at random positions. The rod is mounted between two rigid supports (see figure). If one of the beads is now given a speed v , the average force experienced by each support after a long time is (assume all collisions are elastic):
solution: Space between the supports for motion of beads is $\mathrm{L}-2 \mathrm{nr}$  Average force experienced by each support,  $$ F=\frac{2 m V}{\frac{2(L-2 n r)}{V}}=\frac{m V^{2}}{L-2 n r} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-129}   \begin{enumerate}

question: A body of mass 5 kg under the action of constant force $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{x}} \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{y}} \hat{\mathrm{j}}$ has velocity at $\mathrm{t}=0 \mathrm{~s}$ as $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{v}}=(6 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-2 \hat{\mathrm{j}}) \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$ and at $\mathrm{t}=10 \mathrm{~s}$ as $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{v}}=+6 \hat{\mathrm{j}} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$. The force $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}$ is:
solution: From question,  Mass of body, $m=5 \mathrm{~kg}$  Velocity at $t=0$,  $u=(6 \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}) \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$  Velocity at $t=10 \mathrm{~s}$,  $v=+6 \hat{j} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Force, $F=$ ?  Acceleration, $a=\frac{v-u}{t}$  $=\frac{6 \hat{j}-(6 \hat{i}-2 \hat{j})}{10}=\frac{-3 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j}}{5} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  Force, $F=m a$  $=5 \times \frac{(-3 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j})}{5}=(-3 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j}) N$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle of mass m is at rest at the origin at time $t=0$. It is subjected to a force $F(t)=F_{0} \mathrm{e}^{-b t}$ in the $x$ direction. Its speed $v(t)$ is depicted by which of the following curves?
solution: Given that $F(t)=F_{0} e^{-b t}$  $\Rightarrow m \frac{d v}{d t}=F_{0} e^{-b t}$  $\frac{d v}{d t}=\frac{F_{0}}{m} e^{-b t}$  $\int_{0}^{v} d v=\frac{F_{0}}{m} \int_{0}^{t} e^{-b t} d t$  $v=\frac{F_{0}}{m}\left[\frac{e^{-b t}}{-b}\right]_{0}^{t}=\frac{F_{0}}{m b}\left[-\left(e^{-b t}-e^{-0}\right)\right]$  $\Rightarrow v=\frac{F_{0}}{m b}\left[1-e^{-b t}\right]$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
This question has Statement 1 and Statement 2. Of the four choices given after the Statements, choose the one that best describes the two Statements.

Statement 1: If you push on a cart being pulled by a horse so that it does not move, the cart pushes you back with an equal and opposite force.

Statement 2: The cart does not move because the force described in statement 1 cancel each other.
options: a) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is the correct explanation of Statement 1.
b) Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true.
c) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false.
d) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is not the correct explanation of Statement 1.
solution: According to newton third law of motion i.e. every action is associated with equal and opposite reaction.

question:
Two fixed frictionless inclined planes making an angle $30^{\circ}$ and $60^{\circ}$ with the vertical are shown in the figure. Two blocks A and B are placed on the two planes. What is the relative vertical acceleration of $A$ with respect to $B$ ? \\
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-121(1)}
solution: $m g \sin \theta=m a$   $\therefore a=g \sin \theta$  $\therefore$ Vertical component of acceleration  $=g \sin ^{2} \theta$  $\therefore$ Relative vertical acceleration of $A$ with respect to $B$ is  $g\left(\sin ^{2} 60-\sin ^{2} 30\right]$  $=g\left(\frac{3}{4}-\frac{1}{4}\right)=\frac{g}{2}=4.9 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  in vertical direction  \begin{enumerate}

question: A ball of mass 0.2 kg is thrown vertically upwards by applying a force by hand. If the hand moves 0.2 m while applying the force and the ball goes upto 2 m height further, find the magnitude of the force. (Consider $\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ ).
solution: For the motion of ball, just after the throwing  $v=0, s=2 \mathrm{~m}, a=-g=-10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$  $v^{2}-u^{2}=2 a s$ for upward journey  $\Rightarrow-u^{2}=2(-10) \times 2 \Rightarrow u^{2}=40$  When the ball is in the hands of the thrower  $u=0, v=\sqrt{40} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$  $s=0.2 \mathrm{~m}$  $v^{2}-u^{2}=2 a s$ $\Rightarrow 40-0=2(a) 0.2 \Rightarrow a=100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  $\therefore F=m a=0.2 \times 100=20 \mathrm{~N}$  $\Rightarrow N-m g=20 \Rightarrow N=20+2=22 N$  Note :  $W_{\text {hand }}+W_{\text {gravity }}=\Delta K$  $\Rightarrow F(0.2)+(0.2)(10)(2.2)=0 \Rightarrow F=22 N$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A player caught a cricket ball of mass 150 g moving at a rate of $20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. If the catching process is completed in 0.1 s , the force of the blow exerted by the ball on the hand of the player is equal to
solution: Given, mass of cricket ball, $m=150 \mathrm{~g}=15 \mathrm{~kg}$  Initial velocity, $u=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Force,  $F=\frac{m(v-u)}{t}=\frac{0.15(0-20)}{0.1}=30 \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle of mass 0.3 kg subject to a force $F=-k x$ with $k=15 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$. What will be its initial acceleration if it is released from a point 20 cm away from the origin ?[2005]\\
solution: Mass $(m)=3 \mathrm{~kg}$  Force, $F=m \cdot a=-k x$  $\Rightarrow m a=-15 x$  $\Rightarrow 0.3 a=-15 x$  $\Rightarrow a=-\frac{15}{0.3} x=\frac{-150}{3} x=-50 x$  $$ a=-50 \times 0.2=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A block is kept on a frictionless inclined surface with angle of inclination ' $\alpha$ '. The incline is given an acceleration ' $a$ ' to keep the block stationary. Then $a$ is equal to

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-121(3)}\\
solution: When the incline is given an acceleration a towards the right, the block receives a reaction $m a$ towards left.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-129(2)}   For block to remain stationary, Net force along the incline should be zero.  $m g \sin \alpha=m a \cos \alpha \Rightarrow a=g \tan \alpha$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A rocket with a lift-off mass $3.5 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~kg}$ is blasted upwards with an initial acceleration of $10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$. Then the initial thrust of the blast is
solution: In the absence of air resistance, if the rocket moves up with an acceleration a, then thrust  $F=m g+m a$  $\therefore F=m(g+a)=3.5 \times 10^{4}(10+10)$  $=7 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~N}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-129(1)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
Three forces start acting simultaneously on a particle moving with velocity, $\vec{v}$. These forces are represented in magnitude and direction by the three sides of a triangle ABC . The particle will now move with velocity
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-122(4)}
options: c) $|\vec{v}|$ in the direction of the largest force BC
solution: Resultant force is zero, as three forces are represented by the sides of a triangle taken in the same order. From Newton's second law, $\vec{F}_{\text {net }}=m \vec{a}$.  Therefore, acceleration is also zero i.e., velocity remains unchanged.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A solid sphere, a hollow sphere and a ring are released from top of an inclined plane (frictionless) so that they slide down the plane. Then maximum acceleration down the plane is for (no rolling)
solution: This is a case of sliding (if plane is friction less) and therefore the acceleration of all the bodies is same.

question:
A mass of 10 kg is suspended by a rope of length 4 m , from the ceiling. A force F is applied horizontally at the midpoint of the rope such that the top half of the rope makes an angle of $45^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Then $F$ equals:

(Take $g=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$ and the rope to be massless)
solution: From the free body diagram    \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-129(3)}    \begin{align*} & T \cos 45^{\circ}=100 N  \tag{i}\\ & T \sin 45^{\circ}=F \tag{ii} \end{align*}   On dividing (i) by (ii) we get  $$ \begin{aligned} & \frac{T \cos 45^{\circ}}{T \sin 45^{\circ}}=\frac{100}{F} \\ & \Rightarrow F=100 \mathrm{~N} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: An elevator in a building can carry a maximum of 10 persons, with the average mass of each person being 68 kg . The mass of the elevator itself is 920 kg and it moves with a constant speed of $3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The frictional force opposing the motion is 6000 N . If the elevator is moving up with its full capacity, the power delivered by the motor to the elevator $\left(g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)$ must be at least:
solution: Net force on the elevator $=$ force on elevator + frictional force  $\Rightarrow F=(10 m+M) g+f$  where, $m=$ mass of person, $M=$ mass of elevator, $f=$ frictional force  $\Rightarrow F=(10 \times 68+920) \times 9.8+600$  $\Rightarrow F=22000 N$  $\Rightarrow P=F V=22000 \times 3=66000 \mathrm{~W}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A mass of 10 kg is suspended vertically by a rope from the roof. When a horizontal force is applied on the rope at some point, the rope deviated at an angle of $45^{\circ}$ at the roof point. If the suspended mass is at equilibrium, the magnitude of the force applied is ( $\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$ )
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-130(2)}   At equilibrium,  $\tan 45^{\circ}=\frac{\mathrm{mg}}{\mathrm{F}}=\frac{100}{\mathrm{~F}}$  $\therefore \mathrm{F}=100 \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A mass ' $m$ ' is supported by a massless string wound around a uniform hollow cylinder of mass $m$ and radius $R$. If the string does not slip on the cylinder, with what acceleration will the mass fall or release?\\
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-122(3)}\\
solution: From figure,   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-130(1)}   Acceleration $a=R \alpha$  and $m g-T=m a$  From equation (i) and (ii)  $T \times R=m R^{2} \alpha=m R^{2}\left(\frac{a}{R}\right)$  or $T=m a$  $\Rightarrow m g-m a=m a$  $\Rightarrow a=\frac{g}{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two blocks of mass $\mathrm{M}_{1}=20 \mathrm{~kg}$ and $\mathrm{M}_{2}=12 \mathrm{~kg}$ are connected by a metal rod of mass 8 kg . The system is pulled vertically up by applying a force of 480 N as shown. The tension at the mid-point of the rod is :\\
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-122(1)}
solution: Acceleration produced in upward direction  $\mathrm{a}=\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{M}_{1}+\mathrm{M}_{2}+\text { Mass of metal rod }}$ $=\frac{480}{20+12+8}=12 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$  Tension at the mid point  $\mathrm{T}=\left(\mathrm{M}_{2}+\frac{\text { Mass of rod }}{2}\right) \mathrm{a}$  $=(12+4) \times 12=192 \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A uniform sphere of weight W and radius 5 cm is being held by a string as shown in the figure. The tension in the string will be :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-122(2)}\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-130(3)}   $$ \begin{aligned} & \mathrm{PQ}=\sqrt{\mathrm{OP}^{2}+\mathrm{OQ}^{2}} \\ & =\sqrt{13^{2}+5^{2}}=12 \end{aligned} $$  Tension in the string  $$ \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{w} \cos \theta=\frac{13}{12} \mathrm{~W} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A spring is compressed between two blocks of masses $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ placed on a horizontal frictionless surface as shown in the figure. When the blocks are released, they have initial velocity of $v_{1}$ and $v_{2}$ as shown. The blocks travel distances $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ respectively before coming to rest.

The ratio $\left(\frac{x_{1}}{x_{2}}\right)$ is
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-122}\\

A block of mass $m$ is connected to another block of mass $M$ by a spring (massless) of spring constant $k$. The block are kept on a smooth horizontal plane. Initially the blocks are at rest and the spring is unstretched. Then a constant force $F$ starts acting on the block of mass $M$ to pull it. Find the force of the block of mass $m$.
solution: Writing free body-diagrams for $m \& M$,    \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-130}   we get $T=m a$ and $F-T=M a$  where $T$ is force due to spring  $\Rightarrow F-m a=M a$ or, $F=M a+m a$  $\therefore$ Acceleration of the system  $a=\frac{F}{M+m}$.  Now, force acting on the block of mass $m$ is  $m a=m\left(\frac{F}{M+m}\right)=\frac{m F}{m+M}$.  If $a$ is the acceleration along the inclined plane, then  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two masses $m_{1}=5 \mathrm{~g}$ and $m_{2}=4.8 \mathrm{~kg}$ tied to a string are hanging over a light frictionless pulley. What is the acceleration of the masses when left free to move ? $\left(g=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)$

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-123}\\
solution: Here, $m_{1}=5 \mathrm{~kg}$ and $m_{2}=8 \mathrm{~kg}$.  If a is the acceleration of the masses,  $m_{1} a=m_{1} g-T \quad$...(i)  $m_{2} a=T-m_{2} g \quad$...(ii)  Solving (i) and (ii) we get  $a=\left(\frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right) g$  $\Rightarrow a=\frac{(5-4.8) \times 9.8}{(5+4.8)} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}=0.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A spring balance is attached to the ceiling of a lift. A man hangs his bag on the spring and the spring reads 49 N , when the lift is stationary. If the lift moves downward with an acceleration of $5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$, the reading of the spring balance will be
solution: When lift is stationary, $W_{1}=m g \quad$...(i)  When the lift descends with acceleration, a  $W_{2}=m(g-a)$  $W_{2}=\frac{49}{10}(10-5)=24.5 \mathrm{~N}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-131}   \begin{enumerate}

question: A block of mass $M$ is pulled along a horizontal frictionless surface by a rope of mass m . If a force $P$ is applied at the free end of the rope, the force exerted by the rope on the block is
solution: Taking the rope and the block as a system   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-131(2)}   we get $P=(m+M) a$  $\therefore$ Acceleration produced, $a=\frac{P}{m+M}$  Taking the block as a system,  Force on the block, $F=M a$  $\therefore F=\frac{M P}{m+M}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A light spring balance hangs from the hook of the other light spring balance and a block of mass $M \mathrm{~kg}$ hangs from the former one. Then the true statement about the scale reading is
options: a) both the scales read $M \mathrm{~kg}$ each
b) the scale of the lower one reads $M \mathrm{~kg}$ and of the upper one zero
c) the reading of the two scales can be anything but the sum of the reading will be $M \mathrm{~kg}$
d) both the scales read $M / 2 \mathrm{~kg}$ each
solution: The Earth exerts a pulling force $M g$. The block in turn exerts a reaction force $M g$ on the spring of spring balance $S_{1}$ which therefore shows a reading of $M \mathrm{kgf}$.  As both the springs are massless. Therefore, it exerts a force of $M g$ on the spring of spring balance $S_{2}$ which shows the reading of $M \mathrm{kgf}$.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-131(1)}   \begin{enumerate}

question: Alift is moving down with acceleration $a$. A man in the lift drops a ball inside the lift. The acceleration of the ball as observed by the man in the lift and a man standing stationary on the ground are respectively
solution: Case - I: For the man standing in the lift, the acceleration of the ball  $\vec{a}_{b m}=\vec{a}_{b}-\vec{a}_{m} \Rightarrow a_{b m}=g-a$  Case - II: The man standing on the ground, the acceleration of the ball  $\vec{a}_{b m}=\vec{a}_{b}-\vec{a}_{m} \Rightarrow a_{b m}=g-0=g$  \begin{enumerate}

question: When forces $F_{1}, F_{2}, F_{3}$ are acting on a particle of mass $m$ such that $F_{2}$ and $F_{3}$ are mutually perpendicular, then the particle remains stationary. If the force $F_{1}$ is now removed then the acceleration of the particle is
solution: When forces $F_{1}, F_{2}$ and $F_{3}$ are acting on the particle, it remains in equilibrium. Force $F_{2}$ and $F_{3}$ are perpendicular to each other,  $F_{1}=F_{2}+F_{3}$  $\therefore \quad F_{1}=\sqrt{F_{2}^{2}+F_{3}^{2}}$  The force $F_{1}$ is now removed, so, resultant of $F_{2}$ and $F_{3}$ will now make the particle move with force equal to $F_{1}$.  Then, acceleration, $a=\frac{F_{1}}{m}$\\

question: Two forces are such that the sum of their magnitudes is 18 N and their resultant is 12 N which is perpendicular to the smaller force. Then the magnitudes of the forces are
solution: Let the two forces be $F_{1}$ and $F_{2}$ and let $F_{2}<F_{1}$. $R$ is the resultant force  Given $F_{1}+F_{2}=18$  From the figure $F_{2}^{2}+R^{2}=F_{1}^{2}$  $F_{1}^{2}-F_{2}^{2}=R^{2}$  $\therefore \quad F_{1}^{2}-F_{2}^{2}=144$  Only option (b) follows equation (i) and (ii).   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-131(3)}   \begin{enumerate}

question: A light string passing over a smooth light pulley connects two blocks of masses $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ (vertically). If the acceleration of the system is $g / 8$, then the ratio of the masses is
solution: For mass $m_{1}$  $m_{1} g-T=m_{1} a$  For mass $m_{2}$  $T-m_{2} g=m_{2} a$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-131(5)}   Adding the equations we get  $a=\frac{\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right) g}{m_{1}+m_{2}}$  Here $a=\frac{g}{8}$  $\therefore \frac{1}{8}=\frac{\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}-1}{\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}+1} \Rightarrow \frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}+1=8 \frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}-8 \Rightarrow \frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}=\frac{9}{7}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Three identical blocks of masses $m=2 \mathrm{~kg}$ are drawn by a force $F=10.2 \mathrm{~N}$ with an acceleration of $0.6 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$ on a frictionless surface, then what is the tension (in N ) in the string between the blocks $B$ and $C$ ?

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-123(2)}\\
solution: Force $=$ mass $\times$ acceleration  $\therefore \quad F=(m+m+m) \times a$  $F=3 \mathrm{~m} \times \mathrm{a}$  $a=\frac{F}{3 m}$  $\therefore a=\frac{10.2}{6} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  $\therefore T_{2}=m a=2 \times \frac{10.2}{6}=3.4 \mathrm{~N}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-131(4)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
One end of a massless rope, which passes over a massless and frictionless pulley $P$ is tied to a hook $C$ while the other end is free. Maximum tension that the rope can bear is 360 N . With what value of maximum safe acceleration (in $\mathrm{ms}^{-2}$ ) can a man of 60 kg climb on the rope?
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-123(1)}\\
solution: Tension, $T=360 \mathrm{~N}$  Mass of a man $\mathrm{m}=60 \mathrm{~kg}$  $m g-T=m a$\\ $\therefore a=g-\frac{T}{m}$  $=10-\frac{360}{60}=4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: An insect is at the bottom of a hemispherical ditch of radius 1 m . It crawls up the ditch but starts slipping after it is at height $h$ from the bottom. If the coefficient of friction between the ground and the insect is 0.75 , then $h$ is : $\left(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)$
solution: For balancing, $m g \sin \theta=f=\mu m g \cos \theta$  $\Rightarrow \tan \theta=\mu=\frac{3}{4}=0.75$\\ \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-132(1)}  $h=R-R \cos \theta=R-R\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)=\frac{R}{5}$  $\therefore h=\frac{R}{5}=0.2 \mathrm{~m} \quad[\because$ radius, $R=1 \mathrm{~m}]$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A block starts moving up an inclined plane of inclination $30^{\circ}$ with an initial velocity of $v_{0}$. It comes back to its initial position with velocity $\frac{v_{0}}{2}$. The value of the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the inclined plane is close to $\frac{I}{1000}$. The nearest integer to $I$ is $\qquad$ .]
solution: Acceleration of block while moving up an inclined plane,  $a_{1}=g \sin \theta+\mu g \cos \theta$  $\Rightarrow a_{1}=g \sin 30^{\circ}+\mu g \cos 30^{\circ}$  $=\frac{g}{2}+\frac{\mu g \sqrt{3}}{2}$  $\left(\because \theta=30^{\circ}\right)$  Using $v^{2}-u^{2}=2 a(s)$  $\Rightarrow v_{0}^{2}-0^{2}=2 a_{1}(s)$  $(\because u=0)$  $\Rightarrow v_{0}^{2}-2 a_{1}(s)=0$  $\Rightarrow s=\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{a_{1}}$  Acceleration while moving down an inclined plane  $a_{2}=g \sin \theta-\mu g \cos \theta$  $\Rightarrow a_{2}=g \sin 30^{\circ}-\mu g \cos 30^{\circ}$  $\Rightarrow a_{2}=\frac{g}{2}-\frac{\mu \sqrt{3}}{2} g$  Using again $v^{2}-u^{2}=2 a s$ for downward motion  $\Rightarrow\left(\frac{v_{0}}{2}\right)^{2}=2 a_{2}(s) \Rightarrow s=\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{4 a_{2}}$  Equating equation (ii) and (iv)  $\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{a_{1}}=\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{4 a_{2}} \Rightarrow a_{1}=4 a_{2}$ $\Rightarrow \frac{g}{2}+\frac{\mu g \sqrt{3}}{2}=4\left(\frac{g}{2}-\frac{\mu \sqrt{3}}{2}\right)$  $\Rightarrow 5+5 \sqrt{3} \mu=4(5-5 \sqrt{3} \mu) \quad$ (Substituting, $g=10 \mathrm{~m} /$  $\mathrm{s}^{2}$ )  $\Rightarrow 5+5 \sqrt{3} \mu=20-20 \sqrt{3} \mu \Rightarrow 25 \sqrt{3} \mu=15$  $\Rightarrow \mu=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{5}=0.346=\frac{346}{1000}$  So, $\frac{I}{1000}=\frac{346}{1000}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A block of mass 5 kg is (i) pushed in case (A) and (ii) pulled in case (B), by a force $\mathrm{F}=20 \mathrm{~N}$, making an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal, as shown in the figures. The coefficient of friction between the block and floor is $\mu=0.2$. The difference between the accelerations of the block, in case (B) and case (A) will be : $\left(g=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)$
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-124}\\
solution: $\mathrm{A}: N=5 \mathrm{~g}+20 \sin 30^{\circ}$  $=50+20 \times \frac{1}{2}=60 \mathrm{~N}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-132(2)}   Accelaration, $a_{1}=\frac{F-f}{m}=\frac{20 \cos 30^{\circ}-\mu N}{5}$  $$ =\left[\frac{20 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-0.2 \times 60}{5}\right]=1.06 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-132}   B : $N=5 \mathrm{~g}-20 \sin 30^{\circ}$  $=50-20 \times \frac{1}{2}=40 \mathrm{~N}$  $a_{2}=\frac{F-f}{m}=\left[\frac{20 \cos 30^{\circ}-0.2 \times 40}{5}\right]=1.86 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  Now $a_{2}-a_{1}=1.86-1.06=0.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two blocks $A$ and $B$ masses $m_{A}=1 \mathrm{~kg}$ and $m_{B}=3 \mathrm{~kg}$ are kept on the table as shown in figure. The coefficient of friction between A and B is 0.2 and between B and the surface of the table is also 0.2 . The maximum force F that can be applied on B horizontally, so that the block A does not slide over the block B is : [Take g $\left.=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right]$
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-124(5)}\\
solution: Taking $(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B})$ as system  $F-\mu(M+m) g$  $=(M+m) a$  $\Rightarrow a=\frac{F-\mu(M+m) g}{(M+m)}$  $a=\frac{F-(0.2) 4 \times 10}{4}=\left(\frac{F-8}{4}\right)$  But, $a_{\max }=\mu \mathrm{g}=0.2 \times 10=2$  $\therefore \frac{F-8}{4}=2$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{F}=16 \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A block kept on a rough inclined plane, as shown in the figure, remains at rest upto a maximum force 2 N down the inclined plane. The maximum external force up the inclined plane that does not move the block is 10 N . The coefficient of static friction between the block and the plane is : [Take $\left.\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right]$
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-124(1)}\\
solution: From figure, $2+\mathrm{mg} \sin 30^{\circ}=\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos 30^{\circ}$ and  $10=\mathrm{mg} \sin 30^{\circ}+\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos 30^{\circ}$  $=2 \mu \mathrm{mg} \cos 30^{\circ}-2$  $\Rightarrow 6=\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos 30^{\circ}$ and  $4=m g \cos 30^{\circ}$  By dividing above two  $\Rightarrow \frac{3}{2}=\mu \times \sqrt{3}$  $\therefore$ Coefficient of friction, $\mu=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A block of mass 10 kg is kept on a rough inclined plane as shown in the figure. A force of 3 N is applied on the block. The coefficient of static friction between the plane and the block is 0.6 . What should be the minimum value of force P , such that the block doesnot move downward? $\left(\right.$ take $\left.\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)$
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-124(3)}\\
$[9$ Jan. 2019 I]
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-133(6)}   $\operatorname{mg} \sin 45^{\circ}=\frac{100}{\sqrt{2}}=50 \sqrt{2}$  $\left[\because \mathrm{m}=10 \mathrm{~kg}, \mathrm{~g}=9.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right]$  $\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos \theta=0.6 \times \mathrm{mg} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=0.6^{\prime} 50 \sqrt{2}$  $3+\mathrm{mg} \sin \theta=\mathrm{P}+\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos \theta$  $3+50 \sqrt{2}=\mathrm{P}+30 \sqrt{2}$  $\therefore \mathrm{P}=31.28=32 \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two masses $m_{1}=5 \mathrm{~kg}$ and $m_{2}=10 \mathrm{~kg}$, connected by an inextensible string over a frictionless pulley, are moving as shown in the figure. The coefficient of friction of horizontal surface is 0.15 . The minimum weight $m$ that should be put on top of $\mathrm{m}_{2}$ to stop the motion is: [2018]\\
  \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-124(2)}
solution: Given : $\mathrm{m}_{1}=5 \mathrm{~kg} ; \mathrm{m}_{2}=10 \mathrm{~kg} ; \mu=15$  FBD for $\mathrm{m}_{1}, \mathrm{~m}_{1} \mathrm{~g}-\mathrm{T}=\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{a}$  $\Rightarrow 50-\mathrm{T}=5 \times \mathrm{a}$  and, $\mathrm{T}-0.15(\mathrm{~m}+10) \mathrm{g}=(10+\mathrm{m}) \mathrm{a}$  For rest $a=0$  $$ \text { or, } 50=0.15(\mathrm{~m}+10) 10 $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-133}   $\Rightarrow \quad 5=\frac{3}{20}(\mathrm{~m}+10)$  $\frac{100}{3}=\mathrm{m}+10 \quad \therefore \mathrm{m}=23.3 \mathrm{~kg} ; \quad$ close to option (b)\\

question: A given object takes $n$ times more time to slide down a $45^{\circ}$ rough inclined plane as it takes to slide down a perfectly smooth $45^{\circ}$ incline. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the object and the incline is :
solution: The coefficients of kinetic friction between the object and the incline  $$ \mu=\tan \theta\left(1-\frac{1}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}\right) \Rightarrow \mu=1-\frac{1}{\mathrm{n}^{2}} \quad\left(\because \theta=45^{\circ}\right) $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A body of mass 2 kg slides down with an acceleration of $3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ on a rough inclined plane having a slope of $30^{\circ}$. The external force required to take the same body up the plane with the same acceleration will be: $\left(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)$
solution: Equation of motion when the mass slides down $M g \sin \theta-f=M a$  $\Rightarrow 10-f=6\left(M=2 \mathrm{~kg}, a=3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}, \theta=30^{\circ}\right.$ given $)$  $\therefore f=4 \mathrm{~N}$  Equation of motion when the block is pushed up  Let the external force required to take  \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-133(2)}\\ the block up the plane with same  $$ \begin{aligned} & \text { acceleration be } F \\ & \qquad F-M g \sin \theta-f=M a \end{aligned} $$  $\Rightarrow F-10-4=6$ $F=20 \mathrm{~N}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-133(4)}   \begin{enumerate}

question: A rocket is fired vertically from the earth with an acceleration of 2 g , where g is the gravitational acceleration. On an inclined plane inside the rocket, making an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal, a point object of mass $m$ is kept. The minimum coefficient of friction $\mu_{\min }$ between the mass and the inclined surface such that the mass does not move is :
solution: Let $\mu$ be the minimum coefficient of friction   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-133(3)}   At equilibrium, mass does not move so,  $3 \mathrm{mg} \sin \theta=\mu 3 \mathrm{mg} \cos \theta$  $\therefore \mu_{\min }=\tan \theta$

question:
Given in the figure are two blocks A and B of weight 20 N and 100 N , respectively. These are being pressed against a wall by a force F as shown. If the coefficient of friction between the blocks is 0.1 and between block B and the wall is 0.15 , the frictional force applied by the wall on block B is:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-124(4)}\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-133(1)}   Assuming both the blocks are stationary  $\mathrm{N}=\mathrm{F}$  $f_{1}=20 \mathrm{~N}$  $f_{2}=100+20=120 \mathrm{~N}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-133(5)}   Considering the two blocks as one system and due to equilibrium $f=120 \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}
