question: A block of mass $\mathrm{m}=10 \mathrm{~kg}$ rests on a horizontal table. The coefficient of friction between the block and the table is 0.05 . When hit by a bullet of mass 50 g moving with speed $v$, that gets embedded in it, the block moves and comes to stop after moving a distance of 2 m on the table. If a freely falling object were to acquire speed $\frac{v}{10}$ after being dropped from height H , then neglecting energy losses and taking g $=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$, the value of H is close to:
solution: $f=\mu(M+m) g$  $a=\frac{f}{M+m}=\frac{\mu(M+m) g}{(M+m)}=\mu g$  $=0.05 \times 10=0.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$  $V_{0}=\frac{\text { Initial momentum }}{(M+m)}=\frac{0.05 \mathrm{~V}}{10.05}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-134(1)}   Solving we get $v=201 \sqrt{2}$  Object falling from height $H$.  $\frac{V}{10}=\sqrt{2 g H}$  $\frac{201 \sqrt{2}}{10}=\sqrt{2 \times 10 \times H}$  $H=40 \mathrm{~m}=0.04 \mathrm{~km}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A block of mass $m$ is placed on a surface with a vertical cross section given by $y=\frac{x^{3}}{6}$. If the coefficient of friction is 0.5 , the maximum height above the ground at which the block can be placed without slipping is:
solution: At limiting equilibrium,  $\mu=\tan \theta$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-134}   $\tan \theta=\mu=\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{x^{2}}{2} \quad$ (from question)  $\because$ Coefficient of friction $\mu=0.5$  $\therefore \quad 0.5=\frac{x^{2}}{2}$  $\Rightarrow x= \pm 1$  Now, $y=\frac{x^{3}}{6}=\frac{1}{6} m$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Consider a cylinder of mass M resting on a rough horizontal rug that is pulled out from under it with acceleration ' $a$ ' perpendicular to the axis of the cylinder. What is $\mathrm{F}_{\text {friction }}$ at point P? It is assumed that the cylinder does not slip.
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-125(1)}\\
solution: Force of friction at point P ,  $\mathrm{F}_{\text {friction }}=\frac{1}{3}$ Ma $\sin \theta$  $=\frac{1}{3} \operatorname{Ma} \sin 90^{\circ} \quad\left[\right.$ here $\left.\theta=90^{\circ}\right]$  $=\frac{\mathrm{Ma}}{3}$\\

question: A heavy box is to dragged along a rough horizontal floor. To do so, person A pushes it at an angle $30^{\circ}$ from the horizontal and requires a minimum force $\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{A}}$, while person B pulls the box at an angle $60^{\circ}$ from the horizontal and needs minimum force $\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{B}}$. If the coefficient of friction between the box and the floor is $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{5}$, the ratio $\frac{\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{A}}}{\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{B}}}$ is
solution: $\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{A}}$ (Push)  $\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{A}}=\frac{\mu \mathrm{mg}}{\sin \theta-\mu \cos \theta}$  Similarly,  $$ \begin{aligned} & \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{B}}=\frac{\mu \mathrm{mg}}{\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta} \\ & \therefore \quad \frac{\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{A}}}{\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{B}}}=\frac{\frac{\mu \mathrm{mg}}{\sin \theta-\mu \cos \theta}}{\frac{\mu \mathrm{mg}}{\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta}} \\ & =\frac{\mu \mathrm{mg}}{\sin 60^{\circ}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{\varepsilon} \cos 60^{\circ}} \quad\left[\mu=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{5} \text { given }\right] \\ & \frac{\mu \mathrm{mg}}{\sin 30^{\circ}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{5} \cos 30^{\circ}} \\ & =\frac{\sin 30^{\circ}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{5} \cos 30^{\circ}}{\sin 60^{\circ}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{5} \cos 60^{\circ}} \\ & =\frac{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{5} \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}}{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{5} \times \frac{1}{2}} \\ & =\frac{\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{3}{5}\right)}{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{5}\left(1-\frac{1}{5}\right)}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{8}{5}}{\frac{\sqrt{3} \times 4}{10}} \\ & =\frac{\frac{8}{10}}{\frac{\sqrt{3} \times 4}{10}}=\frac{8}{\sqrt{3} \times 4}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A small ball of mass $m$ starts at a point $A$ with speed $v_{o}$ and moves along a frictionless track AB as shown. The track BC has coefficient of friction $\mu$. The ball comes to stop at C after travelling a distance L which is:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-125(5)}\\
solution: Initial speed at point $\mathrm{A}, u=v_{0}$  Speed at point B, $v=$ ?  $v^{2}-u^{2}=2 g h$  $v^{2}=v_{0}^{2}+2 g h$  Let ball travels distance ' $S$ ' before coming to rest  $S=\frac{v^{2}}{2 \mu g}=\frac{v_{0}^{2}+2 g h}{2 \mu g}$  $=\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{2 \mu g}+\frac{2 g h}{2 \mu g}=\frac{h}{\mu}+\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{2 \mu g}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A block A of mass 4 kg is placed on another block $B$ of mass 5 kg , and the block B rests on a smooth horizontal table. If the minimum force that can be applied on A so that both the blocks move together is 12 N , the maximum force that can be applied to B for the blocks to move together will be:
solution: Minimum force on $A$  $=$ frictional force between the surfaces  $=12 \mathrm{~N}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-135}   Therefore maximum acceleration  $a_{\max }=\frac{12 \mathrm{~N}}{4 \mathrm{~kg}}=3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  Hence maximum force  $\mathrm{F}_{\text {max }}=$ total mass $\times a_{\text {max }}$  $$ =9 \times 3=27 \mathrm{~N} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A block is placed on a rough horizontal plane. A time dependent horizontal force $\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{kt}$ acts on the block, where k is a positive constant. The acceleration - time graph of the block is :
solution: Graph  correctly dipicts the acceleration-time graph of the block.

question: A body starts from rest on a long inclined plane of slope $45^{\circ}$. The coefficient of friction between the body and the plane varies as $\mu=0.3 x$, where $x$ is distance travelled down the plane. The body will have maximum speed (for $g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ ) when $x=$
solution: When the body has maximum speed then   $\mu=0.3 \mathrm{x}=\tan 45^{\circ}$  $\therefore \mathrm{x}=3.33 \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A block of weight $W$ rests on a horizontal floor with coefficient of static friction $\mu$. It is desired to make the block move by applying minimum amount of force. The angle $\theta$ from the horizontal at which the force should be applied and magnitude of the force $F$ are respectively.
solution: Let the force $F$ is applied at an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-135(3)}   For horizontal equilibrium,  $F \cos \theta=\mu R$  For vertical equilibrium,  $R+F \sin \theta=\mathrm{mg}$  or, $R=m g-F \sin \theta$  Substituting this value of $R$ in eq. (i), we get  $F \cos \theta=\mu(\mathrm{mg}-F \sin \theta)$  $=\mu \mathrm{mg}-\mu F \sin \theta$  or, $F(\cos \theta+\mu \sin \theta)=\mu \mathrm{mg}$  or, $\mathrm{F}=\frac{\mu \mathrm{mg}}{\cos \theta+\mu \sin \theta}$  For $F$ to be minimum, the denominator $(\cos \theta+\mu \sin \theta)$ should be maximum.  $\therefore \frac{d}{d \theta}(\cos \theta+\mu \sin \theta)=0$  or, $-\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta=0$  or, $\tan \theta=\mu$  or, $\theta=\tan ^{-1}(\mu)$  Then, $\sin \theta=\frac{\mu}{\sqrt{1+\mu^{2}}}$ and $\cos \theta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\mu^{2}}}$  Hence, $F_{\text {min }}$  $=\frac{\mu w}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\mu^{2}}}+\frac{\mu^{2}}{\sqrt{1+\mu^{2}}}}=\frac{\mu w}{\sqrt{1+\mu^{2}}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An insect crawls up a hemispherical surface very slowly. The coefficient of friction between the insect and the surface is $1 / 3$. If the line joining the centre of the hemispherical surface to the insect makes an angle $\alpha$ with the vertical, the maximum possible value of $\alpha$ so that the insect does not slip is given by 

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-126(2)}\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-135(2)}   The insect crawls up the bowl upto a certain height h only till the component of its weight along the bowl is balanced by limiting frictional force.  For limiting condition at point A  $R=m g \cos \alpha \quad \ldots$ (i)  $F_{1}=m g \sin \alpha \quad$...(ii)  Dividing eq. (ii) by (i)  $\tan \alpha=\frac{1}{\cot \alpha}=\frac{F_{1}}{R}=\mu\left[A s F_{1}=\mu R\right]$  $\Rightarrow \tan \alpha=\mu=\frac{1}{3}\left[\because \mu=\frac{1}{3}\right.$ (Given) $]$  $\therefore \quad \cot \alpha=3$  \begin{enumerate}

question: The minimum force required to start pushing a body up rough (frictional coefficient $\mu$ ) inclined plane is $F_{1}$ while the minimum force needed to prevent it from sliding down is $F_{2}$. If the inclined plane makes an angle $\theta$ from the horizontal such that $\tan \theta=2 \mu$ then the ratio $\frac{F_{1}}{F_{2}}$ is\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-135(1)}   When the body slides up the inclined plane, then $\mathrm{mg} \sin \theta+f_{1}=F_{1}$  or, $\mathrm{F}_{1}=\mathrm{mg} \sin \theta+\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos \theta$  When the body slides down the inclined plane, then $\mathrm{mg} \sin \theta-f_{2}=F_{2}$  or $\quad F_{2}=\mathrm{mg} \sin \theta-\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos \theta$  $\therefore \frac{F_{1}}{F_{2}}=\frac{\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta}{\sin \theta-\mu \cos \theta}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{F_{1}}{F_{2}}=\frac{\tan \theta+\mu}{\tan \theta-\mu}=\frac{2 \mu+\mu}{2 \mu-\mu}=\frac{3 \mu}{\mu}=3$  \begin{enumerate}

question: If a spring of stiffness ' $k$ ' is cut into parts ' $A$ ' and ' $B$ ' of length $\ell_{A}: \ell_{B}=2: 3$, then the stiffness of spring ' $A$ ' is given by
solution: It is given $\ell_{A}: \ell_{B}=2: 3$  $\ell_{A}=\frac{2 \ell}{5}, \ell_{B}=\left(\frac{3 \ell}{5}\right)$  $\therefore$ We know that $k \propto \frac{1}{\ell}$  If initial spring constant is $k$, then  $k \ell=k_{A} \ell_{A}=k_{B} \ell_{B}$  $k \ell=k_{A}\left(\frac{2 \ell}{5}\right)$  $k_{A}=\frac{5 k}{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A smooth block is released at rest on a $45^{\circ}$ incline and then slides a distance ' $d$ '. The time taken to slide is ' $n$ ' times as much to slide on rough incline than on a smooth incline. The coefficient of friction is
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-136(4)}   smooth   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-136(2)}   rough\\ On smooth inclined plane, acceleration of the body $=g$ $\sin \theta$. Let $d$ be the distance travelled  $\therefore \quad d=\frac{1}{2}(g \sin \theta) t_{1}^{2}$,  $$ t_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 d}{g \sin \theta}} $$  On rough inclined plane,  $$ a=\frac{m g \sin \theta-\mu R}{m} $$  $\Rightarrow a=\frac{m g \sin \theta-\mu m g \cos \theta}{m}$  $\Rightarrow a=g \sin \theta-\mu_{k} g \cos \theta$  $\therefore \quad d=\frac{1}{2}(g \sin \theta-\mu \hat{k} g \cos \theta) t_{2}^{2}$  $t_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{2 d}{g \sin \theta-\mu \hat{k g} \cos \theta}}$  According to question, $t_{2}=n t_{1}$  $\sqrt[n]{\frac{2 d}{g \sin \theta}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 d}{g \sin \theta-\mu \hat{k g} \cos \theta}}$  Here, $\mu$ is coefficient of kinetic friction as the block moves over the inclined plane.  $\therefore \quad \sin \theta=(\sin \theta-\mu \hat{k} \cos \theta) n^{2}$  $\Rightarrow n=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\mu_{k}}} \quad \Rightarrow \quad n^{2}=\frac{1}{1-\mu_{k}}$  $\Rightarrow \mu_{k}=1-\frac{1}{n^{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: The upper half of an inclined plane with inclination $\phi$ is perfectly smooth while the lower half is rough. A body starting from rest at the top will again come to rest at the bottom if the coefficient of friction for the lower half is given by
solution: For first half acceleration $=g \sin \phi$;  For second half  acceleration $=-(g \sin \phi-\mu g \cos \phi)$  For the block to come to rest at the bottom, acceleration in I half $=$ retardation in II half. $g \sin \phi=-(g \sin \phi-\mu g \cos \phi)$  $\Rightarrow \mu=2 \tan \phi$  \section*{NOTE} According to work-energy theorem, $W=\Delta K=0$  (Since initial and final speeds are zero)  $\therefore \quad$ Workdone by friction + Work done by gravity $=0$  i.e., $-(\mu m g \cos \phi) \frac{\ell}{2}+m g \ell \sin \phi=0$  or $\frac{\mu}{2} \cos \phi=\sin \phi \quad$ or $\quad \mu=2 \tan \phi$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Consider a car moving on a straight road with a speed of $100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The distance at which car can be stopped is $\left[\mu_{\mathrm{k}}=0.5\right]$
solution: Given, initial velocity, $u=100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.  Final velocity, $v=0$.  Acceleration, $a=\mu_{k} g=0.5 \times 10$  $v^{2}-u^{2}=2 a s$ or  $\Rightarrow 0^{2}-u^{2}=2\left(-\mu_{k} g\right) s$  $\Rightarrow-100^{2}=2 \times-\frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times s$  $\Rightarrow s=1000 \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A block rests on a rough inclined plane making an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. The coefficient of static friction between the block and the plane is 0.8 . If the frictional force on the block is 10 N , the mass of the block (in kg ) is (take $g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ )
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-136(3)}   Since the body is at rest on the inclined plane, $m g \sin 30^{\circ}=$ Force of friction  $\Rightarrow m \times 10 \times \sin 30^{\circ}=10$  $\Rightarrow m \times 5=10 \Rightarrow m=2.0 \mathrm{~kg}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A horizontal force of 10 N is necessary to just hold a block stationary against a wall. The coefficient of friction between the block and the wall is 0.2 . The weight of the block is

 
 \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-126(1)}
solution: Horizontal force, $N=10 \mathrm{~N}$.  Coefficient of friction $\mu=0.2$.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-136}   The block will be stationary so long as  Force of friction $=$ weight of block  $\therefore \mu N=W$  $\Rightarrow 0.2 \times 10=W$  $\Rightarrow W=2 N$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A marble block of mass 2 kg lying on ice when given a velocity of $6 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ is stopped by friction in 10 s . Then the coefficient of friction is
solution: $u=6 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}, v=0, t=10 s, a=$ ?  Acceleration $a=\frac{v-u}{t}$  $\Rightarrow a=\frac{0-6}{10}$  $\Rightarrow a=\frac{-6}{10}=-0.6 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-136(1)}   The retardation is due to the frictional force  $\therefore f=m a \Rightarrow \mu N=m a$\\ $\Rightarrow \mu m g=m a \quad \Rightarrow \quad \mu=\frac{m a}{m g}$  $\Rightarrow \mu=\frac{a}{g}=\frac{0.6}{10}=0.06$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A disc rotates about its axis of symmetry in a hoizontal plane at a steady rate of 3.5 revolutions per second. A coin placed at a distance of 1.25 cm from the axis of rotation remains at rest on the disc. The coefficient of friction between the coin and the disc is $\left(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)$
solution: Using, $\mu m g=\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=m r \omega^{2}$ $\omega=2 \pi n=2 \pi \times 5=7 \pi \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}$ Radius, $r=25 \mathrm{~cm}=25 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}$ Coefficient of friction, $\mu=$ ?  $$ \mu m g=\frac{m(r \omega)^{2}}{r}(\because v=r \omega) $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-137(3)}   $\mu m g=m r \omega^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \mu=\frac{r \omega^{2}}{g}=\frac{1.25 \times 10^{-2} \times\left(7 \times \frac{22}{7}\right)^{2}}{10}$  $=\frac{1.25 \times 10^{-2} \times 22^{2}}{10}=0.6$  \begin{enumerate}

Given, $\theta=45^{\circ}, \mathrm{r}=4 \mathrm{~m}, \mathrm{~g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  $\mathrm{T} \sin \theta=\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}}$  $\mathrm{T} \cos \theta=\mathrm{mg}$  From equation (i) \& (ii) we have, $\tan \theta=\frac{\mathrm{v}^{2}}{\mathrm{rg}}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-137}   Hence, speed of the pendulum in its circular path, $\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\mathrm{rg}}=\sqrt{0.4 \times 10}=2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A particle is released on a vertical smooth semicircular track from point X so that OX makes angle $\theta$ from the vertical (see figure). The normal reaction of the track on the particle vanishes at point Y where OY makes angle $\phi$ with the horizontal. Then: $\quad$ 

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-126(3)}\\

A body of mass ' $m$ ' is tied to one end of a spring and whirled round in a horizontal plane with a constant angular velocity. The elongation in the spring is 1 cm . If the angular velocity is doubled, the elongation in the spring is 5 cm . The original length of the spring is :

A point P moves in counter-clockwise direction on a circular path as shown in the figure. The movement of ' P ' is such that it sweeps out a length $s=t^{3}+5$, where s is in metres and $t$ is in seconds. The radius of the path is 20 m . The acceleration of ' P ' when $t=2 \mathrm{~s}$ is nearly.
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-127}\\
solution: $s=t^{3}+5$   $\Rightarrow$ velocity, $v=\frac{d s}{d t}=3 t^{2}$  Tangential acceleration $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{t}}=\frac{d v}{d t}=6 t$  Radial acceleration $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{v^{2}}{R}=\frac{9 t^{4}}{R}$\\ At $t=2 s, \quad a_{t}=6 \times 2=12 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  $a_{c}=\frac{9 \times 16}{20}=7.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  $\therefore$ Resultant acceleration  $=\sqrt{a_{t}^{2}+a_{c}^{2}}$  $=\sqrt{(12)^{2}+(7.2)^{2}}=\sqrt{144+51.84}$  $=\sqrt{195.84}=14 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: For a particle in uniform circular motion, the acceleration $\vec{a}$ at a point $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{R}, \theta)$ on the circle of radius R is (Here $\theta$ is measured from the $x$-axis)
solution: Clearly $\vec{a}=a_{c} \cos \theta(-\hat{i})+a_{c} \sin \theta(-\hat{j})$  $=\frac{-v^{2}}{R} \cos \theta \hat{i}-\frac{v^{2}}{R} \sin \theta \hat{j}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-137(2)}   \begin{enumerate}

question: An annular ring with inner and outer radii $R_{1}$ and $R_{2}$ is rolling without slipping with a uniform angular speed. The ratio of the forces experienced by the two particles situated on the inner and outer parts of the ring, $\frac{F_{1}}{F_{2}}$ is
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3fd9241b910588e91cb9g-137(1)}   Let $m$ is the mass of each particle and $\omega$ is the angular speed of the annular ring.  $a_{1}=\frac{v_{1}^{2}}{R_{1}}=\frac{\omega^{2} R_{1}^{2}}{R_{1}}=\omega^{2} R_{1}$  $a_{2}=\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{R_{2}}=\omega^{2} R_{2}$  Taking particle masses equal  $\frac{F_{1}}{F_{2}}=\frac{m a_{1}}{m a_{2}}=\frac{m R_{1} \omega^{2}}{m R_{2} \omega^{2}}=\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}$  \section*{NOTE :} The force experienced by any particle is only along radial direction.  Force experienced by the particle, $F=m \omega^{2} R$  $\therefore \frac{F_{1}}{F_{2}}=\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Which of the following statements is FALSE for a particle moving in a circle with a constant angular speed ? [2004]
options: a) The acceleration vector points to the centre of the circle
b) The acceleration vector is tangent to the circle
c) The velocity vector is tangent to the circle
d) The velocity and acceleration vectors are perpendicular to each other.
solution: Only option  is false since acceleration vector is always radial (i.e. towards the center) for uniform circular motion.

question: The minimum velocity $\left(\right.$ in $\mathrm{ms}^{-1}$ ) with which a car driver must traverse a flat curve of radius 150 m and coefficient of friction 0.6 to avoid skidding is
solution: The maximum velocity of the car is   $v_{\max }=\sqrt{\mu r g}$  Here $\mu=0.6, r=150 \mathrm{~m}, g=9.8$  $v_{\max }=\sqrt{0.6 \times 150 \times 9.8} \simeq 30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$   \end{document}

question: A person pushes a box on a rough horizontal platform surface. He applies a force of 200 N over a distance of 15 m . Thereafter, he gets progressively tired and his applied force reduces linearly with distance to 100 N . The total distance through which the box has been moved is 30 m . What is the work done by the person during the total movement of the box ?
solution: The given situation can be drawn graphically as shown in figure.  Work done $=$ Area under $F-x$ graph  $=$ Area of rectangle $A B C D+$ Area of trapezium $B C F E$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-72(1)}   $W=(200 \times 15)+\frac{1}{2}(100+200) \times 15=3000+2250$  $\Rightarrow W=5250 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-63(2)}
 

A small block starts slipping down from a point $B$ on an inclined plane $A B$, which is making an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal section $B C$ is smooth and the remaining section $C A$ is rough with a coefficient of friction $\mu$. It is found that the block comes to rest as it reaches the bottom (point $A$ ) of the inclined plane. If $B C=2 A C$, the coefficient of friction is given by $\mu=k \tan \theta$. The value of $k$ is $\qquad$ .]
solution: If $A C=l$ then according to question, $B C=2 l$ and $A B=$ $3 l$.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-72}   Here, work done by all the forces is zero.  $W_{\text {friction }}+W_{m g}=0$  $m g(3 l) \sin \theta-\mu m g \cos \theta(l)=0$  $\Rightarrow \mu m g \cos \theta l=3 m g l \sin \theta$  $\Rightarrow \mu=3 \tan \theta=k \tan \theta$  $\therefore k=3$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Consider a force $\vec{F}=-x \hat{i}+y \hat{j}$. The work done by this force in moving a particle from point $\mathrm{A}(1,0)$ to $\mathrm{B}(0,1)$ along the line segment is: (all quantities are in SI units)
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-63}\\
solution: Work done, $W=\int \vec{F} \cdot \overrightarrow{d s}$  $=(-x \hat{i}+y \hat{j}) \cdot(d \times \hat{i}+d y \hat{j})$  $\Rightarrow W=-\int_{1}^{0} x d x+\int_{0}^{1} y d y$  $=\left(0+\frac{1}{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2}=1 J$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A block of mass $m$ is kept on a platform which starts from rest with constant acceleration $\mathrm{g} / 2$ upward, as shown in fig. work done by normal reaction on block in time $t$ is:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-63(1)}\\
solution: Here, $\mathrm{N}-\mathrm{mg}=\mathrm{ma}=\frac{\mathrm{mg}}{2} \Rightarrow \mathrm{N}=\frac{3 \mathrm{mg}}{2}$  $\mathrm{N}=$ normal reaction  Now, work done by normal reaction ' N ' on  block in time $\mathrm{t}, \mathrm{W}=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{N}} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{S}}=\left(\frac{3 \mathrm{mg}}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~g} / 2 \mathrm{t}^{2}\right)$ or, $\mathrm{W}=\frac{3 \mathrm{mg}^{2} \mathrm{t}^{2}}{8}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A body of mass starts moving from rest along $x$-axis so that its velocity varies as $v=a \sqrt{s}$ where $a$ is a constant $s$ and is the distance covered by the body. The total work done by all the forces acting on the body in the first second after the start of the motion is: [Online April 16, 2018]\\
solution: From question, $v=\mathrm{a} \sqrt{\mathrm{s}}=\frac{\mathrm{ds}}{\mathrm{dt}}$  or, $\quad 2 \sqrt{\mathrm{s}}=\mathrm{at} \Rightarrow \mathrm{S}=\frac{\mathrm{a}^{2} \mathrm{t}^{2}}{4}$  $\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{m} \times \frac{\mathrm{a}^{2}}{2}$  Work done $=\frac{\mathrm{ma}^{2}}{2} \times \frac{\mathrm{a}^{2} \mathrm{t}^{2}}{4}=\frac{1}{8} \mathrm{ma}^{4} \mathrm{t}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: When a rubber-band is stretched by a distance $x$, it exerts restoring force of magnitude $\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{ax}+\mathrm{bx}^{2}$ where a and b are constants. The work done in stretching the unstretched rubber-band by L is:
solution: Work done in stretching the rubber-band by a distance $d x$ is  $d W=F d x=\left(a x+b x^{2}\right) d x$  Integrating both sides,  $W=\int_{0}^{L} a x d x+\int_{0}^{L} b x^{2} d x=\frac{a L^{2}}{2}+\frac{b L^{3}}{3}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A uniform chain of length 2 m is kept on a table such that a length of 60 cm hangs freely from the edge of the table. The total mass of the chain is 4 kg . What is the work done in pulling the entire chain on the table?
solution: Mass of over hanging part of the chain  $m^{\prime}=\frac{4}{2} \times(0.6) \mathrm{kg}=1.2 \mathrm{~kg}$  Weight of hanging part of the chain  $=1.2 \times 10=12 \mathrm{~N}$  C.M. of hanging part $=0.3 \mathrm{~m}$ below the table  Workdone in putting the entire cha in on the table $=12 \times$ $0.30=3.6 \mathrm{~J}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A force $\vec{F}=(5 \vec{i}+3 \vec{j}+2 \vec{k}) N$ is applied over a particle which displaces it from its origin to the point $\vec{r}=(2 \vec{i}-\vec{j}) m$. The work done on the particle in joules is
solution: Given, Force, $\vec{F}=(5 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k})$  Displacement, $x=(2 \hat{i}-\hat{j})$  Work done,  $W=\vec{F} \cdot \vec{x}=(5 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}) \cdot(2 \hat{i}-\hat{j})$  $=10-3=7$ joules  \begin{enumerate}

question: A spring of spring constant $5 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$ is stretched initially by 5 cm from the unstretched position. Then the work required to stretch it further by another 5 cm is [2003]\\
solution: Spring constant, $k=5 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$  Let $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ be the initial and final stretched position of the spring, then  Work done, $W=\frac{1}{2} k\left(x_{2}^{2}-x_{1}^{2}\right)$  $=\frac{1}{2} \times 5 \times 10^{3}\left[(0.1)^{2}-(0.05)^{2}\right]$  $=\frac{5000}{2} \times 0.15 \times 0.05=18.75 \mathrm{Nm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A spring of force constant $800 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$ has an extension of 5 cm . The work done in extending it from 5 cm to 15 cm is
solution: Small amount of work done in extending the spring by $d x$ is  $d W=k x d x$  $\therefore W=k \int_{0.05}^{0.15} x d x$\\ $=\frac{800}{2}\left[(0.15)^{2}-(0.05)^{2}\right]$  $=400[(0.15+0.05)(0.15-0.05)]$  $=400 \times 0.2 \times 0.1=8 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A cricket ball of mass 0.15 kg is thrown vertically up by a bowling machine so that it rises to a maximum height of 20 m after leaving the machine. If the part pushing the ball applies a constant force $F$ on the ball and moves horizontally a distance of 0.2 m while launching the ball, the value of $F$ (in N$)$ is $\left(g=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)$ $\qquad$ .]
solution: From work energy theorem,  $W=F \cdot s=\Delta K E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}$  Here $V^{2}=2 g h$  $\therefore F \cdot s=F \times \frac{2}{10}=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{15}{100} \times 2 \times 10 \times 20$  $\therefore F=150 \mathrm{~N}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A particle $(m=1 \mathrm{~kg})$ slides down a frictionless track (AOC) starting from rest at a point $A$ (height 2 m ). After reaching $C$, the particle continues to move freely in air as a projectile. When it reaching its highest point $P$ (height 1 m ), the kinetic energy of the particle (in $J$ ) is: (Figure drawn is schematic and not to scale; take $g=10$ $\mathrm{ms}^{-2}$ ) .

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-64(2)}]
solution: Kinetic energy = change in potential energy of the particle,  $\mathrm{KE}=\operatorname{mg} \Delta \mathrm{h}$  Given, $m=1 \mathrm{~kg}$,  $\Delta h=\mathrm{h}_{2}-\mathrm{h}_{1}=2-1=1 \mathrm{~m}$  $\therefore K E=1 \times 10 \times 1=10 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A particle moves in one dimension from rest under the influence of a force that varies with the distance travelled by the particle as shown in the figure. The kinetic energy of the particle after it has travelled 3 m is :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-64(1)}\\
solution: We know area under F-x graph gives the work done by the body  $\therefore W=\frac{1}{2} \times(3+2) \times(3-2)+2 \times 2=2.5+4=6.5 \mathrm{~J}$  Using work energy theorem,  $\Delta \mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E}=$ work done  $\therefore \Delta \mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E}=6.5 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A spring whose unstretched length is $l$ has a force constant $k$. The spring is cut into two pieces of unstretched lengths $l_{1}$ and $l_{2}$ where, $l_{1}=n l_{2}$ and $n$ is an integer. The ratio $k_{1} / k_{2}$ of the corresponding force constants, $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ will be:
solution: $l_{1}+l_{2}=l$ and $l_{1}=n l_{2}$  $\therefore \quad l_{1}=\frac{n l}{n+1}$ and $l_{2}=\frac{l}{n+1}$  As $\boldsymbol{k} \propto \frac{1}{l}$,  $\therefore \quad \frac{k_{1}}{k_{2}}=\frac{l /(n+1)}{(n l) /(n+1)}=\frac{1}{n}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A body of mass 1 kg falls freely from a height of 100 m , on a platform of mass 3 kg which is mounted on a spring having spring constant $\mathrm{k}=1.25 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$. The body sticks to the platform and the spring's maximum compression is found to be x . Given that $\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$, the value of x will be close to :
solution: Velocity of 1 kg block just before it collides with 3 kg  block $=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{gh}}=\sqrt{2000} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Using principle of conservation of linear momentum just before and just after collision, we get  $1 \times \sqrt{2000}=4 v \Rightarrow v=\frac{\sqrt{2000}}{4} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Initial compression of spring  $1.25 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{x}_{0}=30 \Rightarrow \mathrm{x}_{0} \approx 0$  using work energy theorem,  $\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{g}}+\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{sp}}=\Delta \mathrm{KE}$  /7/1/ा//ा/  $\Rightarrow 40 \times \mathrm{x}+\frac{1}{2} \times 1.25 \times 10^{6}\left(0^{2}-\mathrm{x}^{2}\right)$  $=0-\frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times v^{2}$ solving $x \approx 4 \mathrm{~cm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A uniform cable of mass ' $M$ ' and length ' $L$ ' is placed on a horizontal surface such that its $\left(\frac{1}{n}\right)^{\text {th }}$ part is hanging below the edge of the surface. To lift the hanging part of the cable upto the surface, the work done should be:
solution: $\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{u}_{\mathrm{f}}-\mathrm{u}_{i}$  $=0-\left(-\frac{m g}{n} \times \frac{L}{2 n}\right)=\frac{M g L}{2 n^{2}}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A wedge of mass $\mathrm{M}=4 \mathrm{~m}$ lies on a frictionless plane. A particle of mass $m$ approaches the wedge with speed $v$. There is no friction between the particle and the plane or between the particle and the wedge. The maximum height climbed by the particle on the wedge is given by:
solution: $m v=(m+M) V^{\prime}$  or $v=\frac{m v}{m+M}=\frac{m v}{m+4 m}=\frac{v}{5}$  Using conservation of ME, we have  $\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=\frac{1}{2}(m+4 m)\left(\frac{v}{5}\right)^{2}+m g h$  or $h=\frac{2}{5} \frac{v^{2}}{g}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A particle moves in one dimension from rest under the influence of a force that varies with the distance travelled by the particle as shown in the figure. The kinetic energy of the particle after it has travelled 3 m is :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-64}\\
solution: We know area under F-x graph gives the work done by the body  $\therefore W=\frac{1}{2} \times(3+2) \times(3-2)+2 \times 2$  $$ \begin{gathered} =2.5+4 \\ =6.5 \mathrm{~J} \end{gathered} $$  Using work energy theorem,  $$ \Delta \mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E}=\text { work done } $$  $$ \therefore \Delta \mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E}=6.5 \mathrm{~J} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle which is experiencing a force, given by $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}=3 \vec{i}-12 \vec{j}$, undergoes a displacement of $\vec{d}=4 \vec{i}$. If the particle had a kinetic energy of 3 J at the beginning of the displacement, what is its kinetic energy at the end of the displacement?
solution: Work done $=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}=(3 \overrightarrow{\mathrm{i}}-12 \overrightarrow{\mathrm{J}}) \cdot(4 \overrightarrow{\mathrm{i}})=12 \mathrm{~J}$  From work energy theorem,  $\mathrm{w}_{\text {net }}=\Delta \mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E} .=\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{f}}-\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{i}}$  $\Rightarrow 12=\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{f}}-3$  $\therefore \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{f}}=15 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A block of mass m, lying on a smooth horizontal surface, is attached to a spring (of negligible mass) of spring constant $k$. The other end of the spring is fixed, as shown in the figure. The block is initally at rest in its equilibrium position. If now the block is pulled with a constant force F , the maximum speed of the block is: 

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-65(1)}\\


(d)\\
$\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{mk}}}$
solution: Maximum speed is at mean position or equilibrium  At equilibrium Position  $\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{kx} \Rightarrow \mathrm{x}=\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{k}}$  From work-energy theorem,  $\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{F}}+\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{sp}}=\Delta \mathrm{KE}$  $\mathrm{F}(\mathrm{x})-\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{kx}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}-0$  $\mathrm{F}\left(\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{k}}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{k}\left(\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{k}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{F}^{2}}{\mathrm{~K}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}$  or, $v_{\max }=\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{mk}}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A force acts on a 2 kg object so that its position is given as a function of time as $x=3 \mathrm{t}^{2}+5$. What is the work done by this force in first 5 seconds?
solution: Position, $x=3 \mathrm{t}^{2}+5$  $\therefore$ Velocity, $\mathrm{v}=\frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{dt}} \Rightarrow \mathrm{v}=\frac{\mathrm{d}\left(3 \mathrm{t}^{2}+5\right)}{\mathrm{dt}}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{v}=6 \mathrm{t}+0$  At $t=0$ $\mathrm{v}=0$  And, at $\mathrm{t}=5 \mathrm{sec}$ $\mathrm{v}=30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  According to work-energy theorem, $\mathrm{w}=\Delta \mathrm{KE}$  or, $\mathrm{W}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}-0=\frac{1}{2}(2)(30)^{2}=900 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle is moving in a circular path of radius a under the action of an attractive potential $U=-\frac{k}{2 r^{2}}$. Its total energy is:
solution: $\mathrm{F}=-\frac{\partial \mathrm{u}}{\partial \mathrm{r}} \hat{\mathrm{r}}=\frac{\mathrm{K}}{\mathrm{r}^{3}} \hat{\mathrm{r}}$  Since particle is moving in circular path  $\mathrm{F}=\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}}=\frac{\mathrm{K}}{\mathrm{r}^{3}} \Rightarrow \mathrm{mv}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{K}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}$  $\therefore$ K.E. $=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{K}}{2 \mathrm{r}^{2}}$  Total energy $=$ P.E. + K.E.  $=-\frac{\mathrm{K}}{2 \mathrm{r}^{2}}+\frac{\mathrm{K}}{2 \mathrm{r}^{2}}=$ Zero $\quad\left(\because\right.$ P.E. $=-\frac{\mathrm{K}}{2 \mathrm{r}^{2}}$ given $)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two particles of the same mass $m$ are moving in circular orbits because of force, given by $F(r)=\frac{-16}{r}-r^{3}$

The first particle is at a distance $r=1$, and the second, at $r=4$. The best estimate for the ratio of kinetic energies of the first and the second particle is closest to
solution: As the particles moving in circular orbits, So  $\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}}=\frac{16}{\mathrm{r}}+\mathrm{r}^{2}$  Kinetic energy, $\mathrm{KE}_{0}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left[16+\mathrm{r}^{4}\right]$  For first particle, $\mathrm{r}=1, \mathrm{~K}_{1}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}(16+1)$  Similarly, for second particle, $r=4, K_{2}=\frac{1}{2} m(16+256)$  $\therefore \frac{\mathrm{K}_{1}}{\mathrm{~K}_{2}}=\frac{\frac{16+1}{2}}{\frac{16+256}{2}}=\frac{17}{272} \simeq 6 \times 10^{-2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A body of mass $\mathrm{m}=10^{-2} \mathrm{~kg}$ is moving in a medium and experiences a frictional force $\mathrm{F}=-\mathrm{kv}^{2}$. Its intial speed is $\mathrm{v}_{0}=$ $10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$. If, after 10 s , its energy is $\frac{1}{8} m v_{0}^{2}$, the value of k will be:
solution: Let $V_{f}$ is the final speed of the body. From questions,  $\frac{1}{2} m V_{f}^{2}=\frac{1}{8} m V_{0}^{2} \quad \Rightarrow \quad V_{f}=\frac{V_{0}}{2}=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  $F=m\left(\frac{d V}{d t}\right)=-k V^{2} \quad \therefore \quad\left(10^{-2}\right) \frac{d V}{d t}=-k V^{2}$  $\int_{10}^{5} \frac{d V}{V^{2}}=-100 K \int_{0}^{10} d t$  $\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{10}=100 K(10) \quad$ or, $\quad K=10^{-4} \mathrm{kgm}^{-1}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: An object is dropped from a height $h$ from the ground. Every time it hits the ground it looses $50 \%$ of its kinetic energy. The total distance covered as $\mathrm{t} \rightarrow \infty$ is
solution: (K.E.)' $=50 \%$ of K.E. after hit i.e.,  $\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{\prime 2}=\frac{50}{100} \times \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2} \Rightarrow \mathrm{v}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{\sqrt{2}}$  Coefficient of restitution $=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$  Now, total distance travelled by object is  $\mathrm{H}=\mathrm{h}\left(\frac{1+\mathrm{e}^{2}}{1-\mathrm{e}^{2}}\right)=h\left(\frac{1+\frac{1}{2}}{1-\frac{1}{2}}\right)=3 h$\\

question: A time dependent force $\mathrm{F}=6 \mathrm{t}$ acts on a particle of mass 1 kg . If the particle starts from rest, the work done by the force during the first 1 second will be
solution: Using, $\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{ma}=m \frac{d V}{d t}$  $6 t=1 . \frac{d V}{d t} \quad[\because \quad m=1 \mathrm{~kg}$ given $]$  $\int_{0}^{v} d V=\int 6 t d t \quad V=6\left[\frac{t^{2}}{2}\right]_{0}^{1}=3 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$  $[\because \quad t=1 \mathrm{sec}$ given $]$  From work-energy theorem,  $\mathrm{W}=\Delta \mathrm{KE}=\frac{1}{2} m\left(V^{2}-u^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times 9=4.5 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Velocity-time graph for a body of mass 10 kg is shown in figure. Work-done on the body in first two seconds of the motion is :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-65}\\
solution: Acceleration (a) $=\frac{\mathrm{v}-4}{\mathrm{t}}=\frac{(0-50)}{(10-0)}=-5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  $\mathrm{u}=50 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  $\therefore v=u+a t=50-5 \mathrm{t}$  Veocity in first two seconds $t=2$  $\mathrm{v}_{(\mathrm{at} \mathrm{t}=2)}=40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  From work-energy theorem,  $\Delta \mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E} .=\mathrm{W}=\frac{1}{2}\left(40^{2}-50^{2}\right) \times 10=-4500 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A point particle of mass m , moves long the uniformly rough track PQR as shown in the figure. The coefficient of friction, between the particle and the rough track equals $\mu$. The particle is released, from rest from the point P and it comes to rest at a point R . The energies, lost by the ball, over the parts, PQ and QR , of the track, are equal to each other, and no energy is lost when particle changes direction from PQ to QR.

The value of the coefficient of friction $\mu$ and the distance $\mathrm{x}(=\mathrm{QR})$, are, respectively close to :

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-65(2)}\\
solution: Work done by friction at $\mathrm{QR}=\mu \mathrm{mg} x$  In triangle, $\sin 30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2}=\frac{2}{P Q}$  $\Rightarrow P Q=4 m$  Work done by friction at $\mathrm{PQ}=\mu \mathrm{mg} \times \operatorname{Cos} 30^{\circ} \times 4$  $=\mu \mathrm{mg} \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \times 4=2 \sqrt{3} \mu \mathrm{mg}$  Since work done by friction on parts $P Q$ and $Q R$ are equal, $\mu \mathrm{mg} x=2 \sqrt{3}$ umg  $\Rightarrow x=2 \sqrt{3} \cong 3.5 \mathrm{~m}$  Using work energy theorem $\mathrm{mg} \sin 30^{\circ} \times 4=2 \sqrt{3} \mu \mathrm{mg}+\mu \mathrm{mg} x$  $\Rightarrow 2=4 \sqrt{3} \mu$  $\Rightarrow \mu=0.29$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A person trying to lose weight by burning fat lifts a mass of 10 kg upto a height of 1 m 1000 times. Assume that the potential energy lost each time he lowers the mass is dissipated. How much fat will he use up considering the work done only when the weight is lifted up? Fat supplies $3.8 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~J}$ of energy per kg which is converted to mechanical energy with a $20 \%$ efficiency rate. Take $g=9.8$ $\mathrm{ms}^{-2}$ :
solution: $\mathrm{n}=\frac{\mathrm{W}}{\text { input }}=\frac{\mathrm{mgh} \times 1000}{\text { input }}=\frac{10 \times 8 \times 1 \times 1000}{\text { input }}$  Input $=\frac{98000}{0.2}=49 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~J}$  Fat used $=\frac{49 \times 10^{4}}{3.8 \times 10^{7}}=12.89 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~kg}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle is moving in a circle of radius $r$ under the action of a force $\mathrm{F}=\alpha \mathrm{r}^{2}$ which is directed towards centre of the circle. Total mechanical energy (kinetic energy + potential energy) of the particle is (take potential energy $=0$ for $\mathrm{r}=0$ ) :
solution: As we know, $\mathrm{dU}=\mathrm{F} . \mathrm{dr}$  $U=\int_{0}^{r} \alpha r^{2} d r=\frac{a r^{3}}{3}$  As, $\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=\alpha r^{2}$  $m^{2} v^{2}=m \alpha r^{3}$  or, $2 \mathrm{~m}(\mathrm{KE})=\frac{1}{2} \alpha r^{3}$  Total energy $=$ Potential energy + kinetic energy  Now, from eqn (i) and (ii)  Total energy $=$ K.E. + P.E.  $=\frac{\alpha r^{3}}{3}+\frac{\alpha r^{3}}{2}=\frac{5}{6} \alpha r^{3}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A block of mass $m=0.1 \mathrm{~kg}$ is connected to a spring of unknown spring constant k . It is compressed to a distance $x$ from its equilibrium position and released from rest. After approaching half the distance $\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)$ from equilibrium position, it hits another block and comes to rest momentarily, while the other block moves with a velocity $3 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$.

The total initial energy of the spring is :
solution: Applying momentum conservation  $m_{1} u_{1}+m_{2} u_{2}=m_{1} v_{1}+m_{2} v_{2}$  $0.1 u+m(0)=0.1(0)+m(3)$  $0.1 u=3 m$  $\frac{1}{2} 0.1 u^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m(3)^{2}$  Solving we get, $u=3$  $\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}=\frac{1}{2} K\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(0.1) 3^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \quad \frac{3}{4} k x^{2}=0.9$  $\Rightarrow \quad \frac{3}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} k x^{2}=0.9$  $\therefore \quad \frac{1}{2} K x^{2}=0.6 \mathrm{~J}$ (total initial energy of the spring)  \begin{enumerate}

question: A bullet looses $\left(\frac{1}{n}\right)^{\text {th }}$ of its velocity passing through one plank. The number of such planks that are required to stop the bullet can be:
solution: Let $u$ be the initial velocity of the bullet of mass $m$. After passing through a plank of width x , its velocity decreases to v .  $\therefore \quad u-v=\frac{4}{n}$ or, $v=u-\frac{4}{n}=\frac{u(n-1)}{n}$  If F be the retarding force applied by each plank, then using work - energy theorem,  $\mathrm{Fx}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mu}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mu}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mu}^{2} \frac{(\mathrm{n}-1)^{2}}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}$  $=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mu}^{2}\left[\frac{1-(\mathrm{n}-1)^{2}}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}\right]$  $\mathrm{Fx}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mu}^{2}\left(\frac{2 \mathrm{n}-1}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}\right)$  Let P be the number of planks required to stop the bullet.  Total distance travelled by the bullet before coming to rest $=\mathrm{Px}$  Using work-energy theorem again,  $\mathrm{F}(\mathrm{Px})=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mu}^{2}-0$  or, $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{Fx})=\mathrm{P}\left[\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mu}^{2} \frac{(2 \mathrm{n}-1)}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}\right]=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mu}^{2}$  $\therefore \mathrm{P}=\frac{\mathrm{n}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{n}-1}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A spring of unstretched length 1 has a mass $m$ with one end fixed to a rigid support. Assuming spring to be made of a uniform wire, the kinetic energy possessed by it if its free end is pulled with uniform velocity v is:

Two springs of force constants $300 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$ (Spring A) and $400 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$ (Spring B) are joined together in series. The combination is compressed by 8.75 cm . The ratio of energy stored in A and B is $\frac{E_{A}}{E_{B}}$. Then $\frac{E_{A}}{E_{B}}$ is\\
equal

to :
solution: Given: $\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{A}}=300 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}, \mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{B}}=400 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$   Let when the combination of springs is compressed by force F. Spring A is compressed by x . Therefore compression in spring B $\mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{B}}=(8.75-\mathrm{x}) \mathrm{cm}$  $$ F=300 \times x=400(8.75-x) $$  Solving we get, $x=5 \mathrm{~cm}$  $\mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{B}}=8.75-5=3.75 \mathrm{~cm}$  $\frac{\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{A}}}{\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{B}}}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{A}}\left(\mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{A}}\right)^{2}}{\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{B}}\left(\mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{B}}\right)^{2}}=\frac{300 \times(5)^{2}}{400 \times(3.75)^{2}}=\frac{4}{3}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The force $\vec{F}=F \hat{i}$ on a particle of mass 2 kg , moving along the $x$-axis is given in the figure as a function of its position $x$. The particle is moving with a velocity of $5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ along the $x$-axis at $x=0$. What is the kinetic energy of the particle at $x=8 \mathrm{~m}$ ?
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-66}\\
A particle gets displaced by $\Delta \bar{r}=(2 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+4 \hat{k}) \mathrm{m}$ under the action of a force $\vec{F}=(7 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j}+3 \hat{k})$. The change in its kinetic energy is
solution: According to work-energy theorem, Change in kinetic energy $=$ work done   $=\vec{F} \cdot \Delta \vec{r}=(7 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j}+3 \hat{k}) \cdot(2 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+4 \hat{k})$  $=14+12+12=38 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: At time $t=0$ a particle starts moving along the $x$-axis. If its kinetic energy increases uniformly with time ' $t$ ', the net force acting on it must be proportional to [2011 RS]\\
solution: K.E. $\propto t$  K.E. $=c t \quad[$ Here, $c=$ constant $]$  $\Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=c t$  $\Rightarrow \frac{(m v)^{2}}{2 m}=c t$  $\Rightarrow \frac{p^{2}}{2 m}=c t(\because p=m v)$  $\Rightarrow \quad p=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{ctm}}$  $\Rightarrow \quad F=\frac{d p}{d t}=\frac{d(\sqrt{2 c t m})}{d t}$  $\Rightarrow F=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{~cm}} \times \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{t}}$  $\Rightarrow \quad F \propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{t}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The potential energy function for the force between two atoms in a diatomic molecule is approximately given by $U(x)=\frac{a}{x^{12}}-\frac{b}{x^{6}}$, where a and b are constants and x is the distance between the atoms. If the dissociation energy of the molecule is


$D=\left[U(x=\infty)-U_{\text {at equilibrium }}\right], D$ is

$[2010]$\\
solution: At equilibrium: $F=\frac{-d U(x)}{d x}$  $\Rightarrow \quad F=\frac{-d}{d x}\left[\frac{a}{x^{12}}-\frac{b}{x^{6}}\right]$  $\Rightarrow \quad F=-\left[\frac{12 a}{x^{13}}+\frac{6 b}{x^{7}}\right]$  $\Rightarrow \frac{12 a}{x^{13}}=\frac{6 b}{x^{7}} \Rightarrow x=\left(\frac{2 a}{b}\right)^{\frac{1}{6}}$  $\therefore U_{\text {at equilibrium }}=\frac{a}{\left(\frac{2 a}{b}\right)^{2}}-\frac{b}{\left(\frac{2 a}{b}\right)}=-\frac{b^{2}}{4 a}$ and $U_{(x=\infty)}=0$  $\therefore D=0-\left(-\frac{b^{2}}{4 a}\right)=\frac{b^{2}}{4 a}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: An athlete in the olympic games covers a distance of 100 m in 10 s . His kinetic energy can be estimated to be in the range
solution: The average speed of the athelete  $v=\frac{5}{t}=\frac{100}{10}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  $\therefore \quad$ K.E. $=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}$  Assuming the mass of athelet to 40 kg his average K.E would be  K.E $=\frac{1}{2} \times 40 \times(10)^{2}=2000 \mathrm{~J}$  Assuming mass to 100 kg average kinetic energy  K.E. $=\frac{1}{2} \times 100 \times(10)^{2}=5000 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A 2 kg block slides on a horizontal floor with a speed of $4 \mathrm{~m} /$ s. It strikes a uncompressed spring, and compresses it till the block is motionless. The kinetic friction force is 15 N and spring constant is $10,000 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$. The spring compresses by
solution: Suppose the spring gets compressed by $x$ before stopping.  kinetic energy of the block $=$ P.E. stored in the spring + work done against friction.  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times(4)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times 10,000 \times x^{2}+15 \times x$  $\Rightarrow 10,000 x^{2}+30 x-32=0$  $\Rightarrow 5000 x^{2}+15 x-16=0$  $\therefore x=\frac{-15 \pm \sqrt{(15)^{2}-4 \times(5000)(-16)}}{2 \times 5000}$  $$ =0.055 \mathrm{~m}=5.5 \mathrm{~cm} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle is projected at $60^{\circ}$ to the horizontal with a kinetic energy $K$. The kinetic energy at the highest point is\\
solution: Let $u$ be the velocity with which the particle is thrown and $m$ be the mass of the particle. Then  $K=\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}$.  At the highest point the velocity is $u \cos 60^{\circ}$ (only the horizontal component remains, the vertical component being zero at the top-most point). Therefore kinetic energy at the highest point.  $K^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} m\left(u \cos 60^{\circ}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m u^{2} \cos ^{2} 60^{\circ}=\frac{K}{4}$ [From 1]  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle of mass 100 g is thrown vertically upwards with a speed of $5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The work done by the force of gravity during the time the particle goes up is
solution: Given, Mass of the particle, $m=100 \mathrm{~g}$  Initial speed of the particle, $\mu=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Final speed of the particle, $v=0$  Work done by the force of gravity  $=$ Loss in kinetic energy of the body.  $=\frac{1}{2} m\left(v^{2}-u^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{100}{1000}\left(0^{2}-5^{2}\right)$  $=-1.25 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The potential energy of a 1 kg particle free to move along the x -axis is given by $V(x)=\left(\frac{x^{4}}{4}-\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right) J$.

The total mechanical energy of the particle is 2 J . Then, the maximum speed (in $\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$ ) is
solution: Potential energy  $V(x)=\frac{x^{4}}{4} \frac{-x^{2}}{2}$ joule  For maxima of minima  $\frac{d V}{d x}=0 \Rightarrow x^{3}-x=0 \Rightarrow x= \pm 1$  $\Rightarrow$ Min. P.E. $=\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{2}=-\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{~J}$  K.E. ${ }_{\text {(max.) }}+$ P.E. ${ }_{\text {(min.) }}=2$ (Given)  $\therefore$ K.E.(max.) $=2+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{9}{4}$  K.E.max.$=\frac{1}{2} m v_{\max }^{2}$.  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times v_{\max .}^{2}=\frac{9}{4} \Rightarrow v_{\max .}=\frac{3}{\sqrt{2}}$\\

question: A mass of $M \mathrm{~kg}$ is suspended by a weightless string. The horizontal force that is required to displace it until the string makes an angle of $45^{\circ}$ with the initial vertical direction is
solution: Work done by tension + Work done by force (applied) + Work done by gravitational force $=$ change in kinetic energy  Work done by tension is zero   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-76}   $\Rightarrow 0+F \times A B-M g \times A C=0$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{F}=\operatorname{Mg}\left(\frac{\mathrm{AC}}{\mathrm{AB}}\right)=\operatorname{Mg}\left[\frac{1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}\right]$  $\left[\because A B=\ell \sin 45^{\circ}=\frac{\ell}{\sqrt{2}}\right.$ and  $A C=O C-O A=\ell-\ell \cos 45^{\circ}=\ell\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)$  where $\ell=$ length of the string.]  $\Rightarrow F=M g(\sqrt{2}-1)$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A spherical ball of mass 20 kg is stationary at the top of a hill of height 100 m . It rolls down a smooth surface to the ground, then climbs up another hill of height 30 m and finally rolls down to a horizontal base at a height of 20 m above the ground. The velocity attained by the ball is
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-76(1)}   Using conservation of energy,  Total energy at 100 m height  $=$ Total energy at 20 m height  $\mathrm{m}(10 \times 100)=m\left(\frac{1}{2} v^{2}+10 \times 20\right)$  or $\frac{1}{2} v^{2}=800$ or $v=\sqrt{1600}=40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Note :  Loss in potential energy $=$ gain in kinetic energy  $m \times g \times 80=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}$  $10 \times 80=\frac{1}{2} v^{2}$  $v^{2}=1600$ or $v=40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle moves in a straight line with retardation proportional to its displacement. Its loss of kinetic energy for any displacement $x$ is proportional to
solution: Given : retardation $\propto$ displacement  i.e., $a=-k x$ [Here, $k=$ constant $]$  But $a=v \frac{d v}{d x}$  $\therefore \frac{v d v}{d x}=-k x \Rightarrow \int_{v_{1}}^{v_{2}} v d v=-\int_{0}^{x} k x d x$\\ $\Rightarrow\left[\frac{v^{2}}{2}\right]_{v_{1}}^{v_{2}}=-k\left[\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right]_{0}^{x}$  $\Rightarrow\left(v_{2}^{2}-v_{1}^{2}\right)=-\frac{k x^{2}}{2}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m\left(v_{2}^{2}-v_{1}^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\frac{-k x^{2}}{2}\right)$  $\therefore$ Loss in kinetic energy, $\therefore \Delta K \propto x^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle is acted upon by a force of constant magnitude which is always perpendicular to the velocity of the particle, the motion of the particles takes place in a plane. It follows that
options: a) its kinetic energy is constant
d) it moves in a straight line
solution: Work done by such force is always zero since force is acting in a direction perpendicular to velocity.  $\therefore$ From work-energy theorem $=\Delta \mathrm{K}=0$  K remains constant.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A wire suspended vertically from one of its ends is stretched by attaching a weight of 200 N to the lower end. The weight stretches the wire by 1 mm . Then the elastic energy stored in the wire is
solution: The elastic potential energy  $=\frac{1}{2} \times$ Force $\times$ extension  $=\frac{1}{2} \times F \times x$  $=\frac{1}{2} \times 200 \times 0.001=0.1 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A ball whose kinetic energy is $E$, is projected at an angle of $45^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. The kinetic energy of the ball at the highest point of its flight will be
solution: Let $u$ be the speed with which the ball of mass $m$ is projected. Then the kinetic energy (E) at the point of projection is   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-77}   $E=\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}$  When the ball is at the highest point of its flight, the speed of the ball is $\frac{u}{\sqrt{2}}$ (Remember that the horizontal component of velocity does not change during a projectile motion).  $\therefore$ The kinetic energy at the highest point  $=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\frac{u}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{m u^{2}}{2}=\frac{E}{2}$  [From (i)]  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A body of mass 2 kg is driven by an engine delivering a constant power of $1 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}$. The body starts from rest and moves in a straight line. After 9 seconds, the body has moved a distance (in m ) $\qquad$ 
  [5 Sep. 2020 (II)]
solution: Given, Mass of the body, $m=2 \mathrm{~kg}$  Power delivered by engine, $P=1 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}$  Time, $t=9$ seconds  Power, $P=F v$  $\Rightarrow P=$ mav  $[\because F=m a]$  $\Rightarrow m \frac{d v}{d t} v=P$  $\left(\because a=\frac{d v}{d t}\right)$  $\Rightarrow v d v=\frac{P}{m} d t$  Integrating both sides we get $\Rightarrow \int_{0}^{v} v d v=\frac{P}{m} \int_{0}^{t} d t$  $\Rightarrow \frac{v^{2}}{2}=\frac{P t}{m} \Rightarrow v=\left(\frac{2 P t}{m}\right)^{1 / 2}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{d x}{d t}=\sqrt{\frac{2 P}{m}} t^{1 / 2} \quad\left(\because v=\frac{d x}{d t}\right)$  $\Rightarrow \int_{0}^{x} d x=\sqrt{\frac{2 P}{m}} \int_{0}^{t} t^{1 / 2} d t$  $\therefore$ Distance, $x=\sqrt{\frac{2 P}{m}} \frac{t^{3 / 2}}{3 / 2}=\sqrt{\frac{2 P}{m}} \times \frac{2}{3} t^{3 / 2}$  $\Rightarrow x=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 1}{2}} \times \frac{2}{3} \times 9^{3 / 2}=\frac{2}{3} \times 27=18$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle is moving unidirectionally on a horizontal plane under the action of a constant power supplying energy source. The displacement $(s)$ - time $(t)$ graph that describes the motion of the particle is (graphs are drawn schematically and are not to scale) :
solution: We know that  Power, $P=F v$  But $F=m a v=m \frac{d v}{d t} v$  $\therefore P=m v \frac{d v}{d t} \Rightarrow P d t=m v d v$  Integrating both sides $\int_{0}^{t} P d t=m \int_{0}^{v} v d v$\\ P. $\mathrm{t}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} \Rightarrow v=\left(\sqrt{\frac{2 P}{m}}\right) t^{1 / 2}$  Distance, $s=\int_{0}^{t} v d t=\sqrt{\frac{2 P}{m}} \int_{0}^{t} t^{1 / 2} d t=\sqrt{\frac{2 P}{m}} \cdot \frac{t^{3 / 2}}{3 / 2}$  $\Rightarrow s=\sqrt{\frac{8 P}{9 m}} \cdot t^{3 / 2} \Rightarrow \mathrm{s} \propto \mathrm{t}^{3 / 2}$  So, graph (b) is correct.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A 60 HP electric motor lifts an elevator having a maximum total load capacity of 2000 kg . If the frictional force on the elevator is 4000 N , the speed of the elevator at full load is close to: $\left(1 \mathrm{HP}=746 \mathrm{~W}, \mathrm{~g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)$
solution: Total force required to lift maximum load capacity against frictional force $=400 \mathrm{~N}$  $F_{\text {total }}=M g+$ friction  $$ \begin{aligned} & =2000 \times 10+4000 \\ & =20,000+4000=24000 \mathrm{~N} \end{aligned} $$  Using power, $P=F \times v$  $60 \times 746=24000 \times v$  $\Rightarrow v=1.86 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \approx 1.9 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Hence speed of the elevator at full load is close to $1.9 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle of mass $M$ is moving in a circle of fixed radius $R$ in such a way that its centripetal acceleration at time $t$ is given by $\mathrm{n}^{2} R \mathrm{t}^{2}$ where n is a constant. The power delivered to the particle by the force acting on it, is :
solution: Centripetel acceleration $a_{c}=n^{2} R t^{2}$  $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{\mathrm{v}^{2}}{\mathrm{R}}=\mathrm{n}^{2} \mathrm{Rt}^{2}$  $v^{2}=n^{2} R^{2} t^{2}$  $\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{nRt}$  $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{\mathrm{dv}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\mathrm{nR}$  Power $=m a_{\mathrm{t}} \mathrm{v}=\mathrm{mnRnRt}=\mathrm{Mn}^{2} \mathrm{R}^{2} \mathrm{t}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A car of weight W is on an inclined road that rises by 100 m over a distance of 1 Km and applies a constant frictional force $\frac{\mathrm{W}}{20}$ on the car. While moving uphill on the road at a speed of $10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$, the car needs power P. If it needs power $\frac{\mathrm{P}}{2}$ while moving downhill at speed $v$ then value of $v$ is:
solution: While moving downhill power  $P=\left(w \sin \theta+\frac{w}{20}\right) 10$  $\mathrm{P}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{w}}{10}+\frac{\mathrm{w}}{20}\right) 10=\frac{3 \mathrm{w}}{2}$  $\frac{\mathrm{P}}{2}=\frac{3 \mathrm{w}}{4}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{w}}{10}-\frac{\mathrm{w}}{20}\right) \mathrm{V}$ $\tan \theta=\frac{1}{10}$  $\frac{3}{4}=\frac{v}{20} \Rightarrow v=15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  $\therefore$ Speed of car while moving downhill $\mathrm{v}=15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A wind-powered generator converts wind energy into electrical energy. Assume that the generator converts a fixed fraction of the wind energy intercepted by its blades into electrical energy. For wind speed $v$, the electrical power output will be most likely proportional to

A 70 kg man leaps vertically into the air from a crouching position. To take the leap the man pushes the ground with a constant force $F$ to raise himself. The center of gravity rises by 0.5 m before he leaps. After the leap the c.g. rises by another 1 m . The maximum power delivered by the muscles is : (Take $\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$ )
A body of mass ' $m$ ', accelerates uniformly from rest to ' $v$ ' in time ' $t_{1}$ '. The instantaneous power delivered to the body as a function of time ' $t$ ' is\\
solution: Let a be the acceleration of body   Using, $v=u+a t$  $v_{1}=0+a t_{1} \Rightarrow a=\frac{v_{1}}{t_{1}}$  Velocity of the body at instant $t$,  $v=a t$  $\Rightarrow v=\frac{v_{1} t}{t_{1}}$  Instantaneous powr, $\mathrm{P}=\vec{F} \cdot \vec{v}=(m \vec{a}) \cdot \vec{v}$  $=\left(\frac{m v_{1}}{t_{1}}\right)\left(\frac{v_{1} t}{t_{1}}\right)=m\left(\frac{v_{1}}{t_{1}}\right)^{2} t$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A body is moved along a straight line by a machine delivering a constant power. The distance moved by the body in time ' $t$ ' is proportional to
solution: Power, $P=F v=m a . v$  $\Rightarrow P=\frac{m d v}{d t} v=c=$ contant  $$ \left(\because F=m a=\frac{m d v}{d t}\right) $$  $m v_{0} v=c d t$  Integrating both sides, we get  $$ \begin{aligned} & m \int_{0}^{v} v d v=c \int_{0}^{t} d t \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=c t \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{v^{2}}{2}=\frac{c . t}{m} \\ & \Rightarrow v_{2}=\frac{2 c . t}{m} \\ & \Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{2 c}{m}} \times t^{1 / 2} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{d x}{d t}=\sqrt{\frac{2 c}{m}} \times t^{1 / 2} \quad \text { where } v=\frac{d x}{d t} \\ & \Rightarrow \int_{e}^{x} d x=\sqrt{\frac{2 c}{m}} \times \int_{0}^{t} t^{1 / 2} d t \\ & \Rightarrow x=\sqrt{\frac{2 c}{m}} \times \frac{2 t^{3 / 2}}{3} \\ & \Rightarrow x \propto t^{3 / 2} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two bodies of the same mass are moving with the same speed, but in different directions in a plane. They have a completely inelastic collision and move together thereafter with a final speed which is half of their initial speed. The angle between the initial velocities of the two bodies (in degree) is $\qquad$ 
  [NA 6 Sep. 2020 (I)]
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-78}   Momentum conservation along $x$ direction,  $2 m v_{0} \cos \theta=2 m \frac{v_{0}}{2} \Rightarrow \cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}$ or $\theta=60^{\circ}$  Hence angle between the initial velocities of the two bodies $=\theta+\theta=60^{\circ}+60^{\circ}=120^{\circ}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: Particle A of mass $\mathrm{m}_{1}$ moving with velocity $(\sqrt{3} \hat{i}+\hat{j}) \mathrm{ms}^{-1}$ collides with another particle $B$ of mass $\mathrm{m}_{2}$ which is at rest initially. Let $\vec{V}_{1}$ and $\vec{V}_{2}$ be the velocities of particles A and $B$ after collision respectively. If $\mathrm{m}_{1}=2 \mathrm{~m}_{2}$ and after collision $\vec{V}_{1}=(\hat{i}+\sqrt{3} \hat{j}) \mathrm{ms}^{-1}$, the angle between $\vec{V}_{1}$ and $\vec{V}_{2}$ is :
solution: Before collision,  Velocity of particle $A, u_{1}=(\sqrt{3} \hat{i}+\hat{j}) \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$  Velocity of particle $B, u_{2}=0$  After collision,  Velocity of particle $A, v_{1}=(\hat{i}+\sqrt{3} \hat{j})$  Velocity of particle $B, v_{2}=0$  Using principal of conservation of angular momentum  $m_{1} \vec{u}_{1}+m_{2} \vec{u}_{2}=m_{1} \vec{v}_{1}+m_{2} \vec{v}_{2}$  $\Rightarrow 2 m_{2}(\sqrt{3} \hat{i}+\hat{j})+m_{2} \times 0=2 m_{2}(\hat{i}+\sqrt{3} \hat{j})+m_{2} \times \vec{v}_{2}$  $\Rightarrow 2 \sqrt{3} \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}=2 \hat{i}+2 \sqrt{3} \hat{j}+\vec{v}_{2}$  $\Rightarrow \vec{v}_{2}=(\sqrt{3}-1) \hat{i}-(\sqrt{3}-1) \hat{j}$  $\Rightarrow \vec{v}_{1}=\hat{i}+\sqrt{3} \hat{j}$  For angle between $\vec{v}_{1}$ and $\vec{v}_{2}$,  $\cos \theta=\frac{\vec{v}_{1} \cdot \vec{v}_{2}}{\vec{v}_{1} \vec{v}_{2}}=\frac{2(\sqrt{3}-1)(1-\sqrt{3})}{2 \times 2 \sqrt{2}(\sqrt{3}-1)}=\frac{1-\sqrt{3}}{2 \sqrt{2}}$  $\Rightarrow \theta=105^{\circ}$  Angle between $\vec{v}_{1}$ and $\vec{v}_{2}$ is $105^{\circ}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-78(2)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
Blocks of masses $m, 2 m, 4 m$ and $8 m$ are arranged in a line on a frictionless floor. Another block of mass $m$, moving with speed $v$ along the same line (see figure) collides with mass $m$ in perfectly inelastic manner. All the subsequent collisions are also perfectly inelastic. By the time the last block of mass $8 m$ starts moving the total energy loss is $p \%$ of the original energy. Value of ' $p$ ' is close to :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-68(1)}\\
solution: According to the question, all collisions are perfectly inelastic, so after the final collision, all blocks are moving together.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-78(1)}   Let the final velocity be $v^{\prime}$, using momentum conservation  $$ m v=16 m v^{\prime} \Rightarrow v^{\prime}=\frac{v}{16} $$  Now initial energy $E_{i}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}$  Final energy: $E_{f}=\frac{1}{2} \times 16 m \times\left(\frac{v}{16}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{m v^{2}}{16}$  Energy loss : $E_{i}-E_{f}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m \frac{v^{2}}{16}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\left[1-\frac{1}{16}\right] \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\left[\frac{15}{16}\right]$  The total energy loss is $P \%$ of the original energy.  $\therefore \% P=\frac{\text { Energy loss }}{\text { Original energy }} \times 100$  $$ =\frac{\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\left[\frac{15}{16}\right]}{\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}} \times 100=93.75 \% $$  Hence, value of $P$ is close to 94 .  \begin{enumerate}

question: A block of mass 1.9 kg is at rest at the edge of a table, of height 1 m . A bullet of mass 0.1 kg collides with the block and sticks to it. If the velocity of the bullet is $20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ in the horizontal direction just before the collision then the kinetic energy just before the combined system strikes the floor, is [Take $g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$. Assume there is no rotational motion and losss of energy after the collision is negligiable.]
solution: Given,  Mass of block, $m_{1}=1.9 \mathrm{~kg}$  Mass of bullet, $m_{2}=0.1 \mathrm{~kg}$  Velocity of bullet, $v_{2}=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Let $v$ be the velocity of the combined system. It is an inelastic collision.  Using conservation of linear momentum  $$ \begin{aligned} & m_{1} \times 0+m_{2} \times v_{2}=\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) v \\ & \Rightarrow 0.1 \times 20=(0.1+1.9) \times v \\ & \Rightarrow v=1 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned} $$  Using work energy theorem  Work done $=$ Change in Kinetic energy  Let $K$ be the Kinetic energy of combined system.  $\left(\mathrm{m}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2}\right) g h$  $=\mathrm{K}-\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathrm{~m}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2}\right) \mathrm{V}^{2}$  $\Rightarrow 2 \times g \times 1=K-\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 1^{2} \Rightarrow K=21 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle of mass $m$ with an initial velocity $u \hat{i}$ collides perfectly elastically with a mass 3 m at rest. It moves with a velocity $v \hat{j}$ after collision, then, $v$ is given by :
solution: From conservation of linear momentum  $m u \hat{i}+0=m v \hat{j}+3 m \overrightarrow{v^{\prime}}$  $\overrightarrow{v^{\prime}}=\frac{u}{3} \hat{i}-\frac{v}{3} \hat{j}$\\ \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-79(1)}  From kinetic energy conservation,  $$ \frac{1}{2} m u^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(3 m)\left(\left(\frac{u}{3}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{v}{3}\right)^{2}\right) $$  or, $m u^{2}=m v^{2}+\frac{m u^{2}}{3}+\frac{m v^{2}}{3}$  $\therefore v=\frac{u}{\sqrt{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A particle of mass $m$ is moving along the $x$-axis with initial velocity $u \hat{i}$. It collides elastically with a particle of mass 10 m at rest and then moves with half its initial kinetic energy (see figure). If $\sin \theta_{1}=\sqrt{n} \sin \theta_{2}$, then value of $n$ is $\qquad$ .
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-68}]
solution: $$  From momentum conservation in perpendicular direction of initial motion.   \begin{equation*} m u_{1} \sin \theta_{1}=10 m v_{1} \sin \theta_{2} \tag{i} \end{equation*}   It is given that energy of $m$ reduced by half. If $u_{1}$ be velocity of $m$ after collision, then  $\left(\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}\right) \frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{2} m u_{1}^{2}$  $\Rightarrow u_{1}=\frac{u}{\sqrt{2}}$  If $v_{1}$ be the velocity of mass 10 m after collision, then $\frac{1}{2} \times 10 m \times v_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{2^{m}} \frac{u^{2}}{2} \Rightarrow v_{1}=\frac{u}{\sqrt{20}}$  From equation (i), we have  $\sin \theta_{1}=\sqrt{10} \sin \theta_{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Two particles of equal mass $m$ have respective initial velocities $u \hat{i}$ and $u\left(\frac{\hat{i}+\hat{j}}{2}\right)$. They collide completely inelastically. The energy lost in the process is: [9 Jan. 2020 I]\\
solution: \\ \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-79}  $x$-direction  $m u+\frac{m u}{2}=2 m v_{x}^{\prime} \Rightarrow V_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{3 u}{4}$  y-direction $0+\frac{m u}{2}=2 m v_{y}^{\prime} \Rightarrow v_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{u}{4}$  $K . E_{\cdot i}=\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left[\left(\frac{u}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{u}{2}\right)^{2}\right]$  $=\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}+\frac{m u^{2}}{4}=\frac{3 m u^{2}}{4}$  K.E. $f=\frac{1}{2}(2 m)\left(v_{x}^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(2 m)\left(v_{y}^{\prime}\right)^{2}$  $$ =\frac{1}{2} 2 m\left[\left(\frac{3 u}{4}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{u}{4}\right)^{2}\right]=\frac{5}{8} m u^{2} $$  $\therefore$ Loss in $K E=K E_{f}-K E$  $=m u^{2}\left(\frac{6}{8}-\frac{5}{8}\right)=\frac{m u^{2}}{8}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Abody $A$, of mass $m=0.1 \mathrm{~kg}$ has an initial velocity of $3 \hat{i} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$. It collides elastically with another body, $B$ of the same mass which has an initial velocity of $5 \hat{j} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$. After collision, $A$ moves with a velocity $\vec{v}=4(\hat{i}+\hat{j})$. The energy of $B$ after collision is written as $\frac{x}{10} J$. The value of $x$ is $\qquad$ .]
solution: For elastic collision $K E_{\mathrm{i}}=K E_{f}$  $\frac{1}{2} m \times 25+\frac{1}{2} \times m \times 9=\frac{1}{2} m \times 32+\frac{1}{2} m v_{B}^{2}$  $34=32+V_{B}^{2} \Rightarrow V_{B}=\sqrt{2}$  $K E_{B}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{B}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times 0.1 \times 2=0.1 \mathrm{~J}=\frac{1}{10} \mathrm{~J}$  $\therefore x=1$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle of mass $m$ is dropped from a height $h$ above the ground. At the same time another particle of the same mass is thrown vertically upwards from the ground with a speed of $\sqrt{2 g h}$. If they collide head-on completely inelastically, the time taken for the combined mass to reach the ground, in units of $\sqrt{\frac{h}{g}}$ is:
solution: Let t be the time taken by the particle dropped from height h to collide with particle thrown upward.  Using,   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-80}   $v^{2}-u^{2}=2 g h$  $\Rightarrow v^{2}-0^{2}=2 g h$  $\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{2 g h}$  Downward distance travelled  $S_{1}=\frac{1}{2} g t^{2}=\frac{1}{2} g \cdot \frac{h}{2 g}=\frac{h}{4}$  Distance of collision point from ground  $s_{2}=h-\frac{h}{4}=\frac{3 h}{4}$  Speed of (A) just before collision  $v_{1}=g t=\sqrt{\frac{g h}{2}}$  And speed of(B) just before collision  $v_{2}=\sqrt{2 g h}-\sqrt{\frac{g h}{2}}$  Using principle of conservation of linear momentum $m v_{1}+m v_{2}=2 m v_{f}$  $\frac{\Rightarrow v_{f}=m\left(\sqrt{2 g h}-\sqrt{\frac{g h}{2}}\right)-m \sqrt{\frac{g h}{2}}=0}{2 m}$  After collision, time taken $\left(t_{1}\right)$ for combined mass to reach the ground is  $\Rightarrow \frac{3 h}{4}=\frac{1}{2} g t_{1}^{2}$  $\Rightarrow t_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{3 h}{2 g}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A man (mass $=50 \mathrm{~kg}$ ) and his son (mass $=20 \mathrm{~kg}$ ) are standing on a frictionless surface facing each other. The man pushes his son so that he starts moving at a speed of $0.70 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$ with respect to the man. The speed of the man with respect to the surface is :
solution: $\mathrm{P}_{i}=\mathrm{P}_{f}$  or $0=20(0.7-v)=50 v$  or $\quad v=0.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two particles, of masses M and 2 M , moving, as shown, with speeds of $10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and $5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, collide elastically at the origin. After the collision, they move along the indicated directions with speeds $v_{1}$ and $v_{2}$, respectively. The values of $v_{1}$ and $v_{2}$ are nearly :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-69(2)}\\
solution: Apply concervation of linear momentum in X and Y direction for the system then  $\mathrm{M}\left(10 \cos 30^{\circ}\right)+2 \mathrm{M}\left(5 \cos 45^{\circ}\right)=2 \mathrm{M}\left(\mathrm{v}_{1} \cos 30^{\circ}\right)$  $+\mathrm{M}\left(\mathrm{v}_{2} \cos 45^{\circ}\right)$  $5 \sqrt{3}+5 \sqrt{2}=\sqrt{3} \mathrm{v}_{1}+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{2}}{\sqrt{2}}$\\ Also  $2 \mathrm{M}\left(5 \sin 45^{\circ}\right)-\mathrm{M}\left(10 \sin 30^{\circ}\right)=2 \mathrm{Mv}_{1} \sin 30^{\circ}-\mathrm{Mv}_{2} \sin 45^{\circ}$  $5 \sqrt{2}-5=\mathrm{v}_{1}-\frac{\mathrm{v}_{2}}{\sqrt{2}}$  Solving equation (1) and (2)  $(\sqrt{3}+1) v_{1}=5 \sqrt{3}+10 \sqrt{2}-5 \Rightarrow v_{1}=6.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  $\mathrm{v}_{2}=6.3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A body of mass 2 kg makes an elastic collision with a second body at rest and continues to move in the original direction but with one fourth of its original speed. What is the mass of the second body?
solution: $2 u+0=2\left(\frac{u}{4}\right)+m v_{2}$  and $\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times u^{2}+0=\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times\left(\frac{u}{4}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m v_{2}^{2}$  On solving, we get  $\mathrm{m}=1.5 \mathrm{~kg}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle of mass ' $m$ ' is moving with speed ' $2 v$ ' and collides with a mass ' $2 m$ ' moving with speed ' $v$ ' in the same direction. After collision, the first mass is stopped completely while the second one splits into two particles each of mass ' $m$ ', which move at angle $45^{\circ}$ with respect to the original direction.
solution: $m(2 v)+2 m v=0+2 m v^{\prime} \cos 45^{\circ}$  or $v^{\prime}=2 \sqrt{2} v$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A body of mass $m_{1}$ moving with an unknown velocity of $v_{1} \hat{i}$, undergoes a collinear collision with a body of mass $m_{2}$ moving with a velocity $v_{2} \hat{i}$. After collision, $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ move with velocities of $v_{3} \hat{i}$ and $v_{4} \hat{i}$, respectively. If $m_{2}=0.5 \mathrm{~m}_{1}$ and $v_{3}=0.5 v_{1}$, then $v_{1}$ is:

An alpha-particle of mass $m$ suffers 1-dimensional elastic collision with a nucleus at rest of unknown mass. It is scattered directly backwards losing, $64 \%$ of its initial kinetic energy. The mass of the nucleus is :
solution: Using conservation of momentum, $\mathrm{mv}_{0}=\mathrm{mv}_{2}-\mathrm{mv}_{1}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-80(1)}   After collision   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-80(3)}   $\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{1}^{2}=0.36 \times \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{0}^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{v}_{1}=0.6 \mathrm{v}_{0}$  The collision is elastic. So,  $\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{MV}_{2}^{2}=0.64 \times \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{0}^{2}[\therefore \mathrm{M}=$ mass of nucleus $]$  $\Rightarrow V_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{M}}} \times 0.8 \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  $\mathrm{mV}_{0}=\sqrt{\mathrm{mM}} \times 0.8 \mathrm{~V}_{0}-\mathrm{m} \times 0.6 \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  $\Rightarrow 1.6 \mathrm{~m}=0.8 \sqrt{\mathrm{mM}}$  $\Rightarrow 4 \mathrm{~m}^{2}=\mathrm{mM}$  $\therefore \mathrm{M}=4 \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A piece of wood of mass 0.03 kg is dropped from the top of a 100 m height building. At the same time, a bullet of mass 0.02 kg is fired vertically upward, with a velocity $100 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$, from the ground. The bullet gets embedded in the wood. Then the maximum height to which the combined system reaches above the top of the building before falling below is: $\left(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)$ [10 Jan. 2019 I]\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-80(2)}   Time taken for the particles to collide,  $\mathrm{t}=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{V}_{\text {rel }}}=\frac{100}{100}=1 \mathrm{sec}$  Speed of wood just before collision $=\mathrm{gt}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and speed of bullet just before collision $=\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{gt}$\\ $=100-10=90 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  $\mathrm{S}=100 \times 1-\frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times 1=95 \mathrm{~m}$  Now, using conservation of linear momentum just before and after the collision  $-(0.03)(10)+(0.02)(90)=(0.05) v$  $$ \Rightarrow 150=5 v $$  $$ \therefore v=30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} $$  Max. height reached by body  $\mathrm{h}==\frac{30 \times 30}{2 \times 10}=45 \mathrm{~m}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-81(2)}   $\therefore$ Height above tower $=40 \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
There block A, B and C are lying on a smooth horizontal surface, as shown in the figure. A and B have equal masses, m while C has mass M . Block A is given an inital speed $v$ towards B due to which it collides with B perfectly inelastically. The combined mass collides with C, also perfectly inelastically $\frac{5}{6}$ th of the initial kinetic energy is lost in whole process. What is value of $\mathrm{M} / \mathrm{m}$ ?
  \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_f66cf5f3913ae04ecd5dg-69}\\
solution: Kinetic energy of block A  $\mathrm{k}_{1}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{0}^{2}$  $\therefore$ From principle of linear momentum conservation  $\mathrm{mv}_{0}=(2 \mathrm{~m}+\mathrm{M}) \mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{f}} \Rightarrow \mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{f}}=\frac{\mathrm{mv}_{0}}{2 \mathrm{~m}+\mathrm{M}}$  According to question, of $\frac{5}{6}$ th the initial kinetic energy is lost in whole process.  $\therefore \frac{\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{i}}}{\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{f}}}=6 \Rightarrow \frac{\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{0}^{2}}{\frac{1}{2}(2 \mathrm{~m}+\mathrm{M})\left(\frac{\mathrm{mv}}{2 \mathrm{~m}+\mathrm{M}}\right)^{2}}=6$  $\Rightarrow \frac{2 \mathrm{~m}+\mathrm{M}}{\mathrm{m}}=6 \therefore \frac{\mathrm{M}}{\mathrm{m}}=4$  \begin{enumerate}

question: In a collinear collision, a particle with an initial speed $v_{0}$ strikes a stationary particle of the same mass. If the final total kinetic energy is $50 \%$ greater than the original kinetic energy, the magnitude of the relative velocity between the two particles, after collision, is: [2018]\\
solution: Before Collision  After Collision   \begin{gather*} \mathrm{m}) \underset{\text { Stationary }}{\mathrm{v}_{0}} \Rightarrow(\mathrm{m}) \\ \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{2}^{2}=\frac{3}{2}\left(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{0}^{2}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{v}_{2}^{2}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{v}_{0}^{2} \end{gather*}   From momentum conservation  $\mathrm{mv}_{0}=\mathrm{m}\left(\mathrm{v}_{1}+\mathrm{v}_{2}\right)$  Squarring both sides,  $\left(v_{1}+v_{2}\right)^{2}=v_{0}^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{v}_{2}^{2}+2 \mathrm{v}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{2}=\mathrm{v}_{0}^{2}$  $2 \mathrm{v}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{2}=-\frac{\mathrm{v}_{0}^{2}}{2}$  $\left(v_{1}-v_{2}\right)^{2}=v_{1}^{2}+v_{2}^{2}-2 v_{1} v_{2}=\frac{3}{2} v_{0}^{2}+\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{2}$  Solving we get relative velocity between the two particles $\mathrm{v}_{1}-\mathrm{v}_{2}=\sqrt{2} \mathrm{v}_{0}$\\

question: The mass of a hydrogen molecule is $3.32 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}$.
