A particle of mass $m$ moves along line $P C$ with velocity $v$ as shown. What is the angular momentum of the particle about $P$ ?
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-088}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Angular momentum $(L)$  $=($ linear momentum $) \times($ perpendicular distance of the line of action of momentum from the axis of rotation)  As the particle moves with velocity V along line PC , the line of motion passes through P .  $\therefore \mathrm{L}=m v \times r$  $=m v \times 0$  $=0$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
Shown in the figure is a hollow icecream cone (it is open at the top). If its mass is $M$, radius of its top, $R$ and height, $H$, then its moment of inertia about its axis is :

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-088(1)}
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Hollow ice-cream cone can be assume as several parts of discs having different radius, so  $I=\int d I=\int d m\left(r^{2}\right)$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-105}   From diagram,  $\frac{r}{h}=\tan \theta=\frac{R}{H}$ or $r=\frac{R}{H} h$  Mass of element, $d m=\rho\left(\pi r^{2}\right) d h$  From eq. (i), (ii) and (iii),  Area of element, $d A=2 \pi r d l=2 \pi r \frac{d h}{\cos \theta}$  Mass of element, $d m=\frac{2 M h \tan d h}{R \sqrt{R^{2}+H^{2}} \cos \theta}$  (here, $r=h \tan \theta$ )  $$ \begin{aligned} I & =\int d I=\int_{0}^{H} d m\left(r^{2}\right)=\int_{0}^{H} \rho\left(\pi r^{2}\right) d h\left(\frac{R}{H} \cdot h\right)^{2} \\ & =\int_{0}^{H} \rho\left(\pi\left(\frac{R}{H} \cdot h\right)^{4}\right) d h \end{aligned} $$  Solving we get, $I=\frac{M R^{2}}{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: The linear mass density of a thin rod AB of length L varies from A to B as $\lambda(x)=\lambda_{0}\left(1+\frac{x}{\mathrm{~L}}\right)$, where $x$ is the distance from $A$. If $M$ is the mass of the rod then its moment of inertia about an axis passing through A and perpendicular to the rod is :
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-105(2)}   Mass of the small element of the rod  $d m=\lambda \cdot d x$  Moment of inertia of small element,  $d I=d m \cdot x^{2}=\lambda_{0}\left(1+\frac{x}{L}\right) \cdot x^{2} d x$  Moment of inertia of the complete rod can be obtained by integration   \begin{align*} & I=\lambda_{0} \int_{0}^{L}\left(x^{2}+\frac{x^{3}}{L}\right) d x \\ &=\lambda_{0}\left|\frac{x^{3}}{3}+\frac{x^{4}}{4 L}\right|_{0}^{L}=\lambda_{0}\left[\frac{L^{3}}{3}+\frac{L^{3}}{4}\right] \\ & \Rightarrow I=\frac{7 \lambda_{0} L^{3}}{12} \tag{i} \end{align*}   Mass of the thin rod,\\ $M=\int_{0}^{L} \lambda d x=\int_{0}^{L} \lambda_{0}\left(1+\frac{x}{L}\right) d x=\frac{3 \lambda_{0} L}{2}$  $\therefore \lambda_{0}=\frac{2 M}{3 L}$  $\therefore I=\frac{7}{12}\left(\frac{2 M}{3 L}\right) L^{3} \Rightarrow I=\frac{7}{18} M L^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A wheel is rotating freely with an angular speed $\omega$ on a shaft. The moment of inertia of the wheel is I and the moment of inertia of the shaft is negligible. Another wheel\\
of moment of inertia 3I initially at rest is suddenly coupled to the same shaft. The resultant fractional loss in the kinetic energy of the system is :
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: By angular momentum conservation, $L_{c}=L_{f}$  $\omega I+3 I \times 0=4 I \omega^{\prime} \Rightarrow \omega^{\prime}=\frac{\omega}{4}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-106(2)}   $(K E)_{i}=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$  $(K E)_{f}=\frac{1}{2}(3 I+I) \omega^{\prime 2}$  $$ =\frac{1}{2} \times(4 I) \times\left(\frac{\omega}{4}\right)^{2}=\frac{I \omega^{2}}{8} $$  $\Delta K E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}-\frac{1}{8} I \omega^{2}=\frac{3}{8} I \omega^{2}$  $\therefore$ Fractional loss in K.E. $=\frac{\Delta K E}{K E_{l_{i}}}=\frac{\frac{3}{8} I \omega^{2}}{\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}}=\frac{3}{4}$.  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
$A B C$ is a plane lamina of the shape of an equilateral triangle. $D, E$ are mid points of $A B, A C$ and $G$ is the centroid of the lamina. Moment of inertia of the lamina about an axis passing through $G$ and perpendicular to the plane $A B C$ is $I_{0}$. If part $A D E$ is removed, the moment of inertia of the remaining part about the same axis is $\frac{N I_{0}}{16}$ where $N$ is an integer. Value of $N$ is $\qquad$ .

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-089(3)}]
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Let mass of triangular lamina $=m$, and length of side $=l$, then moment of inertia of lamina about an axis passing through centroid $G$ perpendicular to the plane.  $I_{0} \propto m l^{2}$  $I_{0}=k m l^{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-106(4)}   Let moment of inertia of $D E F=I_{1}$ about $G$  So, $I_{1} \propto\left(\frac{m}{4}\right)\left(\frac{l}{2}\right)^{2} \propto \frac{m l^{2}}{16}$ or $I_{1}=\frac{I_{0}}{16}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-106(3)}   Let $I_{A D E}=I_{B D F}=I_{E F C}=I_{2}$  $\therefore 3 I_{2}+I_{1}=I_{0} \Rightarrow 3 I_{2}+\frac{I_{0}}{16}=I_{0} \Rightarrow I_{2}=\frac{5 I_{0}}{16}$  Hence, moment of inertia of $D E C B$ i.e., after removal part $A D E$  $=2 I_{2}+I_{1}=2\left(\frac{5 I_{0}}{16}\right)+\left(\frac{I_{0}}{16}\right)=\frac{11 I_{0}}{16}=\frac{N I_{0}}{16}$  Therefore value of $N=11$.  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A circular disc of mass $M$ and radius $R$ is rotating about its axis with angular speed $\omega_{1}$. If another stationary disc having radius $\frac{R}{2}$ and same mass $M$ is dropped co-axially on to the rotating disc. Gradually both discs attain constant angular speed $\omega_{2}$. The energy lost in the process is $p \%$ of the initial energy. Value of $p$ is $\qquad$ .]
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: As we know moment of inertia disc, $I_{\text {disc }}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-106(1)}   Using angular momentum conservation  $I_{1} \omega_{1}+I_{2} \omega_{2}=\left(I_{1}+I_{2}\right) \times \omega_{f}$  $\frac{M R^{2}}{2} \times \omega+0=\left(\frac{M R^{2}}{2}+\frac{M R^{2}}{8}\right) \omega_{f} \Rightarrow \omega_{f}=\frac{4}{5} \omega$  Initial K.E., $K_{i}=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{M R^{2}}{2}\right) \omega^{2}=\frac{M R^{2} \omega^{2}}{4}$  Final K.E., $K_{f}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{M R^{2}}{2}+\frac{M R^{2}}{8}\right) \frac{16}{25} \omega^{2}=\frac{M R^{2} \omega^{2}}{5}$  Percentage loss in kinetic energy $\%$ loss  $=\frac{\frac{M R^{2} \omega^{2}}{4}-\frac{M R^{2} \omega^{2}}{5}}{\frac{M R^{2} \omega^{2}}{4}} \times 100=20 \%=P \%$  Hence, value of $P=20$.  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Consider two uniform discs of the same thickness and different radii $R_{1}=R$ and $R_{2}=\alpha R$ made of the same material. If the ratio of their moments of inertia $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$, respectively, about their axes is $I_{1}: I_{2}=1: 16$ then the value of $\alpha$ is :
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Let $p$ be the density of the discs and $t$ is the thickness of discs.  Moment of inertia of disc is given by  $I=\frac{M R^{2}}{2}=\frac{\left[\rho\left(\pi R^{2}\right) t\right] R^{2}}{2}$  $I \propto R^{4} \quad$ (As $\rho$ and $t$ are same)  $\frac{I_{2}}{I_{1}}=\left(\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}\right)^{4} \Rightarrow \frac{16}{1}=\alpha^{4} \Rightarrow \alpha=2$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-089}
 

For a uniform rectangular sheet shown in the figure, the ratio of moments of inertia about the axes perpendicular to the sheet and passing through $O$ (the centre of mass) and $O^{\prime}$ (corner point) is :
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Moment of inertia of rectangular sheet about an axis passing through $O$,  $$ I_{O}=\frac{M}{12}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)=\frac{M}{12}\left[(80)^{2}+(60)^{2}\right] $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-106}   From the parallel axis theorem, moment of inertia about $O^{\prime}$,  $$ \begin{aligned} & I_{O^{\prime}}=I_{O}+M(50)^{2} \\ & \frac{I_{O}}{I_{O^{\prime}}}=\frac{\frac{M}{12}\left(80^{2}+60^{2}\right)}{\frac{M}{12}\left(80^{2}+60^{2}\right)+M(50)^{2}}=\frac{1}{4} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Moment of inertia of a cylinder of mass $M$, length $L$ and radius $R$ about an axis passing through its centre and perpendicular to the axis of the cylinder is $I=M\left(\frac{R^{2}}{4}+\frac{L^{2}}{12}\right)$. If such a cylinder is to be made for a given mass of a material, the ratio $L / R$ for it to have minimum possible $I$ is :
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Let there be a cylinder of mass $m$ length $L$ and radius $R$. Now, take elementary disc of radius $R$ and thickness $d x$ at a distance of $x$ from axis $O O^{\prime}$ then moment of inertia about $O O^{\prime}$ of this element.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-107}   $d I=\frac{d m R^{2}}{4}+d m x^{2}$  $\Rightarrow I=\int d I=\int \frac{d m R^{2}}{4}+\int_{n=L / 2}^{n=-L / 2} \frac{M}{L} d x \times x^{2}$  Given : $I=\frac{M R^{2}}{4}+\frac{M L^{2}}{12}$  $\Rightarrow I=\frac{M}{4} \times \frac{V}{\pi L}+\frac{M L^{2}}{12} \Rightarrow I=\frac{M V}{4 \pi L}+\frac{M L^{2}}{12}$  $\frac{d I}{d L}=-\frac{m V}{4 \pi L^{2}}+\frac{M \times 2 L}{12}=0$  $\Rightarrow V=\frac{2}{3} \pi L^{3} \Rightarrow \pi R^{2} L=\frac{2}{3} \pi L^{3}$  $\therefore \frac{L}{R}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
An massless equilateral triangle $E F G$ of side ' $a$ ' (As shown in figure) has three particles of mass $m$ situated at its vertices. The moment of inertia of the system about the line $E X$ perpendicular to $E G$ in the plane of $E F G$ is $\frac{N}{20} m a^{2}$ where $N$ is an integer. The value of $N$ is $\qquad$\\


 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-089(2)}]
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Moment of inertia of the system about axis $X E$.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-107(1)}   $I=I_{E}+I_{F}+I_{G}$  $\Rightarrow I=m\left(r_{E}\right)^{2}+m\left(r_{F}\right)^{2}+m\left(r_{G}\right)^{2}$  $\Rightarrow I=m \times 0^{2}+m\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2}+m a^{2}=\frac{5}{4} m a^{2}=\frac{25}{20} m a^{2}$  $\therefore N=25$.\\
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Two uniform circular discs are rotating independently in the same direction around their common axis passing through their centres. The moment of inertia and angular velocity of the first disc are $0.1 \mathrm{~kg}-\mathrm{m}^{2}$ and $10 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1}$ respectively while those for the second one are $0.2 \mathrm{~kg}-\mathrm{m}^{2}$ and $5 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1}$ respectively. At some instant they get stuck together and start rotating as a single system about their common axis with some angular speed. The kinetic energy of the combined system is :
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Initial angular momentum $=I_{1} \omega_{1}+I_{2} \omega_{2}$  Let $\omega$ be angular speed of the combined system.  Final angular momentum $=I_{1} \omega+I_{2} \omega$  According to conservation of angular momentum  $\left(I_{1}+I_{2}\right) \omega=I_{1} \omega_{1}+I_{2} \omega_{2}$  $\Rightarrow \omega=\frac{I_{1} \omega_{1}+I_{2} \omega_{2}}{I_{1}+I_{2}}=\frac{0.1 \times 10+0.2 \times 5}{0.1+0.2}=\frac{20}{3}$  Final rotational kinetic energy  $K_{f}=\frac{1}{2} I_{1} \omega^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I_{2} \omega^{2}=\frac{1}{2}(0.1+0.2) \times\left(\frac{20}{3}\right)^{2}$  $\Rightarrow K_{f}=\frac{20}{3} \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
Three solid spheres each of mass $m$ and diameter $d$ are stuck together such that the lines connecting the centres form an equilateral triangle of side of length $d$. The ratio $\frac{\mathrm{I}_{0}}{\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{A}}}$ of moment of inertia $\mathrm{I}_{0}$ of the system about an axis passing the centroid and about center of any of the spheres $\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{A}}$ and perpendicular to the plane of the triangle is:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-089(1)}
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Moment of inertia,   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-107(2)}   $I_{1}=\frac{2}{5} m\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^{2}+m(A O)^{2}$  and $A O=\frac{d}{\sqrt{3}}$  Moment of inertia about ' O '  $I_{0}=3 I_{1}=3\left[\frac{2}{5} m\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^{2}+m\left(\frac{d}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}\right]$  $\Rightarrow I_{0}=\frac{13}{10} M d^{2}$  And $I_{A}=2\left[\frac{2}{5} M\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^{2}+M d^{2}\right]+\frac{2}{5} M\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^{2}$  $\Rightarrow I_{A}=\frac{23}{10} M d^{2}$  $\therefore \frac{I_{O}}{I_{A}}=\frac{\frac{13}{10} M d^{2}}{\frac{23}{10} M d^{2}}=\frac{13}{23}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
One end of a straight uniform 1 m long bar is pivoted on horizontal table. It is released from rest when it makes an angle $30^{\circ}$ from the horizontal (see figure). Its angular speed when it hits the table is given as $\sqrt{n} s^{-1}$, where $n$ is an integer. The value of $n$ is $\qquad$ .

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-090(1)}]
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Here, length of bar, $1=1 \mathrm{~m}$ angle, $\theta=30^{\circ}$  $$ \Delta P E=\Delta K E \text { or } m g h=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2} $$  $\Rightarrow(\mathrm{mg}) \frac{l}{2} \sin 30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m l^{2}}{3}\right) \omega^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{mg} \frac{l}{2} \times \frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m l^{2}}{3}\right) \omega^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{15} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A uniformly thick wheel with moment of inertia I and radius R is free to rotate about its centre of mass (see fig). A massless string is wrapped over its rim and two blocks of masses $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}\left(m_{1}>m_{2}\right)$ are attached to the ends of the string. The system is released from rest. The angular speed of the wheel when $m_{1}$ descents by a distance $h$ is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Using principal of conservation of energy  $\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right) g h=\frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \quad\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right) g h=\frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)(\omega R)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$  $(\because v=\omega R)$  $\Rightarrow \quad\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right) g h=\frac{\omega^{2}}{2}\left[\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) R^{2}+I\right]$  $\Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\frac{2\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right) g h}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) R^{2}+I}}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
As shown in the figure, a bob of mass $m$ is tied by a massless string whose other end portion is wound on a fly wheel (disc) of radius $r$ and mass $m$. When released from rest the bob starts falling vertically. When it has covered a distance of h , the angular speed of the wheel will be:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-090(2)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: When the bob covered a distance ' $h$ '  Using $m g h=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$  $=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}(\omega \mathrm{r})^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{m r^{2}}{2} \times \omega^{2}(\because v=\omega r$ no slipping $)$  $\Rightarrow m g h=\frac{3}{4} m \omega^{2} r^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\frac{4 g h}{3 r^{2}}}=\frac{1}{r} \sqrt{\frac{4 g h}{3}}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: The radius of gyration of a uniform rod of length $l$, about an axis passing through a point $\frac{l}{4}$ away from the centre of the rod, and perpendicular to it, is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Moment inertia of the rod passing through a point $\frac{\ell}{4}$ away from the centre of the rod  $I=I g+\mathrm{m} \ell^{2}$  $\Rightarrow I=\frac{M I^{2}}{12}+M \times\left(\frac{I^{2}}{16}\right)=\frac{7 M I^{2}}{48}$  Using $I=M K^{2}=\frac{7 M I^{2}}{48}(K=$ radius of gyration $)$  $\Rightarrow K=\sqrt{\frac{7}{48}} I$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Mass per unit area of a circular disc of radius a depends on the distance $r$ from its centre as $\sigma(r)=A+B r$. The moment of inertia of the disc about the axis, perpendicular to the plane and passing through its centre is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Given,  mass per unit area of circular disc, $\sigma=A+B r$  Area of the ring $=2 \pi \mathrm{r} d r$  Mass of the ring, $d m=\sigma 2 \pi r d r$  Moment of inertia,  $I=\int d m r^{2}=\int \sigma 2 \pi r d r . r^{2}$  $\Rightarrow I=2 \pi \int_{0}^{a}(A+B r) r^{3} d r=2 \pi\left[\frac{A a^{4}}{4}+\frac{B a^{5}}{5}\right]$  $\Rightarrow \quad I=2 \pi a^{4}\left[\frac{A}{4}+\frac{B a}{5}\right]$\\
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A circular disc of radius $b$ has a hole of radius $a$ at its centre (see figure). If the mass per unit area of the disc varies as $\left(\frac{\sigma_{0}}{r}\right)$, then the radius of gyration of the disc about its axis passing through the centre is :
 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-090}
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: $I=\int_{a}^{b}(d m) r^{2}$  $=\int_{a}^{b}\left(\frac{\sigma_{0}}{r} \times 2 \pi r d r\right) r^{2}=\frac{2 \pi \sigma_{0}}{3}\left|r^{3}\right|_{a}^{b}$  $=\frac{2 \pi \sigma_{0}}{3}\left(b^{3}-a^{3}\right)$  Mass of the disc,  $m=\int_{a}^{b} \frac{\sigma_{0}}{r} \times 2 \pi r d r=2 \pi \sigma_{0}(b-a)$  Radius of gyration,  $k=\sqrt{\frac{I}{m}}$  $=\sqrt{\frac{\left(2 \pi \sigma_{0} / 3\right)\left(b^{3}-a^{3}\right)}{2 \pi \sigma_{0}(b-a)}}=\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+a b}{3}}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Two coaxial discs, having moments of inertia $\mathrm{I}_{1}$ and $\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{2}$, are rotating with respective angular velocities $\omega_{1}$ and $\frac{\omega_{1}}{2}$, about their common axis. They are brought in contact with each other and thereafter they rotate with a common angular velocity. If $\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{f}}$ and $\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{i}}$ are the final and initial total energies, then $\left(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{f}}-\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{i}}\right)$ is :
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: As no external torque is acting so angular momentum should be conserved  $\left(\mathrm{I}_{1}+\mathrm{I}_{2}\right) \omega=\mathrm{I}_{1} \omega_{1}+\mathrm{I}_{2} \omega_{2}\left[\omega_{\mathrm{c}}=\right.$ common angular velocity of the system, when discs are in contact]  $\omega_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1} \omega_{1}+\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1} \omega_{1}}{4}}{\mathrm{I}_{1}+\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{2}}\left(\frac{5}{4} \times \frac{2}{3}\right) \omega_{1}$  $\omega_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{5 \omega_{1}}{6}$  $\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{f}}-\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{i}}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathrm{I}_{1}+\mathrm{I}_{2}\right) \omega_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{I}_{1} \omega_{1}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{I}_{2} \omega_{2}^{2}$  Put $\mathrm{I}_{2}=\mathrm{I}_{1} / 2$ and $\omega_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{5 \omega_{1}}{6} 5 \omega_{1} / 6$  We get :  $E_{\mathrm{f}}-E_{\mathrm{i}}=-\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1} \omega_{1}^{2}}{24}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A thin disc of mass M and radius R has mass per unit area $\sigma(r)=k r^{2}$ where $r$ is the distance from its centre. Its moment of inertia about an axis going through its centre of mass and perpendicular to its plane is :

$[10$ Apr. 2019 I]\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: As from the question density $(\sigma)=\mathrm{kr}^{2}$  Mass of disc $\mathrm{M}=\int_{0}^{\mathrm{R}}\left(\mathrm{kr}^{2}\right) 2 \pi \mathrm{rdr}=2 \pi \mathrm{k} \frac{\mathrm{R}^{4}}{4}=\frac{\pi \mathrm{kR}^{4}}{2}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{k}=\frac{2 \mathrm{M}}{\pi \mathrm{R}^{4}}$  $\therefore$ Moment of inertia about the axis of the disc.  $\mathrm{l}=\int \mathrm{dl}=\int(\mathrm{dm}) \mathrm{r}^{2}=\int \sigma \mathrm{dAr}{ }^{2}$  $=\int\left(\mathrm{kr}^{2}\right)(2 \pi \mathrm{rdr}) \mathrm{r}^{2}$  $\int_{0}^{\mathrm{R}} 2 \pi \mathrm{k} \mathrm{r}^{5} \mathrm{dr}=\frac{\pi \mathrm{kR}^{6}}{3}=\frac{\pi \times\left(\frac{2 \mathrm{M}}{\pi \mathrm{R}^{4}}\right) \times \mathrm{R}^{6}}{3}=\frac{2}{3} \mathrm{MR}^{2}$\\ $\quad[$ putting value of k from eqn ...  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A solid sphere of mass M and radius R is divided into two unequal parts. The first part has a mass of $\frac{7 M}{8}$ and is converted into a uniform disc of radius 2 R . The second part is converted into a uniform solid sphere. Let $I_{1}$ be the moment of inertia of the new sphere about its axis. The ratio $I_{1} / I_{2}$ is given by :
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-109(2)}   $$ I_{1}=\left(\frac{7 M}{8}\right)(2 R)^{2} \frac{1}{2}=\left(\frac{7}{16} \times 4\right) M R^{2}=\frac{14}{8} \mathrm{mR}^{2} $$  $I_{2}=\frac{2}{5}\left(\frac{M}{8}\right) r^{2}$  $\Rightarrow I_{2}=\frac{2}{5}\left(\frac{M}{8}\right)\left(\frac{R^{2}}{4}\right)=\frac{M R^{2}}{80}$  $\left[\begin{array}{l}\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3} \rho=\frac{1}{8} \frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \times \rho \\ \Rightarrow r=R / 2\end{array}\right]$  $\frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}=\frac{14 \times 80}{8}=140$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A stationary horizontal disc is free to rotate about its axis. When a torque is applied on it, its kinetic energy as a function of $\theta$, where $\theta$ is the angle by which it has rotated, is given as $\mathrm{k} \theta^{2}$. If its moment of inertia is I then the angular acceleration of the disc is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: $\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}=k Q^{2}$  or $\omega=\left(\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{I}}\right) Q$  or $\alpha=\frac{d \omega}{\pi}=\sqrt{\frac{2 K}{I}}\left(\frac{d Q}{d t}\right)=\left(\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{I}}\right) \omega$  $=\left(\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{I}}\right)\left(\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{I}}\right) \theta=\frac{2 k \theta}{I}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Moment of inertia of a body about a given axis is 1.5 kg $\mathrm{m}^{2}$. Initially the body is at rest. In order to produce a rotational kinetic energy of 1200 J , the angular acceleration of $20 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ must be applied about the axis for a duration of:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: $\omega=\alpha t=20 t$  Given, $\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}=1200$  or $\frac{1}{2} \times 1.5 \times(20 t)^{2}=1200$  or $t=2 \mathrm{~s}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A thin smooth rod of length L and mass M is rotating freely with angular speed $\omega_{0}$ about an axis perpendicular to the rod and passing through its center. Two beads of mass m and negligible size are at the center of the rod initially. The beads are free to slide along the rod. The angular speed of the system, when the beads reach the opposite ends of the rod, will be:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: $I_{i} \omega_{i}=I_{f} \omega_{f}$  $$ \begin{aligned} & \text { or }\left(\frac{M L^{2}}{12}\right) \omega_{0}=\left(\frac{M L^{2}}{12}+2 m\left(\frac{L}{2}\right)^{2}\right) \omega_{f} \\ & \therefore \omega_{f}=\left(\frac{M \omega_{0}}{M+6 m}\right) \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A thin circular plate of mass M and radius R has its density varying as $\rho(r)=\rho_{0} r$ with $\rho_{0}$ as constant and $r$ is the distance from its center. The moment of Inertia of the circular plate about an axis perpendicular to the plate and passing through its edge is $I=a \mathrm{MR}^{2}$. The value of the coefficient $a$ is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Taking a circular ring of radius $r$ and thickness $d r$ as a mass element, so total mass,  $$ \begin{aligned} M & =\int_{0}^{R} \rho_{0} r \times 2 \pi r d r=\frac{2 \pi \rho_{0} R^{3}}{3} \\ I_{C} & =\int_{0}^{R} \rho_{0} r \times 2 \pi r d r \times r^{2}=\frac{2 \pi \rho_{0} R^{5}}{5} \end{aligned} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-109}   Using parallel axis theorem  $$ \begin{aligned} & \therefore I=I_{C}+M R^{2}=2 \pi \rho_{0} R^{5}\left(\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{5}\right)=\frac{16 \pi \rho_{0} R^{5}}{15} \\ & =\frac{8}{5}\left[\frac{2}{3} \pi \rho_{0} R^{3}\right] R^{2}=\frac{8}{5} M R^{2} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Let the moment of inertia of a hollow cylinder of length 30 cm (inner radius 10 cm and outer radius 20 cm ), about its axis be 1 . The radius of a thin cylinder of the same mass such that its moment of inertia about its axis is also I, is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
An equilateral triangle ABC is cut from a thin solid sheet of wood. (See figure) D, E and F are the mid-points of its sides as shown and G is the centre of the triangle. The moment of inertia of the triangle about an axis passing through G and perpendicular to the plane of the triangle is $\mathrm{I}_{0}$. If the smaller triangle DEF is removed from ABC , the moment of inertia of the remaining figure about the same axis is I. Then :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-091(1)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Let mass of the larger triangle $=M$  Side of larger triangle $=\ell$  Moment of inertia of larger triangle $=\mathrm{ma}^{2}$  Mass of smaller triangle $=\frac{M}{4}$  Length of smaller triangle $=\frac{\ell}{2}$  Moment of inertia of removed triangle  $=\frac{M}{4}\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2}$  $\therefore \frac{I_{\text {removed }}}{I_{\text {original }}}=\frac{\frac{M}{4}}{M} \cdot \frac{\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2}}{(\mathrm{a})^{2}}$  $\mathrm{I}_{\text {removed }}=\frac{\mathrm{I}_{0}}{16}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
a string is wound around a hollow cylinder of mass 5 kg and radius 0.5 m . If the string is now pulled with a horizontal force of 40 N , and the cylinder is rolling without slipping on a horizontal surface (see figure), then the angular acceleration of the cylinder will be (Neglect the mass and thickness of the string) 

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-091(4)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: So, $\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{I}_{0}-\frac{\mathrm{I}_{0}}{16}=\frac{15 \mathrm{I}_{0}}{16}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-109(1)}   From newton's second law $40+\mathrm{f}=\mathrm{m}(\mathrm{R} \alpha)$  Taking torque about 0 we get  $40 \times \mathrm{R}-\mathrm{f} \times \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{I} \alpha$  $40 \times \mathrm{R}-\mathrm{f} \times \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{mR}^{2} \alpha$  $40-\mathrm{f}=\mathrm{mR} \alpha$  Solving equation (i) and (ii)   \begin{equation*} \alpha=\frac{40}{\mathrm{mR}}=16 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \tag{ii} \end{equation*}   \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A circular disc $D_{1}$ of mass $M$ and radius $R$ has two identical discs $\mathrm{D}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{D}_{3}$ of the same mass M and radius R attached rigidly at its opposite ends (see figure). The moment of inertia of the system about the axis OO', passing through the centre of $\mathrm{D}_{1}$, as shown in the figure, will be :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-091(3)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Moment of inertia of disc $D_{1}$ about $\mathrm{OO}^{\prime}=\mathrm{I}_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}$  M.O.I of $\mathrm{D}_{2}$ about $\mathrm{OO}^{\prime}$  $=\mathrm{I}_{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}\right)+\mathrm{MR}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{4}+\mathrm{MR}^{2}$  M.O.I of $\mathrm{D}_{3}$ about $\mathrm{OO}^{\prime}$  $=\mathrm{I}_{3}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}\right)+\mathrm{MR}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{4}+\mathrm{MR}^{2}$\\ so, resultant M.O.I about $\mathrm{OO}^{\prime}$ is $\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{I}_{1}+\mathrm{I}_{2}+\mathrm{I}_{3}$  $$ \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow & =\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}+2\left(\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{4}+\mathrm{MR}^{2}\right) \\ & =\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}+\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}+2 \mathrm{MR}^{2}=3 \mathrm{MR}^{2} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
Two identical spherical balls of mass $M$ and radius $R$ each are stuck on two ends of a rod of length $2 R$ and mass M (see figure). The moment of inertia of the system about the axis passing perpendicularly through the centre of the rod is:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-091(2)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: For Ball  using parallel axes theorem, for ball moment of inertaia,  $\mathrm{I}_{\text {ball }}=\frac{2}{5} \mathrm{MR}^{2}+\mathrm{M}(2 \mathrm{R})^{2}=\frac{22}{5} \mathrm{MR}^{2}$  For two balls $\mathrm{I}_{\text {balls }}=2 \times \frac{22}{5} \mathrm{MR}^{2}=$ and,  $$ \begin{aligned} \mathrm{Irod} & =\frac{\mathrm{M}(2 \mathrm{R})^{2}}{12}=\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{3} \\ \mathrm{I}_{\text {system }} & =\mathrm{I}_{\text {balls }}+\mathrm{I}_{\text {rod }} \\ & =\frac{44}{5} \mathrm{MR}^{2}+\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{3}=\frac{137}{15} \mathrm{MR}^{2} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
Two masses m and $\frac{\mathrm{m}}{2}$ are connected at the two ends of a massless rigid rod of length $l$. The rod is suspended by a thin wire of torsional constant $k$ at the centre of mass of the rod-mass system (see figure). Because of torsional constant $k$, the restoring toruque is $\tau=k \theta$ for angular displacement $\theta$. If the rod is rotated by $\theta_{0}$ and released, the tension in it when it passes through its mean position will be:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-092(6)}\\
$[9$ Jan. 2019 I]
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: As we know, $\omega=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{I}}}$  $$ \begin{aligned} & \omega=\sqrt{\frac{3 \mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{m} \ell^{2}}}\left[\because \quad \mathrm{I} \operatorname{rod}=\frac{1}{3} \mathrm{~m} \ell^{2}\right] \end{aligned} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-110(3)}   Tension when it passes through the mean position,  $$ =\mathrm{m} \omega^{2} \theta_{0}^{2} \frac{\ell}{3}=\mathrm{m} \frac{3 \mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{m} \ell^{2}} \theta_{0}^{2} \frac{\ell}{3}=\frac{\mathrm{k} \theta_{0}^{2}}{\ell} $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A rod of length 50 cm is pivoted at one end. It is raised such that if makes an angle of $30^{\circ}$ from the horizontal as shown and released from rest. Its angular speed when it passes through the horizontal (in $\mathrm{rads}^{-1}$ ) will be $\left(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)$
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-092(4)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-110(2)}   By the low of conservation of energy, P.E. of rod $=$ Rotational K.E.  $\operatorname{mg} \frac{\ell}{2} \operatorname{Sin} \theta=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{I} \omega^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \operatorname{mg} \frac{\ell}{2} \operatorname{Sin} 30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{m} \ell^{2}}{3} \omega^{2} \Rightarrow \mathrm{mg} \frac{\ell}{2} \times \frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{m} \ell^{2}}{3} \omega^{2}$  For complete length of rod,  $\omega=\sqrt{3 \mathrm{~g} / 2(2 \ell)}=\sqrt{\frac{30}{2}} \mathrm{rods}^{-1}$\\
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
Seven identical circular planar disks, each of mass $M$ and radius R are welded symmetrically as shown. The moment of inertia of the arrangement about the axis normal to the plane and passing through the point P is:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-092(5)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Using parallel axes theorem, moment of inertia about ' $O$ ' $\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}}=\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{cm}}+\mathrm{md}^{2}$  $$ =\frac{7 \mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}+6\left(\mathrm{M} \times(2 \mathrm{R})^{2}\right)=\frac{55 \mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2} $$  Again, moment of inertia about point $P, I_{p}=I_{o}+m d^{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-110(1)}   $=\frac{55 \mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}+7 \mathrm{M}(3 \mathrm{R})^{2}=\frac{181}{2} \mathrm{MR}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
From a uniform circular disc of radius R and mass $9 \mathrm{M}, \mathrm{a}$ small disc of radius $\frac{R}{3}$ is removed as shown in the figure. The moment of inertia of the remaining disc about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the disc and passing, through centre of disc is :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-092}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Let $\sigma$ be the mass per unit area.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-110}   The total mass of the disc  $$ =\sigma \times \pi R^{2}=9 M $$  The mass of the circular disc cut  $$ =\sigma \times \pi\left(\frac{R}{3}\right)^{2}=\sigma \times \frac{\pi R^{2}}{9}=M $$  Let us consider the above system as a complete disc of mass $9 M$ and a negative mass $M$ super imposed on it.  Moment of inertia $\left(I_{1}\right)$ of the complete disc $=$ $\frac{1}{2} 9 M R^{2}$ about an axis passing through $O$ and perpendicular to the plane of the disc.  M.I. of the cut out portion about an axis passing through $O^{\prime}$ and perpendicular to the plane of disc  $=\frac{1}{2} \times M \times\left(\frac{R}{3}\right)^{2}$  $\therefore \quad$ M.I. $\left(I_{2}\right)$ of the cut out portion about an axis passing through $O$ and perpendicular to the plane of disc  $=\left[\frac{1}{2} \times M \times\left(\frac{R}{3}\right)^{2}+M \times\left(\frac{2 R}{3}\right)^{2}\right]$  [Using perpendicular axis theorem] $\therefore$ The total M.I. of the system about an axis passing through $O$ and perpendicular to the plane of the disc is $I=I_{1}+I_{2}$  $$ \begin{aligned} = & \frac{1}{2} 9 M R^{2}-\left[\frac{1}{2} \times M \times\left(\frac{R}{3}\right)^{2}+M \times\left(\frac{2 R}{3}\right)^{2}\right] \\ & =\frac{9 M R^{2}}{2}-\frac{9 M R^{2}}{18}=\frac{(9-1) M R^{2}}{2}=4 M R^{2} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A thin circular disk is in the xy plane as shown in the figure. The ratio of its moment of inertia about $z$ and $z^{\prime}$ axes will be
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-092(2)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: As we know, moment of inertia of a disc about an axis passing through C.G. and perpendicular to its plane,  $\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{Z}}=\frac{\mathrm{mR}^{2}}{2}$  Moment of inertia of a disc about a tangential axis perpendicular to its own plane,  $\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{z}}^{\prime}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{mR}^{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-111}   $\therefore \quad \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{z}} / \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{z}}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{mR}^{2}}{2} / \frac{3 \mathrm{mR}^{2}}{2}=1 / 3$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A thin rod $M N$, free to rotate in the vertical plane about the fixed end N , is held horizontal. When the end M is released the speed of this end, when the rod makes an angle $\alpha$ with the horizontal, will be proportional to: (see figure)
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-092(1)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: When the rod makes an angle $\alpha$  Displacement of centre of mass $=\frac{l}{2} \cos \alpha$  $m g \frac{l}{2} \cos \alpha=\frac{l}{2} I \omega^{2}$  $m g \frac{l}{2} \cos \alpha=\frac{m l^{2}}{6} \omega^{2} \quad(\because$ M.I. of thin uniform rod about an axis passing through its centre of mass and perpendicular to the $\operatorname{rod} I=\frac{m l^{2}}{12}$ )  $\Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\frac{3 g \cos \alpha}{l}}$  Speed of end $=\omega \times l=\sqrt{3 g \cos \alpha l}$  i.e., Speed of end, $\omega \propto \sqrt{\cos \alpha}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: The moment of inertia of a uniform cylinder of length $\ell$ and radius R about its perpendicular bisector is I . What is the ratio $\ell / \mathrm{R}$ such that the moment of inertia is minimum?
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: As we know, moment of inertia of a solid cylinder about an axis which is perpendicular bisector  $I=\frac{m R^{2}}{4}+\frac{m l^{2}}{12}$  $I=\frac{m}{4}\left[R^{2}+\frac{l^{2}}{3}\right]$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-111(3)}   $=\frac{m}{4}\left[\frac{V}{\pi l}+\frac{l^{2}}{3}\right] \Rightarrow \frac{d l}{d l}=\frac{m}{4}\left[\frac{-V}{\pi l^{2}}+\frac{2 l}{3}\right]=0$  $\frac{V}{\pi l^{2}}=\frac{2 l}{3} \quad \Rightarrow V=\frac{2 \pi l^{3}}{3}$  $\pi R^{2} l=\frac{2 \pi l^{3}}{3} \Rightarrow \frac{l^{2}}{R^{2}}=\frac{3}{2}$ or, $\frac{l}{R}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
Moment of inertia of an equilateral triangular lamina ABC , about the axis passing through its centre O and perpendicular to its plane is $\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}}$ as shown in the figure. A cavity DEF is cut out from the lamina, where D, E, F are the mid points of the sides. Moment of inertia of the remaining part of lamina about the same axis is :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-092(3)}
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: According to theorem of perpendicular axes, moment of inertia of triangle $(\mathrm{ABC})$  $\mathrm{I}_{0}=\mathrm{km} l^{2}$  $\mathrm{BC}=1$  Moment of inertia of a cavity DEF  $$ \begin{aligned} \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{DEF}} & =\mathrm{K} \frac{\mathrm{m}}{4}\left(\frac{l}{2}\right)^{2} \\ & =\frac{\mathrm{k}}{16} \mathrm{~m} l^{2} \end{aligned} $$  From equation (i),  $\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{DEF}}=\frac{\mathrm{I}_{0}}{16}$  Moment of inertia of remaining part  $\mathrm{I}_{\text {remain }}=\mathrm{I}_{0}-\frac{\mathrm{I}_{0}}{16}=\frac{15 \mathrm{I}_{0}}{16}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A circular hole of radius $\frac{R}{4}$ is made in a thin uniform disc having mass M and radius R , as shown in figure. The moment of inertia of the remaining portion of the disc about an axis passing through the point O and perpendicular to the plane of the disc is :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-093}
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Moment of Inertia of complete disc about ' O ' point $\mathrm{I}_{\text {total }}=\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}$  Radius of removed disc $=\mathrm{R} / 4$  $\therefore \quad$ Mass of removed disc $=\mathrm{M} / 16$  $\left[\right.$ As $\left.\mathrm{M} \propto \mathrm{R}^{2}\right]$  M.I of removed disc about its own axis ( $\left.\mathrm{O}^{\prime}\right)$  $=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{M}}{16}\left(\frac{\mathrm{R}}{4}\right)^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{512}$  M.I of removed disc about O  $\mathrm{I}_{\text {removed disc }}=\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{cm}}+\mathrm{mx}^{2}$  $=\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{512}+\frac{\mathrm{M}}{16}\left(\frac{3 \mathrm{R}}{4}\right)^{2}=\frac{19 \mathrm{MR}^{2}}{512}$  M.I of remaining disc  $\mathrm{I}_{\text {remaining }}=\frac{\mathrm{MR}^{2}}{2}-\frac{19}{512} \mathrm{MR}^{2}=\frac{237}{512} \mathrm{MR}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: From a solid sphere of mass $M$ and radius $R$ a cube of maximum possible volume is cut. Moment of inertia of cube about an axis passing through its center and perpendicular to one of its faces is :
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Here $a=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} R$  Now, $\frac{M}{M^{\prime}}=\frac{\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}}{a^{3}}$  $=\frac{\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}}{\left(\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} R\right)^{3}}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \pi$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-111(2)}   $M^{\prime}=\frac{2 M}{\sqrt{3} \pi}$  Moment of inertia of the cube about the given axis,  $I=\frac{M^{\prime} a^{2}}{6}$  $=\frac{\frac{2 M}{\sqrt{3} \pi} \times\left(\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} R\right)^{2}}{6}=\frac{4 M R^{2}}{9 \sqrt{3} \pi}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Consider a thin uniform square sheet made of a rigid material. If its side is ' $a$ ' mass $m$ and moment of inertia I about one of its diagonals, then :[Online April 10, 2015]\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: For a thin uniform square sheet  $I_{1}=I_{2}=I_{3}=\frac{m a^{2}}{12}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-111(1)}   \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A ring of mass M and radius R is rotating about its axis with angular velocity $\omega$. Two identical bodies each of mass m are now gently attached at the two ends of a diameter of the ring. Because of this, the kinetic energy loss will be:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Kinetic energy ${ }_{\text {(rotational) }} \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{R}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{I} \omega^{2}$  Kinetic energy $_{\text {(translational) }} \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{T}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{Mv}^{2} \quad(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{R} \omega)$  M.I. (initial) $\mathrm{I}_{\text {ring }}=\mathrm{MR}^{2} ; \omega_{\text {initial }}=\omega$  M.I. ${ }_{(\text {new) }} \mathrm{I}_{(\text {system) }}^{\prime}=\mathrm{MR}^{2}+2 \mathrm{mR}^{2}$  $\omega_{\text {(system) }}^{\prime}=\frac{M \omega}{M+2 m}$  Solving we get loss in K.E.  $=\frac{M m}{(M+2 m)} \omega^{2} R^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
This question has Statement 1and Statement 2. Of the four choices given after the Statements, choose the one that best describes the two Statements.

Statement 1: When moment of inertia $I$ of a body rotating about an axis with angular speed $\omega$ increases, its angular momentum $L$ is unchanged but the kinetic energy $K$ increases if there is no torque applied on it.

Statement 2: $L=I \omega$, kinetic energy of rotation $=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$
options: a) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is not the correct explanation of Statement 1.
b) Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true.
c) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is correct explanation of the Statement 1.
d) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false.
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: As $L=I \omega$ so $L$ increases with increase in $\omega$.  \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-112(1)}\\ ' $\omega$ ' and moment of inertia of the body $I$.  i.e., $K . E{ }_{(\text {rotational })}=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A solid sphere having mass $m$ and radius $r$ rolls down an inclined plane. Then its kinetic energy is
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: $K . E_{\text {rotational }}=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$  $=\frac{1}{2} \frac{2}{5} \omega r^{2} d^{2}\left(\because I_{\text {Solid sphere }}=\frac{2}{5} m r^{2}\right)$  $K . E_{\text {translational }}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}$  $\therefore \frac{K \cdot E_{\text {rotational }}}{K \cdot E_{\text {translational }}}=\frac{2}{5}$  Hence option (b) is correct  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A circular hole of diameter R is cut from a disc of mass $M$ and radius $R$; the circumference of the cut passes through the centre of the disc. The moment of inertia of the remaining portion of the disc about an axis perpendicular to the disc and passing through its centre is
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: M.I. of complete disc about its centre $O$.  $I_{\text {Total }}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-112(3)}   Mass of circular hole (removed)  $=\frac{M}{4} \quad\left(\right.$ As $\left.M=\pi R^{2} t \therefore M \propto R^{2}\right)$  M.I. of removed hole about its own axis  $=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{M}{4}\right)\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{32} M R^{2}$  M.I. of removed hole about $O^{\prime}$  $$ \begin{aligned} I_{\text {removed hole }} & =I_{\mathrm{cm}}+m x^{2} \\ & =\frac{M R^{2}}{32}+\frac{M}{4}\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{2} \\ & =\frac{M R^{2}}{32}+\frac{M R^{2}}{16}=\frac{3 M R^{2}}{32} \end{aligned} $$  M.I. of complete disc can also be written as  $I_{\text {Total }}=I_{\text {removed hole }}+I_{\text {remaining disc }}$  $I_{\text {Total }}=\frac{3 M R^{2}}{32}+I_{\text {remaining disc }}$  From eq. (i) and (ii),  $\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}=\frac{3 M R^{2}}{32}+I_{\text {remaining disc }}$  $\Rightarrow I_{\text {remaining disc }}$  $=\frac{M R^{2}}{2}-\frac{3 M R^{2}}{32}=\left(\frac{13}{32}\right) M R^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A mass $m$ hangs with the help of a string wrapped around a pulley on a frictionless bearing. The pulley has mass $m$ and radius $R$. Assuming pulley to be a perfect uniform circular disc, the acceleration of the mass $m$, if the string does not slip on the pulley, is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: For translational motion, $m g-T=m a$  For rotational motion,  $\mathrm{T} . \mathrm{R}=I \alpha$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-112}   $\Rightarrow \mathrm{T} . \mathrm{R}=\frac{1}{2} m R^{2} \alpha$  Also, acceleration, $a=\mathrm{R} \alpha$  $\therefore T=\frac{1}{2} m R \alpha=\frac{1}{2} m a$  Substituting the value of T is equation (1) we get mg -  $\frac{1}{2} m a=m a \Rightarrow a=\frac{2}{3} g$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A pulley of radius 2 m is rotated about its axis by a force $F=\left(20 t-5 t^{2}\right)$ newton (where $t$ is measured in seconds) applied tangentially. If the moment of inertia of the pulley about its axis of rotation is $10 \mathrm{~kg}-\mathrm{m}^{2}$ the number of rotations made by the pulley before its direction of motion is reversed, is:
options: a) more than 3 but less than 6
b) more than 6 but less than 9
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Given,  Force, $\mathrm{F}=\left(20 t-5 t^{2}\right)$  Radius, $r=2 m$  Torque, $T=r f=I \alpha$  $\Rightarrow 2\left(20 t-5 t^{2}\right)=10 \alpha$  $\therefore \alpha=4 t-t^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{d \omega}{d t}=4 t-t^{2} \Rightarrow \int_{0}^{\omega} d \omega=\int_{0}^{t}\left(4 t-t^{2}\right) d t$  $\Rightarrow \omega=2 t^{2}-\frac{t^{3}}{3}($ as $\omega=0$ at $t=0,6 \mathrm{~s})$  $\int_{0}^{\theta} d \theta=\int_{0}^{6}\left(2 t^{2}-\frac{t^{3}}{3}\right) d t$  $\Rightarrow \theta=36 \mathrm{rad} \Rightarrow 2 \pi n=36 \Rightarrow n=\frac{36}{2 \pi}<6$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A thin uniform rod of length $l$ and mass $m$ is swinging freely about a horizontal axis passing through its end. Its maximum angular speed is $\omega$. Its centre of mass rises to a maximum height of
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-112(2)}   The moment of inertia of the rod about $O$ is $\frac{1}{3} m \ell^{2}$. The kinetic energy of the rod at position $\mathrm{A}=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$ where $I$ is the moment of inertia of the rod about $O$. When the rod is in position B , its angular velocity is zero. In this case, the energy of the rod is mgh where $h$ is the maximum height to which the centre of mass (C.M) rises Gain in potential energy $=$ Loss in kinetic energy  $\therefore m g h=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{3} m l^{2}\right) \omega^{2}$  $\Rightarrow h=\frac{\ell^{2} \omega^{2}}{6 g}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Consider a uniform square plate of side ' $a$ ' and mass ' $M$ '. The moment of inertia of this plate about an axis perpendicular to its plane and passing through one of its corners is
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: $I_{n n^{\prime}}=\frac{1}{12} M\left(a^{2}+a^{2}\right)=\frac{M a^{2}}{6}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-113(2)}   Also, $D O=\frac{D B}{2}=\frac{\sqrt{2} a}{2}=\frac{a}{\sqrt{2}}$  By parallel axes the orem, moment of inertia of plate about an axis through one of its corners.  $$ \begin{aligned} \mathrm{I}_{m m^{\prime}} & =I_{n n^{\prime}}+M\left(\frac{a}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}=\frac{M a^{2}}{6}+\frac{M a^{2}}{2} \\ & =\frac{M a^{2}+3 M a^{2}}{6}=\frac{2}{3} M a^{2} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
For the given uniform square lamina $A B C D$, whose centre is $O$,
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-094(2)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: By the theorem of perpendicular axes, $I=I_{E F}+I_{G H}$  Here, $I$ is the moment of inertia of square lamina about an axis through $O$ and perpendicular to its plane.  $\therefore I_{E F}=I_{G H}$ (By Symmetry of Figure)   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-113}   $\therefore I_{E F}=\frac{I}{2}$\\ Again, by the same theorem $I=I_{A C}+I_{B D}=2 I_{A C}$  ( $\therefore I_{A C}=I_{B D}$ by symmetry of the figure)  $\therefore \quad I_{A C}=\frac{I}{2}$  From (i) and (ii), we get, $I_{E F}=I_{A C}$.  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Four point masses, each of value $m$, are placed at the corners of a square $A B C D$ of side $\ell$. The moment of inertia of this system about an axis passing through $A$ and parallel to $B D$ is
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-113(1)}   $I_{n n^{\prime}}=$ M.I due to the point mass at $B+$ M.I due to the point mass at $D+$ M.I due to the point mass at $C$.  $\mathrm{I}_{n n^{\prime}}=m\left(\frac{\ell}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}$  $+m\left(\frac{\ell}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}$  $+m(\sqrt{2} \ell)^{2}$  $\Rightarrow I_{n n^{\prime}}=2 \times m\left(\frac{\ell}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}+m(\sqrt{2} \ell)^{2}$  $=m \ell^{2}+2 m \ell^{2}=3 m \ell^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: The moment of inertia of a uniform semicircular disc of mass $M$ and radius $r$ about a line perpendicular to the plane of the disc through the centre is
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: The disc may be assumed as combination of two semi circular parts. Therefore, circular disc will have twice the mass of semicircular disc.  Moment of inertia of disc $=\frac{1}{2}(2 \mathrm{~m}) \mathrm{r}^{2}=\mathrm{Mr}^{2}$  Let $I$ be the moment of inertia of the uniform semicircular disc  $\Rightarrow 2 I=2 M r^{2} \Rightarrow I=\frac{M r^{2}}{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
One solid sphere $A$ and another hollow sphere $B$ are of same mass and same outer radii. Their moment of inertia about their diameters are respectively $I_{A}$ and $I_{B}$ Such that




where $d_{A}$ and $d_{B}$ are their densities.
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: The moment of inertia of solid sphere $A$ about its diameter $I_{A}=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$.  The moment of inertia of a hollow sphere B about its diameter $I_{B}=\frac{2}{3} M R^{2}$.  $\therefore I_{A}<I_{B}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A circular disc $X$ of radius $R$ is made from an iron plate of thickness $t$, and another disc $Y$ of radius $4 R$ is made from an iron plate of thickness $\frac{t}{4}$. Then the relation between the moment of inertia $I_{X}$ and $I_{I}$ is
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: We know that density $=\frac{\operatorname{mass}(M)}{\operatorname{volume}(V)}$  $\therefore M=d \times V=d \times\left(\pi R^{2} \times t\right)$.  The moment of inertia of a disc is given by $I=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$  $\therefore I_{x}=\frac{1}{2} M x R_{x}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(d \times \pi R^{2} \times t\right) R^{2}$\\ $=\frac{\pi d}{2} t \times R^{4}$  $I_{y}=\frac{1}{2} M_{y} R_{y}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left[\pi\left(4 R^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4}\right) d\right] \times(4 R)^{2}$  $\therefore \frac{I_{X}}{I_{Y}}=\frac{t_{X} R_{X}^{4}}{t_{Y} R_{Y}^{4}}=\frac{t \times R^{4}}{\frac{t}{4} \times(4 R)^{4}}=\frac{1}{64}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A particle performing uniform circular motion has angular frequency is doubled $\&$ its kinetic energy halved, then the new angular momentum is
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Rotational kinetic energy $=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$,  Angular momentum, $L=I \omega \Rightarrow I=\frac{L}{\omega}$  $\therefore \quad K . E .=\frac{1}{2} \frac{L}{\omega} \times \omega^{2}=\frac{1}{2} L \omega$  $\mathrm{L}^{\prime}=\frac{2 \mathrm{~K} . \mathrm{E}}{\omega}$  When $\omega$ is doubled and K.E is haled.  New angular momentum,  $L^{\prime}=\frac{\frac{2 \mathrm{~K} . \mathrm{E}}{2}}{2 \omega}$  $\Rightarrow \therefore L^{\prime}=\frac{L}{4}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: Moment of inertia of a circular wire of mass $M$ and radius $R$ about its diameter is
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: M. I of a circular wire about an axis $n n^{\prime}$ passing through the centre of the circle and perpendicular to the plane of the circle $=M R^{2}$\\ \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-114(1)}  As shown in the figure, $X$-axis and $Y$-axis lie along diameter of the ring. Using perpendicular axis theorem  $I_{X}+I_{Y}=I_{Z}$  Here, $I_{X}$ and $I_{Y}$ are the moment of inertia about the diameter. $\Rightarrow 2 I_{X}=M R^{2} \quad\left[\because I_{X}=I_{Y}\right.$ (by symmetry) and $\left.I_{Z}=M R^{2}\right]$  $\therefore I_{X}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
Initial angular velocity of a circular disc of mass $M$ is $\omega_{1}$. Then two small spheres of mass $m$ are attached gently to diametrically opposite points on the edge of the disc. What is the final angular velocity of the disc? 
  [2002]\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Moment of inertia of circular disc  $I_{1}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$  When two small sphere are attached on the edge of the disc, the moment of inertia becomes  $I_{2}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}+2 m R^{2}$  When two small spheres of mass $m$ are attached gently, the external torque, about the axis of rotation, is zero and therefore the angular momentum about the axis of rotation is constant.  $\therefore I_{1} \omega_{1}=I_{2} \omega_{2} \Rightarrow \omega_{2}=\frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}} \omega_{1}$  $\therefore \omega_{2}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}}{\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}+2 m R^{2}} \times \omega_{1}=\frac{M}{M+4 m} \omega_{1}$\\
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A uniform sphere of mass 500 g rolls without slipping on a plane horizontal surface with its centre moving at a speed of $5.00 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}$. Its kinetic energy is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: $K . E$ of the sphere $=$ translational $K . E+$ rotational $K . E$ $=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}$  Where, $I=$ moment of inertia,  $\omega=$ Angular, velocity of rotation  $m=$ mass of the sphere  $v=$ linear velocity of centre of mass of sphere  $\because$ Moment of inertia of sphere $I=\frac{2}{5} m R^{2}$  $\therefore K . E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{2}{5} m R^{2} \times \omega^{2}$  $\Rightarrow K . E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{2}{5} m R^{2} \times\left(\frac{v}{R}\right)^{2}\left(\because \omega=\frac{v}{R}\right)$  $\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{2}{5} m R^{2}+m R^{2}\right)\left(\frac{v}{R}\right)^{2}$  $\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{2} m R^{2} \times \frac{7}{5} \times \frac{v^{2}}{R^{2}}=\frac{7}{10} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{25}{10^{4}}$  $\Rightarrow K E=\frac{35}{4} \times 10^{-4}$ joule  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{KE}=8.75 \times 10^{-4}$ joule  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-094}
 

Consider a uniform cubical box of side a on a rough floor that is to be moved by applying minimum possible force $F$ at $a$ point $b$ above its centre of mass (see figure). If the coefficient of friction is $\mu=0.4$, the maximum possible value of $100 \times \frac{b}{a}$ for box not to topple before moving is $\qquad$ .]
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: For the box to be slide  $$ F=\mu m g=0.4 \mathrm{mg} $$  For no toppling  $$ \begin{aligned} & F\left(\frac{a}{2}+b\right) \leq m g \frac{a}{2} \\ \Rightarrow & 0.4 m g\left(\frac{a}{2}+b\right) \leq m g \frac{a}{2} \\ \Rightarrow & 0.2 a+0.4 b \leq 0.5 a \\ \Rightarrow & \frac{b}{a} \leq \frac{3}{4} \end{aligned} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-114}   i.e. $b \leq 0.75 a$ but this is not possible.  As the maximum value of $b$ can be equal to $0.5 a$.  $\Rightarrow \frac{100 b}{a}=50$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A solid sphere and solid cylinder of identical radii approach an incline with the same linear velocity (see figure). Both roll without slipping all throughout. The two climb maximum heights $h_{s p h}$ and $h_{c y l}$ on the incline. The ratio $\frac{h_{s p h}}{h_{c y l}}$ is given by :
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-094(1)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: For sphere,  $\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\mathrm{I} \omega^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m g h$  or $\quad \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{2}{5} m R^{2}\right) \frac{v^{2}}{R^{2}}=m g h$ or $h=\frac{7 v^{2}}{10 g}$  For cylinder  $\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m R^{2}}{2}\right)=m g h^{\prime}$  $$ \begin{aligned} & \text { or } \quad h^{\prime}=\frac{3 v^{2}}{4 g} \\ & \therefore \quad \frac{h}{h^{\prime}}=\frac{7 v^{2} / 10 g}{3 v^{2} / 4 g}=\frac{14}{15} \end{aligned} $$
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
The following bodies are made to roll up (without slipping) the same inclined plane from a horizontal plane:

(i) a ring of radius R , (ii) a solid cylinder of radius $\frac{R}{2}$ and (iii) a solid sphere of radius $\frac{R}{4}$. If, in each case, the speed of the center of mass at the bottom of the incline is same, the ratio of the maximum heights they climb is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: $m g h=\frac{1}{2} m v_{c m}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I_{c m} \omega^{2}$  $=\frac{1}{2} m v_{c m}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I_{c m}\left(\frac{v_{c m}}{R}\right)^{2}$  $=\frac{1}{2}\left(m+\frac{I_{c m}}{R^{2}}\right) v_{c m}^{2}$  For ring : $\mathrm{mgh}=\frac{1}{2}\left(m+\frac{m R^{2}}{R^{2}}\right) v_{c m}^{2}$  $\therefore h=\frac{v_{c m}^{2}}{g}$.  For solid cylinder, $m g h=\frac{1}{2}\left(m+\frac{m R^{2}}{2 R^{2}}\right) v_{c m}^{2}$  $\therefore h=\frac{3 v_{c m}^{2}}{4 g}$  For sphere, $m g h=\frac{1}{2}\left(m+\frac{2}{5} \frac{m R^{2}}{R^{2}}\right) v_{c m}^{2}$  $\therefore h=\frac{7 v_{c m}^{2}}{10 g}$  Ratio of heights $1: \frac{3}{4}: \frac{7}{10} \Rightarrow 20: 15: 14$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A homogeneous solid cylindrical roller of radius R and mass M is pulled on a cricket pitch by a horizontal force. Assuming rolling without slipping, angular acceleration of the cylinder is: [10 Jan. 2019 I]\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-115(2)}   $\mathrm{F}-\mathrm{fr}=\mathrm{ma}$  $\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{r}} \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{I} \alpha=\frac{m R^{2}}{2} \alpha$  for pure rolling $\mathrm{a}=\alpha \mathrm{R}$  from (1) (2) and (3)  $F-\frac{m R \alpha}{2}=m \alpha R$  $$ \begin{aligned} & F=\frac{3}{2} m R \alpha \\ & \alpha=\frac{2 F}{3 m R} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A roller is made by joining together two cones at their vertices O . It is kept on two rails AB and CD , which are placed asymmetrically (see figure), with its axis perpendicular to CD and its centre O at the centre of line joining AB and Cd (see figure). It is given a light push so that it starts rolling with its centre O moving parallel to CD in the direction shown. As it moves, the roller will tend to:

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-095(2)}
options: b) turn left and right alternately.
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: As shown in the diagram, the normal reaction of AB on roller will shift towards O .  This will lead to tending of the system of cones to turn left.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-115(1)}   \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A uniform solid cylindrical roller of mass ' $m$ ' is being pulled on a horizontal surface with force $F$ parallel to the surface and applied at its centre. If the acceleration of the cylinder is ' a ' and it is rolling without slipping then the value of ' $F$ ' is:
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: From figure,   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-115}   And, torque $\tau=I \alpha$  $\frac{m R^{2}}{2} \alpha=f R$  $\frac{m R^{2}}{2} \frac{a}{R}=f R\left[\because \alpha=\frac{a}{R}\right]$  $\frac{m a}{2}=f$  Put this value in equation (i),  $m a=F-\frac{m a}{2}$ or $F=\frac{3 m a}{2}$
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A cylinder of mass $M_{c}$ and sphere of mass $M_{s}$ are placed at points A and B of two inclines, respectively (See\\
Figure). If they roll on the incline without slipping such that their accelerations are the same, then the ratio $\frac{\sin \theta_{c}}{\sin \theta_{s}}$ is:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-095}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: As we know,  Acceleration, $a=\frac{m g \sin \theta}{m+\frac{I}{r^{2}}}$  For cylinder, $a_{c}=\frac{M_{c} \cdot g \cdot \sin \theta_{c}}{M_{c}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{M_{c} R^{2}}{R^{2}}}=\frac{M_{c} \cdot g \cdot \sin \theta_{c}}{M_{c}+\frac{M_{c} R^{2}}{2 R^{2}}}$  or, $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{2}{3} \mathrm{~g} \sin \theta_{\mathrm{c}}$  For sphere,  $a_{s}=\frac{M_{s} g \sin \theta_{s}}{M_{s}+\frac{I_{s}}{r^{2}}}=\frac{M_{s} g \sin \theta_{s}}{M_{s}+\frac{2}{5} \frac{M R^{2}}{R^{2}}}$\\ or, $\quad a_{s}=\frac{5}{7} g \sin \theta_{\mathrm{s}}$  given, $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{c}}=\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{s}}$  i.e., $\frac{2}{3} \mathrm{~g} \sin \theta_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{5}{7} \mathrm{~g} \sin \theta_{\mathrm{s}}$  $\therefore \quad \frac{\sin \theta_{c}}{\sin \theta_{s}}=\frac{\frac{5}{7} g}{\frac{2}{3} g}=\frac{15}{14}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A loop of radius $r$ and mass $m$ rotating with an angular velocity $\omega_{0}$ is placed on a rough horizontal surface. The initial velocity of the centre of the hoop is zero. What will be the velocity of the centre of the hoop when it ceases to slip?
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-116}   From conservation of angular momentum about any fix point on the surface, $m r^{2} \omega_{0}=2 m r^{2} \omega$  $$ \Rightarrow \omega=\omega_{0} / 2 \Rightarrow v=\frac{\omega_{0} r}{2} \quad[\because v=r \omega] $$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A tennis ball (treated as hollow spherical shell) starting from O rolls down a hill. At point A the ball becomes air borne leaving at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. The ball strikes the ground at B . What is the value of the distance AB ?

(Moment of inertia of a spherical shell of mass $m$ and radius $R$ about its diameter $=\frac{2}{3} m R^{2}$ )

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-095(1)}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Velocity of the tennis ball on the surface of the earth or ground  $\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{gh}}{1+\frac{\mathrm{k}^{2}}{\mathrm{R}^{2}}}}($ where $\mathrm{k}=$ radius of gyration of spherical  shell $=\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} \mathrm{R}$ )  Horizontal range $\mathrm{AB}=\frac{v^{2} \sin 2 \theta}{g}$  $=\frac{\left(\sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{gh}}{1+\mathrm{k}^{2} / \mathrm{R}^{2}}}\right)^{2} \sin \left(2 \times 30^{\circ}\right)}{\mathrm{g}}=2.08 \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A thick-walled hollow sphere has outside radius $R_{0}$. It rolls down an incline without slipping and its speed at the bottom is $v_{0}$. Now the incline is waxed, so that it is practically frictionless and the sphere is observed to slide down (without any rolling). Its speed at the bottom is observed to be $5 v_{0} / 4$. The radius of gyration of the hollow sphere about an axis through its centre is [Online May 26, 2012]\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: When body rolls dawn on inclined plane with velocity $\mathrm{V}_{0}$ at bottom then body has both rotational and translational kinetic energy.  Therefore, by law of conservation of energy,  $$ \begin{aligned} & \text { P.E. }=K . E_{\text {trans }}+K . E_{\text {rotational }} \\ & =\frac{1}{2} m V_{0}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2} \end{aligned} $$  $=\frac{1}{2} m V_{0}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m k^{2} \frac{V_{0}^{2}}{R_{0}^{2}}$   \begin{equation*} \left[\because \mathrm{I}=m k^{2}, \omega=\frac{V}{R_{0}}\right] \tag{i} \end{equation*}   When body is sliding down then body has only translatory motion.  $\therefore P . E .=K . E_{\text {trans }}$  $=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\frac{5}{4} v_{0}\right)^{2}$  Dividing (i) by (ii) we get  $\frac{P . E .}{P . E .}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} m v_{0}^{2}\left[1+\frac{K^{2}}{R_{0}^{2}}\right]}{\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{25}{16} \times m V_{0}^{2}}=\frac{25}{16}=1+\frac{K^{2}}{R_{0}^{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{K^{2}}{R_{0}^{2}}=\frac{9}{16}$  or, $K=\frac{3}{4} R_{0}$.  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
A solid sphere is rolling on a surface as shown in figure, with a translational velocity $v \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$. If it is to climb the inclined surface continuing to roll without slipping, then minimum velocity for this to happen is

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_e4a6fe40ca32fbc82a73g-096}\\
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Minimum velocity for a body rolling without slipping  $v=\sqrt{\frac{2 g h}{1+\frac{K^{2}}{R^{2}}}}$  For solid sphere, $\frac{K^{2}}{R^{2}}=\frac{2}{5}$  $\therefore \quad v=\sqrt{\frac{2 g h}{1+\frac{K^{2}}{R^{2}}}}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{7} g h}$  \begin{enumerate}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question: A round uniform body of radius $R$, mass $M$ and moment of inertia $I$ rolls down (without slipping) an inclined plane making an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal. Then its acceleration is
chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion
solution: Acceleration of the body rolling down an inclined plane is given by.  $$ a=\frac{g \sin \theta}{1+\frac{I}{M R^{2}}} $$   \end{document}
courseName: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

question:
If the angular momentum of a planet of mass $m$, moving around the Sun in a circular orbit is L , about the center of the Sun, its areal velocity is:

$\\
solution: Areal velocity; $\frac{\mathrm{dA}}{\mathrm{dt}}$  $$ \begin{aligned} & \mathrm{dA}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{r}^{2} \mathrm{~d} \theta \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{dA}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{r}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{d} \theta}{\mathrm{dt}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{r}^{2} \omega \end{aligned} $$  Also, $\mathrm{L}=\mathrm{mvr}=\mathrm{mr}^{2} \omega$  $$ \therefore \frac{\mathrm{dA}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{L}}{\mathrm{m}} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Figure shows elliptical path abcd of a planet around the sun S such that the area of triangle csa is $\frac{1}{4}$ the area of the ellipse. (See figure) With db as the semimajor axis, and ca as the semiminor axis. Ift $t_{1}$ is the time taken for planet to go over path abc and $\mathrm{t}_{2}$ for path taken over cda then:



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-116(2)}\\
solution: Let area of ellipse $\mathrm{abcd}=\mathrm{x}$  Area of SabcS $=\frac{x}{2}+\frac{x}{4}$ (i.e., ar of abca + SacS)  (Area of half ellipse + Area of triangle)  $=\frac{3 x}{4}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-124(1)}   Area of SadcS $=x-\frac{3 x}{4}=\frac{x}{4}$  $\frac{\text { Area of SabcS }}{\text { Area of SadcS }}=\frac{3 x / 4}{x / 4}=\frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}$  $\frac{\mathrm{t}_{1}}{\mathrm{t}_{2}}=3$ or, $\mathrm{t}_{1}=3 \mathrm{t}_{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
India's Mangalyan was sent to the Mars by launching it into a transfer orbit EOM around the sun. It leaves the earth at $E$ and meets Mars at $M$. If the semi-major axis of Earth's orbit is $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{e}}=1.5 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~m}$, that of Mars orbit $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{m}}=$ $2.28 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~m}$, taken Kepler's laws give the estimate of time for Mangalyan to reach Mars from Earth to be close to



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-116(1)}\\

solution: According to Kepler's law of periods $T^{2} \propto R^{3}$   $$ \begin{aligned} & \therefore\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}\right)^{3} \\ & \Rightarrow T_{2}=T_{1}\left(\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}\right)^{3 / 2}=5 \times\left[\frac{4 R}{R}\right]^{3 / 2} \\ & =5 \times 2^{3}=40 \text { hours } \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A straight rod of length L extends from $x=a$ to $x=\mathrm{L}+\mathrm{a}$. The gravitational force it exerts on point mass ' m ' at $x=0$, if the mass per unit length of the rod is $\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B} x^{2}$, is given by:

$
solution: Given $\lambda=\left(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{Bx}^{2}\right)$,  Taking small element dm of length dx at a distance x from $\mathrm{x}=0$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-124(2)}   so, $\mathrm{dm}=\lambda \mathrm{dx}$  $\mathrm{dm}=\left(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{Bx}^{2}\right) d x$  $\mathrm{dF}=\frac{\mathrm{Gmdm}}{\mathrm{x}^{2}}$ $\Rightarrow F=\int_{a}^{a+L} \frac{G m}{x^{2}}\left(A+B x^{2}\right) d x$  $=\operatorname{Gm}\left[-\frac{\mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{x}}+\mathrm{Bx}\right]_{\mathrm{a}}^{\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{L}}$  $=\mathrm{Gm}\left[\mathrm{A}\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{a}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{L}}\right)+\mathrm{BL}\right]$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Take the mean distance of the moon and the sun from the earth to be $0.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$ and $150 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$ respectively. Their masses are $8 \times 10^{22} \mathrm{~kg}$ and $2 \times 10^{30} \mathrm{~kg}$ respectively. The radius of the earth is 6400 km . Let $\Delta \mathrm{F}_{1}$ be the difference in the forces exerted by the moon at the nearest and farthest points on the earth and $\Delta \mathrm{F}_{2}$ be the difference in the force exerted by the sun at the nearest and farthest points on the earth. Then, the number closest to $\frac{\Delta F_{1}}{\Delta F_{2}}$ is:

\\
solution: As we know, Gravitational force of attraction, $\mathrm{F}=\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{R}^{2}}$  $\mathrm{F}_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}^{2}}$ and $\mathrm{F}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}}}{\mathrm{r}_{2}^{2}}$  $\Delta \mathrm{F}_{1}=\frac{2 \mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}^{3}} \Delta \mathrm{r}_{1}$ and $\Delta \mathrm{F}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}}}{\mathrm{r}_{2}^{3}} \Delta \mathrm{r}_{2}$  $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{F}_{1}}{\Delta \mathrm{F}_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{m} \Delta \mathrm{r}_{1}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}^{3}} \frac{\mathrm{r}_{2}^{3}}{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}} \Delta \mathrm{r}_{2}}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}}}\right)\left(\frac{\mathrm{r}_{2}^{3}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}^{3}}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta \mathrm{r}_{1}}{\Delta \mathrm{r}_{2}}\right)$  Using $\Delta \mathrm{r}_{1}=\Delta \mathrm{r}_{2}=2 \mathrm{R}_{\text {earth }} ; \mathrm{m}=8 \times 10^{22} \mathrm{~kg}$;  $\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}}=2 \times 10^{30} \mathrm{~kg}$  $\mathrm{r}_{1}=0.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$ and $\mathrm{r}_{2}=150 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$  $$ \frac{\Delta \mathrm{F}_{1}}{\Delta \mathrm{F}_{2}}=\left(\frac{8 \times 10^{22}}{2 \times 10^{30}}\right)\left(\frac{150 \times 10^{6}}{0.4 \times 10^{6}}\right)^{3} \times 1 \cong 2 $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Four particles, each of mass M and equidistant from each other, move along a circle of radius R under the action of their mutual gravitational attraction. The speed of each particle is:

\\
solution: $2 F \cos 45^{\circ}+F^{\prime}=\frac{M v^{2}}{R}$ (From figure)  Where $F=\frac{G M^{2}}{(\sqrt{2} R)^{2}}$ and $F^{\prime}=\frac{G M^{2}}{4 R^{2}}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-124}   $\Rightarrow \frac{2 \times G M^{2}}{\sqrt{2}(R \sqrt{2})^{2}}+\frac{G M^{2}}{4 R^{2}}=\frac{M v^{2}}{R}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{G M^{2}}{R}\left[\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right]=M v^{2}$  $\therefore v=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}+4}{4 \sqrt{2}}\right)}=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}(1+2 \sqrt{2})}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
From a sphere of mass M and radius R , a smaller sphere of radius $\frac{\mathrm{R}}{2}$ is carved out such that the cavity made in the original sphere is between its centre and the periphery (See figure). For the configuration in the figure where the distance between the centre of the original sphere and the removed sphere is 3 R , the gravitational force between the two sphere is:



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-117}\\
solution: Volume of removed sphere  $V_{\text {remo }}=\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{3}=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)$  Volume of the sphere (remaining)  $V_{\text {remain }}=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}-\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\left(\frac{7}{8}\right)$  Therefore mass of sphere carved and remaining sphere are at respectively $\frac{1}{8} \mathrm{M}$ and $\frac{7}{8} \mathrm{M}$.  Therefore, gravitational force between these two sphere,  $F=\frac{G \mathrm{M} m}{r^{2}}=\frac{G \frac{7 M}{8} \times \frac{1}{8} M}{(3 R)^{2}}=\frac{7}{64 \times 9} \frac{G M^{2}}{R^{2}}$  $\simeq \frac{41}{3600} \frac{\mathrm{GM}^{2}}{\mathrm{R}^{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two particles of equal mass ' $m$ ' go around a circle of radius $R$ under the action of their mutual gravitational attraction. The speed of each particle with respect to their centre of mass is

\\
solution: As two masses revolve about the common centre of mass $O$.  $\therefore \quad$ Mutual gravitational attraction $=$ centripetal force  $$ \begin{aligned} & \frac{G m^{2}}{(2 R)^{2}}=m \omega^{2} R \\ & \Rightarrow \quad \frac{G m}{4 R^{3}}=\omega^{2} \\ & \Rightarrow \quad \omega=\sqrt{\frac{G m}{4 R^{3}}} \end{aligned} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-125(2)}   If the velocity of the two particles with respect to the centre of gravity is $v$ then  $$ \begin{aligned} v & =\omega R \\ v & =\sqrt{\frac{G m}{4 R^{3}}} \times R=\sqrt{\frac{G m}{4 R}} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Two spherical bodies of mass $M$ and $5 M \&$ radii $R \& 2 R$ respectively are released in free space with initial separation between their centres equal to $12 R$. If they attract each other due to gravitational force only, then the distance covered by the smaller body just before collision is \\
