solution: We know that  Force $=$ mass $\times$ acceleration.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-125(1)}   The gravitational force acting on both the masses is the same.  $F_{1}=F_{2}$  $m a_{1}=m a_{2}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{9 M}{95 M}=\frac{5 M}{M}=5$  $\Rightarrow \frac{9 M}{95 M}=\frac{1}{5}$  Let $t$ be the time taken for the two masses to collide and $x_{5 M}, \mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{M}}$ be the distance travelled by the mass $5 M$ and $M$ respectively.  \section*{For mass $5 M$} $u=0$, $S=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}$  $\therefore x_{5 M}=\frac{1}{2} a_{5 M} t^{2}$  For mass $M$  $u=0, s=x_{M}, t=t, a=a_{M}$  $\therefore s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}$  $\Rightarrow x_{M}=\frac{1}{2} a_{M} t^{2}$  Dividing (ii) by (iii)  $\frac{x_{5 M}}{x_{M}}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} a_{5 M} t^{2}}{\frac{1}{2} a_{M} t^{2}}=\frac{a_{5 M}}{a_{M}}=\frac{1}{5} \quad[$ From (i) $]$  $\therefore 5 x_{5 M}=x_{M}$  From the figure it is clear that  $x_{5 M}+x_{M}=9 R$  Where $O$ is the point where the two spheres collide.  From (iv) and (v)  $\frac{x_{M}}{5}+x_{M}=9 R$  $\therefore \quad 6 x_{M}=45 R$  $\therefore \quad x_{M}=\frac{45}{6} R=7.5 R$  \begin{enumerate}

question: The value of acceleration due to gravity is $g_{1}$ at a height $h=\frac{R}{2}$ ( $R=$ radius of the earth) from the surface of the earth. It is again equal to $g_{1}$ and a depth $d$ below the surface of the earth. The ratio $\left(\frac{d}{R}\right)$ equals : \\
solution: According to question, $g_{h}=g_{d}=g_{1}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-125}   $g_{h}=\frac{G M}{\left(R+\frac{R}{2}\right)^{2}}$ and $g_{d}=\frac{G M(R-d)}{R^{3}}$  $\frac{G M}{\left(\frac{3 R}{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{G M(R-d)}{R^{3}} \Rightarrow \frac{4}{9}=\frac{(R-d)}{R}$  $\Rightarrow 4 R=9 R-9 d \Rightarrow 5 R=9 d$  $\therefore \frac{d}{R}=\frac{5}{9}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The acceleration due to gravity on the earth's surface at the poles is $g$ and angular velocity of the earth about the axis passing through the pole is $\omega$. An object is weighed at the equator and at a height $h$ above the poles by using a spring balance. If the weights are found to be same, then $h$ is: $(h<<R$, where $R$ is the radius of the earth $)$\\


\\
solution: Value of $g$ at equator, $g_{A}=g \cdot-R \omega^{2}$ Value of $g$ at height $h$ above the pole,  $g_{B}=g \cdot\left(1-\frac{2 h}{R}\right)$  As object is weighed equally at the equator and poles, it means $g$ is same at these places.\\ $g_{A}=g_{B}$  $\Rightarrow g-R \omega^{2}=g\left(1-\frac{2 h}{R}\right)$  $\Rightarrow R \omega^{2}=\frac{2 g h}{R} \Rightarrow h=\frac{R^{2} \omega^{2}}{2 g}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The height ' $h$ ' at which the weight of a body will be the same as that at the same depth ' $h$ ' from the surface of the earth is (Radius of the earth is $R$ and effect of the rotation of the earth is neglected) :


\\
solution: The acceleration due to gravity at a height $h$ is given by  $g=\frac{G M}{(R+h)^{2}}$  Here, $G=$ gravitation constant  $M=$ mass of earth  The acceleration due to gravity at depth $h$ is  $g^{\prime}=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}\left(1-\frac{h}{R}\right)$  Given, $g=g^{\prime}$  $\therefore \frac{G M}{(R+h)^{2}}=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}\left(1-\frac{h}{R}\right)$  $\therefore R^{3}=(R+h)^{2}(R-h)=\left(R^{2}+h^{2}+2 h R\right)(R-h)$  $\Rightarrow R^{3}=R^{3}+h^{2} R+2 h R^{2}-R^{2} h-h^{3}-2 h^{2} R$  $\Rightarrow h^{3}+h^{2}(2 R-R)-R^{2} h=0$  $\Rightarrow h^{3}+h^{2} R-R^{2} h=0$  $\Rightarrow h^{2}+h R-R^{2}=0$  $\Rightarrow h=\frac{-R \pm \sqrt{R^{2}+4(1) R^{2}}}{2}$  $=\frac{-R+\sqrt{5} R}{2}=\frac{(\sqrt{5}-1)}{2} R$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A box weighs 196 N on a spring balance at the north pole. Its weight recorded on the same balance if it is shifted to the equator is close to (Take $g=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$ at the north pole and the radius of the earth $=6400 \mathrm{~km}$ ): $\\
solution: Weight at pole, $w=m g=196 N$  $$ \Rightarrow \quad m=19.6 \mathrm{~kg} $$  Weight at equator, $w^{\prime}=m g^{\prime}=m\left(g-\omega^{2} R\right)$  $$ \begin{aligned} =19.6\left[10-\left(\frac{2 \pi}{24 \times 3600}\right)^{2} \times 6400 \times 10^{3}\right] & \\ & \left(\because \omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right) \end{aligned} $$  $=19.6[10-0.034]=195.33 \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The ratio of the weights of a body on the Earth's surface to that on the surface of a planet is $9: 4$. The mass of the planet is $\frac{1}{9}$ th of that of the Earth. If ' $R$ ' is the radius of the Earth, what is the radius of the planet? (Take the planets to have the same mass density).


\\
solution: $\frac{W_{e}}{W_{p}}=\frac{m g_{e}}{m g_{p}}=\frac{9}{4}$ or $\frac{g_{e}}{g_{p}}=\frac{9}{4}$  or $\frac{G M / R^{2}}{G(M / 9) / R_{p}^{2}}=\frac{9}{4}$  $\therefore \quad \boldsymbol{R}_{p}=\frac{R}{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The value of acceleration due to gravity at Earth's surface is $9.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$. The altitude above its surface at which the acceleration due to gravity decreases to $4.9 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$, is close to : (Radius of earth $=6.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}$ )

\\
solution: Given  Acceleration due to gravity at a height h from earth's surface is $g_{h}=g\left(1+\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}\right)^{-2} \Rightarrow 4.9=9.8\left(1+\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}\right)^{-2}$  $\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=\left(1-\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}\right) \quad\left[\right.$ as $\left.\mathrm{h} \ll<\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}\right]$  $\mathrm{h}=\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}(\sqrt{2}-1)$  $\mathrm{h}=6400 \times 0.414 \mathrm{~km}=2.6 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Suppose that the angular velocity of rotation of earth is increased. Then, as a consequence.
options: a) There will be no change in weight anywhere on the earth
b) Weight of the object, everywhere on the earth, wild decrease
c) Weight of the object, everywhere on the earth, will increase
d) Except at poles, weight of the object on the earth will decrease
solution: With rotation of earth or latitude, acceleration due to gravity vary as $\mathrm{g}^{\prime}=\mathrm{g}-\omega^{2} \mathrm{R} \cos ^{2} \phi$  Where $\phi$ is latitude, there will be no change in gravity at poles as $\phi=90^{\circ}$  At all other points as $\omega$ increases $g^{\prime}$ will decreases hence, weight, $\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{mg}$ decreases.  \begin{enumerate}

The variation of acceleration due to gravity $g$ with distance d from centre of the earth is best represented by $(\mathrm{R}=$ Earth's radius):

solution: Variation of acceleration due to gravity, $g$ with distance ' $d$ ' from centre of the earth  If $d<R, g=\frac{G m}{R^{2}}$. $\quad$ i.e., $g \propto d$ (straight line)  If $d=R, g_{s}=\frac{G m}{R^{2}}$  If $d>R, \mathrm{~g}=\frac{G m}{d^{2}} \quad$ i.e., $g \propto \frac{1}{d^{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

solution: Given that, mass density $\left(\frac{\text { mass }}{\text { volume }}\right)$ of a spherical body $\rho(\mathrm{r})=\frac{\mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{r}}$  $\frac{\mathrm{M}}{\mathrm{V}}=\frac{\mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{r}}$ for inside $\mathrm{r} \leq \mathrm{R}$  $M=\frac{\mathrm{kv}}{\mathrm{r}}$  Inside the surface of sphere Intensity  $\mathrm{I}=\frac{\mathrm{GMr}}{\mathrm{R}^{3}}$  $\because \quad \mathrm{I}=\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{m}}$  $\mathrm{g}_{\text {inside }}=\frac{\mathrm{GMr}}{\mathrm{R}^{3}} \quad$ or $\quad \mathrm{I}=\frac{\mathrm{mg}}{\mathrm{m}}=\mathrm{g}$ $=\frac{\mathrm{G}}{\mathrm{R}^{3}} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{kv}}{\mathrm{r}} \cdot \mathrm{r}=$ constant $\quad$ From eq. (i),  Similarly, $g_{\text {out }}=\frac{G M}{r^{2}}$  Hence, option (2) is correct graph.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If the Earth has no rotational motion, the weight of a person on the equator is W. Determine the speed with which the earth would have to rotate about its axis so that the person at the equator will weight $\frac{3}{4} \mathrm{~W}$. Radius of the Earth is 6400 km and $\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$.

\\
solution: We know, $g^{\prime}=g-\omega^{2} R \cos ^{2} \theta$  $\frac{3 g}{4}=g-\omega^{2} R$  Given, $\mathrm{g}^{\prime}=\frac{3}{4} \mathrm{~g}$  $\omega^{2} \mathrm{R}=\frac{\mathrm{g}}{4}$  $\omega=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{g}}{4 \mathrm{R}}}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{4 \times 6400 \times 10^{3}}}$  $=\frac{1}{2 \times 8 \times 100}=0.6 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The change in the value of acceleration of earth towards sun, when the moon comes from the position of solar eclipse to the position on the other side of earth in line with sun is:

(mass of the moon $=7.36 \times 10^{22} \mathrm{~kg}$, radius of the moon's orbit $=3.8 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m}$.

\\
Assuming the earth to be a sphere of uniform density, the acceleration due to gravity inside the earth at a distance of $r$ from the centre is proportional to\\
solution: Acceleration due to gravity at depth d from the surface of the earth or at a distance $r$ from the centre ' $O$ ' of the earth $g^{\prime}=\frac{4}{3} \pi \rho G r$   Hence $g^{\prime} \propto r$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-127(2)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
The height at which the acceleration due to gravity becomes $\frac{g}{9}$ (where $g=$ the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the earth) in terms of $R$, the radius of the earth, is


\\
solution: On earth's surface $g=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}$  At height above earth's surface  $g_{h}=\frac{G M}{(R+h)^{2}}$  $\therefore \frac{g_{n}}{g}=\frac{R^{2}}{(R+h)^{2}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{g / 9}{g}=\left[\frac{R}{R+h}\right]^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{R}{R+h}=\frac{1}{3}$  $\therefore \quad h=2 R$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The change in the value of ' $g$ ' at a height ' $h$ ' above the surface of the earth is the same as at a depth ' $d$ ' below the surface of earth. When both ' $d$ ' and ' $h$ ' are much smaller than the radius of earth, then which one of the following is correct?

\\
solution: Value of $g$ with altitude is,  $g_{h}=g\left[1-\frac{2 h}{R}\right]$;  Value of $g$ at depth $d$ below earth's surface, $g_{d}=g\left[1-\frac{d}{R}\right]$  Equating $g_{h}$ and $g_{d}$, we get $d=2 h$  \begin{enumerate}

options: a) is a complex function of $g$
solution: Value of $g$ on earth's surface,  $$ \begin{array}{r} g=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}=\frac{G \rho \times V}{R^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow g=\frac{G \times \rho \times \frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}}{R^{2}} \end{array} $$  $g=\frac{4}{3} \rho \pi G . R$ where $\rho \rightarrow$ average density  $\rho=\left(\frac{3 g}{4 \pi G R}\right)$  $\Rightarrow \rho$ is directly proportional to $g$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two planets have masses $M$ and $16 M$ and their radii are $a$ and $2 a$, respectively. The separation between the centres of the planets is $10 a$. A body of mass m is fired from the surface of the larger planet towards the smaller planet along the line joining their centres. For the body to be able to reach the surface of smaller planet, the minimum firing speed needed is :

$[6$ Sep. 2020 (II)\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-127}   Let $A$ be the point where gravitation field of both planets cancel each other i.e. zero.  $\frac{G M}{x^{2}}=\frac{G(16 M)}{(10 a-x)^{2}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{x}=\frac{4}{(10 a-x)} \Rightarrow 4 x=10 a-x \Rightarrow x=2 a$  Using conservation of energy, we have  $-\frac{G M m}{8 a}-\frac{G(16 M) m}{2 a}+K E=-\frac{G M m}{2 a}-\frac{G(16 M) m}{8 a}$  $K E=G M m\left[\frac{1}{8 a}+\frac{16}{2 a}-\frac{1}{2 a}-\frac{16}{8 a}\right]$  $\Rightarrow K E=G M m\left[\frac{1+64-4-16}{8 a}\right]$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=G M m\left[\frac{45}{8 a}\right] \Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{90 G M}{8 a}}$  $\Rightarrow v=\frac{3}{2} \sqrt{\frac{5 G M}{a}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
On the $x$-axis and at a distance $x$ from the origin, the gravitational field due to a mass distribution is given by $\frac{A x}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}$ in the $x$-direction. The magnitude of gravitational potential on the $x$-axis at a distance $x$, taking its value to be zero at infinity, is :

\\
solution: Given: Gravitational field,  $E_{G}=\frac{A x}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}, V_{\infty}=0$  $\int_{V_{\infty}}^{V_{x}} d V=-\int_{\infty}^{x} \vec{E}_{G} \cdot \vec{d}_{x}$  $\Rightarrow V_{x}-V_{\infty}=-\int_{\infty}^{x} \frac{A x}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}} d x$  $\therefore V_{x}=\frac{A}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}-0=\frac{A}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The mass density of a planet of radius $R$ varies with the distance $r$ from its centre as $\rho(r)=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right)$. Then the gravitational field is maximum at :

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-127(1)}   Mass of small element of planet of radius $x$ and thickness $d x$.  $d m=\rho \times 4 \pi x^{2} d x=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{x^{2}}{R^{2}}\right) \times 4 \pi x^{2} d x$  Mass of the planet  $$ \begin{aligned} M & =4 \pi \rho_{0} \int_{0}^{r}\left(x^{2}-\frac{x^{4}}{R^{2}}\right) d x \\ \Rightarrow M & =4 \pi \rho_{0}\left|\frac{r^{3}}{3}-\frac{r^{5}}{5 R^{2}}\right| \end{aligned} $$  Gravitational field,  $$ E=\frac{G M}{r^{2}}=\frac{G}{r^{2}} \times 4 \pi \rho_{0}\left(\frac{r^{3}}{3}-\frac{r^{5}}{5 R^{2}}\right) $$  $\Rightarrow E=4 \pi G \rho_{0}\left(\frac{r}{3}-\frac{r^{3}}{5 R^{2}}\right)$  $E$ is maximum when $\frac{d E}{d r}=0$  $\Rightarrow \frac{d E}{d r}=4 \pi G \rho_{0}\left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{3 r^{2}}{5 R^{2}}\right)=0$  $\Rightarrow r=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{3} R$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Consider two solid spheres of radii $R_{1}=1 m, R_{2}=2 m$ and masses $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$, respectively. The gravitational field due to sphere (1) and (2) are shown. The value of $\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}$ is:

$

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-119(5)}\\
solution: Gravitation field at the surface  $E=\frac{G m}{r^{2}}$  $\therefore E_{1}=\frac{G m_{1}}{r_{1}^{2}}$ and $E_{2}=\frac{G m_{2}}{r_{2}^{2}}$  From the diagram given in question,  $\frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}=\frac{2}{3}\left(r_{1}=1 \mathrm{~m}, R_{2}=2 m\right.$ given $)$  $\therefore \frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}=\left(\frac{r_{2}}{r_{1}}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}\right) \Rightarrow \frac{2}{3}=\left(\frac{2}{1}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}\right)$  $\Rightarrow\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{6}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An asteroid is moving directly towards the centre of the earth. When at a distance of $10 R(R$ is the radius of the earth) from the earths centre, it has a speed of $12 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}$. Neglecting the effect of earths atmosphere, what will be the speed of the asteroid when it hits the surface of the earth (escape velocity from the earth is $11.2 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}$ )? Give your answer to the nearest integer in kilometer/s

 }}$
solution: Using law of conservation of energy  Total energy at height $10 \mathrm{R}=$ total energy at earth  $$ -\frac{G M_{E} m}{10 R}+\frac{1}{2} m V_{0}^{2}=-\frac{G M_{E} m}{R}+\frac{1}{2} m V^{2} $$  $\left[\because\right.$ Gravitational potential energy $\left.=-\frac{G M m}{r}\right]$  $\Rightarrow \frac{G M_{E}}{R}\left(1-\frac{1}{10}\right)+\frac{V_{0}^{2}}{2}=\frac{V^{2}}{2}$  $\Rightarrow V^{2}=V_{0}^{2}+\frac{9}{5} g R$  $\Rightarrow V=\sqrt{V_{0}^{2}+\frac{9}{5} g R} \approx 16 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}$  $\left[\because \mathrm{V}_{0}=12 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\right.$ given $]$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A solid sphere of mass ' $M$ ' and radius ' $a$ ' is surrounded by a uniform concentric spherical shell of thickness 2a and mass 2 M . The gravitational field at distance ' 3 a ' from the centre will be:

\\

Four identical particles of mass M are located at the corners of a square of side ' $a$ '. What should be their speed if each of them revolves under the influence of others' gravitational field in a circular orbit circumscribing the square?



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-119(2)}\\
solution: $A C=a \sqrt{2} \quad \because r=\frac{A C}{2}=\frac{a \sqrt{2}}{2}=\frac{a}{\sqrt{2}}$   Resultant force on the body  $B=\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}} \hat{i}+\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}} \hat{j}+\frac{G M^{2}}{(a \sqrt{2})^{2}}\left(\cos 45^{\circ} \hat{i}+\sin 45^{\circ} \hat{j}\right)$ $\Rightarrow|F|=\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}}(\sqrt{2})+\frac{G M^{2}}{2 a^{2}}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-128}   $\frac{M v^{2}}{r}=$ Resultant force towards centre  $\therefore \frac{M v^{2}}{\left(\frac{a}{\sqrt{2}}\right)}=\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}}\left(\sqrt{2}+\frac{1}{2}\right)$  $\Rightarrow v^{2}=\frac{G M}{a}\left(1+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}\right)$  $\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{a}\left(1+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}\right)}=1.16 \sqrt{\frac{G M}{a}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A test particle is moving in circular orbit in the gravitational field produced by a mass density $r(r)=\frac{K}{r^{2}}$. Identify the correct relation between the radius R of the particle's orbit and its period T :

\\
solution: $F=\frac{G M m}{r}=\int a \frac{\rho(d V) m}{r^{2}}$  $=m G \int_{0}^{R} \frac{k}{r^{2}} \frac{4 \pi r^{2} d r}{r^{2}}$  $=-4 \pi k G m\left(\frac{1}{r}\right)_{0}^{R}$  $=-\frac{4 \pi k G m}{R}$  Using Newton's second law, we have  $\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{R}=\frac{4 \pi k G m}{R}$  or $v_{0}=\mathrm{C}$ (const.)  Time period, $T=\frac{2 \pi R}{v_{0}}=\frac{2 \pi R}{C}$  or $=\frac{T}{R}=$ constant.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A body of mass $m$ is moving in a circular orbit of radius $R$ about a planet of mass $M$. At some instant, it splits into two equal masses. The first mass moves in a circular orbit of radius $\frac{R}{2}$, and the other mass, in a circular orbit of radius $\frac{3 R}{2}$. The difference between the final and initial total energies is:

\\
solution: Initial gravitational potential energy, $E_{i}=-\frac{G M m}{2 R}$ Final gravitational potential energy,  $E_{f}=-\frac{G M m / 2}{2\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)}-\frac{G M m / 2}{2\left(\frac{3 R}{2}\right)}=-\frac{G M m}{2 R}-\frac{G M m}{6 R}$  $=-\frac{4 G M m}{6 R}=-\frac{2 G M m}{3 R}$  $\therefore$ Difference between initial and final energy,  $E_{f}-E_{i}=\frac{G M m}{R}\left(-\frac{2}{3}+\frac{1}{2}\right)=-\frac{G M m}{6 R}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
From a solid sphere of mass $M$ and radius $R$, a spherical portion of radius $R / 2$ is removed, as shown in the figure. Taking gravitational potential $\mathrm{V}=0$ at $\mathrm{r}=\infty$, the potential at the centre of the cavity thus formed is :

( $G=$ gravitational constant $)$



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-119(3)}\\
solution: Due to complete solid sphere, potential at point $P$  $\mathrm{V}_{\text {sphere }}=\frac{-\mathrm{GM}}{2 \mathrm{R}^{3}}\left[3 \mathrm{R}^{2}-\left(\frac{\mathrm{R}}{2}\right)^{2}\right]$  $=\frac{-\mathrm{GM}}{2 \mathrm{R}^{3}}\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{R}^{2}}{4}\right)=-11 \frac{\mathrm{GM}}{8 \mathrm{R}}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-129}   Due to cavity part potential at point $P$  $\mathrm{V}_{\text {cavity }}=-\frac{3}{2} \frac{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{8}}{\frac{R}{2}}=-\frac{3 \mathrm{GM}}{8 \mathrm{R}}$  So potential at the centre of cavity  $=V_{\text {sphere }}-V_{\text {cavity }}$  $=-\frac{11 \mathrm{GM}}{8 \mathrm{R}}-\left(-\frac{3}{8} \frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}}\right)=\frac{-\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The gravitational field in a region is given by $\vec{g}=5 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{kg} \hat{\mathrm{i}}+12 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{kg} \hat{j}$. The change in the gravitational potential energy of a particle of mass 1 kg when it is taken from the origin to a point $(7 \mathrm{~m},-3 \mathrm{~m})$ is:

\\
solution: Gravitational field, $I=(5 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+12 \hat{\mathrm{j}}) \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{kg}$  $I=-\frac{d v}{d r}$  $v=-\left[\int_{0}^{x} I_{x} d x+\int_{0}^{y} I_{y} d y\right]$  $=-\left[\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{x}} \cdot \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{y}} \cdot \mathrm{y}\right]$  $=-[5(7-0)+12(-3-0)]$  $=-[35+(-36)]=1 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg}$  i.e., change in gravitational potential $1 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg}$.  Hence change in gravitational potential energy 1 J  \begin{enumerate}

We choose reference point, infinity, where total energy of the system is zero.  So, initial energy of the system $=0$  Final energy $=\frac{1}{2} m_{1} v_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{2} v_{2}^{2}-\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{d}$  From conservation of energy,  Initial energy $=$ Final energy  $\therefore 0=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}_{2} \mathrm{v}_{2}^{2}-\frac{\mathrm{Gm}_{1} \mathrm{~m}_{2}}{\mathrm{~d}}$  or $\frac{1}{2} m_{1} v_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{1} v_{2}^{2}=\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{d}$\\ By conservation of linear momentum  $m_{1} v_{1}+m_{2} v_{2}=0$ or $\frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}=-\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}} \Rightarrow v_{2}=-\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}} v_{1}$  Putting value of $v_{2}$ in equation (1), we get  $\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{m}_{2}\left(-\frac{\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}}{\mathrm{~m}_{2}}\right)^{2}=\frac{2 \mathrm{Gm}_{1} \mathrm{~m}_{2}}{\mathrm{~d}}$  $\frac{\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{~m}_{2} \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{m}_{1}^{2} \mathrm{v}_{1}^{2}}{\mathrm{~m}_{2}}=\frac{2 \mathrm{Gm}_{1} \mathrm{~m}_{2}}{\mathrm{~d}}$  $v_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G m_{2}^{2}}{d\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}}=m_{2} \sqrt{\frac{2 G}{d\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}}$  Similarly $\mathrm{v}_{2}=-\mathrm{m}_{1} \sqrt{\frac{2 G}{d\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The gravitational field, due to the 'left over part' of a uniform sphere (from which a part as shown, has been 'removed out'), at a very far off point, P , located as shown, would be (nearly):



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-120(1)}\\
solution: Let mass of smaller sphere (which has tobe removed) is m  Radius $=\frac{\mathrm{R}}{2}$ (from figure)  $\frac{M}{\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}}=\frac{m}{\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{3}}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{m}=\frac{\mathrm{M}}{8}$  Mass of the left over part of the sphere  $M^{\prime}=M-\frac{M}{8}=\frac{7}{8} M$  Therefore gravitational field due to the left over part of the sphere  $=\frac{\mathrm{GM}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{x}^{2}}=\frac{7}{8} \frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{x}^{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The mass of a spaceship is 1000 kg . It is to be launched from the earth's surface out into free space. The value of $g$ and $R$ (radius of earth) are $10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ and 6400 km respectively. The required energy for this work will be

\\
solution: The work done to launch the spaceship  $W=-\int_{R}^{\infty} \vec{F} \cdot \overrightarrow{d r}=-\int_{R}^{\infty} \frac{G M m}{r^{2}} d r$  $W=+\frac{G M m}{R}$  The force of attraction of the earth on the spaceship, when it was on the earth's surface  $F=\frac{G M m}{R^{2}}$  $\Rightarrow m g=\frac{G M m}{R^{2}} \Rightarrow g=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}$  Substituting the value of $g$ in (i) we get  $W=\frac{g R^{2} m}{R}$  $\Rightarrow \quad W=m g R$  $\Rightarrow W=1000 \times 10 \times 6400 \times 10^{3}$  $=6.4 \times 10^{10}$ Joule  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A point particle is held on the axis of a ring of mass $m$ and radius $r$ at a distance $r$ from its centre $C$. When released, it reaches $C$ under the gravitational attraction of the ring. Its speed at $C$ will be

\\
solution: Let ' $M$ ' be the mass of the particle  Now, $\mathrm{E}_{\text {initial }}=\mathrm{E}_{\text {final }}$  i.e. $\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\sqrt{2} r}+0=\frac{\mathrm{GM} m}{r}+\frac{1}{2} M \mathrm{~V}^{2}$  or, $\frac{1}{2} M V^{2}=\frac{G M m}{r}\left[1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right]$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} V^{2}=\frac{G m}{r}\left[1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right]$  or, $V=\sqrt{\frac{2 G m}{r}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two bodies of masses $m$ and $4 m$ are placed at a distance $r$. The gravitational potential at a point on the line joining them where the gravitational field is zero is:

\\
solution: Let $P$ be the point where gravitational field is zero.  $\therefore \frac{G m}{x^{2}}=\frac{4 G m}{(r-x)^{2}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{x}=\frac{2}{r-x} \quad \Rightarrow r-x=2 x \quad \Rightarrow x=\frac{r}{3}$  $\xrightarrow[m]{P} \xrightarrow{m}$  $\xrightarrow[\text { Gravitational potential at }]{r} P$,  $V=-\frac{G m}{\frac{r}{3}}-\frac{4 G m}{\frac{2 r}{3}}=-\frac{9 G m}{r}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
This question contains Statement-1 and Statement-2. Of the four choices given after the statements, choose the one that best describes the two statements.



Statement-1 : For a mass $M$ kept at the centre of a cube of side ' $a$ ', the flux of gravitational field passing through its sides $4 \pi G M$. and

Statement-2: If the direction of a field due to a point source is radial and its dependence on the distance ' $r$ ' from the source is given as $\frac{1}{r^{2}}$, its flux through a closed surface depends only on the strength of the source enclosed by the surface and not on the size or shape of the surface.
options: a) Statement -1 is false, Statement-2 is true
b) Statement -1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is a correct explanation for Statement-1
c) Statement -1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement 2 is not a correct explanation for Statement-1
d) Statement -1 is true, Statement-2 is false
solution: Gravitational field, $E=-\frac{G M}{r^{2}}$  Flux, $\phi=\int \overrightarrow{E_{g}} \cdot \vec{d} S=\left|E \cdot 4 \pi r^{2}\right|=-4 \pi G M$  where, $M=$ mass enclosed in the closed surface  This relationship is valid when $\left|\vec{E}_{g}\right| \mu \frac{1}{r^{2}}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A particle of mass 10 g is kept on the surface of a uniform sphere of mass 100 kg and radius 10 cm . Find the work to be done against the gravitational force between them to take the particle far away from the sphere

(you may take $G=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}$ )

$[2005$\\
solution: Initial P.E. $U_{i}=-\frac{G M m}{R}$  When the particle is far away from the sphere, the P.E. of the system is zero.  $\therefore U_{f}=0$  $W=\Delta U=U_{f}-U_{i}=0-\left[\frac{-G M m}{R}\right]$  $W=\frac{6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 100}{0.1} \times \frac{10}{1000} \quad=6.67 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If ' $g$ ' is the acceleration due to gravity on the earth's surface, the gain in the potential energy of an object of mass ' $m$ ' raised from the surface of the earth to a height equal to the radius ' $R$ ' of the earth is

\\
solution: On earth's surface potential energy,  $U=\frac{G m M}{R}$  At a height $R$ from the earth's surface, $P . E$. of system $=$  $-\frac{G m M}{2 R}$  $\therefore \Delta U=\frac{-G m M}{2 R}+\frac{G m M}{R}$;  $\Rightarrow \Delta U=\frac{G m M}{2 R}$  Now $\frac{G M}{R^{2}}=g ; \therefore \frac{G M}{R}=g R \quad \therefore \Delta U=\frac{1}{2} m g R$\\

question:
Energy required to move a body of mass $m$ from an orbit of radius $2 R$ to $3 R$ is

\\
solution: Gravitational potential energy of mass $m$ in an orbit of radius R  $u=-\frac{G M m}{R}$  Energy required $=$ potential energy at $3 \mathrm{R}-$ potential energy a 2R  $=\frac{-G M m}{3 R}-\left(\frac{-G M m}{2 R}\right)$  $=\frac{-G M m}{3 R}+\frac{G M m}{2 R}$  $=\frac{-2 G M m+3 G M m}{6 R}=\frac{G M m}{6 R}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A satellite is in an elliptical orbit around a planet P. It is observed that the velocity of the satellite when it is farthest from the planet is 6 times less than that when it is closest to the planet. The ratio of distances between the satellite and the planet at closest and farthest points is :

\\
solution: By angular momentum conservation  $r_{\min } v_{\max }=m r_{\max } v_{\min }$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-130}   Given, $v_{\min }=\frac{v_{\max }}{6}$  $\therefore \frac{r_{\text {min }}}{r_{\text {max }}}=\frac{v_{\text {min }}}{v_{\text {max }}}=\frac{1}{6}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A body is moving in a low circular orbit about a planet of mass $M$ and radius $R$. The radius of the orbit can be taken to be $R$ itself. Then the ratio of the speed of this body in the orbit to the escape velocity from the planet is :\\





$
solution: Orbital speed of the body when it revolves very close to the surface of planet   \begin{equation*} V_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}} \tag{i} \end{equation*}   Here, $G=$ gravitational constant  Escape speed from the surface of planet   \begin{equation*} V_{e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}} \tag{ii} \end{equation*}   Dividing (i) by (ii), we have   \begin{equation*} \frac{V_{0}}{V_{e}}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}}}{\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \tag{c} \end{equation*}

question:
A satellite is moving in a low nearly circular orbit around the earth. Its radius is roughly equal to that of the earth's radius $R_{e}$. By firing rockets attached to it, its speed is instantaneously increased in the direction of its motion so that it become $\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}}$ times larger. Due to this the farthest distance from the centre of the earth that the satellite reaches is $R$. Value of $R$ is :

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-130}   Orbital velocity, $V_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R_{e}}}$  From energy conversation,  $-\frac{G M m}{R_{e}}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} V\right)^{2}=\frac{G M m}{R_{\max }}+\frac{1}{2} m V_{\min }^{2}$  From angular momentum conversation   \begin{equation*} \sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} V R_{e}=V_{\min } R_{\max } \tag{2} \end{equation*}   Solving equation (1) and (2) we get,  $$ R_{\max }=3 R_{e} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The mass density of a spherical galaxy varies as $\frac{K}{r}$ over a large distance ' $r$ ' from its centre. In that region, a small star is in a circular orbit of radius $R$. Then the period of revolution, $T$ depends on $R$ as :

\\


$T^{2} \propto \frac{1}{R^{3}}$\\
solution: According to question, mass density of a spherical galaxy varies as $\frac{k}{r}$.  Mass, $M=\int \rho d V$  $\Rightarrow M=\int_{0}^{r=R_{0}} \frac{k}{r} 4 \pi r^{2} d r$  $\Rightarrow M=4 \pi k \int_{0}^{R_{0}} r d r$  or, $M=\frac{4 \pi k R_{0}^{2}}{2}=2 \pi k R^{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-131(1)}   $F_{G}=\frac{G M m}{R_{0}^{2}}=m \omega_{0}^{2} R\left(=F_{C}\right)$  $\Rightarrow \frac{G \frac{4 \pi k R^{2}}{2}}{R^{2}}=\omega_{0}^{2} R \Rightarrow \omega_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi K G}{R}} \quad\left(\because \omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right)$  $\therefore T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{0}}=\frac{2 \pi \sqrt{R}}{\sqrt{2 \pi K G}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi R}{K G}} \Rightarrow T^{2}=\frac{2 \pi R}{K G}$  $\because 2 \pi, K$ and $G$ are constants  $\therefore T^{2} \propto R$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A body A of mass $m$ is moving in a circular orbit of radius R about a planet. Another body B of mass $\frac{m}{2}$ collides with A with a velocity which is half $\left(\frac{\vec{v}}{2}\right)$ the instantaneous velocity $\vec{v}$ or A. The collision is completely inelastic. Then, the combined body:

$$
options: a) continues to move in a circular orbit
b) Escapes from the Planet's Gravitational field
c) Falls vertically downwards towards the planet
d) starts moving in an elliptical orbit around the planet
solution: From law of conservation of momentum, $\vec{p}_{i}=\vec{p}_{f}$  $$ \begin{aligned} & m_{1} u_{1}+m_{2} u_{2}=M V_{f} \\ & \Rightarrow v_{f}=\frac{\left(m v+\frac{m v}{4}\right)}{\frac{3 m}{2}}=\frac{5 v}{6} \end{aligned} $$  Clearly, $v_{f}<v_{i} \therefore$ Path will be elliptical  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The energy required to take a satellite to a height ' $h$ ' above Earth surface (radius of Eareth $=6.4 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~km}$ ) is $\mathrm{E}_{1}$ and kinetic energy required for the satellite to be in a circular orbit at this height is $\mathrm{E}_{2}$. The value of $h$ for which $\mathrm{E}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{E}_{2}$ are equal, is:

\\
solution: K.E. of satellite is zero at earth surface and at height h from energy conservation  $$ \mathrm{U}_{\text {surface }}+\mathrm{E}_{1}=\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{h}} $$  $$ \begin{aligned} -\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}+\mathrm{E}_{1}=-\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{(\mathrm{Re}+\mathrm{h})} \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{E}_{1}=\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}}\right) \Rightarrow \mathrm{E}_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}\right)} \times \frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}} \end{aligned} $$  Gravitational attraction  $F_{G}=m a_{c}=\frac{m v^{2}}{\left(R_{e}+h\right)}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}\right)^{2}}$  $\mathrm{mv}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}\right)}$  $\mathrm{E}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{2\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}+\mathrm{h}\right)}$  $\mathrm{E}_{1}=\mathrm{E}_{2}$  Clearly, $\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}=\frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow \mathrm{h}=\frac{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}{2}=3200 \mathrm{~km}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Planet $A$ has mass $M$ and radius $R$. Planet $B$ has half the mass and half the radius of Planet A . If the escape velocities from the Planets A and B are $v_{\mathrm{A}}$ and $v_{\mathrm{B}}$, respectively, then $\frac{v_{\mathrm{A}}}{v_{\mathrm{B}}}=\frac{n}{4}$. The value of $n$ is :

\\
solution: Escape velocity of the planet $A$ is $V_{A}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M_{A}}{R_{A}}}$ where $M_{A}$ and $R_{A}$ be the mass and radius of the planet A.  According to given problem  $M_{B}=\frac{M_{A}}{2}, R_{B}=\frac{R_{A}}{2}$  $\therefore V_{B}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G \frac{M_{A}}{2}}{\frac{R_{A}}{2}}} \therefore \frac{V_{A}}{V_{B}}=\sqrt{\frac{\frac{2 G M_{A}}{R_{A}}}{\frac{2 G M_{A} / 2}{R_{A} / 2}}}=\frac{n}{4}=1$  $\Rightarrow n=4$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A satellite of mass $m$ is launched vertically upwards with an initial speed $u$ from the surface of the earth. After it reaches height $R(R=$ radius of the earth), it ejects a rocket of mass $\frac{m}{10}$ so that subsequently the satellite moves in a circular orbit. The kinetic energy of the rocket is ( $G$ is the gravitational constant; $M$ is the mass of the earth):

\\
solution: $\square$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-131}   $\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}+\frac{-G M m}{R}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{-G M m}{2 R}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m\left(v^{2}-u^{2}\right)=\frac{-G M m}{2 R}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{V}=\sqrt{\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{u}^{2}-\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{R}}}$  $v_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{2 R}} \quad \therefore v_{\text {rad }}=\frac{m \times v}{\left(\frac{m}{10}\right)}=10 v$  Ejecting a rocket of mass $\frac{m}{10}$  $\therefore \frac{9 m}{10} \times \sqrt{\frac{G M}{2 R}}=\frac{m}{10} \times v_{\tau} \Rightarrow V_{\tau}^{2}=81 \frac{G M}{2 R}$  Kinetic energy of rocket,  $$ \begin{aligned} & \mathrm{KE}_{\text {rocket }}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{M}{10}\left(V_{T}^{2}+V_{r}^{2}\right) \\ & =\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{m}{10} \times\left(\left(u^{2}-\frac{G M}{R}\right) 100+81 \frac{G M}{R}\right) \\ & \quad=\frac{m}{20} \times 100\left(u^{2}-\frac{G M}{R}+\frac{81}{200} \frac{G M}{R}\right) \end{aligned} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-132}   $$ =5 m\left(u^{2}-\frac{119}{200} \frac{G M}{R}\right) $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A spaceship orbits around a planet at a height of 20 km from its surface. Assuming that only gravitational field of the planet acts on the spaceship, what will be the number of complete revolutions made by the spaceship in 24 hours around the planet? $

[10 April 2019 II]\\
reference: Given : Mass of Planet $=8 \times 10^{22} \mathrm{~kg}$, Radius of planet $=2 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}$, Gravitational constant $\left.\mathrm{G}=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}\right
solution: Time period of revolution of satellite,  $T=\frac{2 \pi r}{v}$  $v=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{r}}$  $\therefore T=2 \pi r \sqrt{\frac{r}{G M}}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{r^{3}}{G M}}$  Substituting the values, we get  $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{(202)^{3} \times 10^{12}}{6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 8 \times 10^{22}}} \mathrm{sec}$  $\mathrm{T}=7812.2 \mathrm{~s}$  $\mathrm{T} \simeq 2.17 \mathrm{hr} \Rightarrow 11$ revolutions.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A rocket has to be launched from earth in such a way that it never returns. If E is the minimum energy delivered by the rocket launcher, what should be the minimum energy that the launcher should have if the same rocket is to be launched from the surface of the moon? Assume that the density of the earth and the moon are equal and that the earth's volume is 64 times the volume of the moon.

\\
solution: Escape velocity,  $v_{c}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G \rho V}{R}}$  $=\sqrt{\frac{2 G S \times 4 \pi R^{3}}{R}}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi \rho G R^{2}}$  For moon, $v_{c}^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi \rho G R_{m}^{2}}$  Given, $\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}=64 \times \frac{4}{3} \pi R_{m}^{3}$ or $R_{m}=\frac{R}{4}$  $\therefore \quad v_{e}^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi \rho G\left(\frac{R}{4}\right)^{2}}=\frac{v_{c}}{4}$  $\frac{E}{E^{\prime}}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} m v_{e}^{2}}{\frac{1}{2} m v_{e}^{\prime 2}}=\frac{v_{e}^{2}}{v_{c}^{\prime 2}}=\frac{v_{e}}{\left(\frac{v_{e}}{4}\right)}=16$ or $E^{\prime}=\frac{E}{16}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A satellite of mass M is in a circular orbit of radius R about the centre of the earth. A meteorite of the same mass, falling towards the earth collides with the satellite completely in elastically. The speeds of the satellite and the meteorite are the same, Just before the collision. The subsequent motion of the combined body will be

$\\
options: a) such that it escape to infinity
c) in the same circular orbit of radius R
d) in a circular orbit of a different radius
solution: $\mathrm{mvv} \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\mathrm{mv \hat {j }}=2 \mathrm{~m} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{v}}$  $$ \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \vec{v} & =\frac{v}{2} \hat{i}+\frac{v}{2} \hat{j} \\ \Rightarrow \vec{v} & =\sqrt{\left(\frac{v}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{v}{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{v}{\sqrt{2}} \\ & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \times \sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}} \end{aligned} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-132(1)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two satellites, A and B , have masses m and 2 m respectively. $A$ is in a circular orbit of radius $R$, and $B$ is in a circular orbit of radius 2 R around the earth. The ratio of their kinetic energies, $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{A}} / \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{B}}$, is :

\\
solution: Orbital, velocity, $v=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{r}}}$  Kinetic energy of satellite A ,  $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{A}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}_{\mathrm{A}} \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}$  Kinetic energy of satellite B,  $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{B}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}_{\mathrm{B}} \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{T_{A}}{T_{B}}=\frac{m \times \frac{G M}{R}}{2 \mathrm{~m} \times \frac{G M}{2 R}}=1$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A satellite is revolving in a circular orbit at a height $h$ from the earth surface, such that $\mathrm{h}<<\mathrm{R}$ where R is the radius of the earth. Assuming that the effect of earth's atmosphere can be neglected the minimum increase in the speed required so that the satellite could escape from the gravitational field of earth is:

\\
solution: For a satellite orbiting close to the earth, orbital velocity is given by  $v_{0}=\sqrt{g(R+h)} \approx \sqrt{g R}$  Escape velocity $\left(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{e}}\right)$ is  $\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{e}}=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{~g}(\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{h})} \approx \sqrt{2 \mathrm{gR}} \quad[\because \mathrm{h}<<\mathrm{R}]$  $\Delta v=v_{e}-v_{0}=(\sqrt{2}-1) \sqrt{g R}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A satellite is moving with a constant speed $v$ in circular orbit around the earth. An object of mass ' $m$ ' is ejected from the satellite such that it just escapes from the gravitational pull of the earth. At the time of ejection, the kinetic energy of the object is:

\\
solution: At height $r$ from center of earth, orbital velocity  $v=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{r}}$  By principle of energy conservation  KE of ' m ' $+\left(-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{r}}\right)=0+0$  $(\because$ At infinity, $\mathrm{PE}=\mathrm{KE}=0)$  or KE of ' m ' $=\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{r}}=\left(\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{r}}}\right)^{2} \mathrm{~m}=\mathrm{mv}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two stars of masses $3 \times 10^{31} \mathrm{~kg}$ each, and at distance $2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~m}$ rotate in a plane about their common centre of mass O. A meteorite passes through O moving perpen-dicular to the star's rotation plane. In order to escape from the gravitational field of this double star, the minimum speed that meteorite should have at O is: (Take Gravitational constant $\mathrm{G}=66 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-2}$ )

\\
solution: Let $M$ is mass of star $m$ is mass of meteroite By energy convervation between 0 and $\infty$.  $-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{r}}+\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{r}}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mV}_{\mathrm{ssc}}^{2}=0+0$  $\therefore v=\sqrt{\frac{4 \mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{r}}}=\sqrt{\frac{4 \times 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 3 \times 10^{31}}{10^{11}}}$  $\simeq 2.8 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A satellite is revolving in a circular orbit at a height ' $h$ ' from the earth's surface (radius of earth $\mathrm{R} ; \mathrm{h}<<\mathrm{R}$ ). The minimum increase in its orbital velocity required, so that the satellite could escape from the earth's gravitational field, is close to : (Neglect the effect of atmosphere.)

\\
solution: For $h \ll R$, the orbital velocity is $\sqrt{g R}$  Escape velocity $=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{gR}}$  $\therefore$ The minimum increase in its orbital velocity  $=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{gR}}-\sqrt{\mathrm{gR}}=\sqrt{\mathrm{gR}}(\sqrt{2}-1)$  \begin{enumerate}

question: An astronaut of mass $m$ is working on a satellite orbiting the earth at a distance $h$ from the earth's surface. The radius of the earth is R , while its mass is M . The gravitational pull $\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{G}}$ on the astronaut is :
options: a) Zero since astronaut feels weightless
solution: According to universal law of Gravitation,  $$ \text { Gravitational force } \mathrm{F}=\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{(\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{h})^{2}} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_3ebc049d6ebe7ae4b29dg-133}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
A very long (length L) cylindrical galaxy is made of uniformly distributed mass and has radius $\mathrm{R}(\mathrm{R}<<\mathrm{L})$. A star outside the galaxy is orbiting the galaxy in a plane perpendicular to the galaxy and passing through its centre. If the time period of star is T and its distance from the galaxy's axis is $r$, then :

\\
solution: $F=\frac{2 G M}{L r} m$ or, $\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=\frac{2 G M}{L r} m$ $m r\left(\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right)^{2}=\frac{2 G M m}{L r}\left[\because v=r \omega\right.$ and $\left.\omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right]$  $\Rightarrow \quad T \propto r$  \begin{enumerate}

question: What is the minimum energy required to launch a satellite of mass $m$ from the surface of a planet of mass $M$ and radius R in a circular orbit at an altitude of 2 R ? \\
solution: As we know,  Gravitational potential energy $=\frac{-G M m}{r}$ and orbital velocity, $v_{0}=\sqrt{\mathrm{GM} / \mathrm{R}+\mathrm{h}}$  $$ \begin{aligned} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{f}} & =\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{0}^{2}-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{3 \mathrm{R}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m} \frac{\mathrm{GM}}{3 \mathrm{R}}-\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{3 \mathrm{R}} \\ & =\frac{\mathrm{GMm}}{3 \mathrm{R}}\left(\frac{1}{2}-1\right)=\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{6 \mathrm{R}} \end{aligned} $$  $\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{i}}=\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{\mathrm{R}}+\mathrm{K}$  $E_{i}=E_{f}$  Therefore minimum required energy, $\mathrm{K}=\frac{5 \mathrm{GMm}}{6 \mathrm{R}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A planet in a distant solar system is 10 times more massive than the earth and its radius is 10 times smaller. Given that the escape velocity from the earth is $11 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$, the escape velocity from the surface of the planet would be


\\
solution: Escape velocity on earth,  $$ v_{e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M_{e}}{R_{e}}}=11 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} $$  $\therefore \frac{\left(v_{e}\right)_{p}}{\left(v_{e}\right)_{e}}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{2 G M_{p}}{R_{p}}}}{\sqrt{\frac{2 G M_{e}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}}}=\sqrt{\frac{M_{p}}{M_{e}} \times \frac{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}{R_{p}}}$  $=\sqrt{\frac{10 M_{e}}{M_{e}} \times \frac{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}}}{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}} / 10}}=10$  $\therefore\left(v_{e}\right)_{p}=10 \times\left(v_{e}\right)_{e}=10 \times 11=110 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}$\\

question: Suppose the gravitational force varies inversely as the nth power of distance. Then the time period of a planet in circular orbit of radius ' $R$ ' around the sun will be proportional to\\
solution: Gravitational force, $F=K R^{-n}$  This force provides the centripetal force $M R \omega^{2}$ to the planet at height $h$ above earth's surface.  $\therefore \quad F=K R^{-n}=M R \omega^{2}$  $\stackrel{\Rightarrow}{\Rightarrow} \omega^{2}=K R^{-(n+1)}$  $\Rightarrow \omega=K R^{\frac{-(n+1)}{2}}$  $\frac{2 \pi}{T} \propto R^{\frac{-(n+1)}{2}}$  $\therefore T \propto R^{\frac{+(n+1)}{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: The time period of an earth satellite in circular orbit is independent of
options: a) both the mass and radius of the orbit
c) the mass of the satellite
d) neither the mass of the satellite nor the radius of its orbit.
solution: Time period of satellite is given by  $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{(R+h)^{3}}{G M}}$  Where $R+h=$ radius of orbit of satellite  $M=$ mass of earth.  Time period is independent of mass of satellite.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A satellite of mass $m$ revolves around the earth of radius $R$ at a height $x$ from its surface. If $g$ is the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the earth, the orbital speed of the satellite is

\\
solution: Gravitational force provides the necessary centripetal force.  $\therefore$ Centripetal force on a satellite $=$ Gravitational force  $\therefore \quad \frac{m v^{2}}{(R+x)}=\frac{G m M}{(R+x)^{2}}$ also $g=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}$  $\therefore \frac{m v^{2}}{(R+x)}=m\left(\frac{G M}{R^{2}}\right) \frac{R^{2}}{(R+x)^{2}} \frac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$  $\therefore \frac{m v^{2}}{(R+x)}=m g \frac{R^{2}}{(R+x)^{2}}$  $\therefore v^{2}=\frac{g R^{2}}{R+x} \Rightarrow v=\left(\frac{g R^{2}}{R+x}\right)^{1 / 2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The escape velocity for a body projected vertically upwards from the surface of earth is $11 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}$. If the body is projected at an angle of $45^{\circ}$ with the vertical, the escape velocity will be

\\
solution: $v_{e}=\sqrt{2 g R}$  Clearly escape velocity does not depend on the angle at which the body is projected.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The kinetic energy needed to project a body of mass $m$ from the earth surface (radius $R$ ) to infinity is

\\
solution: $K . E=\frac{1}{2} m v_{e}^{2}$  Here $v_{e}=$ escape velocity is independent of mass of the body  Escape velocity, $v_{e}=\sqrt{2 g R}$  Substituting value of $v_{e}$ in above equation we get  $K . E=\frac{1}{2} m \times 2 g R=m g R$  \begin{enumerate}

question: If suddenly the gravitational force of attraction between Earth and a satellite revolving around it becomes zero, then the satellite will
options: a) continue to move in its orbit with same velocity
b) move tangentially to the original orbit in the same velocity
c) become stationary in its orbit
solution: Due to inertia of motion it will move tangentially to the original orbit with the same velocity.

question:
The escape velocity of a body depends upon mass as

\\
solution: Escape velocity, $v_{e}=\sqrt{2 g R}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}$   $\Rightarrow v_{e} \propto m^{0}$  Where $M, R$ are the mass and radius of the planet respectively. Clearly, escape velocity is independent of mass of the body   \end{document}

question: If the potential energy between two molecules is given by $U=-\frac{A}{r^{6}}+\frac{B}{r^{12}}$, then at equilibrium, separation between molecules, and the potential energy are: \\
solution: Given : $U=\frac{-A}{r^{6}}+\frac{B}{r^{12}}$   For equilibrium,  $F=\frac{d U}{d r}=-\left(A\left(-6 r^{-7}\right)\right)+B\left(-12 r^{-13}\right)=0$  $\Rightarrow 0=\frac{6 A}{r^{7}}-\frac{12 B}{r^{13}} \Rightarrow \frac{6 A}{12 B}=\frac{1}{r^{6}}$  $\therefore$ Separation between molecules, $r=\left(\frac{2 B}{A}\right)^{1 / 6}$  Potential energy,  $$ \begin{aligned} U\left(r=\left(\frac{2 B}{A}\right)^{1 / 6}\right) & =-\frac{A}{2 B / A}+\frac{B}{4 B^{2} / A^{2}} \\ & =\frac{-A^{2}}{2 B}+\frac{A^{2}}{4 B}=\frac{-A^{2}}{4 B} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A body of mass $\mathrm{m}=10 \mathrm{~kg}$ is attached to one end of a wire of length 0.3 m . The maximum angular speed (in $\mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1}$ ) with which it can be rotated about its other end in space station is (Breaking stress of wire $=4.8 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$ and area of crosssection of the wire $=10^{-2} \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$ ) is $\qquad$\\
solution: Given : Wire length, $l=3 \mathrm{~m}$  Mass of the body, $\mathrm{m}=10 \mathrm{~kg}$  Breaking stress, $\sigma=4.8 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$  Area of cross-section, $\mathrm{a}=10^{-2} \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$  Maximum angular speed $\omega=$ ?  $\mathrm{T}=\mathrm{M} l \omega^{2}$  $$ \begin{aligned} & \sigma=\frac{T}{A}=\frac{m l \omega^{2}}{A} \\ & \frac{m l \omega^{2}}{A} \leq 48 \times 10^{7} \Rightarrow \omega^{2} \leq \frac{\left(48 \times 10^{7}\right) A}{m l} \\ & \Rightarrow \omega^{2} \leq \frac{\left(48 \times 10^{7}\right)\left(10^{-6}\right)}{10 \times 3}=16 \Rightarrow \omega_{\max }=4 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A uniform cylindrical rod of length L and radius $r$, is made from a material whose Young's modulus of Elasticity equals Y . When this rod is heated by temperature T and simultaneously subjected to a net longitudinal compressional force F , its length remains unchanged. The coefficient of volume expansion, of the material of the rod, is (nearly) equal to :


\\
solution: $\Delta_{\text {temp }}=\Delta_{\text {force }}$  $$ \text { or } \quad L \alpha(\Delta T)=\frac{F L}{A Y} \quad \therefore \quad \alpha=\frac{F L}{A Y T}=\frac{F}{\pi r^{2} Y T} $$  Coefficient of volume expression  $$ r=3 \alpha=\frac{3 F}{\pi r^{2} Y T} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
In an environment, brass and steel wires of length 1 m each with areas of cross section $1 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$ are used. The wires are connected in series and one end of the combined wire is connected to a rigid support and other end is subjected to elongation. The stress required to produce a net elongation of 0.2 mm is,



[10 April 2019 II]\\
reference: Given, the Young's modulus for steel and brass are, respectively, $120 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ and $60 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-4}   Young modulus, $Y=\frac{\text { Stress }}{\left(\frac{\Delta l}{L}\right)}$  Let $\sigma$ be the stress  Total elongation $\Delta l_{\text {net }}=\frac{\sigma L_{1}}{Y_{1}}+\frac{\sigma L_{2}}{Y_{2}}$  $\Delta l_{\text {net }}=\sigma\left[\frac{1}{Y_{1}}+\frac{1}{Y_{2}}\right] \quad\left[\because L_{1}=L_{2}=1 \mathrm{~m}\right]$  $\sigma=\Delta l\left(\frac{Y_{1} Y_{2}}{Y_{1}+Y_{2}}\right)$  $=0.2 \times 10^{-3} \times\left(\frac{120 \times 60}{180}\right) \times 10^{9}=8 \times 10^{6} \frac{\mathrm{N}}{\mathrm{m}^{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The elastic limit of brass is 379 MPa . What should be the minimum diameter of a brass rod if it is to support a 400 N load without exceeding its elastic limit?

\\
solution: Stress $=\frac{F}{A}=\frac{400 \times 4}{\pi d^{2}}=379 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$  $\Rightarrow d^{2}=\frac{400 \times 4}{379 \times 10^{6} \pi}$  $d=1.15 \mathrm{~mm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A steel wire having a radius of 2.0 mm , carrying a load of 4 kg , is hanging from a ceiling. Given that $\mathrm{g}=3.1 \mathrm{À} \mathrm{ms}^{-2}$, what will be the tensile stress that would be developed in the wire?

\\
solution: Given,  Radius of wire, $r=2 \mathrm{~mm}$  Mass of the load $\mathrm{m}=4 \mathrm{~kg}$  Stress $=\frac{F}{A}=\frac{m g}{\pi(r)^{2}}$  $=\frac{4 \times 3.1 \pi}{\pi \times\left(2 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{2}}=3.1 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A steel wire having a radius of 2.0 mm , carrying a load of 4 kg , is hanging from a ceiling. Given that $\mathrm{g}=3.1 \mathrm{Ams}^{-2}$, what will be the tensile stress that would be developed in the wire?

\\
solution: Given,  Radius of wire, $r=2 \mathrm{~mm}$  Mass of the load $\mathrm{m}=4 \mathrm{~kg}$  Stress $=\frac{F}{A}=\frac{m g}{\pi(r)^{2}}=\frac{4 \times 3.1 \pi}{\pi \times\left(2 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{2}}=3.1 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Young's moduli of two wires A and B are in the ratio $7: 4$. Wire A is 2 m long and has radius R . Wire B is 1.5 m long and has radius 2 mm . If the two wires stretch by the same length for a given load, then the value of R is close to :

\\
solution: $\Delta_{1}=\Delta_{2}$  or $\frac{F l_{1}}{\pi r_{1}^{2} y_{1}}=\frac{F l_{2}}{\pi r_{2}^{2} y_{2}}$ or $\frac{2}{R^{2} \times 7}=\frac{1.5}{2^{2} \times 4}$  $\therefore R=1.75 \mathrm{~mm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
As shown in the figure, forces of $10^{5} \mathrm{~N}$ each are applied in opposite directions, on the upper and lower faces of a cube of side 10 cm , shifting the upper face parallel to itself by 0.5 cm . If the side of another cube of the same material is, 20 cm , then under similar conditions as above, the displacement will be:



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-1}\\
solution: For same material the ratio of stress to strain is same For first cube  $$ \text { Stress }_{1}=\frac{\text { force }_{1}}{\text { area }_{1}}=\frac{10^{5}}{\left(0.1^{2}\right)} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-5}   For second block,  stress $_{2}=\frac{\text { force }_{2}}{\text { area }_{2}}=\frac{10^{5}}{\left(0.2^{2}\right)}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-5(2)}   $x$ is the displacement for second block.  For same material, $\frac{\text { stress }_{1}}{\text { strain }_{1}}=\frac{\text { stress }_{2}}{\text { strain }_{2}}$  or, $\frac{\frac{10.5}{(0.1)^{2}}}{\frac{0.5 \times 10^{-2}}{0.1}}=\frac{\frac{10^{5}}{(0.2)^{2}}}{\frac{x}{0.2}}$  Solving we get, $x=0.25 \mathrm{~cm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A thin 1 m long rod has a radius of 5 mm . A force of $50 \pi \mathrm{kN}$ is applied at one end to determine its Young's modulus. Assume that the force is exactly known. If the least count in the measurement of all lengths is 0.01 mm , which of the following statements is false ?
options: a) The maximum value of Y that can be determined is $2 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$.
b) $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{Y}}{\mathrm{Y}}$ gets minimum contribution from the uncertainty in the length
c) $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{Y}}{\mathrm{Y}}$ gets its maximum contribution from the uncertainty in strain
d) The figure of merit is the largest for the length of the rod.
solution: Young's modulus $\mathrm{Y}=\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{A}} / \frac{\Delta \ell}{\ell}$  $\mathrm{Y}=\frac{\mathrm{F} \ell}{\pi \mathrm{r}^{2} \Delta \ell}$  Given, radius $\mathrm{r}=5 \mathrm{~mm}$, force $\mathrm{F}=50 \pi \mathrm{kN}$,  $\frac{\ell}{\Delta \ell}=0.01 \mathrm{~mm}$  $\therefore \mathrm{Y}=\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\pi \mathrm{r}^{2}} \frac{\ell}{\Delta \ell}=2 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: A uniformly tapering conical wire is made from a material of Young's modulus Y and has a normal, unextended length L . The radii, at the upper and lower ends of this conical wire, have values $R$ and 3 R , respectively. The upper end of the wire is fixed to a rigid support and a mass $M$ is suspended from its lower end. The equilibrium extended length, of this wire, would equal : \\
solution: Consider a small element dx of radius r , $r=\frac{2 R}{L} x+R$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-5(1)}   At equilibrium change in length of the wire  $$ \int_{0}^{1} \mathrm{dL}=\int \frac{\mathrm{Mgdx}}{\pi\left[\frac{2 \mathrm{R}}{\mathrm{L}} \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{R}\right]^{2} \mathrm{y}} $$  Taking limit from 0 to L  $\Delta \mathrm{L}=\frac{\mathrm{Mg}}{\pi \mathrm{y}}\left[-\frac{1}{\left[\frac{2 \mathrm{Rx}}{\mathrm{L}}+\mathrm{R}\right]_{0}^{\mathrm{L}}} \times \frac{\mathrm{L}}{2 \mathrm{R}}\right]=\frac{\mathrm{MgL}}{3 \pi \mathrm{R}^{2} \mathrm{y}}$  The equilibrium extended length of wire $=\mathrm{L}+\Delta \mathrm{L}$  $=\mathrm{L}+\frac{\mathrm{MgL}}{3 \pi \mathrm{R}^{2} \mathrm{Y}}=\mathrm{L}\left(1+\frac{1}{3} \frac{\mathrm{Mg}}{\pi \mathrm{YR}^{2}}\right)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The pressure that has to be applied to the ends of a steel wire of length 10 cm to keep its length constant when its temperature is raised by $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is:


(For steel Young's modulus is $2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$ and coefficient of thermal expansion is $1.1 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$ )

\\
solution: Young's modulus $Y=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}$  stress $=\mathrm{Y} \times$ strain  Stress in steel wire $=$ Applied pressure  Pressure $=$ stress $=\mathrm{Y} \times$ strain  Strain $=\frac{\Delta L}{L}=\alpha \Delta T$  (As length is constant)  $=2 \times 10^{11} \times 1.1 \times 10^{-5} \times 100=2.2 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~Pa}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two blocks of masses m and M are connected by means of a metal wire of cross-sectional area A passing over a frictionless fixed pulley as shown in the figure. The system is then released. If $\mathrm{M}=2 \mathrm{~m}$, then the stress produced in the wire is :



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-2}\\
solution: Tension in the wire, $T=\left(\frac{2 \mathrm{mM}}{\mathrm{m}+\mathrm{M}}\right) \mathrm{g}$  Stress $=\frac{\text { Force } / \text { Tension }}{\text { Area }}=\frac{2 \mathrm{mM}}{\mathrm{A}(\mathrm{m}+\mathrm{M})} \mathrm{g}$  $=\frac{2(\mathrm{~m} \times 2 \mathrm{~m}) \mathrm{g}}{\mathrm{A}(\mathrm{m}+2 \mathrm{~m})} \quad(\mathrm{M}=2 \mathrm{~m}$ given $)$  $=\frac{4 \mathrm{~m}^{2}}{3 \mathrm{~mA}} \mathrm{~g}=\frac{4 \mathrm{mg}}{3 \mathrm{~A}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A copper wire of length 1.0 m and a steel wire of length 0.5 m having equal cross-sectional areas are joined end to end. The composite wire is stretched by a certain load which stretches the copper wire by 1 mm . If the Young's modulii of copper and steel are respectively $1.0 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{Nm}^{-}$ ${ }^{2}$ and $2.0 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$, the total extension of the composite wire is :

\\
solution: $\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{c}} \times\left(\Delta \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{c}} / \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{c}}\right)=\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{s}} \times\left(\Delta \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{s}} / \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{s}}\right)$  $\Rightarrow 1 \times 10^{11} \times\left(\frac{1 \times 10^{-3}}{1}\right)=2 \times 10^{11} \times\left(\frac{\Delta \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{s}}}{0.5}\right)$  $\therefore \Delta \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{s}}=\frac{0.5 \times 10^{-3}}{2}=0.25 \mathrm{~mm}$  Therefore, total extension of the composite wire  $=\Delta \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{c}}+\Delta \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{s}}$  $=1 \mathrm{~mm}+0.25 \mathrm{~m}=1.25 \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A uniform wire (Young's modulus $2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$ ) is subjected to longitudinal tensile stress of $5 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$. If the overall volume change in the wire is $0.02 \%$, the fractional decrease in the radius of the wire is close to\\
solution: Given, $\mathrm{y}=2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$  $\operatorname{Stress}\left(\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{A}}\right)=5 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$  $\Delta \mathrm{V}=0.02 \%=2 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}^{3}$  $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{r}}{\mathrm{r}}=$ ?  $\gamma=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }} \Rightarrow \operatorname{strain}\left(\frac{\Delta \ell}{\ell_{0}}\right)=\frac{\gamma}{\text { stress }}$  $\Delta \mathrm{V}=2 \pi \mathrm{r} \ell_{0} \Delta \mathrm{r}-\pi \mathrm{r}^{2} \Delta \ell$  From eqns (i) and (ii) putting the value of $\Delta \ell, \ell_{0}$ and $\Delta \mathrm{V}$ and solving we get  $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{r}}{\mathrm{r}}=0.25 \times 10^{-4}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If the ratio of lengths, radii and Young's moduli of steel and brass wires in the figure are $a, b$ and $c$ respectively, then the corresponding ratio of increase in their lengths is :



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-2(2)}\\
solution: According to questions,  $\frac{\ell_{\mathrm{s}}}{\ell_{\mathrm{b}}}=\mathrm{a}, \frac{\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{s}}}{\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{b}}}=\mathrm{b}, \frac{\mathrm{y}_{\mathrm{s}}}{\mathrm{y}_{\mathrm{b}}}=\mathrm{c}, \frac{\Delta \ell \mathrm{s}}{\Delta \ell_{\mathrm{b}}}=$ ?  As, $\mathrm{y}=\frac{\mathrm{F} \ell}{\mathrm{A} \Delta \ell} \Rightarrow \Delta \ell=\frac{\mathrm{F} \ell}{\mathrm{Ay}}$  $\Delta \ell_{\mathrm{s}}=\frac{3 \mathrm{mg} \ell_{\mathrm{s}}}{\pi \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{s}}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{y}_{\mathrm{s}}}\left[\because \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{s}}=(\mathrm{M}+2 \mathrm{M}) \mathrm{g}\right]$  $\Delta \ell_{\mathrm{b}}=\frac{2 \mathrm{Mg} \ell_{\mathrm{b}}}{\pi \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{y}_{\mathrm{b}}}\left[\because \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{b}}=2 \mathrm{Mg}\right]$  $\therefore \frac{\Delta \ell_{\mathrm{s}}}{\Delta \ell_{\mathrm{b}}}=\frac{\frac{3 \mathrm{Mg} \ell_{\mathrm{s}}}{\pi \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{s}}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{y}_{\mathrm{s}}}}{\frac{2 \mathrm{Mg} \cdot \ell_{\mathrm{b}}}{\pi \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{b}}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{y}_{\mathrm{b}}}}=\frac{3 \mathrm{a}}{2 \mathrm{~b}^{2} \mathrm{C}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A steel wire can sustain 100 kg weight without breaking. If the wire is cut into two equal parts, each part can sustain a weight of

\\
solution: Breaking force $\alpha$ area of cross section of wire Load hold by wire is independent of length of the wire.

question:
A structural steel rod has a radius of 10 mm and length of 1.0 m . A 100 kN force stretches it along its length. Young's modulus of structural steel is $2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$. The percentage strain is about

\\
solution: Given: $F=100 \mathrm{kN}=10^{5} \mathrm{~N}$   $\mathrm{Y}=2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$  $\ell_{0}=1.0 \mathrm{~m}$  radius $\mathrm{r}=10 \mathrm{~mm}=10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}$  From formula, $Y=\frac{\text { Stress }}{\text { Strain }}$  $\Rightarrow$ Strain $=\frac{\text { Stress }}{Y}=\frac{F}{A Y}$  $$ =\frac{10^{5}}{\pi r^{2} Y}=\frac{10^{5}}{3.14 \times 10^{-4} \times 2 \times 10^{11}}=\frac{1}{628} $$  Therefore $\%$ strain $=\frac{1}{628} \times 100=0.16 \%$\\
From the graph, it is clear that for the same value of load, elongation is maximum for wire $O A$. Hence $O A$ is the thinnest wire among the four wires.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two wires are made of the same material and have the same volume. However wire 1 has cross-sectional area $A$ and wire 2 has cross-sectional area $3 A$. If the length of wire 1 increases by $\Delta x$ on applying force $F$, how much force is needed to stretch wire 2 by the same amount?

\\
solution: \\ \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-6(1)}  For wire 1  Length, $L_{1}=1$  Area, $A_{1}=A$  For wire 2  Length, $L_{2}=\frac{\ell}{3}$  Area, $A_{2}=3 \mathrm{~A}$  As the wires are made of same material, so they will have same young's modulus.  For wire 1,  $Y=\frac{F / A}{\Delta x / \ell}$  For wire 2,  $Y=\frac{F^{\prime} / 3 A}{\Delta x /(\ell / 3)}$  From (i) and (ii) we get,  $\frac{F}{A} \times \frac{\ell}{\Delta x}=\frac{F^{\prime}}{3 A} \times \frac{\ell}{3 \Delta x} \Rightarrow F^{\prime}=9 F$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A wire elongates by $l \mathrm{~mm}$ when a load $W$ is hanged from it. If the wire goes over a pulley and two weights $W$ each are hung at the two ends, the elongation of the wire will be (in mm )

\\
solution: Case (i)\\ \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-6}  At equilibrium, $T=W$  Young's modules, $Y=\frac{W / A}{\ell / L}$  Elongation, $\ell=\frac{W}{A} \times \frac{L}{Y}$  Case (ii) At equilibrium $T=W$  $\therefore$ Young's moduls, $Y=\frac{W / A}{\frac{\ell / 2}{L / 2}}$  $\Rightarrow \quad Y=\frac{W / A}{\ell / L} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \ell=\frac{W}{A} \times \frac{L}{Y}$  $\Rightarrow$ Elongation is the same.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two steel wires having same length are suspended from a ceiling under the same load. If the ratio of their energy stored per unit volume is $1: 4$, the ratio of their diameters is:

\\
solution: If force $F$ acts along the length L of the wire of crosssection $A$, then energy stored in unit volume of wire is given by  Energy density $=\frac{1}{2}$ stress $\times$ strain  $=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{F}{A} \times \frac{F}{A Y}\left(\because\right.$ stress $=\frac{F}{A}$ and strain $\left.=\frac{X}{A Y}\right)$  $=\frac{1}{2} \frac{F^{2}}{A^{2} Y}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{F^{2} \times 16}{\left(\pi d^{2}\right)^{2} Y}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{F^{2} \times 16}{\pi d^{4} Y}$  If $u_{1}$ and $u_{2}$ are the densities of two wires, then  $\frac{u_{1}}{u_{2}}=\left(\frac{d_{2}}{d_{1}}\right)^{4} \Rightarrow \frac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}=(4)^{1 / 4} \Rightarrow \frac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}=\sqrt{2}: 1$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A boy's catapult is made of rubber cord which is 42 cm long, with 6 mm diameter of cross-section and of negligible mass. The boy keeps a stone weighing 0.02 kg on it and stretches the cord by 20 cm by applying a constant force. When released, the stone flies off with a velocity of $20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-}$ ${ }^{1}$. Neglect the change in the area of cross-section of the cord while stretched. The Young's modulus of rubber is closest to :

\\
solution: When a catapult is stretched up to length $l$, then the stored energy in it $=\Delta \mathrm{k} . \mathrm{E} \Rightarrow$  $\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(\frac{Y A}{L}\right)(\Delta I)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} \Rightarrow y=\frac{m v^{2} L}{\Delta(\Delta l)^{2}}$  $\mathrm{m}=0.02 \mathrm{~kg}$  $\mathrm{v}=20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$  $\mathrm{L}=0.42 \mathrm{~m}$  $\mathrm{A}=\left(\pi \mathrm{d}^{2}\right) /(4)$  $\mathrm{d}=6 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}$  $\Delta l=0.2 \mathrm{~m}$  $y=\frac{0.02 \times 400 \times 0.42 \times 4}{\pi \times 36 \times 10^{-6} \times 0.04}=2.3 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$  So, order is $10^{6}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A solid sphere of radius $r$ made of a soft material of bulk modulus K is surrounded by a liquid in a cylindrical container. A massless piston of area a floats on the surface of the liquid, covering entire cross-section of cylindrical container. When a mass $m$ is placed on the surface of the piston to compress the liquid, the fractional decrement in the radius of the sphere $\left(\frac{d r}{r}\right)$, is :

\\
solution: Bulk modulus, $\mathrm{K}=\frac{\text { volumetric stress }}{\text { volumetric strain }}$   \begin{align*} & K=\frac{m g}{a\left(\frac{d V}{V}\right)} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{d V}{V}=\frac{m g}{K a} \tag{i} \end{align*}   volume of sphere, $V=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}$\\ Fractional change in volume $\frac{d V}{V}=\frac{3 d r}{r}$  Using eq. (i) $\&$ (ii) $\frac{3 d r}{r}=\frac{m g}{K a}$  $\therefore \frac{d r}{r}=\frac{m g}{3 K a}$ (fractional decrement in radius)  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A bottle has an opening of radius a and length $b$. A cork of length $b$ and radius $(a+\Delta a)$ where $(\Delta a<<a)$ is compressed to fit into the opening completely (see figure). If the bulk modulus of cork is B and frictional coefficient between the bottle and cork is $\mu$ then the force needed to push the cork into the bottle is :



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-3}\\
solution: Stress $=\frac{\text { Normal force }}{\text { Area }}=\frac{\mathrm{N}}{\mathrm{A}}=\frac{\mathrm{N}}{(2 \pi \mathrm{a}) \mathrm{b}}$  Stress $=\mathrm{B} \times$ strain  $\frac{\mathrm{N}}{(2 \pi \mathrm{a}) \mathrm{b}}=\mathrm{B} \frac{2 \pi \mathrm{a} \Delta \mathrm{a} \times \mathrm{b}}{\pi \mathrm{a}^{2} \mathrm{~b}}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{N}=\mathrm{B} \frac{(2 \pi \mathrm{a})^{2} \Delta \mathrm{ab}^{2}}{\pi \mathrm{a}^{2} \mathrm{~b}}$  Force needed to push the cork.  $\mathrm{f}=\mu \mathrm{N}=\mu 4 \pi \mathrm{b} \Delta \mathrm{aB}=(4 \pi \mu \mathrm{Bb}) \Delta \mathrm{a}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Steel ruptures when a shear of $3.5 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}^{-2}$ is applied. The force needed to punch a 1 cm diameter hole in a steel sheet 0.3 cm thick is nearly:

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-7(1)}   Shearing strain is created along the side surface of the punched disk. Note that the forces exerted on the disk are exerted along the circumference of the disk, and the total force exerted on its center only.  Let us assume that the shearing stress along the side surface of the disk is uniform, then   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_b472a34d0c7dd6085811g-7}   $=\int \sigma_{\max } \cdot \mathrm{A}=\sigma_{\max } \cdot 2 \pi\left(\frac{\mathrm{D}}{2}\right) \mathrm{h}$  $=3.5 \times 10^{8} \times\left(\frac{1}{2} \times 10^{-2}\right) \times 0.3 \times 10^{-2} \times 2 \pi$  $=3.297 \times 10^{4} \simeq 3.3 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: The bulk moduli of ethanol, mercury and water are given as $0.9,25$ and 2.2 respectively in units of $10^{9} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$. For a given value of pressure, the fractional compression in volume is $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}}$. Which of the following statements about $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}}$ for these three liquids is correct?
solution: Compressibility $=\frac{1}{\text { Bulk modulus }}$  As bulk modulus is least for ethanol (0.9) and maximum for mercury (25) among ehtanol, mercury and water. Hence compression in volume $\frac{\Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}}$  Ethanol $>$ Water $>$ Mercury  \begin{enumerate}

question: In materials like aluminium and copper, the correct order of magnitude of various elastic modului is:
options: a) Young's modulus $<$ shear modulus $<$ bulk modulus.
b) Bulk modulus $<$ shear modulus $<$ Young's modulus
c) Shear modulus $<$ Young's modulus $<$ bulk modulus.
d) Bulk modulus $<$ Young's modulus $<$ shear modulus.
solution: Poisson's ratio, $\sigma=\frac{\text { lateral strain }(\beta)}{\text { longitudinal strain }(\alpha)}$  For material like copper, $\sigma=0.33$  And, $\mathrm{Y}=3 \mathrm{k}(1-2 \sigma)$  Also, $\frac{9}{\mathrm{Y}}=\frac{1}{\mathrm{k}}+\frac{3}{\eta}$  $Y=2 \eta(1+\sigma)$  Hence, $\eta<\mathrm{Y}<\mathrm{k}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: If ' $S$ ' is stress and ' $Y$ ' is young's modulus of material of a wire, the energy stored in the wire per unit volume is \\
solution: Energy stored in the wire per unit volume,  $E=\frac{1}{2} \times$ stress $\times$ strain  We know that,  $Y=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}$ $\Rightarrow$ strain $=\frac{\text { stress }}{Y}$  On substituting the expression of strain in equation (i) we get  $E=\frac{1}{2} \times \operatorname{stress} \times \frac{\text { stress }}{Y}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{S^{2}}{Y}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A wire fixed at the upper end stretches by length $\ell$ by applying a force $F$. The work done in stretching is \\
solution: Let $A$ and $L$ be the area and length of the wire. Work done by constant force in displacing the wire by a distance $\ell$.  $=$ change in potential energy  $=\frac{1}{2} \times$ stress $\times$ strain $\times$ volume  $=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{F}{A} \times \frac{\ell}{L} \times A \times L=\frac{F \ell}{2}$   \end{document}

question:
A hollow spherical shell at outer radius $R$ floats just submerged under the water surface. The inner radius of the shell is $r$. If the specific gravity of the shell material is $\frac{27}{8}$ w.r.t water, the value of $r$ is :

$\\
solution: In equilibrium, $m g=F_{e}$  $F_{B}=V \rho_{0} g$ and mass $=$ volume $\times$ density  $\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(R^{3}-r^{3}\right) \rho_{0} g=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho_{w} g$  Given, relative density, $\frac{\rho_{0}}{\rho_{w}}=\frac{27}{8}$  $\Rightarrow\left[1-\left(\frac{r}{R}\right)^{3}\right] \frac{27}{8} \rho_{w}=\rho_{w}$  $\Rightarrow 1-\frac{r^{3}}{R^{3}}=\frac{9}{27} \Rightarrow 1-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{r^{3}}{R^{3}} \Rightarrow \frac{2}{3}=\frac{r^{3}}{R^{3}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{r}{R}=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{1 / 3} \Rightarrow 1-\frac{r^{3}}{R^{3}}=\frac{8}{27}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{r^{3}}{R^{3}}=1-\frac{8}{27}=\frac{19}{27}$  $\therefore r=0.89 R=\frac{8}{9} R$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An air bubble of radius 1 cm in water has an upward acceleration $9.8 \mathrm{~cm} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}$. The density of water is 1 gm $\mathrm{cm}^{-3}$ and water offers negligible drag force on the bubble. The mass of the bubble is $\left(\mathrm{g}=980 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)$

$\\
solution: Given:  Radius of air bubble $=1 \mathrm{~cm}$,  Upward acceleration of bubble, $a=9.8 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$,  $\rho_{\text {water }}=1 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$  Volume $V=\frac{4 \pi}{3} r^{3}=\frac{4 \pi}{3} \times(1)^{3}=4.19 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$  $F_{\text {buoyant }}-m g=m a \Rightarrow m=\frac{F_{\text {buoyant }}}{g+a}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_5835db82d07e80bafd14g-08(1)}   $\therefore m=\frac{\left(V \rho_{\omega} g\right)}{g+a}=\frac{V \rho_{\omega}}{1+\frac{a}{g}}=\frac{(4.19) \times 1}{1+\frac{9.8}{980}}=\frac{4.19}{1.01}=4.15 \mathrm{~g}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Two identical cylindrical vessels are kept on the ground and each contain the same liquid of density $d$. The area of the base of both vessels is $S$ but the height of liquid in one vessel is $x_{1}$ and in the other, $x_{2}$. When both cylinders are connected through a pipe of negligible volume very close to the bottom, the liquid flows from one vessel to the other until it comes to equilibrium at a new height. The change in energy of the system in the process is : \\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_5835db82d07e80bafd14g-08(3)}   Initial potential energy,  $U_{1}=\left(\rho S x_{1}\right) g \cdot \frac{x_{1}}{2}+\left(\rho S x_{2}\right) g \cdot \frac{x_{2}}{2}$  Final potential energy,  $U_{f}=\left(\rho S x_{f}\right) g \cdot \frac{x_{f}}{2} \times 2$\\ By volume conservation,  $$ \begin{aligned} & S x_{1}+S x_{2}=S\left(2 x_{f}\right) \\ & x_{f}=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2} \end{aligned} $$  When valve is opened loss in potentail energy occur till water level become same.  $$ \begin{aligned} \Delta U & =U_{i}-U_{f} \\ \Delta U & =\rho S g\left[\left(\frac{x_{1}^{2}}{2}+\frac{x_{2}^{2}}{2}\right)-x_{f}^{2}\right] \\ & =\rho S g\left[\frac{x_{1}^{2}}{2}+\frac{x_{2}^{2}}{2}-\left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}\right)^{2}\right] \\ & =\frac{\rho S g}{2}\left[\frac{x_{1}^{2}}{2}+\frac{x_{2}^{2}}{2}-x_{1} x_{2}\right]=\frac{\rho S g}{4}\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A leak proof cylinder of length 1 m , made of a metal which has very low coefficient of expansion is floating vertically in water at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ such that its height above the water surface is 20 cm . When the temperature of water is increased to $4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the height of the cylinder above the water surface becomes 21 cm . The density of water at $T=4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, relative to the density at $T=0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is close to:


\\
solution: When cylinder is floating in water at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  Net thrust $=A\left(h_{2}-h_{1}\right) \rho_{0^{\circ}}{ }^{c} g$  $=A(100-80) \rho_{0^{\circ} c} g$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_5835db82d07e80bafd14g-08(2)}   When cylinder is floating in water at $4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  Net thrust $=A\left(h_{2}-h_{1}\right) \rho_{4^{\circ}} c g$  $$ =A(100-21) \rho_{4^{\circ}} g $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_5835db82d07e80bafd14g-08}   $\therefore \frac{\rho_{4^{\circ} c}}{\rho_{0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}}=\frac{80}{79}=1.01$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Consider a solid sphere of radius $R$ and mass density $\rho(r)=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right), 0<r \leq R$. The minimum density of a liquid in which it will float is:

\\
solution: For minimum density of liquid, solid sphere has to float (completely immersed) in the liquid.  $m g=F_{B}\left(\right.$ also $\left.V_{\text {immersed }}=V_{\text {total }}\right)$  or $\int \rho d V=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho_{\ell}$  $\left[\rho(r)=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right) 0<r \leq R\right.$ given $]$  $\Rightarrow \int_{0}^{R} \rho_{0} 4 \pi\left(1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right) \cdot r^{2} d r=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho_{\ell}$\\ $\Rightarrow 4 \pi \rho_{0}\left[\frac{r^{3}}{3}-\frac{r^{5}}{5 R^{2}}\right]_{0}^{R}=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho_{\ell}$  $\frac{4 \pi \rho_{0} R^{3}}{3} \times \frac{2}{5}=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho_{\ell}$  $\therefore \rho_{\ell}=\frac{2 \rho_{0}}{5}$

question:
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_5835db82d07e80bafd14g-01}
 

Two liquids of densities $\rho_{1}$ and $\rho_{2}\left(\rho_{2}=2 \rho_{1}\right)$ are filled up behind a square wall of side 10 m as shown in figure. Each liquid has a height of 5 m . The ratio of the forces due to these liquids exerted on upper part $M N$ to that at the lower part $N O$ is (Assume that the liquids are not mixing): \\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_5835db82d07e80bafd14g-09}   Let $P_{1}, P_{2}$ and $P_{3}$ be the pressure at points $M, N$ and $O$ respectively.  Pressure is given by $P=\rho g h$  Now, $P_{1}=0(\because h=0)$  $$ \begin{aligned} P_{2}^{1} & =\rho g(5) \\ P_{3} & =\rho g(15) \\ & =15 \rho g \end{aligned} $$  Force on upper part, $F_{1}=\frac{\left(P_{1}+P_{2}\right)}{2} A$  Force on lower part, $F_{2}=\frac{\left(P_{2}+P_{3}\right)}{2} \mathrm{~A}$  $\therefore \frac{F_{1}}{F_{2}}=\frac{5 \rho g}{20 \rho g}=\frac{5}{20}=\frac{1}{4}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A cubical block of side 0.5 m floats on water with $30 \%$ of its volume under water. What is the maximum weight that can be put on the block without fully submerging it under water? $

[10 April 2019 (II)]\\
