question: Three rods of Copper, Brass and Steel are welded together to form a Y shaped structure. Area of cross - section of each $\operatorname{rod}=4 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$. End of copper rod is maintained at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ where as ends of brass and steel are kept at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Lengths of the copper, brass and steel rods are 46,13 and 12 cms respectively. The rods are thermally insulated from surroundings excepts at ends. Thermal conductivities of copper, brass and steel are $0.92,0.26$ and 0.12 CGS units respectively. Rate of heat flow through copper rod is:\\
solution: Rate of heat flow is given by,  $\mathrm{Q}=\frac{\mathrm{KA}\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)}{l}$  Where, $\mathrm{K}=$ coefficient of thermal conductivity $l=$ length of rod and $\mathrm{A}=$ area of cross-section of $\operatorname{rod}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_bbb0b2f044a24cc35a7fg-133}   If the junction temperature is $T$, then  $\mathrm{Q}_{\text {Copper }}=\mathrm{Q}_{\text {Brass }}+\mathrm{Q}_{\text {Stee }}$  $\frac{0.92 \times 4(100-T)}{46}$  $=\frac{0.26 \times 4 \times(T-0)}{13}+\frac{0.12 \times 4 \times(T-0)}{12}$  $\Rightarrow \quad 200-2 \mathrm{~T}=2 \mathrm{~T}+\mathrm{T}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}=40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  $\therefore \quad Q_{\text {Copper }}=\frac{0.92 \times 4 \times 60}{46}=4.8 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A black coloured solid sphere of radius $R$ and mass M is inside a cavity with vacuum inside. The walls of the cavity are maintained at temperature $\mathrm{T}_{0}$. The initial temperature of the sphere is $3 \mathrm{~T}_{0}$. If the specific heat of the material of the sphere varies as $\alpha \mathrm{T}^{3}$ per unit mass with the temperature T of the sphere, where $\alpha$ is a constant, then the time taken for the sphere to cool down to temperature $2 \mathrm{~T}_{0}$ will be ( $\sigma$ is Stefan Boltzmann constant)


\\
solution: In the given problem, fall in temperature of sphere,  $\mathrm{dT}=\left(3 \mathrm{~T}_{0}-2 \mathrm{~T}_{0}\right)=\mathrm{T}_{0}$  Temperature of surrounding, $\mathrm{T}_{\text {surr }}=\mathrm{T}_{0}$  Initial temperature of sphere, $\mathrm{T}_{\text {initial }}=3 \mathrm{~T}_{0}$  Specific heat of the material of the sphere varies as,  $\mathrm{c}=\alpha \mathrm{T}^{3}$ per unit mass $(\alpha=$ a constant $)$  Applying formula,  $\frac{\mathrm{dT}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\frac{\sigma \mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{McJ}}\left(\mathrm{T}^{4}-\mathrm{T}_{\text {surr }}^{4}\right)$  $\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{T}_{0}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\frac{\sigma 4 \pi \mathrm{R}^{2}}{\mathrm{M \alpha}\left(3 \mathrm{~T}_{0}\right)^{3} \mathrm{~J}}\left[\left(3 \mathrm{~T}_{0}\right)^{4}-\left(\mathrm{T}_{0}\right)^{4}\right]$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{dt}=\frac{\mathrm{M} \alpha 27 \mathrm{~T}_{0}^{4} \mathrm{~J}}{\sigma 4 \pi \mathrm{R}^{2} \times 80 \mathrm{~T}_{0}^{4}}$  Solving we get,  Time taken for the sphere to cool down temperature $2 \mathrm{~T}_{0}$,  $\mathrm{t}=\frac{\mathrm{M} \alpha}{16 \pi \mathrm{R}^{2} \sigma} \ln \left(\frac{16}{3}\right)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Water of volume 2 L in a closed container is heated with a coil of 1 kW . While water is heated, the container loses energy at a rate of $160 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}$. In how much time will the temperature of water rise from $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $77^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ? (Specific heat of water is $4.2 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg}$ and that of the container is negligible).

\\
solution: From question,  In 1 sec heat gained by water  $=1 \mathrm{KW}-160 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}$  $=1000 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}-160 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}$  $=840 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}$  Total heat required to raise the temperature of water (volume 2 L ) from $27^{\circ} \mathrm{c}$ to $77^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  $=\mathrm{m}_{\text {water }} \times$ sp. ht $\times \Delta \theta$  $=2 \times 10^{3} \times 4.2 \times 50[\because$ mass $=$ density $\times$ volume $]$  And, $840 \times \mathrm{t}=2 \times 10^{3} \times 4.2 \times 50$  or, $\mathrm{t}=\frac{2 \times 10^{3} \times 4.2 \times 50}{840}$  $=500 \mathrm{~s}=8 \mathrm{~min} 20 \mathrm{~s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Assume that a drop of liquid evaporates by decrease in its surface energy, so that its temperature remains unchanged. What should be the minimum radius of the drop for this to be possible? The surface tension is T, density of liquid is $\rho$ and $L$ is its latent heat of vaporization.

\\
solution: When radius is decrease by $\Delta R$,  $$ \begin{aligned} & 4 \pi \mathrm{R}^{2} \Delta \mathrm{R} \rho \mathrm{L}=4 \pi \mathrm{T}\left[\mathrm{R}^{2}-(\mathrm{R}-\Delta \mathrm{R})^{2}\right] \\ & \Rightarrow \rho \mathrm{R}^{2} \Delta \mathrm{RL}=\mathrm{T}\left[\mathrm{R}^{2}-\mathrm{R}^{2}+2 \mathrm{R} \Delta \mathrm{R}-\Delta \mathrm{R}^{2}\right] \\ & \Rightarrow \rho \mathrm{R}^{2} \Delta \mathrm{RL}=\mathrm{T} 2 \mathrm{R} \Delta \mathrm{R} \quad[\Delta \mathrm{R} \text { is very small }] \\ & \Rightarrow R=\frac{2 T}{\rho L} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A mass of 50 g of water in a closed vessel, with surroundings at a constant temperature takes 2 minutes to cool from $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. A mass of 100 g of another liquid in an identical vessel with identical surroundings takes the same time to cool from $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The specific heat of the liquid is :

(The water equivalent of the vessel is 30 g .)

\\
solution: As the surrounding is identical, vessel is identical time taken to cool both water and liquid (from $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) is same 2 minutes, therefore  $\left(\frac{\mathrm{dQ}}{\mathrm{dt}}\right)_{\text {water }}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{dQ}}{\mathrm{dt}}\right)_{\text {liquid }}$  or, $\frac{\left(\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{w}} \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{w}}+\mathrm{W}\right) \Delta \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{t}}=\frac{\left(\mathrm{m}_{\ell} \mathrm{C}_{\ell}+\mathrm{W}\right) \Delta \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{t}}$  ( $\mathrm{W}=$ water equivalent of the vessel)  or, $\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{w}} \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{w}}=\mathrm{m}_{\ell} \mathrm{C}_{\ell}$  $\therefore$ Specific heat of liquid, $\mathrm{C}_{\ell}=\frac{\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{W}} \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{W}}}{\mathrm{m}_{\ell}}$  $=\frac{50 \times 1}{100}=0.5 \mathrm{kcal} / \mathrm{kg}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
500 g of water and 100 g of ice at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ are in a calorimeter whose water equivalent is 40 g .10 g of steam at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is added to it. Then water in the calorimeter is : (Latent heat of ice $=80 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{g}$, Latent heat of steam $=540 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{g}$ )

\\
solution: As 1 g of steam at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ melts 8 g of ice at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.  10 g of steam will melt $8 \times 10 \mathrm{~g}$ of ice at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  Water in calorimeter $=500+80+10 \mathrm{~g}=590 \mathrm{~g}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Given that 1 g of water in liquid phase has volume $1 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ and in vapour phase $1671 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ at atmospheric pressure and the latent heat of vaporization of water is $2256 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{g}$; the change in the internal energy in joules for 1 g of water at 373 K when it changes from liquid phase to vapour phase at the same temperature is :

\\

A large cylindrical rod of length $L$ is made by joining two identical rods of copper and steel of length $\left(\frac{L}{2}\right)$ each. The rods are completely insulated from the surroundings. If the free end of copper rod is maintained at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and that of steel at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ then the temperature of junction is (Thermal conductivity of copper is 9 times that of steel)

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_bbb0b2f044a24cc35a7fg-134}   Let conductivity of steel $K_{\text {steel }}=k$ then from question Conductivity of copper $K_{\text {copper }}=9 k$  $\theta_{\text {copper }}=100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  $\theta_{\text {steel }}=0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  $l_{\text {steel }}=l_{\text {copper }}=\frac{L}{2}$\\ From formula temperature of junction;  $\theta=\frac{K_{\text {copper }} \theta_{\text {copper }} l_{\text {steel }}+K_{\text {steel }} \theta_{\text {steel }} l_{\text {copper }}}{K_{\text {copper }} l_{\text {steel }}+K_{\text {steel }} l_{\text {copper }}}$  $=\frac{9 k \times 100 \times \frac{L}{2}+k \times 0 \times \frac{L}{2}}{9 k \times \frac{L}{2}+k \times \frac{L}{2}}$  $=\frac{\frac{900}{2} k L}{\frac{10 k L}{2}}=90^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The heat radiated per unit area in 1 hour by a furnace whose temperature is 3000 K is $\left(\sigma=5.7 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-2} \mathrm{~K}^{-4}\right)$

\\
solution: According to Stefan's law  $E=\sigma T^{4}$  Heat radiated per unit area in 1 hour ( 3600 s) is $=5.7 \times 10^{-8} \times(300)^{4} \times 3600=1.7 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: 100 g of water is heated from $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Ignoring the slight expansion of the water, the change in its internal energy is (specific heat of water is $4184 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{K}$ ): \\
solution: $\Delta U=\Delta Q=m c \Delta T$  $$ =\frac{100}{1000} \times 4184(50-30) \approx 8.4 \mathrm{~kJ} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The specific heat capacity of a metal at low temperature (T) is given as


$$
C_{p}\left(k J K^{-1} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}\right)=32\left(\frac{T}{400}\right)^{3}
$$

A 100 gram vessel of this metal is to be cooled from $20^{\circ} \mathrm{K}$ to $4^{\circ} \mathrm{K}$ by a special refrigerator operating at room temperature $\left(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$. The amount of work required to cool the vessel is
solution: Required work = energy released  Here, $Q=\int m c d T$  $$ \begin{aligned} & =\int_{20}^{4} 0.1 \times 32 \times\left(\frac{T^{3}}{400^{3}}\right) d T=\int_{20}^{4} \frac{3.2}{64 \times 10^{6}} T^{3} d T \\ & =5 \times 10^{-8} \int_{20}^{4} T^{3} d T=0.002 \mathrm{~kJ} \end{aligned} $$  Therefore, required work $=0.002 \mathrm{~kJ}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A long metallic bar is carrying heat from one of its ends to the other end under steady-state. The variation of temperature $\theta$ along the length $x$ of the bar from its hot end is best described by which of the following figures?\\
solution: Let $Q$ be the temperature at a distance $x$ from hot end of bar. Let $Q$ is the temperature of hot end.  The heat flow rate is given by  $\frac{d Q}{d t}=\frac{k A\left(\theta_{1}-\theta\right)}{x}$  $\Rightarrow \theta_{1}-\theta=\frac{x}{k A} \frac{d Q}{d t} \quad \Rightarrow \theta=\theta_{1}-\frac{x}{k A} \frac{d Q}{d t}$  Thus, the graph of $Q$ versus $x$ is a straight line with a positive intercept and a negative slope.  The above equation can be graphically represented by option (a).  \begin{enumerate}

question:
One end of a thermally insulated rod is kept at a temperature $T_{1}$ and the other at $T_{2}$. The rod is composed of two sections of length $l_{1}$ and $l_{2}$ and thermal conductivities $K_{1}$ and $K_{2}$ respectively. The temperature at the interface of the two section is



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_bbb0b2f044a24cc35a7fg-128(2)}\\
solution: Let $T$ be the temperature of the interface. In the steady state, $\mathrm{Q}_{1}=\mathrm{Q}_{2}$  $$ \begin{aligned} T_{1} \ell_{1} & \ell_{2} \\ \hline & T_{2} \\ \hline K_{1} & K_{2} \\ \therefore & \frac{K_{1} A\left(T_{1}-T\right)}{\ell_{1}}=\frac{K_{2} A\left(T-T_{2}\right)}{\ell_{2}}, \end{aligned} $$  where A is the area of cross-section.  $\Rightarrow \quad K_{1} A\left(T_{1}-T\right) \ell_{2}=K_{2} A\left(T-T_{2}\right) \ell_{1}$  $\Rightarrow \quad K_{1} T_{1} \ell_{2}-K_{1} T \ell_{2}=K_{2} T \ell_{1}-K_{2} T_{2} \ell_{1}$  $\Rightarrow \quad\left(K_{2} \ell_{1}+K_{1} \ell_{2}\right) T=K_{1} T_{1} \ell_{2}+K_{2} T_{2} \ell_{1}$  $\Rightarrow T=\frac{K_{1} T_{1} \ell_{2}+K_{2} T_{2} \ell_{1}}{K_{2} \ell_{1}+K_{1} \ell_{2}}$  $=\frac{K_{1} \ell_{2} T_{1}+K_{2} \ell_{1} T_{2}}{K_{1} \ell_{2}+K_{2} \ell_{1}}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Assuming the Sun to be a spherical body of radius $R$ at a temperature of $T K$, evaluate the total radiant powerd incident of Earth at a distance $r$ from the Sun

\\





where $r_{0}$ is the radius of the Earth and $\sigma$ is Stefan's constant.
solution: From stefan's law, total power radiated by $\operatorname{Sun}, E=\sigma T^{4} \times$ $4 \pi R^{2}$  The intensity of power Per unit area incident on earth's surface  $=\frac{\sigma T^{4} \times 4 \pi R^{2}}{4 \pi r^{2}}$  Total power received by Earth  $E^{\prime}=\frac{E}{4 \pi r^{2}} \times$ Cross - Section area of earth facing the  $\operatorname{sun}=\frac{\sigma T^{4} R^{2}}{r^{2}}\left(\pi r_{0}^{2}\right)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two rigid boxes containing different ideal gases are placed on a table. Box A contains one mole of nitrogen at

temperature $T_{0}$, while Box contains one mole of helium at temperature $\left(\frac{7}{3}\right) T_{0}$. The boxes are then put into thermal contact with each other, and heat flows between them until the gases reach a common final temperature (ignore the heat capacity of boxes). Then, the final temperature of the gases, $T_{f}$ in terms of $T_{0}$ is

$$\\
solution: When two gases are mixed to gether then Heat lost by He gas $=$ Heat gained by $\mathrm{N}_{2}$ gas  $n_{1} C_{v_{1}} \Delta T_{1}=n_{2} C_{v_{2}} \Delta T_{2}$  $\frac{3}{2} R\left[\frac{7}{3} T_{0}-T_{f}\right]=\frac{5}{2} R\left[T_{f}-T_{0}\right]$  $7 T_{0}-3 T_{f}=5 T_{f}-5 T_{0}$  $\Rightarrow 12 T_{0}=8 T_{f} \Rightarrow T_{f}=\frac{12}{8} T_{0}$  $\Rightarrow T_{f}=\frac{3}{2} T_{0} .$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The figure shows a system of two concentric spheres of radii $r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ are kept at temperatures $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$, respectively. The radial rate of flow of heat in a substance between the two concentric spheres is proportional to



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_bbb0b2f044a24cc35a7fg-128(1)}\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_bbb0b2f044a24cc35a7fg-135}   Consider a thin concentric shell of thickness $(d r)$ and of radius ( $r$ ) and let the temperature of inner and outer surfaces of this shell be $T$ and $(T-d T)$ respectively.\\ The radial rate of flow of heat through this elementary shell will be  $\frac{d Q}{d t}=\frac{K A[(T-d T)-T]}{d r}=\frac{-K A d T}{d r}$  $=-4 \pi K r^{2} \frac{d T}{d r}$  $\left(\because A=4 \pi r^{2}\right)$  Since the area of the surface through which heat will flow is not constant. Integrating both sides between the limits of radii and temperatures of the two shells, we get  $$ \begin{aligned} & \left(\frac{d Q}{d t}\right) \int_{r_{1}}^{r_{2}} \frac{1}{r^{2}} d r=-4 \pi K \int_{T_{1}}^{T_{2}} d T \\ & \left(\frac{d Q}{d t}\right) \int_{r_{1}}^{r_{2}} r^{-2} d r=-4 \pi K \int_{T_{1}}^{T_{2}} d T \end{aligned} $$  $\frac{d Q}{d t}\left[\frac{1}{r_{1}}-\frac{1}{r_{2}}\right]=-4 \pi K\left[T_{2}-T_{1}\right]$  or $\frac{d Q}{d t}=\frac{-4 \pi K r_{1} r_{2}\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right)}{\left(r_{2}-r_{1}\right)}$  $\therefore \quad \frac{d Q}{d t} \propto \frac{r_{1} r_{2}}{\left(r_{2}-r_{1}\right)}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If the temperature of the sun were to increase from $T$ to $2 T$ and its radius from $R$ to $2 R$, then the ratio of the radiant energy received on earth to what it was previously will be

\\
solution: From stefan's law, energy radiated by sun per second $E=\sigma A T^{4}$  $\therefore A \propto R^{2}$  $\therefore E \propto R^{2} T^{4}$  $\therefore \frac{E_{2}}{E_{1}}=\frac{R_{2}^{2} T_{2}^{4}}{R_{1}^{2} T_{1}^{4}}$  put $R_{2}=2 R, R_{1}=R ; T_{2}=2 T, T_{1}=T$  $\Rightarrow \frac{E_{2}}{E_{1}}=\frac{(2 R)^{2}(2 T)^{4}}{R^{2} T^{4}}=64$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The temperature of the two outer surfaces of a composite slab, consisting of two materials having coefficients of thermal conductivity $K$ and $2 K$ and thickness $x$ and $4 x$, respectively, are $T_{2}$ and $T_{1}\left(T_{2}>T_{1}\right)$. The rate of heat transfer through the slab, in a steady state is $\left(\frac{A\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right) K}{x}\right) f$, with $f$ equal to



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_bbb0b2f044a24cc35a7fg-128(4)}\\
solution: The thermal resistance is given by  $\frac{x}{K A}+\frac{4 x}{2 K A}=\frac{x}{K A}+\frac{2 x}{K A}=\frac{3 x}{K A}$  Amount of heat flow per second,  $\frac{d Q}{d t}=\frac{\Delta T}{\frac{3 x}{K A}}=\frac{\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right) K A}{3 x}$  $=\frac{1}{3}\left\{\frac{A\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right) K}{x}\right\} \quad \therefore f=\frac{1}{3}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: The earth radiates in the infra-red region of the spectrum. The spectrum is correctly given by
solution: Wein's law correctly explains the spectrum

question: Heat given to a body which raises its temperature by $1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is
solution: Heat required for raising the temperature of a body through $1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is called its thermal capacity.

question:
Infrared radiation is detected by

\\
solution: Pyrometer is used to detect infra-red radiation.

question:
Which of the following is more close to a black body?

\\
solution: Black body is one which absorb all incident radiation. Black board paint is quite approximately equal to black bodies.

question: If mass-energy equivalence is taken into account, when water is cooled to form ice, the mass of water should
solution: When water is cooled at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to form ice, energy is released from water in the form of heat. As energy is equivalent to mass, therefore, when water is cooled to ice, its mass decreases.

question:
Two spheres of the same material have radii 1 m and 4 m and temperatures 4000 K and 2000 K respectively. The ratio of the energy radiated per second by the first sphere to that by the second is

\\
solution: From stefan's law, the energy radiated per second is given by $E=e \sigma T^{4} A$   Here, $T=$ temperature of the body  $A=$ surface area of the body  For same material e is same. $\sigma$ is stefan's constant  Let $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$ be the temperature of two spheres. $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ be the area of two spheres.  $\therefore \frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}=\frac{T_{1}^{4} A_{1}}{T_{2}^{4} A_{2}}=\frac{T_{1}^{4} 4 \pi r_{1}^{2}}{T_{2}^{4} 4 \pi r_{2}^{2}}$  $=\frac{(4000)^{4} \times 1^{2}}{(2000)^{4} \times 4^{2}}=\frac{1}{1}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A metallic sphere cools from $50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ in 300 s . If atmospheric temperature around is $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, then the sphere's temperature after the next 5 minutes will be close to :

\\
solution: From Newton's Law of cooling,  $$ \frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{t}=K\left[\frac{T_{1}+T_{2}}{2}-T_{0}\right] $$  Here, $\mathrm{T}_{1}=50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \mathrm{T}_{2}=40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  an $\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{o}}=20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \mathrm{t}=600 \mathrm{~S}=5$ minutes  $\Rightarrow \frac{50-40}{5 \mathrm{Min}}=K\left(\frac{50+40}{2}-20\right)$  Let $T$ be the temperature of sphere after next 5 minutes. Then   \begin{equation*} \frac{40-T}{5}=K\left(\frac{40+T}{2}-20\right) \tag{ii} \end{equation*}   Dividing eqn. (ii) by (i), we get  $$ \begin{aligned} & \frac{40-T}{10}=\frac{40+T-40}{50+40-40}=\frac{T}{50} \\ & \Rightarrow 40-T=\frac{T}{5} \Rightarrow 200-5 T=T \\ & \therefore T=\frac{200}{6}=33.3^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two identical beakers $A$ and $B$ contain equal volumes of two different liquids at $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ each and left to cool down. Liquid in A has density of $8 \times 10^{2} \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$ and specific heat of $2000 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$ while liquid in B has density of $10^{3} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$ and specific heat of $4000 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$. Which of the following best describes their temperature versus time graph schematically? (assume the emissivity of both the beakers to be the same)

\\
solution: Rate of Heat loss $=m S\left(\frac{d T}{d t}\right)=e \sigma A T^{4}$ $-\frac{d T}{d t}=\frac{e \sigma \times A \times T^{4}}{\rho \times \text { Vol. } \times S} \Rightarrow-\frac{d T}{d t} \propto \frac{1}{\rho S}$  $\frac{\left(-\frac{d T}{d t}\right)_{A}}{\left(-\frac{d T}{d t}\right)_{B}}=\frac{\rho_{B}}{\rho_{A}} \times \frac{S_{B}}{S_{A}}=\frac{10^{3}}{8 \times 10^{2}} \times \frac{4000}{2000}$  $\Rightarrow\left(-\frac{d T}{d t}\right)_{A}>\left(-\frac{d T}{d t}\right)_{B}$  So, A cools down at faster rate.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A body takes 10 minutes to cool from $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The temperature of surroundings is constant at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Then, the temperature of the body after next 10 minutes will be approximately

\\
solution: According to Newton's law of cooling, $\left(\frac{\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}}{t}\right)=K\left(\frac{\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}}{2}-\theta_{0}\right)$  $\left(\frac{60-50}{10}\right)=K\left(\frac{60+50}{2}-25\right)$  and, $\left(\frac{50-\theta}{10}\right)=K\left(\frac{50+\theta}{2}-25\right)$  Dividing eq. (i) by (ii),  $$ \frac{10}{(50-\theta)}=\frac{60}{\theta} \Rightarrow \theta=42.85^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \cong 43^{\circ} \mathrm{C} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Hot water cools from $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ in the first 10 minutes and to $42^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ in the next 10 minutes. The temperature of the surroundings is:

\\
solution: By Newton's law of cooling  $$ \frac{\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}}{\mathrm{t}}=-\mathrm{K}\left[\frac{\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}}{2}-\theta_{0}\right] $$  where $\theta_{0}$ is the temperature of surrounding.  Now, hot water cools from $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ in 10 minutes,  $\frac{60-50}{10}=-K\left[\frac{60+50}{2}-\theta_{0}\right]$  Again, it cools from $50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $42^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ in next 10 minutes.   \begin{equation*} \frac{50-42}{10}=-K\left[\frac{50+42}{2}-\theta_{0}\right] \tag{ii} \end{equation*}   Dividing equations (i) by (ii) we get  $\frac{1}{0.8}=\frac{55-\theta_{0}}{46-\theta_{0}}$  $\frac{10}{8}=\frac{55-\theta_{0}}{46-\theta_{0}}$  $460-10 \theta_{0}=440-8 \theta_{0}$  $2 \theta_{0}=20$  $\theta_{0}=10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A hot body, obeying Newton's law of cooling is cooling down from its peak value $80^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to an ambient temperature of $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. It takes 5 minutes in cooling down from $80^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. How much time will it take to cool down from $62^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $32^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ?

(Given In 2 = 0.693, In 5 = 1.609) \\
solution: From Newton's law of cooling,  $t=\frac{1}{k} \log _{e}\left(\frac{\theta_{2}-\theta_{0}}{\theta_{1}-\theta_{0}}\right)$  From question and above equation,  $5=\frac{1}{k} \log _{e} \frac{(40-30)}{(80-30)}$  And, $t=\frac{1}{k} \log _{e} \frac{(32-30)}{(62-30)}$  Dividing equation (2) by (1),  $\frac{t}{5}=\frac{\frac{1}{k} \log _{e} \frac{(32-30)}{(62-30)}}{\frac{1}{k} \log _{e} \frac{(40-30)}{(80-30)}}$  On solving we get, time taken to cool down from $62^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $32^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, t=8.6$ minutes.\\

question:
If a piece of metal is heated to temperature $\theta$ and then allowed to cool in a room which is at temperature $\theta_{0}$, the graph between the temperature T of the metal and time t will be closest to

\\
solution: According to Newton's law of cooling, the temperature goes on decreasing with time non-linearly.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A liquid in a beaker has temperature $\theta(t)$ at time $t$ and $\theta_{0}$ is temperature of surroundings, then according to Newton's law of cooling the correct graph between $\log _{e}\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)$ and $t$ is :

\\
solution: According to newton's law of cooling  $$ \begin{aligned} & \frac{d \theta}{d t}=-k\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right) \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{d \theta}{\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)}=-k d t \\ & \Rightarrow \int_{\theta_{0}}^{\theta} \frac{d \theta}{\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)}=-k \int_{\theta}^{t} d t \\ & \Rightarrow \log \left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)=-k t+c \end{aligned} $$  Which represents an equation of straight line.  Thus the option (a) is correct.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
According to Newton's law of cooling, the rate of cooling of a body is proportional to $(\Delta \theta)^{n}$, where $\Delta \theta$ is the difference of the temperature of the body and the surroundings, and $n$ is equal to

\\
solution: From Newton's law of cooling $-\frac{\mathrm{dQ}}{\mathrm{dt}} \propto(\Delta \theta)$  \end{document}

question:
A gas can be taken from A to B via two different processes ACB and ADB .

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-158}
 

When path ACB is used 60 J of heat flows into the system and 30 J of work is done by the system. If path ADB is used work done by the system is 10 J . The heat Flow into the system in path ADB is :

$\\
solution: \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-166} \end{center}  $\Delta \mathrm{U}$ remains same for both paths ACB and ADB  $\Delta \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{ACB}}=\Delta \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{ACB}}+\Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{ACB}}$  $\Rightarrow 60 \mathrm{~J}=30 \mathrm{~J}+\Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{ACB}}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{ACB}}=30 \mathrm{~J}$  $\therefore \Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{ADB}}=\Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{ACB}}=30 \mathrm{~J}$  $\Delta \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{ADB}} \stackrel{\mathrm{ADB}}{=} \Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{ADB}}+\Delta \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{ADB}}$  $=10 \mathrm{~J}+30 \mathrm{~J}=40 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
200 g water is heated from $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Ignoring the slight expansion of water, the change in its internal energy is close to (Given specific heat of water $=4184 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kgK}$ ):

\\
solution: Volume of water does not change, no work is done on or by the system $(\mathrm{W}=0)$  According to first law of thermodynamics  $\mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{U}+\mathrm{W}$  For Isochoric process $\mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{U}$  $\Delta \mathrm{U}=\mu \mathrm{cdT}=2 \times 4184 \times 20=16.7 \mathrm{~kJ}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A gas is compressed from a volume of $2 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ to a volume of $1 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ at a constant pressure of $100 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$. Then it is heated at constant volume by supplying 150 J of energy. As a result, the internal energy of the gas:

\\
solution: As we know,  $\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{u}+\Delta \mathrm{w}$  (Ist law of thermodynamics)  $\Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{u}+\mathrm{P} \Delta \mathrm{v}$  or $150=\Delta \mathrm{u}+100(1-2)$  $=\Delta \mathrm{u}-100$  $\therefore \quad \Delta \mathrm{u}=150+100=250 \mathrm{~J}$  Thus the internal energy of the gas increases by 250 J  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An insulated container of gas has two chambers separated by an insulating partition. One of the chambers has volume $V_{1}$ and contains ideal gas at pressure $P_{1}$ and temperature $T_{1}$. The other chamber has volume $V_{2}$ and contains ideal gas at pressure $P_{2}$ and temperature $T_{2}$. If the partition is removed without doing any work on the gas, the final equilibrium temperature of the gas in the container will be

\\
solution: Here $Q=0$ and $W=0$. Therefore from first law of thermodynamics $\Delta U=Q+W=0$  Internal energy of first vessle + Internal energy of second vessel $=$ Internal energy of combined vessel  $n_{1} C_{v} T_{1}+n_{2} C_{v} T_{2}=\left(n_{1}+n_{2}\right) C_{v} T$  $\therefore T=\frac{n_{1} T_{1}+n_{2} T_{2}}{n_{1}+n_{2}}$  For first vessel $n_{1}=\frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{R T_{1}}$ and for second vessle $n_{2}=\frac{P_{2} V_{2}}{R T_{2}}$  $\therefore T=\frac{\frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{R T_{1}} \times T_{1}+\frac{P_{2} V_{2}}{R T_{2}} \times T_{2}}{\frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{R T_{1}}+\frac{P_{2} V_{2}}{R T_{2}}}$  $=\frac{T_{1} T_{2}\left(P_{1} V_{1}+P_{2} V_{2}\right)}{P_{1} V_{1} T_{2}+P_{2} V_{2} T_{1}}$\\

question:
When a system is taken from state i to state $f$ along the path iaf, it is found that $Q=50 \mathrm{cal}$ and $W=20$ cal. Along the path ibf $Q=36$ cal. $W$ along the path ibf is



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-158(1)}\\
solution: For path iaf,  $Q_{1}=50 \mathrm{cal}, W_{1}=20 \mathrm{cal}$  By first law of thermodynamics,  $\Delta U=Q_{1}-W_{1}=50-20=30 \mathrm{cal}$.  For path $i b f$  $Q_{2}=36 \mathrm{cal}$  \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-166(1)} \end{center}  $W_{2}=$ ?  $\Delta U_{i b f}=Q_{2}-W_{2}$  Since, the change in internal energy does not depend on the path, therefore $\Delta U_{i a f}=\Delta U_{i b f}$  $\Delta U_{i a f}=\Delta U_{i b f}$  $\Rightarrow 30=Q_{2}-W_{2}$  $\Rightarrow \quad W_{2}=36-30=6 \mathrm{cal}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A system goes from $A$ to $B$ via two processes I and II as shown in figure. If $\Delta U_{1}$ and $\Delta U_{2}$ are the changes in internal energies in the processes I and II respectively, then



 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-158(2)}
options: a) relation between $\Delta U_{1}$ and $\Delta U_{2}$ can not be determined
solution: Change in internal energy is independent of path taken by the process. It only depends on initial and final states i.e.,  $$ \Delta U_{1}=\Delta U_{2} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the first law of thermodynamics?
options: a) It is a restatement of the principle of conservation of energy
b) It is not applicable to any cyclic process
c) It does not introduces the concept of the entropy
d) It introduces the concept of the internal energy
solution: First law is applicable to a cyclic process. Concept of entropy is introduced by the second law of thermodynamics.

Temperature change $\Delta T$ is same for all three processes   $A \rightarrow B ; A \rightarrow C$ and $A \rightarrow D$  $\Delta U=n C_{v} \Delta T=$ same  $E_{A B}=E_{A C}=E_{A D}$  Work done, $W=P \times \Delta V$  $A B \rightarrow$ volume is increasing $\Rightarrow W_{A B}>0$  $A D \rightarrow$ volume is decreasing $\Rightarrow W_{A D}<0$  $A C \rightarrow$ volume is constant $\Rightarrow W_{A C}=0$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
In an adiabatic process, the density of a diatomic gas becomes 32 times its initial value. The final pressure of the gas is found to be $n$ times the initial pressure. The value of $n$ is :

\\
solution: In adiabatic process  $P V^{\gamma}=$ constant  $\therefore P\left(\frac{m}{\rho}\right)^{\gamma}=$ constant $\quad\left(\because V=\frac{m}{\rho}\right)$  As mass is constant  $\therefore P \propto \rho^{\gamma}$  If $P_{i}$ and $P_{f}$ be the initial and final pressure of the gas and $\rho_{i}$ and $\rho_{f}$ be the initial and final density of the gas. Then  $\frac{P_{f}}{P_{i}}=\left(\frac{\rho_{f}}{\rho_{i}}\right)^{\gamma}=(32)^{7 / 5}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{n P_{i}}{P_{i}}=\left(2^{5}\right)^{7 / 5}=2^{7}$  $\Rightarrow n=2^{7}=128$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Match the thermodynamic processes taking place in a system with the correct conditions. In the table : $\Delta Q$ is the heat supplied, $\Delta W$ is the work done and $\Delta U$ is change in internal energy of the system.



Condition

(I) Adiabatic

(A) $\Delta W=0$\\
(B) $\Delta Q=0$

(II) Isothermal

(III) Isochoric

(C) $\Delta U \neq 0, \Delta W \neq 0$,

$\Delta Q \neq 0$

(IV) Isobaric

(D) $\Delta U=0$
solution:
(I) Adiabatic process : No exchange of heat takes place with surroundings.  $\Rightarrow \Delta Q=0$  (II) Isothermal process : Temperature remains constant\ $	herefore \Delta T=0 \Rightarrow \Delta U= rac{f}{2} n R \Delta T \Rightarrow \Delta U=0$  No change in internal energy $[\Delta U=0]$.  (III) Isochoric process volume remains constant  $\Delta V=0 \Rightarrow W=\int P \cdot d V=0$  Hence work done is zero.  (IV) In isobaric process pressure remains constant.  $W=P \cdot \Delta V 
eq 0$  $\Delta U= rac{f}{2} n R \Delta T= rac{f}{2}[P \Delta V] 
eq 0$  $	herefore \Delta Q=n C_{p} \Delta T 
eq 0$   egin{enumerate}

question:
A balloon filled with helium $\left(32^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right.$ and 1.7 atm . ) bursts. Immediately afterwards the expansion of helium can be considered as :

\\
solution: Bursting of helium balloon is irreversible and in this process $\Delta Q=0$, so adiabatic.

question: An engine takes in 5 mole of air at $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1 atm , and compresses it adiabaticaly to $1 / 10^{\text {th }}$ of the original volume. Assuming air to be a diatomic ideal gas made up of rigid molecules, the change in its internal energy during this process comes out to be $X \mathrm{~kJ}$. The value of $X$ to the nearest integer is . $\qquad$\\
solution: For adiabatic process, $T V^{\gamma-1}=$ constant  or, $T_{1} V_{1}^{\gamma-1}=T_{2} V_{2}^{\gamma-1}$  $T_{1}=20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}+273=293 \mathrm{~K}, V_{2}=\frac{V_{1}}{10}$ and $\gamma=\frac{7}{5}$  $T_{1}\left(V_{1}\right)^{\gamma-1}=T_{2}\left(\frac{V_{1}}{10}\right)^{\gamma-1}$  $\Rightarrow 293=T_{2}\left(\frac{1}{10}\right)^{2 / 5} \Rightarrow T_{2}=293(10)^{2 / 5} \simeq 736 \mathrm{~K}$  $\Delta T=736-293=443 \mathrm{~K}$  During the process, change in internal energy  $\Delta U=N C_{V} \Delta T=5 \times \frac{5}{2} \times 8.3 \times 443 \simeq 46 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~J}=X \mathrm{~kJ}$  $\therefore X=46$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Which of the following is an equivalent cyclic process corresponding to the thermodynamic cyclic given in the figure?


where, $1 \rightarrow 2$ is adiabatic.

(Graphs are schematic and are not to scale)

$

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-159(2)}\\
solution: For process $3 \rightarrow 1$ volume is constant  $\therefore$ Graph given in option (d) is wrong.  And process $1 \rightarrow 2$ is adiabatic $\therefore$ graph in option (1) is wrong  $\because \quad v=$ constant  $P \uparrow, T \uparrow$  For Process $2 \rightarrow 3$ Pressure constant i.e., $P=$ constant $\therefore \quad V \downarrow T \downarrow$  Hence graph (c) is the correct $V-T$ graph of given $P-V$ graph  \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-167(1)} \end{center}  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Starting at temperature 300 K , one mole of an ideal diatomic gas $(\gamma=1.4)$ is first compressed adiabatically from volume

$\mathrm{V}_{1}$ to $\mathrm{V}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{V}_{1}}{16}$. It is then allowed to expand isobarically to volume $2 \mathrm{~V}_{2}$. If all the processes are the quasi-static then the final temperature of the gas (in ${ }^{\circ} \mathrm{K}$ ) is (to the nearest integer) $\qquad$ .
solution: For an adiabatic process, $\mathrm{TV}^{\gamma-1}=$ constant  $\therefore T_{1} V_{1}^{\gamma-1}=T_{2} V_{2}^{\gamma-1}$  $\Rightarrow T_{2}=(300) \times\left(\frac{V_{1}}{\frac{V_{1}}{16}}\right)^{1.4-1}$  $\Rightarrow T_{2}=300 \times(16)^{0.4}$  Ideal gas equation, $P V=n R T$  $\therefore \quad V=\frac{n R T}{P}$  $\Rightarrow V=k T$ (since pressure is constant for isobaric process)  So, during isobaric process  $V_{2}=k T_{2}$  $2 \mathrm{~V}_{2}=k T_{f}$  Dividing (i) by (ii)  $\frac{1}{2}=\frac{T_{2}}{T_{f}}$  $T_{f}=2 T_{2}=300 \times 2 \times(16)^{0.4}=1818 \mathrm{~K}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A thermodynamic cycle $x y z x$ is shown on a $V$-T diagram.

The $P-V$ diagram that best describes this cycle is: (Diagrams are schematic and not to scale)

$\\
solution: From the corresponding V-T graph given in question, Process $x y \rightarrow$ Isobaric expansion,  Process $y z \rightarrow$ Isochoric (Pressure decreases)  Process $z x \rightarrow$ Isothermal compression  Therefore, corresponding $P V$ graph is as shown in figure  \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-167} \end{center}  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A litre of dry air at STP expands adiabatically to a volume of 3 litres. If $\gamma=1.40$, the work done by air is:

$\left(3^{1.4}=4.6555\right)$ 

[7 Jan. 2020 I]\\
reference: Take air to be an ideal gas
solution: Given, $V_{1}=1$ litre, $P_{1}=1 \mathrm{~atm}$  $V_{2}=3$ litre, $\gamma=1.40$,  Using, $P V^{r}=$ constant $\Rightarrow P_{1} V_{1}^{\gamma}=P_{2} V_{2}^{\gamma}$  $\Rightarrow P_{2}=P_{1} \times\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{1.4}=\frac{1}{4.6555} \mathrm{~atm}$  $\therefore$ Work done, $W=\frac{P_{1} V_{1}-P_{2} V_{2}}{\gamma-1}$  $=\frac{\left(1 \times 1-\frac{1}{4.6555} \times 3\right) 1.01325 \times 10^{5} \times 10^{-3}}{0.4}=90.1 \mathrm{~J}$  Closest value of $W=90.5 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Under an adiabatic process, the volume of an ideal gas gets doubled. Consequently the mean collision time between the gas molecule changes from $\tau_{1}$ to $\tau_{2}$. If $\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}=\gamma$ for this gas then a good estimate for $\frac{\tau_{2}}{\tau_{1}}$ is given by:

\\
solution: We know that Relaxation time,  $T \propto \frac{V}{\sqrt{T}}$  Equation of adiabatic process is $T V^{-1}=$ constant  $\Rightarrow \quad T \propto \frac{1}{V^{\gamma-1}}$  $$ \begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow T \propto V^{1+\frac{\gamma-1}{2}} \quad \text { using (i) } \\ & \Rightarrow T \propto V^{\frac{1+\gamma}{2}} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{T_{f}}{T_{i}}=\left(\frac{2 V}{V}\right)^{\frac{1+\gamma}{2}}=(2)^{\frac{1+\gamma}{2}} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}
$\Delta U_{\mathrm{ac}}=-\left(\Delta U_{\mathrm{ca}}\right)=-(-180)=180 \mathrm{~J}$  $Q=250+60=310 \mathrm{~J}$  Now $Q=\Delta U+W$  or $310=180+W$  or $W=130 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A cylinder with fixed capacity of 67.2 lit contains helium gas at STP. The amount of heat needed to raise the temperature of the gas by $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is : 

$[10$ Apr. 2019 I]\\
solution: As the process is isochoric so,  $$ \mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{nc}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \mathrm{T}=\frac{67.2}{22.4} \times \frac{3 \mathrm{R}}{2} \times 20=90 \mathrm{R}=90 \times 8.31 \simeq 748 \mathrm{j} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
n moles of an ideal gas with constant volume heat capacity $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}$ undergo an isobaric expansion by certain volume. The ratio of the work done in the process, to the heat supplied is:

\\
solution: At constant volume  Work done $(\mathrm{W})=\mathrm{nR} \Delta \mathrm{T}$  Heat given $\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \mathrm{T}+\mathrm{nR} \Delta \mathrm{T}$  So, $\therefore \frac{\mathrm{W}}{\mathrm{Q}}=\frac{\mathrm{nR} \Delta \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \mathrm{T}+\mathrm{nR} \Delta \mathrm{T}}=\frac{\mathrm{nR}}{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}+\mathrm{nR}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
One mole of an ideal gas passes through a process where pressure and volume obey the relation $P=P_{0}\left$.

Here $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{o}}$ and $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{o}}$ are constants. Calculate the charge in the temperature of the gas if its volume changes from $\mathrm{V}_{0}$ to $2 \mathrm{~V}_{\mathrm{o}}$.

[10 Apr. 2019 II]\\
solution: We have given,  $P=P_{0}\left[1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{V_{0}}{V}\right)^{2}\right]$  When $\mathrm{V}_{1}=\mathrm{V}_{0}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}_{1}=\mathrm{P}_{0}\left[1-\frac{1}{2}\right]=\frac{P_{0}}{2}$  When $\mathrm{V}_{2}=2 \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}_{2}=\mathrm{P}_{0}\left[1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\right]=\left(\frac{7 P_{0}}{8}\right)$  $\Delta T=T_{2}-T_{1}=\left|\frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{n R}-\frac{P_{2} V_{2}}{n R}\right|\left[\because T=\frac{P V}{n R}\right]$  $\Delta T=\left|\left(\frac{1}{n R}\right)\left(P_{1} V_{1}-P_{2} V_{2}\right)\right|=\left(\frac{1}{n R}\right)\left|\left(\frac{P_{0} V_{0}}{2}-\frac{7 P_{0} V_{0}}{4}\right)\right|$  $=\frac{5 P_{0} V_{0}}{4 n R}=\frac{5 P_{0} V_{0}}{4 R} \quad(\because n=1)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Following figure shows two processes A and B for a gas. If $\Delta Q_{A}$ and $\Delta Q_{B}$ are the amount of heat absorbed by the system in two cases, and $\Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{A}}$ and $\Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{B}}$ are changes in internal energies, respectively, then:\\
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-160(3)}\\
solution: Internal energy depends only on initial and final state So, $\Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{A}}=\Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{B}}$  Also $\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{U}^{\mathrm{B}}+\mathrm{W}$  As $\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{A}}>\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{B}} \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{A}}>\Delta \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{B}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A thermally insulted vessel contains 150 g of water at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Then the air from the vessel is pumped out adiabatically. A fraction of water turns into ice and the rest evaporates at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ itself. The mass of evaporated water will be closed to: (Latent heat of vaporization of water $=2.10 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$ and Latent heat of Fusion of water $=3.36 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$ )

\\
solution: Suppose amount of water evaporated be M gram. Then $(150-\mathrm{M})$ gram water converted into ice.  so, heat consumed in evoporation $=$ Heat released in fusion  $\mathrm{M} \times \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{v}}=(150-\mathrm{M}) \times \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{s}}$  $\mathrm{M} \times 2.1 \times 10^{6}=(150-\mathrm{M}) \times 3.36 \times 10^{5}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{M}-20 \mathrm{~g}$\\
a $\rightarrow$ Isobasic, b $\rightarrow$ Isothermal, c $\rightarrow$ Adiabatic, $\mathrm{d} \rightarrow$ Isochoric  \begin{enumerate}

For the given cyclic process CAB as shown for gas, the work done is:

solution: Total work done by the gas during the cycle is equal to area of triangle ABC .  $\therefore \Delta \mathrm{W}=\frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 5=10 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A rigid diatomic ideal gas undergoes an adiabatic process at room temperature. The relation between temperature and volume for this process is $\mathrm{TV}^{\mathrm{x}}=$ constant, then x is:

$\\
solution: Equation of adiabatic change is $\mathrm{TV}^{\gamma-1}=$ constant  Put $\gamma=\frac{7}{5}$, we get: $\gamma-1=\frac{7}{5}-1$  $\therefore \mathrm{x}=\frac{2}{5}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Half mole of an ideal monoatomic gas is heated at constant pressure of 1 atm from $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $90^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Work done by gas is close to: (Gas constant $\mathrm{R}=8.31 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{mol}-\mathrm{K}$ ) \\
solution: Work done,  $\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{P} \Delta \mathrm{V}=\mathrm{nR} \Delta \mathrm{T}=\frac{1}{2} \times 8.31 \times 70 \simeq 291 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
One mole of an ideal monoatomic gas is taken along the path ABCA as shown in the PV diagram. The maximum temperature attained by the gas along the path BC is given by




\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-161(1)}\\
solution: Equation of the BC  $\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{P}_{0}-\frac{2 \mathrm{P}_{0}}{\mathrm{~V}_{0}}\left(\mathrm{~V}-2 \mathrm{~V}_{0}\right)$  using $\mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{nRT}$  Temperature, $\mathrm{T}=\frac{\mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}-\frac{2 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}^{2}}{\mathrm{~V}_{0}}+4 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}}{1 \times \mathrm{R}}$  $(\because \mathrm{n}=1$ mole given $)$  $\mathrm{T}=\frac{\mathrm{P}_{0}}{\mathrm{~F}}\left[5 \mathrm{~V}-\frac{2 \mathrm{~V}^{2}}{\mathrm{~V}_{0}}\right]$  $\frac{\mathrm{dT}}{\mathrm{dV}}=0 \Rightarrow 5-\frac{4 \mathrm{~V}}{\mathrm{~V}_{0}}=0 \Rightarrow \mathrm{V}=\frac{5}{4} \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  $\mathrm{T}=\frac{\mathrm{P}_{0}}{\mathrm{R}}\left[5 \times \frac{5 \mathrm{~V}_{0}}{4}-\frac{2}{\mathrm{~V}_{0}} \times \frac{25}{16} \mathrm{~V}_{0}^{2}\right]=\frac{25}{8} \frac{\mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}}{\mathrm{R}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
One mole of an ideal monoatomic gas is compressed isothermally in a rigid vessel to double its pressure at room temperature, $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The work done on the gas will be:

\\
solution: Work done on gas $=$ nRT $\ln \left(\frac{p_{f}}{p_{1}}\right)=\mathrm{R}(300) \ln (2)$  $=300 \mathrm{R} \ln 2\left(\because \frac{P_{f}}{p_{i}}=2\right.$ given $)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
'n' moles of an ideal gas undergoes a process $\mathrm{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{B}$ as shown in the figure. The maximum temperature of the gas during the process will be :



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-161(7)}\\
solution: The equation for the line is  \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-168} \end{center}  $\mathrm{P}=\frac{-\mathrm{P}_{0}}{\mathrm{~V}_{0}} \mathrm{~V}+3 \mathrm{P} \quad\left[\right.$ slope $\left.=\frac{-\mathrm{P}_{0}}{\mathrm{~V}_{0}}, \mathrm{c}=3 \mathrm{P}_{0}\right]$  $\mathrm{PV}_{0}+\mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}=3 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  But $\mathrm{pV}=\mathrm{nRT}$  $\therefore \mathrm{P}=\frac{\mathrm{nRT}}{\mathrm{V}}$  From (i) \& (ii) $\frac{\mathrm{nRT}}{\mathrm{V}} \mathrm{V}_{0}+\mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}=3 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  From (i) \& (ii) $\frac{\mathrm{nRT}}{\mathrm{V}} \mathrm{V}_{0}+\mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}=3 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  $\therefore \mathrm{nRTV}_{0}+\mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}^{2}=3 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0} \mathrm{~V}$  For temperature to be maximum $\frac{\mathrm{dT}}{\mathrm{dV}}=0$  Differentiating e.q. (iii) by ' V ' we get  $n R V_{0} \frac{d T}{d V}+\mathrm{P}_{0}(2 \mathrm{~V})=3 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  $\therefore \mathrm{nRV} \mathrm{V}_{0} \frac{\mathrm{dT}}{\mathrm{dV}}=3 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}-2 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}$  $\frac{\mathrm{dT}}{\mathrm{dV}}=\frac{3 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}-2 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}}{\mathrm{nRV}_{0}}=0$  $\mathrm{V}=\frac{3 \mathrm{~V}_{0}}{2} \quad \therefore \quad P=\frac{3 P_{0}}{2}$  [From (i)]  $\therefore \mathrm{T}_{\text {max }}=\frac{9 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}}{4 \mathrm{nR}}$  [From (iii)]  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The ratio of work done by an ideal monoatomic gas to the heat supplied to it in an isobaric process is :

\\
solution: Efficiency of heat engine is given by  $\eta=\frac{\mathrm{w}}{\mathrm{Q}}=1-\frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}}{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}}=\frac{\mathrm{R}}{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}}=\frac{\mathrm{R}}{\frac{5 \mathrm{R}}{2}}=\frac{2}{5}$  $\left(\because \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}-\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=\mathrm{R}\right)$  For monoatomic gas $C_{P}=\frac{5}{2} R$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Consider an ideal gas confined in an isolated closed chamber. As the gas undergoes an adiabatic expansion, the average time of collision between molecules increases as Vq , where V is the volume of the gas. The value of q

is: $\left(\gamma=\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}\right)$

\\
solution: $\tau=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi \mathrm{d}^{2}\left(\frac{\mathrm{N}}{\mathrm{V}}\right) \sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}}$  $\mathrm{t} \mu \frac{\mathrm{V}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{T}}}$  As, $\mathrm{TV}^{\gamma-1}=\mathrm{K}$  So, $\tau \propto \mathrm{V}^{\gamma+1 / 2}$  Therefore, $\mathrm{q}=\frac{\mathrm{g}+1}{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Consider a spherical shell of radius $R$ at temperature T. The black body radiation inside it can be considered as an ideal gas of photons with internal energy per unit volume $\mathrm{u}=$ $\frac{\mathrm{U}}{\mathrm{V}} \propto \mathrm{T}^{4}$ and pressure $\mathrm{p}=\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{\mathrm{U}}{\mathrm{V}}\right)$. If the shell now undergoes an adiabatic expansion the relation between T and R is :

\\
solution: As, $P=\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{U}{V}\right)$  But $\frac{\mathrm{U}}{\mathrm{V}}=\mathrm{KT}^{4}$  So, $\mathrm{P}=\frac{1}{3} \mathrm{KT}^{4}$  or $\frac{\mathrm{uRT}}{\mathrm{V}}=\frac{1}{3} \mathrm{KT}^{4}[\mathrm{As} \mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{uRT}]$  $\frac{4}{3} \mathrm{pR}^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{3}=$ constant  Therefore, $T \propto \frac{1}{R}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An ideal gas goes through a reversible cycle $a \rightarrow b \rightarrow c \rightarrow d$ has the V - T diagram shown below. Process $\mathrm{d} \rightarrow \mathrm{a}$ and $\mathrm{b} \rightarrow \mathrm{c}$ are adiabatic.

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-161(2)}
 

The corresponding P - V diagram for the process is (all figures are schematic and not drawn to scale) :

\\
solution: In $V T$ graph  ab-process : Isobaric, temperature increases.  bc process : Adiabatic, pressure decreases.  cd process : Isobaric, volume decreases.  da process : Adiabatic, pressure increases.  The above processes correctly represented in $P-V$ diagram (b).\\

question:
One mole of a diatomic ideal gas undergoes a cyclic process ABC as shown in figure. The process BC is adiabatic. The temperatures at $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}$ and C are $400 \mathrm{~K}, 800 \mathrm{~K}$ and 600 K respectively. Choose the correct statement:



 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-161(5)}
options: a) The change in internal energy in whole cyclic process is 250 R .
b) The change in internal energy in the process CA is 700 R .
c) The change in internal energy in the process AB is 350 R .
d) The change in internal energy in the process BC is 500 R .
solution: In cyclic process, change in total internal energy is zero. $\Delta \mathrm{U}_{\text {cyclic }}=0$  $\Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{BC}}=n C_{v} \Delta T=1 \times \frac{5 R}{2} \Delta T$  Where, $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=$ molar specific heat at constant volume.  For $\mathrm{BC}, \Delta \mathrm{T}=-200 \mathrm{~K}$  $\therefore \quad \Delta \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{BC}}=-500 \mathrm{R}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An ideal monoatomic gas is confined in a cylinder by a spring loaded piston of cross section $8.0 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}^{2}$. Initially the gas is at 300 K and occupies a volume of $2.4 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ and the spring is in its relaxed state as shown in figure. The gas is heated by a small heater until the piston moves out slowly by 0.1 m . The force constant of the spring is $8000 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$ and the atmospheric pressure is $1.0 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$. The cylinder and\\
the piston are thermally insulated. The piston and the spring are massless and there is no friction between the piston and the cylinder. The final temperature of the gas will be: (Neglect the heat loss through the lead wires of the heater. The heat capacity of the heater coil is also negligible).



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-162}\\

During an adiabatic compression, 830 J of work is done on 2 moles of a diatomic ideal gas to reduce its volume by $50 \%$. The change in its temperature is nearly:

$\left(\mathrm{R}=8.3 \mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\right.$ )

\\
solution: Given : work done, $W=830 \mathrm{~J}$   No. of moles of gas, $\mu=2$  For diatomic gas $\gamma=1.4$  Work done during an adiabatic change  $W=\frac{\mu R\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right)}{\gamma-1}$  $\Rightarrow 830=\frac{2 \times 8.3(\Delta T)}{1.4-1}=\frac{2 \times 8.3(\Delta T)}{0.4}$  $\Rightarrow \Delta T=\frac{830 \times 0.4}{2 \times 8.3}=20 \mathrm{~K}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The equation of state for a gas is given by $\mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{nRT}+\alpha \mathrm{V}$, where n is the number of moles and $\alpha$ is a positive constant. The initial temperature and pressure of one mole of the gas contained in a cylinder are $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{o}}$ and $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{o}}$ respectively. The work done by the gas when its temperature doubles isobarically will be:

\\

A certain amount of gas is taken through a cyclic process (A B C D A) that has two isobars, one isochore and one isothermal. The cycle can be represented on a $\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{V}$ indicator diagram as :

\\
solution: $\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{V}$ indicator diagram for isobaric   \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-169(1)} \end{center}  $\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{V}$ indicator diagram for isochoric process  \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-169} \end{center}  $\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{V}$ indicator diagram for isothermal process $\mathrm{P} \uparrow$  slope  $$ \xrightarrow[\mathrm{V}]{=\frac{\mathrm{dP}}{\mathrm{dV}}}=\underset{\mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{P}} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An ideal gas at atmospheric pressure is adiabatically compressed so that its density becomes 32 times of its initial value. If the final pressure of gas is 128 atmospheres, the value of ' $\gamma$ ' of the gas is :

\\
solution: Volume of the gas  $\mathrm{v}=\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{d}}$ and  Using $\mathrm{PV}^{\gamma}=$ constant  $\frac{\mathrm{P}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{P}}=\frac{\mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{d}}\right)^{\gamma}$  or $128=(32)^{\gamma}$  $\therefore \gamma=\frac{7}{5}=1.4$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Helium gas goes through a cycle ABCDA (consisting of two isochoric and isobaric lines) as shown in figure. The efficiency of this cycle is nearly : (Assume the gas to be close to ideal gas)









 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-162(2)}
solution: The efficiency  $\eta=\frac{\text { output work }}{\text { heat given to the system }}$\\ $=n \frac{3}{2} R \Delta T=\frac{3}{2} V_{0} \Delta P=\frac{3}{2} P_{0} V_{0}$  $W_{i}=\frac{\mathrm{n}}{2}\left(P_{0} V_{0}\right)+\frac{n}{2}\left(2 P_{0} V_{0}\right)+2 P_{0} V_{0}$  Heat given in going $B$ to $C=n C p \Delta T$  $=n\left(\frac{5}{2} R\right) \Delta T=\frac{5}{2}\left(2 P_{0}\right) \Delta V$  $=5 P_{0} V_{0}$  and $W_{0}=$ area under PV diagram $P_{0} V_{0}$  $\eta=\frac{W}{Q}=\frac{P_{0} V_{0}}{\frac{13}{2} P_{0} V_{0}}=\frac{2}{13}$  Efficiency in \%  $\eta=\frac{2}{13} \times 100=\frac{200}{13} \simeq 15.4 \%$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An ideal monatomic gas with pressure $P$, volume $V$ and temperature $T$ is expanded isothermally to a volume $2 V$ and a final pressure $P_{i}$. If the same gas is expanded adiabatically to a volume $2 V$, the final pressure is $P_{a}$. The ratio $\frac{P_{a}}{P_{i}}$ is

\\
solution: For isothermal process :  $P V=P_{i} .2 V$  $P=2 P_{i}$  For adiabatic process  $\mathrm{PV}^{\gamma}=\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{a}}(2 \mathrm{~V})^{\gamma}$  ( $\because$ for monatomic gas $\gamma=5 / 3$ )  or, $2 \mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}} \mathrm{V}^{\frac{5}{3}}=P_{a}(2 \mathrm{~V})^{\frac{5}{3}}$  [From (i)]  $\Rightarrow \frac{P_{a}}{P_{i}}=\frac{2}{2^{\frac{5}{3}}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{P_{a}}{P_{i}}=2^{\frac{-2}{3}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The pressure of an ideal gas varies with volume as $P=\alpha V$, where $\alpha$ is a constant. One mole of the gas is allowed to undergo expansion such that its volume becomes ' $m$ ' times its initial volume. The work done by the gas in the process is

\\
solution: Given $P=\alpha V$  Work done, $w=\int_{V}^{m V} P d V$  $=\int_{V}^{m V} \alpha V d V=\frac{\alpha V^{2}}{2}\left(m^{2}-1\right)$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
$n$ moles of an ideal gas undergo a process $A \rightarrow B$ as shown in the figure. Maximum temperature of the gas during the process is



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-162(5)}\\
solution: Work done during the process $A \rightarrow B$  $=$ Area of trapezium (= area bounded by indicator diagram with $V$-axis)  $=\frac{1}{2}\left(2 P_{0}+P_{0}\right)\left(2 V_{0}-V_{0}\right)=\frac{3}{2} P_{0} V_{0}$  Ideal gas eqn : $P V=n R T$  $\Rightarrow T=\frac{P V}{n R}=\frac{3 P_{0} V_{0}}{2 n R}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
This question has Statement 1 and Statement 2. Of the four choices given after the Statements, choose the one that best describes the two Statements.

Statement 1: In an adiabatic process, change in internal energy of a gas is equal to work done on/by the gas in the process.

Statement 2: The temperature of a gas remains constant in an adiabatic process.
options: a) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is a correct explanation of Statement 1\\
b) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false.\\
c) Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true.\\
d) Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is not a correct explanation of Statement 1.
solution: In an adiabatic process, $\delta \mathrm{H}=0$  And according to first law of thermodynamics  $\delta H=\delta U+W$  $\therefore W=-\delta U$\\

question:
A container with insulating walls is divided into equal parts by a partition fitted with a valve. One part is filled with an ideal gas at a pressure $P$ and temperature $T$, whereas the other part is completly evacuated. If the valve is suddenly opened, the pressure and temperature of the gas will be :

\\





Directions for questions 47 to 49: Questions are based on the following paragraph.

Two moles of helium gas are taken over the cycle $A B C D A$, as shown in the $P-T$ diagram.

[2009]

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-163(2)}
solution: \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-170(1)} \end{center}  It is the free expansion  $\therefore$ So, T remains constant  $\Rightarrow P_{1} V_{1}=P_{2} V_{2}$  $\Rightarrow P \frac{V}{2}=P_{2}(V)$  $P_{2}=\left(\frac{P}{2}\right)$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Assuming the gas to be ideal the work done on the gas in taking it from $A$ to $B$ is\\
solution: The process $A \rightarrow B$ is isobaric.  $\therefore$ work done $W_{A B}=n R\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right)$  $=2 R(500-300)=400 R$  \begin{enumerate}

question: The work done on the gas in taking it from $D$ to $A$ is\\
solution: The process $D$ to $A$ is isothermal as temperature is constant.  Work done, $W_{D A}=2.303 n R T \log _{10} \frac{P_{D}}{P_{A}}$  $=2.303 \times 2 R \times 300$  $\log _{10} \frac{1 \times 10^{5}}{2 \times 10^{5}}-414 \mathrm{R}$.  Therefore, work done on the gas is $+414 R$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: The net work done on the gas in the cycle $A B C D A$ is\\
solution: The net work in the cycle $A B C D A$ is  $W=W_{A B}+W_{B C}+W_{C D}+W_{D A}$  $=400 R+2.303 n R T \log \frac{P_{B}}{P_{C}}+(-400 R)-414 R$  $=2.303 \times 2 R \times 500 \log \frac{2 \times 10^{5}}{1 \times 10^{5}}-414 R$  $=693.2 R-414 R \quad=279.2 R$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The work of 146 kJ is performed in order to compress one kilo mole of gas adiabatically and in this process the temperature of the gas increases by $7^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The gas is


 ( $R=8.3 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$ )
options: c) a mixture of monoatomic and diatomic
solution: Work done in adiabatic compression is given by  $W=\frac{n R \Delta T}{1-\gamma}$  $\Rightarrow-146000=\frac{1000 \times 8.3 \times 7}{1-\gamma}$  or $1-\gamma=-\frac{58.1}{146} \Rightarrow \gamma=1+\frac{58.1}{146}=1.4$  Hence the gas is diatomic.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Which of the following parameters does not characterize the thermodynamic state of matter?

\\
solution: Work is not a state function. The remaining three parameters are state function.

question:
An engine operates by taking a monatomic ideal gas through the cycle shown in the figure. The percentage efficiency of the engine is close is $\qquad$ .



 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-163(1)}
solution: \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-170} \end{center}  From the figure,  Work, $W=2 P_{0} V_{0}$  Heat given, $Q_{\mathrm{in}}=W_{A B}+W_{B C}=n \cdot C_{V} \Delta T_{A B}+n C_{P} \Delta T_{B C}$  $=n \frac{3 R}{2}\left(T_{B}-T_{A}\right)+\frac{n 5 R}{2}\left(T_{C}-T_{B}\right)$ $\left(\because C_{v}=\frac{3 R}{2}\right.$ and $\left.C_{P}=\frac{5 R}{2}\right)$  $=\frac{3}{2}\left(P_{B} V_{B}-P_{A} V_{A}\right)+\frac{5}{2}\left(P_{C} V_{C}-P_{B} V_{B}\right)$  $=\frac{3}{2} \times\left[3 P_{0} V_{0}-P_{0} V_{0}\right]+\frac{5}{2}\left[6 P_{0} V_{0}-3 P_{0} V_{0}\right]$  $=3 P_{0} V_{0}+\frac{15}{2} P_{0} V_{0}=\frac{21}{2} P_{0} V_{0}$  Efficiency, $\eta=\frac{W}{Q_{\text {in }}}=\frac{2 P_{0} V_{0}}{\frac{21}{2} P_{0} V_{0}}=\frac{4}{21}$  $\eta \%=\frac{400}{21} \approx 19$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: If minimum possible work is done by a refrigerator in converting 100 grams of water at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to ice, how much heat (in calories) is released to the surroundings at temperature $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ (Latent heat of ice $=80 \mathrm{Ca} 1 /$ gram $)$ to the nearest integer?
solution: Given,  Heat absorbed, $Q_{2}=m L=80 \times 100=8000 \mathrm{Cal}$  Temperature of ice, $T_{2}=273 \mathrm{~K}$  Temperature of surrounding,  $T_{1}=273+27=300 \mathrm{~K}$  Efficiency $=\frac{w}{Q_{2}}=\frac{Q_{1}-Q_{2}}{Q_{2}}=\frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{T_{2}}=\frac{300-273}{273}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{Q_{1}-8000}{8000}=\frac{27}{273} \Rightarrow Q_{1}=8791 \mathrm{Cal}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A heat engine is involved with exchange of heat of 1915 J , $-40 \mathrm{~J},+125 \mathrm{~J}$ and $-Q \mathrm{~J}$, during one cycle achieving an efficiency of $50.0 \%$. The value of $Q$ is :

\\
solution: Efficiency, $\eta=\frac{\text { Work done }}{\text { Heat absorbed }}=\frac{W}{\Sigma Q}$  $$ =\frac{Q_{1}+Q_{2}+Q_{3}+Q_{4}}{Q_{1}+Q_{3}}=0.5 $$  Here, $Q_{1}=1915 \mathrm{~J}, Q_{2}=-40 \mathrm{~J}$ and $Q_{3}=125 \mathrm{~J}$  $\therefore \frac{1915-40+125+Q_{4}}{1915+125}=0.5$  $\Rightarrow 1915-40+125+Q_{4}=1020$  $\Rightarrow Q_{4}=1020-2000$  $\Rightarrow Q_{4}=-Q=-980 \mathrm{~J}$  $\Rightarrow Q=980 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A Carnot engine having an efficiency of $\frac{1}{10}$ is being used as a refrigerator. If the work done on the refrigerator is 10 J , the amount of heat absorbed from the reservoir at lower temperature is:

\\
solution: For carnot refrigerator  Efficiency $=\frac{Q_{1}-Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}$  Where,  $Q_{1}=$ heat lost from sorrounding  $Q_{2}=$ heat absorbed from reservoir at low temperature.\\ Also, $\frac{Q_{1}-Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=\frac{w}{Q_{1}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{10}=\frac{\mathrm{w}}{\mathrm{Q}_{1}}$  $\Rightarrow Q_{1}=w \times 10=100 \mathrm{~J}$  So, $\mathrm{Q}_{1}-Q_{2}=w$  $\Rightarrow Q_{2}=Q_{1}-w$  $\Rightarrow 100-10=Q_{2}=90 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A Carnot engine operates between two reservoirs of temperatures 900 K and 300 K . The engine performs 1200 J of work per cycle. The heat energy (in J) delivered by the engine to the low temperature reservoir, in a cycle, is
solution: Given; $T_{1}=900 \mathrm{~K}, T_{2}=300 \mathrm{~K}, W=1200 \mathrm{~J}$  Using, $1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=\frac{W}{Q_{1}}$  $\Rightarrow 1-\frac{300}{900}=\frac{1200}{Q_{1}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{2}{3}=\frac{1200}{Q_{1}} \Rightarrow Q_{1}=1800$  Therefore heat energy delivered by the engine to the low temperature reservoir, $\mathrm{Q}_{2}=\mathrm{Q}_{1}-\mathrm{W}=1800-1200=$ 600.00 J  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two ideal Carnot engines operate in cascade (all heat given up by one engine is used by the other engine to produce work) between temperatures, $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$. The temperature of the hot reservoir of the first engine is $T_{1}$ and the temperature of the cold reservoir of the second engine is $T_{2}$. T is temperature of the sink of first engine which is also the source for the second engine. How is $T$ related to $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$, if both the engines perform equal amount of work ?

\\
solution: Let $Q_{H}=$ Heat taken by first engine  $Q_{L}=$ Heat rejected by first engine  $Q_{2}=$ Heat rejected by second engine  Work done by $1^{\text {st }}$ engine $=$ work done by $2^{\text {nd }}$ engine  $W=Q_{H}-Q_{L}=Q_{L}-Q_{2} \quad \Rightarrow 2 Q_{L}=Q_{H}+Q_{2}$  $2=\frac{\theta_{H}}{\theta_{L}}+\frac{\theta_{2}}{\theta_{L}}$  Let T be the temperature of cold reservoir of first engine. Then in carnot engine.  $\frac{Q_{H}}{Q_{L}}=\frac{T_{1}}{T}$ and $\frac{Q_{L}}{Q_{2}}=\frac{T}{T_{2}}$  $\Rightarrow 2=\frac{T_{1}}{T}+\frac{T_{2}}{T}$  using (i)  $\Rightarrow \quad 2 T=T_{1}+T_{2} \quad \Rightarrow \quad T=\frac{T_{1}+T_{2}}{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A Carnot engine has an efficiency of $1 / 6$. When the temperature of the sink is reduced by $62^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, its efficiency is doubled. The temperatures of the source and the sink are, respectively.

\\
solution: Using, $n=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}$  $n=\frac{1}{6}=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}$  and $\frac{T}{3}=1-\frac{T_{2}-62}{T_{1}}$  On solving, we get  $T_{1}=99^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $T_{2}=37^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Three Carnot engines operate in series between a heat source at a temperature $T_{1}$ and a heat sink at temperature $\mathrm{T}_{4}$ (see figure). There are two other reservoirs at temperature $\mathrm{T}_{2}^{4}$ and $\mathrm{T}_{3}$, as shown, with $\mathrm{T}_{1}>\mathrm{T}_{2}>\mathrm{T}_{3}>\mathrm{T}(4)$ The three engines are equally efficient if:

\\
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-163}\\
solution: According to question, $\eta_{1}=\eta_{2}=\eta_{3}$  $\therefore 1-\frac{\mathrm{T}_{2}}{\mathrm{~T}_{1}}=1-\frac{\mathrm{T}_{3}}{\mathrm{~T}_{2}}=1-\frac{\mathrm{T}_{4}}{\mathrm{~T}_{3}}$  $[\because$ Three engines are equally efficient $]$\\ $\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{T}_{2}}{\mathrm{~T}_{1}}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{3}}{\mathrm{~T}_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{4}}{\mathrm{~T}_{3}}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_{2}=\sqrt{\mathrm{T}_{1} \mathrm{~T}_{3}}$  $\mathrm{T}_{3}=\sqrt{\mathrm{T}_{2} \mathrm{~T}_{4}}$  From (i) and (ii)  $\mathrm{T}_{2}=\left(\mathrm{T}_{1}^{2} \mathrm{~T}_{4}\right)^{1 / 3}$  $\mathrm{T}_{3}=\left(\mathrm{T}_{1} \mathrm{~T}_{4}^{2}\right)^{1 / 3}$

question:
Two Carnot engines A and B are operated in series. The first one, A receives heat at $\mathrm{T}_{1}(=600 \mathrm{~K})$ and rejects to a reservoir at temperature $\mathrm{T}_{2}$. The second engine B receives heat rejected by the first engine and in turn, rejects to a heat reservoir at $\mathrm{T}_{3}(=400 \mathrm{~K})$. Calculate the temperature $\mathrm{T}_{2}$ if the work outputs of the two engines are equal:

\\
solution: $\eta_{\mathrm{A}}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{1}-T_{2}}{\mathrm{~T}_{1}}=\frac{\mathrm{w}_{\mathrm{A}}}{\mathrm{Q}_{1}}$  and, $\eta_{B}=\frac{T_{2}-T_{3}}{T_{2}}=\frac{W_{B}}{Q_{2}}$  According to question,  $\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{B}}$  $\therefore \frac{\mathrm{Q}_{1}}{\mathrm{Q}_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{1}}{\mathrm{~T}_{2}} \times \frac{\mathrm{T}_{2}-\mathrm{T}_{3}}{\mathrm{~T}_{1}-\mathrm{T}_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{1}}{\mathrm{~T}_{2}}$  $\therefore \mathrm{T}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{1}+\mathrm{T}_{3}}{2}$  $=\frac{600+400}{2}$  $=500 \mathrm{~K}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A Carnot's engine works as a refrigerator between 250 K and 300 K . It receives 500 cal heat from the reservoir at the lower temperature. The amount of work done in each cycle to operate the refrigerator is: \\
solution: Given: Temperature of cold body, $\mathrm{T}_{2}=250 \mathrm{~K}$ temperature of hot body; $\mathrm{T}_{1}=300 \mathrm{~K}$  Heat received, $Q_{2}=500$ cal work done, $\mathrm{W}=$ ?  Efficiency $=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=\frac{W}{Q_{2}+W} \Rightarrow 1-\frac{250}{300}=\frac{W}{Q_{2}+W}$  $\mathrm{W}=\frac{Q_{2}}{5}=\frac{500 \times 4.2}{5} \mathrm{~J}=420 \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two Carnot engines A and B are operated in series. Engine A receives heat from a reservoir at 600 K and rejects heat to a reservoir at temperature T. Engine B receives heat rejected by engine A and in turn rejects it to a reservoir at 100 K . If the efficiencies of the two engines $A$ and $B$ are represented by $\eta_{A}$ and $\eta_{B}$ respectively, then what is the value of $\frac{\eta_{A}}{\eta_{B}}$


\\
solution: Efficiency of engine $A, n_{A}=\frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{T_{1}}$  and $n_{B}=\frac{T_{2}-T_{3}}{T_{2}} ; T_{2}=\frac{T_{1}+T_{3}}{2}=350 \mathrm{~K}$  or $\frac{n_{A}}{n_{B}}=\frac{\frac{600-350}{600}}{\frac{350-100}{350}}=\frac{7}{12}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An engine operates by taking n moles of an ideal gas through the cycle ABCDA shown in figure. The thermal efficiency of the engine is : (Take $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=1.5 \mathrm{R}$, where R is gas constant)











 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-164(1)}
solution: Work-done $(\mathrm{W})=\mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  According to principle of calorimetry  Heat given $=\mathrm{Q}_{A B}=Q_{B C}$  $=\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{V}} \mathrm{dT}_{\mathrm{AB}}+\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{P}} \mathrm{dT}_{\mathrm{BC}}$  $=\frac{3}{2}\left(\mathrm{nRT}_{\mathrm{B}}-\mathrm{nRT}_{\mathrm{A}}\right)+\frac{5}{2}\left(\mathrm{nRT}_{\mathrm{C}}-\mathrm{nRT}_{\mathrm{B}}\right)$  $=\frac{3}{2}\left(2 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}-\mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}\right)+\frac{5}{2}\left(4 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}-2 \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}\right)$  $=\frac{13}{2} \mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~V}_{0}$  \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-172} \end{center}  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A Carnot freezer takes heat from water at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ inside it and rejects it to the room at a temperature of $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The latent heat of ice is $336 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$. If 5 kg of water at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is converted into ice at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ by the freezer, then the energy consumed by the freezer is close to :

\\
solution: $\Delta \mathrm{H}=\mathrm{mL}=5 \times 336 \times 10^{3}=\mathrm{Q}_{\text {sink }}$  $\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{\text {sink }}}{\mathrm{Q}_{\text {source }}}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\text {sink }}}{\mathrm{T}_{\text {source }}}$  $\therefore \mathrm{Q}_{\text {source }}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\text {source }}}{\mathrm{T}_{\text {sink }}} \times \mathrm{Q}_{\text {sink }}$  Energy consumed by freezer  $\therefore \mathrm{w}_{\text {output }}=\mathrm{Q}_{\text {source }}-\mathrm{Q}_{\text {sink }}=\mathrm{Q}_{\text {sink }}\left(\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\text {source }}}{\mathrm{T}_{\text {sink }}}-1\right)$  Given: $\mathrm{T}_{\text {source }}=27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}+273=300 \mathrm{~K}$,  $\mathrm{T}_{\text {sink }}=0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}+273=273 \mathrm{k}$  $\mathrm{W}_{\text {output }}=5 \times 336 \times 10^{3}\left(\frac{300}{273}-1\right)=1.67 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A solid body of constant heat capacity $1 \mathrm{~J} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is being heated by keeping it in contact with reservoirs in two ways : 

(i) Sequentially keeping in contact with 2 reservoirs such that each reservoir supplies same amount of heat.\\
(ii) Sequentially keeping in contact with 8 reservoirs such that each reservoir supplies same amount of heat.

In both the cases body is brought from initial temperature $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to final temperature $200^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Entropy change of the body in the two cases respectively is :\\
solution: The entropy change of the body in the two cases is same as entropy is a state function.

question:
A Carnot engine absorbs 1000 J of heat energy from a reservoir at $127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and rejects 600 J of heat energy during each cycle. The efficiency of engine and temperature of sink will be:

\\
solution: Given: $\mathrm{Q}_{1}=1000 \mathrm{~J}$   $$ \begin{aligned} & \mathrm{Q}_{2}=600 \mathrm{~J} \\ & \mathrm{~T}_{1}=127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=400 \mathrm{~K} \\ & \mathrm{~T}_{2}=? \\ & \eta=? \end{aligned} $$  Efficiency of carnot engine,  $$ \eta=\frac{W}{Q_{1}} \times 100 \% $$  or, $\eta=\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{2}-\mathrm{Q}_{1}}{\mathrm{Q}_{1}} \times 100 \%$  or, $\eta=\frac{1000-600}{1000} \times 100 \%$  $\eta=40 \%$  Now, for carnot cycle $\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{2}}{\mathrm{Q}_{1}}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{2}}{\mathrm{~T}_{1}}$  $\frac{600}{1000}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{2}}{400}$  $\mathrm{T}_{2}=\frac{600 \times 400}{1000}$  $=240 \mathrm{~K}$  $=240-273$  $\therefore \mathrm{T}_{2}=-33^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  \begin{enumerate}

Heat is extracted from the source in path DA and AB is  $\Delta Q=\frac{3}{2} R\left(\frac{P_{0} V_{0}}{R}\right)+\frac{5}{2} R\left(\frac{2 P_{0} V_{0}}{R}\right)$  $\Rightarrow \frac{3}{2} P_{0} V_{0}+\frac{5}{2} 2 P_{0} V_{0}=\left(\frac{13}{2}\right) P_{0} V_{0}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A Carnot engine, whose efficiency is $40 \%$, takes in heat from a source maintained at a temperature of 500 K . It is desired to have an engine of efficiency $60 \%$. Then, the intake temperature for the same exhaust (sink) temperature must be :
options: a) efficiency ofCarnot engine cannot be made larger than $50 \%$
solution: The efficiency of the carnot's heat engine is given as  $\eta=\left(1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right) \times 100$  When efficiency is $40 \%$,  $\mathrm{T}_{1}=500 \mathrm{~K} ; \eta=40$  $40=\left(1-\frac{T_{2}}{500}\right) \times 100$  $\Rightarrow \frac{40}{100}=1-\frac{T_{2}}{500}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{T_{2}}{500}=\frac{60}{100} \Rightarrow T_{2}=300 \mathrm{~K}$  When efficiency is $60 \%$, then  $\frac{60}{100}=\left(1-\frac{300}{T_{2}}\right) \Rightarrow \frac{300}{T_{2}}=\frac{40}{100}$  $\Rightarrow T_{2}=\frac{100 \times 300}{40} \Rightarrow T_{2}=750 \mathrm{~K}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: The door of a working refrigerator is left open in a well insulated room. The temperature of air in the room will
options: b) increase in winters and decrease in summers
solution: In a refrigerator, the heat dissipated in the atmosphere is more than that taken from the cooling chamber, therefore the room is heated. If the door of a refrigerator is kept open.

question:
This question has Statement 1 and Statement 2. Of the four choices given after the Statements, choose the one that best describes the two Statements.

Statement 1: An inventor claims to have constructed an engine that has an efficiency of $30 \%$ when operated between the boiling and freezing points of water. This is not possible.

Statement 2: The efficiency of a real engine is always less than the efficiency of a Carnot engine operating between the same two temperatures.
options: a) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is not the correct explanation of Statement 1.
b) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false.
c) Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true.
d) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is the correct explanation of Statement 1.
solution: According to Carnot's theorem - no heat engine working between two given temperatures of source and sink can be more efficient than a perfectly reversible engine i.e. Carnot engine working between the same two temperatures.   Efficiency of Carnot's engine, $n=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}$  where, $T_{1}=$ temperature of source  $T_{2}=$ temperature of sink  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A Carnot engine operating between temperatures $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$ has efficiency $\frac{1}{6}$. When $T_{2}$ is lowered by 62 K its efficiency increases to $\frac{1}{3}$. Then $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$ are, respectively:

\\
solution: Efficiency of engine  $\eta_{1}=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=\frac{1}{6}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=\frac{5}{6}$  When $T_{2}$ is lowered by 62 K , then  Again, $\eta_{2}=1-\frac{T_{2}-62}{T_{1}}$  $=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}+\frac{62}{T_{1}}=\frac{1}{3}$  Solving (i) and (ii), we get,  $T_{1}=372 \mathrm{~K}$ and $T_{2}=\frac{5}{6} \times 372=310 \mathrm{~K}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A diatomic ideal gas is used in a Carnot engine as the working substance. If during the adiabatic expansion part of the cycle the volume of the gas increases from $V$ to 32 $V$, the efficiency of the engine is

\\
solution: \begin{center} \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-173(1)} \end{center}  For adiabatic expansion $T_{1} V_{1}^{\gamma-1}=T_{2} V_{2}^{\gamma-1}$  $\Rightarrow T_{1} V^{g-1}=T_{2}(32 V)^{g-1}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=(32)^{\gamma-1}$  For diatomic gas, $\gamma=\frac{7}{5}$  $\therefore \gamma-1=\frac{2}{5}$  $\therefore \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=(32)^{\frac{2}{5}} \Rightarrow T_{1}=4 T_{2}$  Now, efficiency $=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}$  $=1-\frac{T_{2}}{4 T_{2}}=1-\frac{1}{4}=\frac{3}{4}=0.75$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A Carnot engine, having an efficiency of $\eta=1 / 10$ as heat engine, is used as a refrigerator. If the work done on the system is 10 J , the amount of energy absorbed from the reservoir at lower temperature is

\\
solution: The efficiency $(\eta)$ of a Carnot engine and the coefficient of performance $(\beta)$ of a refrigerator are related as  $\beta=\frac{1-\eta}{\eta}$  Also, $\beta=\frac{Q_{2}}{W}$  $\therefore \beta=\frac{1-n}{n}=\frac{Q_{2}}{W}$  $\therefore \beta=\frac{1-\frac{1}{10}}{\left(\frac{1}{10}\right)}=\frac{Q_{2}}{W}$.  is independent of path taken by the process.  $\Rightarrow 9=\frac{Q_{2}}{10}$  $\Rightarrow Q_{2}=90 \mathrm{~J}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The temperature-entropy diagram of a reversible engine cycle is given in the figure. Its efficiency is



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-165}\\
solution: $Q_{1}=$ area under $\mathrm{BC}=T_{0} S_{0}+\frac{1}{2} T_{0} S_{0}$  $Q_{2}=$ area under $\mathrm{AC}=T_{0}\left(2 S_{0}-S_{0}\right)=T_{0} S_{0}$ and $Q_{3}=0$  Efficiency, $\eta=\frac{W}{Q_{1}}=\frac{Q_{1}-Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}$  \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_994712a208f33052b085g-173}\\ $=1-\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=1-\frac{T_{0} S_{0}}{\frac{3}{2} T_{0} S_{0}}=\frac{1}{3}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Which of the following statements is correct for any thermodynamic system?
options: a) The change in entropy can never be zero
b) Internal energy and entropy are state functions
c) The internal energy changes in all processes
d) The work done in an adiabatic process is always zero.
solution: Internal energy and entropy are state function, they are independent of path taken.

question: "Heat cannot by itself flow from a body at lower temperature to a body at higher temperature" is a statement or consequence of
solution: This is a consequence of second law of thermodynamics

question:
A Carnot engine takes $3 \times 10^{6}$ cal of heat from a reservoir at $627^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and gives it to a sink at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The work done by the engine is

\\
solution: Here, $T_{1}=627+273=900 \mathrm{~K}$   $T_{2}=27+273=300 \mathrm{~K}$  Efficiency, $\eta=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}$  $=1-\frac{300}{900}=1-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{2}{3}$  But $\eta=\frac{W}{Q}$ $\therefore \frac{W}{Q}=\frac{2}{3} \Rightarrow W=\frac{2}{3} \times Q=\frac{2}{3} \times 3 \times 10^{6}$  $=2 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{cal}$  $=2 \times 10^{6} \times 4.2 \mathrm{~J}=8.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Which statement is incorrect?
options: a) All reversible cycles have same efficiency
b) Reversible cycle has more efficiency than an irreversible one
c) Carnot cycle is a reversible one
d) Carnot cycle has the maximum efficiency in all cycles
solution: All reversible engines have same efficiencies if they are working for the same temperature of source and sink. If the temperatures are different, the efficiency is different.

question: Even Carnot engine cannot give $100 \%$ efficiency because we cannot
solution: In Carnot's cycle we assume frictionless piston, absolute insulation and ideal source and sink (reservoirs).   The efficiency of carnot's cycle $\eta=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}$  The efficiency of carnot engine will be $100 \%$ when its sink $\left(T_{2}\right)$ is at 0 K .
