solution: Time lost/gained per day $=\frac{1}{2} \propto \Delta \theta \times 86400$ second  $12=\frac{1}{2} \alpha(40-\theta) \times 86400$  $4=\frac{1}{2} \alpha(\theta-20) \times 86400$  On dividing we get, $3=\frac{40-\theta}{\theta-20}$  $3 \theta-60=40-\theta$  $4 \theta=100 \Rightarrow \theta=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
In an engine the piston undergoes vertical simple harmonic motion with amplitude 7 cm . A washer rests on top of the piston and moves with it. The motor speed is slowly increased. The frequency of the piston at which the washer no longer stays in contact with the piston, is close to :

\\
solution: Washer contact with piston $\Rightarrow \mathrm{N}=0$  Given Amplitude $\mathrm{A}=7 \mathrm{~cm}=0.07 \mathrm{~m}$.  $\mathrm{a}_{\max }=\mathrm{g}=\omega^{2} \mathrm{~A}$  The frequency of piston  $\mathrm{f}=\frac{\omega}{2 \pi}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{g}}{\mathrm{A}}} \frac{1}{2 \pi}=\sqrt{\frac{1000}{7}} \frac{1}{2 \pi}=1.9 \mathrm{~Hz}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A pendulum made of a uniform wire of cross sectional area A has time period T . When an additional mass M is added to its bob, the time period changes to $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{M}}$. If the Young's modulus of the material of the wire is Y then $\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y}}$ is equal to:

$(g=$ gravitational acceleration)

$$\\
solution: As we know, time period, $\mathrm{T}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{\mathrm{g}}}$  When additional mass M is added then  $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{M}}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell+\Delta \ell}{\mathrm{g}}}$  $\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{M}}}{\mathrm{T}}=\sqrt{\frac{\ell+\Delta \ell}{\ell}}$  $\Rightarrow\left(\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{M}}}{\mathrm{T}}\right)^{2}=\frac{\ell+\Delta \ell}{\ell}$  or, $\left(\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{M}}}{\mathrm{T}}\right)^{2}=1+\frac{\mathrm{Mg}}{\mathrm{AY}} \quad\left[\because \Delta \ell=\frac{\mathrm{Mg} \ell}{\mathrm{AY}}\right]$  $\therefore \frac{1}{\mathrm{Y}}=\left[\left(\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{M}}}{\mathrm{T}}\right)^{2}-1\right] \frac{\mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{Mg}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A particle moves with simple harmonic motion in a straight line. In first $\tau \mathrm{s}$, after starting from rest it travels a distance a , and in next $\tau \mathrm{s}$ it travels 2 a , in same direction, then:
options: a) amplitude of motion is 3 a
b) time period of oscillations is $8 \tau$
c) amplitude of motion is 4 a
d) time period of oscillations is $6 \tau$
solution: In simple harmonic motion, starting from rest, At $t=0, x=A$  $x=A \cos \omega t$  When $t=\tau, x=A-a$  When $\mathrm{t}=2 \tau, x=A-3 a$  From equation (i)  $A-a=A \cos \omega \tau$  $A-3 a=A \cos 2 \omega \tau$  As $\cos 2 \omega \tau=2 \cos ^{2} \omega \tau-1$...(iv)  From equation (ii), (iii) and (iv)  $\frac{A-3 a}{A}=2\left(\frac{A-a}{A}\right)^{2}-1$  $\Rightarrow \quad \frac{A-3 a}{A}=\frac{2 A^{2}+2 a^{2}-4 A a-A^{2}}{A^{2}}$  $$ \begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \quad A^{2}-3 a A=A^{2}+2 a^{2}-4 A a \\ & \Rightarrow \quad 2 a^{2}=a A \\ & \Rightarrow \quad A=2 a \\ & \Rightarrow \quad \frac{a}{A}=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned} $$  Now, $A-a=\mathrm{A} \cos \omega \tau$  $\Rightarrow \quad \cos \omega \tau=\frac{A-a}{A}$  $\Rightarrow \quad \cos \omega \tau=\frac{1}{2} \quad$ or $\quad \frac{2 \pi}{T} \tau=\frac{\pi}{3}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}=6 \tau$  \begin{enumerate}

From graph it is clear that when  $\mathrm{L}=1 \mathrm{~m}, \mathrm{~T}^{2}=4 \mathrm{~s}^{2}$  As we know,  $\mathrm{T}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{L}{\mathrm{~g}}}$  $\Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{g}=\frac{4 \pi^{2} \mathrm{~L}}{\mathrm{~T}^{2}}$  $=4 \times\left(\frac{22}{7}\right)^{2} \times \frac{1}{4}=\left(\frac{22}{7}\right)^{2}$  $\therefore \quad \mathrm{g}=\frac{484}{49}=9.87 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The amplitude of a simple pendulum, oscillating in air with a small spherical bob, decreases from 10 cm to 8 cm in 40 seconds. Assuming that Stokes law is valid, and ratio of the coefficient of viscosity of air to that of carbon dioxide is 1.3. The time in which amplitude of this pendulum will reduce from 10 cm to 5 cm in carbon dioxide will be close to (In $5=1.601, \operatorname{In} 2=0.693$ ).

\\
solution: As we know,  $x=x_{0} e^{-b t / 2 m}$  From question,  $8=10 e^{-\frac{40 b}{2 m}}$  Similarly, $5=10 e^{-\frac{b t}{2 m}}$  Solving eqns (i) and (ii) we get  $\mathrm{t} \cong 142 \mathrm{~s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two bodies of masses 1 kg and 4 kg are connected to a vertical spring, as shown in the figure. The smaller mass executes simple harmonic motion of angular frequency $25 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$, and amplitude 1.6 cm while the bigger mass remains stationary on the ground. The maximum force exerted by the system on the floor is (take $\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$ )



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-35}\\
solution: Mass of bigger body $M=4 \mathrm{~kg}$  Mass of smaller body $\mathrm{m}=1 \mathrm{~kg}$  Smaller mass ( $\mathrm{m}=1 \mathrm{~kg}$ ) executes S.H.M of angular frequency $\omega=25 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$  Amplitude $\mathrm{x}=1.6 \mathrm{~cm}=1.6 \times 10^{-2}$  As we know,  $\mathrm{T}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{K}}}$  or, $\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{K}}}$  or, $\frac{1}{25}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{\mathrm{~K}}}[\because \mathrm{m}=1 \mathrm{~kg} ; \omega=25 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}]$  or, $\mathrm{K}=625 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}$.  The maximum force exerted by the system on the floor  $$ =\quad \mathrm{Mg}+\mathrm{Kx}+\mathrm{mg} $$  $$ \begin{array}{ll} = & 4 \times 10+625 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-2}+1 \times 10 \\ = & 40+10+10 \\ = & 60 \mathrm{~N} \end{array} $$

question:
An ideal gas enclosed in a vertical cylindrical container supports a freely moving piston of mass M. The piston and the cylinder have equal cross sectional area A . When the piston is in equilibrium, the volume of the gas is $V_{0}$ and its pressure is $\mathrm{P}_{0}$. The piston is slightly displaced from the equilibrium position and released. Assuming that the system is completely isolated from its surrounding, the piston executes a simple harmonic motion with frequency

\\
solution: $\frac{M g}{A}=P_{0}$  $P_{0} V_{0}^{\gamma}=P V^{\gamma}$  $\mathrm{Mg}=\mathrm{P}_{0} \mathrm{~A}$  Let piston is displaced by distance $x$   \begin{equation*} P_{0} A x_{0}^{\gamma}=P A\left(x_{0}-x\right)^{\gamma} \tag{1} \end{equation*}   $P=\frac{P_{0} x_{0}^{\gamma}}{\left(x_{0}-x\right)^{\gamma}}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-46}   $M g-\left(\frac{P_{0} x_{0}^{\gamma}}{\left(x_{0}-x\right)^{\gamma}}\right) A=F_{\text {restoring }}$  $P_{0} A\left(1-\frac{x_{0}^{\gamma}}{\left(x_{0}-x\right)^{\gamma}}\right)=F_{\text {restoring }} \quad\left[x_{0}-x \approx x_{0}\right]$  $F=-\frac{\gamma P_{0} A x}{x_{0}}$  $\therefore$ Frequency with which piston executes SHM  $f=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{\gamma P_{0} A}{x_{0} M}}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{\gamma P_{0} A^{2}}{M V_{0}}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A mass $m=1.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ is put on a flat pan attached to a vertical spring fixed on the ground. The mass of the spring and the pan is negligible. When pressed slightly and released, the mass executes simple harmonic motion. The spring constant is $500 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$. What is the amplitude A of the motion, so that the mass $m$ tends to get detached from the pan?

(Take $g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ ).

The spring is stiff enough so that it does not get distorted during the motion.



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-36(1)}\\
solution: As $\mathrm{F}=-\mathrm{kx}$

question:
Two simple pendulums of length 1 m and 4 m respectively are both given small displacement in the same direction at the same instant. They will be again in phase after the shorter pendulum has completed number of oscillations equal to :

\\
solution: Let $\mathrm{T}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{T}_{2}$ be the time period of the two pendulums   $\mathrm{T}_{1}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{1}{\mathrm{~g}}}$ and $\mathrm{T}_{2}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{4}{\mathrm{~g}}}$  As $\ell_{1}<\ell_{2}$ therefore $\mathrm{T}_{1}<\mathrm{T}_{2}$  Let at $\mathrm{t}=0$ they start swinging together. Since their time periods are different, the swinging will not be in unison always. Only when number of completed oscillations differ by an integer, the two pendulums will again begin to swing together  Let longer length pendulum complete n oscillation and shorter length pendulum complete $(\mathrm{n}+1)$ oscillation. For unison swinging  $$ \begin{aligned} & (\mathrm{n}+1) \mathrm{T}_{1}=\mathrm{nT}_{2} \\ & (\mathrm{n}+1) \times 2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{\mathrm{~g}}}=(\mathrm{n}) \times 2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{4}{\mathrm{~g}}} \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{n}=1 \\ & \therefore \mathrm{n}+1=1+1=2 \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If a simple pendulum has significant amplitude (up to a factor of $1 / \mathrm{e}$ of original) only in the period between $t=$ 0 s to $t=\tau \mathrm{s}$, then $\tau$ may be called the average life of the pendulum. When the spherical bob of the pendulum suffers a retardation (due to viscous drag) proportional to its velocity with $b$ as the constant of proportionality, the average life time of the pendulum in second is (assuming damping is small)

\\
solution: The equation of motion for the pendulum, for damped harmonic motion   \begin{align*} & F=-k x-b v \\ & \Rightarrow m a+k x+b v=0 \\ & \Rightarrow \quad m \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}+k x+b \frac{d x}{d t}=0 \\ & \Rightarrow \quad \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}+\frac{k}{m} x+\frac{b}{m} \frac{d x}{d t}=0 \\ & \Rightarrow \quad \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}+\frac{b}{m} \frac{d x}{d t}+\frac{k}{m} x=0 \tag{1} \end{align*}   Let $x=e^{\lambda t}$ is the solution of the equation (1)  $\frac{d x}{d t}=\lambda e^{\lambda t} \Rightarrow \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=\lambda^{2} e^{\lambda t}$  Substituting in the equation (1)  $\lambda^{2} e^{\lambda t}+\frac{b}{m} \lambda e^{\lambda t}+\frac{k}{m} e^{\lambda t}=0$  $\lambda^{2}+\frac{b}{m} \lambda+\frac{k}{m}=0$  $\lambda=\frac{-\frac{b}{m} \pm \sqrt{\frac{b^{2}}{m^{2}}-4 \frac{k}{m}}}{2}=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 k m}}{2 m}$  Solving the equation (1) for $x$, we have  $x=e^{\frac{-b}{2 m} t}$  $\omega=\sqrt{\omega_{0}^{2}-\lambda^{2}}$ where $\omega_{0}=\frac{k}{m}, \lambda=\frac{+b}{2}$  The average life $=\frac{1}{\lambda}=\frac{2}{b}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A ring is suspended from a point $S$ on its rim as shown in the figure. When displaced from equilibrium, it oscillates with time period of 1 second. The radius of the ring is

(take $g=\pi^{2}$ )



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-36}\\

A wooden cube (density of wood ' $d$ ') of side ' $\ell$ ' floats in a liquid of density ' $\rho$ ' with its upper and lower surfaces horizontal. If the cube is pushed slightly down and released, it performs simple harmonic motion of period 'T'

\\
solution: Let the cube be at a depth $x$ from the equilibrium position.   Force acting on the cube $=$ up thrust on the portion of length $x$.  $F=-\rho \ell^{2} x g[\therefore$ mass density $X$ volume $]$  Clearly $F \propto-x$, Hence it is a SHM.  Equation of SHM is $F=-k x$  Comparing equation (i) and (ii) we have  $k=\rho \ell^{2} g$  Now, Time period, $\mathrm{T}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}$  $\Rightarrow T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell^{3} d}{\rho \ell^{2} g}}$  $=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell d}{\rho g}}$  Comparing the above equation with $a=-\omega^{2} x$, we get  $$ \therefore \omega=\sqrt{\frac{\rho g}{d \ell}} \Rightarrow T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell d}{\rho g}} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If $x, v$ and $a$ denote the displacement, the velocity and the acceleration of a particle executing simple harmonic motion of time period $T$, then, which of the following does not change with time?

\\
solution: For an SHM, the acceleration  $a=-\omega^{2} x$ where $\omega^{2}$ is a constant.  $a=\frac{-4 \pi^{2} x}{T^{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{a T}{x}=\frac{-4 \pi^{2}}{T}$  The time period $T$ is also constant. Therefore, $\frac{a T}{x}$ is a constant.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two springs, of force constants $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ are connected to a mass $m$ as shown. The frequency of oscillation of the mass is $f$. If both $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ are made four times their original values, the frequency of oscillation becomes



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-36(2)}\\
solution: The two springs are in parallel.  $\therefore$ Effective spring constant,  $k=k_{1}+k_{2}$  Initial frequency of oscillation is given by  $v=\frac{1}{2 \mathrm{p}} \sqrt{\frac{k_{1}+k_{2}}{m}}$  When both $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ are made four times their original values, the new frequency is given by  $v^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{4 k_{1}+4 k_{2}}{m}}$  $=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{4\left(k_{1}+4 k_{2}\right)}{m}}=2\left(\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{k_{1}+k_{2}}{m}}\right)=2 v$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The displacement of an object attached to a spring and executing simple harmonic motion is given by $x=2 \times 10^{-2}$ $\cos \pi t$ metre. The time at which the maximum speed first occurs is

\\
solution: Here, Displacement, $x=2 \times 10^{-2} \cos \pi t$ Velocity is given by  $v=\frac{d x}{d t}=2 \times 10^{-2} \pi \sin \pi t$  For the first time, the when velocity becomes maximum, $\sin \pi t=1$  $\Rightarrow \sin \pi t=\sin \frac{\pi}{2}$  $\Rightarrow \pi t=\frac{\pi}{2}$ or, $t=\frac{1}{2}=0.5 \mathrm{sec}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question: The bob of a simple pendulum is a spherical hollow ball filled with water. A plugged hole near the bottom of the oscillating bob gets suddenly unplugged. During observation, till water is coming out, the time period of oscillation would
options: a) first decrease and then increase to the original value
b) first increase and then decrease to the original value
c) increase towards a saturation value
solution: When plugged hole near the bottom of the oscillating bob gets suddenly unplugged, centre of mass of combination of liquid and hollow portion (at position $\ell$ ), first goes down (to $\ell+\Delta \ell$ ) and when total water is drained out, centre of mass regain its original position (to $\ell$ ),  Time period, $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{g}}$  $\therefore$ ' $T$ ' first increases and then decreases to original value.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-47}

question:
If a simple harmonic motion is represented by $\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}+\alpha x=0$, its time period is

\\
solution: \begin{enumerate}

question:
The bob of a simple pendulum executes simple harmonic motion in water with a period $t$, while the period of oscillation of the bob is $t_{0}$ in air. Neglecting frictional force of water and given that the density of the bob is $(4 / 3) \times 1000 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$. Which relationship between $t$ and $t_{0}$ is true?

\\
solution: Time period, $t=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{g_{\text {eff }}}}$;  In air, $t_{0}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{g}}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-48(1)}   Net force $=\left(\frac{4}{3}-1\right) \times 1000 \mathrm{Vg}=\frac{1000}{3} \mathrm{Vg}$  $g_{\text {eff }}=\frac{1000 \mathrm{Vg}}{3 \times \frac{4}{3} \times 1000 \mathrm{~V}}=\frac{g}{4}$  $\therefore t=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{g / 4}}=2 \times 2 \pi \frac{\ell}{g}$  $t=2 t_{0}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A particle at the end of a spring executes S.H.M with a period $t_{1}$. while the corresponding period for another spring is $t_{2}$. If the period of oscillation with the two springs in series is T then

\\
solution: Time period for first spring, $t_{1}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k_{1}}}$,  Time period for second spring, $t_{2}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k_{2}}}$  Force constant of the series combination $k_{\text {eff }}=\frac{k_{1} k_{2}}{k_{l}+k_{2}}$  $\therefore$ Time period of oscillation for series combination  $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m\left(k_{l}+k_{2}\right)}{k_{1} k_{2}}}$  $\therefore T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k_{2}}+\frac{m}{k_{1}}}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{t_{2}^{2}}{(2 \pi)^{2}}+\frac{t_{1}^{2}}{(2 \pi)^{2}}}$  $\Rightarrow T^{2}=t_{1}^{2}+t_{2}^{2}$  where $x$ is the displacement from the mean position  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A mass $M$ is suspended from a spring of negligible mass. The spring is pulled a little and then released so that the mass executes SHM of time period $T$. If the mass is increased by m , the time period becomes $\frac{5 T}{3}$. Then the ratio of $\frac{m}{M}$ is

\\
solution: With mass M , the time period of the spring.  $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{M}{k}}$  With mass $M+m$, the time period becomes,  $T^{\prime}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{M+m}{k}}=\frac{5 T}{3}$  $\therefore 2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{M+m}{k}}=\frac{5}{3} \times 2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{M}{k}}$  $\Rightarrow \quad M+m=\frac{25}{9} \times M$ $\Rightarrow 1+\frac{m}{M}=\frac{25}{9}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{m}{M}=\frac{25}{9}-1=\frac{16}{9}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The length of a simple pendulum executing simple harmonic motion is increased by $21 \%$. The percentage increase in the time period of the pendulum of increased length is

\\
solution: Time period, $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{g}}$  New length, $\ell^{\prime}=\ell+21 \%$ of $\ell$  $\ell^{\prime}=\ell+0.21 \ell$  $\Rightarrow \quad \ell^{\prime}=1.21 \ell$  $T^{\prime}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{1.21 \ell}{g}}$  $\%$ increase in length $=\frac{T^{\prime}-T}{T} \times 100$  $=\frac{\sqrt{1.21 \ell}-\sqrt{\ell}}{\sqrt{\ell}} \times 100=(\sqrt{1.21}-\sqrt{1}) \times 100$  $=(1.1-1) \times 100=10 \%$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If a spring has time period T , and is cut into $n$ equal parts, then the time period of each part will be

\\
solution: Let $k$ be the spring constant of the original spring.  Time period $\mathrm{T}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}$ where m is the mas s of oscillating body.  When the spring is cut into $n$ equal parts, the spring constant of one part becomes $n k$. Therefore the new time period,  $T^{\prime}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{n k}}=\frac{T}{\sqrt{n}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A child swinging on a swing in sitting position, stands up, then the time period if the swing will
options: d) increases if the child is long and decreases if the child is short
solution: The time period $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{g}}$ where $\ell=$ distance between the point of suspension and the centre of mass of the child.  As the child stands up, her centre of mass is raised. The distance between point of suspension and centre of mass decreases ie length $\ell$ decreases.  $\therefore \ell^{\prime}<\ell$  $\therefore T^{\prime}<T$ i.e., the period decreases.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-48}   Case (ii) child standing Case (i) child sitting   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-49}   Case (ii) child standing point of suspension   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_451c46c05f0435e6a846g-49(1)}   Case (i) child sitting  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A damped harmonic oscillator has a frequency of 5 oscillations per second. The amplitude drops to half its value for every 10 oscillations. The time it will take to drop to $\frac{1}{1000}$ of the original amplitude is close to :

\\
solution: Time of half the amplitude is $=2 s$  Using, $A=A_{0} e^{-k t}$  $\frac{A_{0}}{2}=A_{e} e^{-k \times 2}$  and $\frac{A_{0}}{1000}=A_{e} e^{-k t}$  Dividing (i) by (ii) and solving, we get $t=20 \mathrm{~s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The displacement of a damped harmonic oscillator is given by $x(t)=e^{-11 t} \cdot \cos (10 \pi t+\varphi)$. Here $t$ is in seconds.

The time taken for its amplitude of vibration to drop to half of its initial value is close to :

\\
solution: Amplitude of vibration at time $t=0$ is given by  $$ \mathrm{A}=\mathrm{A}_{0} \mathrm{e}^{-0.1 \times 0}=1 \times \mathrm{A}_{0}=\mathrm{A}_{0} $$  also at $\mathrm{t}=\mathrm{t}$, if $\mathrm{A}=\frac{\mathrm{A}_{0}}{2}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}=\mathrm{e}^{-0.1 \mathrm{t}}$  $\mathrm{t}=10 \ln 2 \simeq 7 \mathrm{~s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An oscillator of mass $M$ is at rest in its equilibrium position in a potential $V=\frac{1}{2} k(x-X)^{2}$. A particle of mass $m$ comes from right with speed $u$ and collides completely inelastically with M and sticks to it. This process repeats every time the oscillator crosses its equilibrium position. The amplitude of oscillations after 13 collisions is: $(M=10, m=5, u=1, k=1)$.

\\
solution: In first collision mu momentum will be imparted to system, in second collision when momentum of $(\mathrm{M}+\mathrm{m})$ is in opposite direction mu momentum of particle will make its momentum zero.  On $13^{\text {th }}$ collision, $\mathrm{m} \rightarrow \mathrm{M}+12 ; \mathrm{M}+13 \mathrm{~m} \rightarrow \mathrm{V}$  $$ m u=(M+13 m) v \Rightarrow v=\frac{m u}{M+13 m}=\frac{u}{15} $$  $v=\omega A \Rightarrow \frac{u}{15}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{M-13 m}} \times A$  Putting value of $\mathrm{M}, \mathrm{m}, \mathrm{u}$ and K we get amplitude  $$ A=\frac{1}{15} \sqrt{\frac{75}{1}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The angular frequency of the damped oscillator is given by, $\omega=\sqrt{\left(\frac{\mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{m}}-\frac{\mathrm{r}^{2}}{4 \mathrm{~m}^{2}}\right)}$ where k is the spring constant, m is the mass of the oscillator and $r$ is the damping constant. If the ratio $\frac{\mathrm{r}^{2}}{\mathrm{mk}}$ is $8 \%$, the change in time period compared to the undamped oscillator is approximately as follows:

\\
solution: The change in time period compared to the undamped oscillator increases by $8 \%$.

question: The amplitude of a damped oscillator decreases to 0.9 times its original magnitude in 5 s . In another 10 s it will decrease to $\alpha$ times its original magnitude, where $\alpha$ equals \\
solution: $\because \mathrm{A}=\mathrm{A}_{0} \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{\mathrm{bt}}{2 \mathrm{~m}}}$   (where, $\mathrm{A}_{0}=$ maximum amplitude)  According to the questions, after 5 second,  $0.9 \mathrm{~A}_{0}=\mathrm{A}_{0} \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{\mathrm{b}(5)}{2 \mathrm{~m}}}$  After 10 more second,  $A=A_{0} e^{-\frac{b(15)}{2 m}}$  From eq ${ }^{\mathrm{n}} \mathrm{s}$ (i) and (ii)  $\mathrm{A}=0.729 \mathrm{~A}_{0}$  $\therefore \alpha=0.729$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A uniform cylinder of length $L$ and mass $M$ having crosssectional area A is suspended, with its length vertical, from a fixed point by a massless spring, such that it is half submerged in a liquid of density $\sigma$ at equilibrium position. When the cylinder is given a downward push and released, it starts oscillating vertically with a small amplitude. The time period T of the oscillations of the cylinder will be :
Bob of a simple pendulum of length $l$ is made of iron. The pendulum is oscillating over a horizontal coil carrying direct current. If the time period of the pendulum is T then :
options: a) $T<2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}$ and damping is smaller than in air alone.
b) $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}$ and damping is larger than in air alone.
c) $T>2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}$ and damping is smaller than in air alone.
d) $T<2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}$ and damping is larger than in air alone.\\
solution: When the pendulum is oscillating over a current carrying coil, and when the direction of oscillating pendulum bob is opposite to the direction of current. Its instantaneous acceleration increases.   Hence time period $\mathrm{T}<2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{g}}$  and damping is larger than in air alone due energy dissipation.  \begin{enumerate}

question: In forced oscillation of a particle the amplitude is maximum for a frequency $\omega_{1}$ of the force while the energy is maximum for a frequency $\omega_{2}$ of the force; then
options: a) $\omega_{1}<\omega_{2}$ when damping is small and $\omega_{1}>\omega_{2}$ when damping is large
solution: As energy $\propto(\text { Amplitude })^{2}$, the maximum for both of them occurs at the same frequency and this is only possible in case of resonance.  In resonance state $\omega_{1}=\omega_{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A particle of mass $m$ is attached to a spring (of spring constant $k$ ) and has a natural angular frequency $\omega_{0}$. An external force $F(t)$ proportional to $\cos \omega t\left(\omega \neq \omega_{0}\right)$ is applied to the oscillator. The displacement of the oscillator will be proportional to

\\
solution: Equation of displacement in forced oscillation is given by  $y=\frac{F_{0}}{m\left(\omega_{0}{ }^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}}$  $=\frac{F_{0}}{m\left(\omega_{0}{ }^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}$  Here damping effect is considered to be zero  $$ \therefore x \propto \frac{1}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)} $$   \end{document}

question:
Assume that the displacement $(s)$ of air is proportional to the pressure difference $(\Delta p)$ created by a sound wave. Displacement $(s)$ further depends on the speed of sound (v), density of air ( $\rho$ ) and the frequency ( $f$ ). If $\Delta p \sim$ $10 \mathrm{~Pa}, v \sim 300 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}, \rho \sim 1 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$ and $f \sim 1000 \mathrm{~Hz}$, then $s$ will be of the order of (take the multiplicative constant to be 1 )

\\
solution: As we know,   Pressure amplitude, $\Delta P_{0}=a K B=S_{0} K B=S_{0} \times \frac{\omega}{V} \times \rho V^{2}$ $\left[\because K=\frac{\omega}{V}, V=\sqrt{\frac{B}{\rho}}\right]$  $\Rightarrow S_{0}=\frac{\Delta P_{0}}{\rho V \omega} \approx \frac{10}{1 \times 300 \times 1000} \mathrm{~m}=\frac{1}{30} \mathrm{~mm} \approx \frac{3}{100} \mathrm{~mm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
For a transverse wave travelling along a straight line, the distance between two peaks (crests) is 5 m , while the distance between one crest and one trough is 1.5 m . The possible wavelengths (in m ) of the waves are :

\\
solution: Given : Distance between one crest and one trough $=5 \mathrm{~m}$  $=\left(2 n_{1}+1\right) \frac{\lambda}{2}$  Distance between two crests $=5 \mathrm{~m}=n_{2} \lambda$  $\frac{1.5}{5}=\frac{\left(2 n_{1}+1\right)}{2 n_{2}} \Rightarrow 3 n_{2}=10 n_{1}+5$  Here $n_{1}$ and $n_{2}$ are integer.  $$ \begin{aligned} & \text { If } \quad n_{1}=1, n_{2}=5 \quad \therefore \lambda=1 \\ & n_{1}=4, n_{2}=15 \quad \therefore \lambda=1 / 3 \\ & n_{1}=7, n_{2}=25 \quad \therefore \lambda=1 / 5 \end{aligned} $$  Hence possible wavelengths $\frac{1}{1}, \frac{1}{3}, \frac{1}{5}$ metre.  \begin{enumerate}
At $t=0, x=0, y=0$  $\phi=\pi \mathrm{rad}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A small speaker delivers 2 W of audio output. At what distance from the speaker will one detect 120 dB intensity sound? 

[12 April 2019 II]\\
reference: Given reference intensity of sound as $10^{-12} \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$
solution: Using, $\beta=10$  or $120=10 \log 10\left(\frac{I}{10^{-12}}\right)$  Also $I=\frac{P}{4 \pi r^{2}}=\frac{2}{4 \pi r^{2}}$  On solving above equations, we get $r=40 \mathrm{~cm}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The pressure wave,

$\mathrm{P}=0.01 \sin  \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$, corresponds to the sound produced by a vibrating blade on a day when atmospheric temperature is $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. On some other day when temperature is T , the speed of sound produced by the same blade and at the same frequency is found to be $336 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$. Approximate value of T is :

[9 April 2019 I]\\
solution: On comparing with $\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{P}_{0} \sin (\mathrm{wt}-\mathrm{kx})$, we have $\mathrm{w}=1000 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}, \mathrm{K}=3 \mathrm{~m}^{-1}$  $\therefore v_{0}=\frac{w}{k}=\frac{1000}{3}=333.3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  $\frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}}$  or $\frac{333.3}{336}=\sqrt{\frac{273+0}{273+t}}$  $\therefore \mathrm{t}=4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$\\

question: A travelling harmonic wave is represented by the equation $y(x, \mathrm{t})=10^{-3} \sin (50 \mathrm{t}+2 x)$, where $x$ and $y$ are in meter and $t$ is in seconds. Which of the following is a correct statement about the wave?
options: a) The wave is propagating along the negative x -axis with speed $25 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$.
b) The wave is propagating along the positive x -axis with speed $100 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$.
c) The wave is propagating along the positive $x$-axis with speed $25 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$.
d) The wave is propagating along the negative x -axis with speed $100 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$.
solution: Comparing the given equation  $y=10^{-3} \sin (50 t+2 x)$ with standard equation, $y=a \sin (\omega t-k x)$  $\Rightarrow$ wave is moving along - ve x -axis with speed  $\mathrm{v}=\frac{\omega}{\mathrm{K}} \Rightarrow \mathrm{v}=\frac{50}{2}=25 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A transverse wave is represented by

$\mathrm{y}=\frac{10}{\pi} \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{t}-\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \mathrm{x}\right)$

For what value of the wavelength the wave velocity is twice the maximum particle velocity?

\\
solution: Given, amplitude $\mathrm{a}=10 \mathrm{~cm}$  wave velocity $=2 \times$ maximum particle velocity  i.e, $\frac{\omega \lambda}{2 \pi}=2 \frac{a \omega}{\pi}$  or, $\lambda=4 \mathrm{a}=4 \times 10=40 \mathrm{~cm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
In a transverse wave the distance between a crest and neighbouring trough at the same instant is 4.0 cm and the distance between a crest and trough at the same place is 1.0 cm . The next crest appears at the same place after a time interval of 0.4 s . The maximum speed of the vibrating particles in the medium is :

\\

When two sound waves travel in the same direction in a medium, the displacements of a particle located at ' $x$ ' at time ' $t$ ' is given by :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{1}=0.05 \cos (0.50 \pi x-100 \pi t) \\
& y_{2}=0.05 \cos (0.46 \pi x-92 \pi t)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $y_{1}, y_{2}$ and $x$ are in meters and $t$ in seconds. The speed of sound in the medium is : \\
solution: Standard equation   $y(x, t)=A \cos \left(\frac{\omega}{V} x-\omega t\right)$  From any of the displacement equation  Say $\mathrm{y}_{1}$  $\frac{\omega}{\mathrm{V}}=0.50 \pi$ and $\omega=100 \pi$  $\therefore \frac{100 \pi}{\mathrm{V}}=0.5 \pi$  $\therefore \mathrm{V}=\frac{100 \pi}{0.5 \pi}=200 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The disturbance $y(x, t)$ of a wave propagating in the positive $x$-direction is given by $y=\frac{1}{1+x^{2}}$ at time $t=0$ and by $y=\frac{1}{\left}$ at $t=2 \mathrm{~s}$, where $x$ and $y$ are in meters. The shape of the wave disturbance does not change during the propagation. The velocity of wave in $\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$ is

[Online May 26, 2012]\\
solution: The equation of wave at any time is obtained by putting $\mathrm{X}=x-\mathrm{vt}$  $\mathrm{y}=\frac{1}{1+x^{2}}=\frac{1}{1+(x-v t)^{2}}$  We know at $t=2 \mathrm{sec}$,  $y=\frac{1}{1+(x-1)^{2}}$  On comparing (i) and (ii) we get  $v t=1$  $V=\frac{1}{t}$  As $t=2 \mathrm{sec}$  $\therefore V=\frac{1}{2}=0.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The transverse displacement $y(x, t)$ of a wave is given by $y(x, t)=e^{\left.-\left(a x^{2}+b t^{2}+2 \sqrt{a b}\right) x t\right)}$

This represents a:
options: a) wave moving in $-x$ direction with speed $\sqrt{\frac{b}{a}}$
d) wave moving in $+x$ direction speed $\sqrt{\frac{a}{b}}$
solution: Given  $y(x, t)=e^{\left(-a x^{2}+b t^{2}+2 \sqrt{a b} x t\right)}$  $=e^{-\left[(\sqrt{a x})^{2}+(\sqrt{b} t)^{2}+2 \sqrt{a} x \cdot \sqrt{b} t\right]}$  $=e^{-(\sqrt{a} x+\sqrt{b} t)^{2}}$  $=e^{-\left(x+\sqrt{\frac{b}{a}} t\right)^{2}}$  It is a function of type $y=f(x+v t)$  $\therefore y(x, t)$ represents wave travelling along-ve $x$ direction  $\Rightarrow$ Speed of wave $=\frac{w}{k}=\sqrt{\frac{b}{a}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A wave travelling along the $x$-axis is described by the equation $y(x, t)=0.005 \cos (\alpha x-\beta t)$. If the wavelength and the time period of the wave are 0.08 m and 2.0 s , respectively, then $\alpha$ and $\beta$ in appropriate units are \\
solution: Given,  Wavelength, $l=0.08 \mathrm{~m}$  Time period, $\mathrm{T}=2.05$  $y(x, t)=0.005 \cos (\alpha x-\beta t)($ Given $)$  Comparing it with the standard equation of wave  $y(x, t)=a \cos (k x-\omega t)$ we get  $\mathrm{k}=\alpha=\frac{2 \pi}{l}$ and $\omega=\beta=\frac{2 \pi}{T}$  $\therefore \alpha=\frac{2 \pi}{0.08}=25 \pi \quad$ and $\beta=\frac{2 \pi}{2}=\pi$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A sound absorber attenuates the sound level by 20 dB . The intensity decreases by a factor of


\\
solution: Loudness of sound. $\mathrm{L}_{1}=10 \log \left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{\mathrm{I}_{0}}\right)$;  $\mathrm{L}_{2}=10 \log \left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{2}}{\mathrm{I}_{0}}\right)$  $\therefore \mathrm{L}_{1}-\mathrm{L}_{2}=10 \log \left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{\mathrm{I}_{0}}\right)-10 \log \left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{2}}{\mathrm{I}_{0}}\right)$  or, $\Delta \mathrm{L}=10 \log \left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{\mathrm{I}_{0}} \times \frac{\mathrm{I}_{0}}{\mathrm{I}_{2}}\right)$  or, $\Delta \mathrm{L}=10 \log \left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{\mathrm{I}_{2}}\right)$  The sound level attenuated by 20 dB ie  $\mathrm{L}_{1}-\mathrm{L}_{2}=20 \mathrm{~dB}$  or, $20=10 \log \left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{\mathrm{I}_{2}}\right)$ or, $2=\log \left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{\mathrm{I}_{2}}\right)$  or, $\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{\mathrm{I}_{2}}=10^{2}$ or, $\mathrm{I}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{I}_{1}}{100}$.  $\Rightarrow$ Intensity decreases by a factor 100 .  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The displacement $y$ of a particle in a medium can be expressed as, $y=10^{-6} \sin \left(100 t+20 x+\frac{\pi}{4}\right) m$ where $t$ is

in second and $x$ in meter. The speed of the wave is

\\
solution: Given, $y=10^{-6} \sin \left(100 t+20 x+\frac{\pi}{4}\right) m$  Comparing it with standard equation, we get $\omega=100$ and $\mathrm{k}=20$  $\mathrm{v}=\frac{\omega}{\mathrm{k}}=\frac{100}{20}=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The displacement $y$ of a wave travelling in the $x$-direction is given by $y=10^{-4} \sin \left(600 t-2 x+\frac{\pi}{3}\right)$ metres

where x is expressed in metres and t in seconds. The speed of the wave - motion, in $\mathrm{ms}^{-1}$, is

\\
solution: $y=10^{-4} \sin \left(600 t-2 x+\frac{\pi}{3}\right)$  On comparing with standard equation $\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{A} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t}-\mathrm{kx}+\phi)$  we get $\omega=600 ; \mathrm{k}=2$  Velocity of wave  $\mathrm{v}=\frac{\omega}{\mathrm{k}}=\frac{600}{2}=300 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
When temperature increases, the frequency of a tuning fork











TOPIC 2 Vibration of String and Organ Pipe
options: d) increases or decreases depending on the material
solution: The frequency of a tuning fork is given by $\mathrm{f}=\frac{\mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{k}}{4 \sqrt{3} \pi \ell^{2}} \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{Y}}{\rho}}$  As temperature increases, the length or dimension of the prongs increases and also young's modulus increases therefore f decreases  \begin{enumerate}

question:
In a resonance tube experiment when the tube is filled with water up to a height of 17.0 cm from bottom, it resonates with a given tuning fork. When the water level is raised the next resonance with the same tuning fork occurs at a height of 24.5 cm . If the velocity of sound in air is $330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the tuning fork frequency is :

\\
solution: Here, $l_{1}=17 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $l_{2}=5 \mathrm{~cm}, V=330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, $f=$ ? $\lambda=2\left(l_{2}-l_{1}\right)=2 \times(5-17)=15 \mathrm{~cm}$  Now, from $v=f \lambda \Rightarrow 330=\lambda \times 15 \times 10^{-2}$  $\therefore \lambda=\frac{330}{15} \times 100=\frac{1100 \times 100}{5}=2200 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A uniform thin rope of length 12 m and mass 6 kg hangs vertically from a rigid support and a block of mass 2 kg is attached to its free end. A transverse short wave-train of wavelength 6 cm is produced at the lower end of the rope. What is the wavelength of the wavetrain (in cm ) when it reaches the top of the rope ?\\
solution: Using, $V=f \lambda$  $\frac{V_{1}}{\lambda_{1}}=\frac{V_{2}}{\lambda_{2}} \Rightarrow \lambda_{2}=\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \lambda_{1}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-59}   Again using,  $$ \begin{aligned} n & =\frac{V}{\lambda}=\sqrt{\frac{T}{M}} \lambda_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}} \lambda_{1}} \quad T_{2}=8 \mathrm{~g}(\text { Top }) \\ & =\sqrt{\frac{8 g}{2 g}} \lambda_{1}=2 \lambda_{1}=12 \mathrm{~cm} T_{1}=2 \mathrm{~g}(\text { Bottom }) \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two identical strings $X$ and $Z$ made of same material have tension $T_{X}$ and $T_{Z}$ in them. If their fundamental frequencies are 450 Hz and 300 Hz , respectively, then the ratio $T_{X} / T_{Z}$ is:


$\\
solution: Using $f=\frac{1}{2 \ell} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}$,  where, $T=$ tension and $\mu=\frac{\text { mass }}{\text { length }}$  $f_{x}=\frac{1}{2 \ell} \sqrt{\frac{T_{x}}{\mu}}$ and $f_{z}=\frac{1}{2 \ell} \sqrt{\frac{T_{z}}{\mu}}$  $\frac{f_{x}}{f_{z}}=\frac{450}{300}=\sqrt{\frac{T_{x}}{T_{z}}}$  $\therefore \frac{T_{x}}{T_{z}}=\frac{9}{4}=2.25$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A wire of density $9 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ is stretched between two clamps 1 m apart. The resulting strain in the wire is $4.9 \times 10^{-4}$. The lowest frequency of the transverse vibrations in the wire is

(Young's modulus of wire $Y=9 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$ ), (to the nearest integer),
solution: Given,  Denisty of wire, $\sigma=9 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$  Young's modulus of wire, $Y=9 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$  Strain $=4.9 \times 10^{-4}$  $Y=\frac{\text { Stress }}{\text { Strain }}=\frac{T / A}{\text { Strain }}$  $\therefore \frac{T}{A}=Y \times$ Strain $=9 \times 10^{9} \times 4.9 \times 10^{-4}$  Also, mass of wire, $m=A l \sigma$  Mass per unit length, $\mu=\frac{m}{J}=A \sigma$  Fundamental frequency in the string  $$ \begin{aligned} f & =\frac{1}{2 l} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}=\frac{1}{2 l} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\sigma A}} \\ & =\frac{1}{2 \times 1} \sqrt{\frac{9 \times 10^{9} \times 4.9 \times 10^{-4}}{9 \times 10^{3}}} \\ & =\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{49 \times 10^{9-4-3}}=\frac{1}{2} \times 70=35 \mathrm{~Hz} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A one metre long (both ends open) organ pipe is kept in a gas that has double the density of air at STP. Assuming the speed of sound in air at STP is $300 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the frequency difference between the fundamental and second harmonic of this pipe is $\qquad$ Hz .
solution: Given : $V_{\text {air }}=300 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}, \rho_{\mathrm{gas}}=2 \rho$ air  Using, $V=\sqrt{\frac{B}{\rho}}$  $\frac{V_{\text {gas }}}{V_{\text {air }}}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{B}{2 \rho_{\text {air }}}}}{\sqrt{\frac{B}{\rho_{\text {air }}}}}$  $\Rightarrow V_{\text {gas }}=\frac{V_{\text {air }}}{\sqrt{2}}=\frac{300}{\sqrt{2}}=150 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  And $\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{nth}}$ harmonic $=\frac{n v}{2 L}$ (in open organ pipe)  ( $\mathrm{L}=1$ metre given)  $\therefore f_{\text {2nd }}$ harmonic $-f_{\text {fundamental }}=\frac{2 v}{2 \times 1}-\frac{v}{2 \times 1}=\frac{v}{2}$  $\therefore f_{2 \mathrm{n}}$ harmonic $-f_{\text {fundamental }}=\frac{150 \sqrt{2}}{2}=\frac{150}{\sqrt{2}} \approx 106 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A transverse wave travels on a taut steel wire with a velocity of $v$ when tension in it is $2.06 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~N}$. When the tension is changed to $T$, the velocity changed to $v / 2$. The value of $T$ is close to:

$\\
solution: The velocity of a transverse wave in a stretched wire is given by  $v=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}$  Where,  $T=$ Tension in the wire  $\mu=$ linear density of wire  $(\because V \propto T)$  $\therefore \frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{v}{v} \times 2=\sqrt{\frac{2.06 \times 10^{4}}{T_{2}}}$  $\Rightarrow T_{2}=\frac{2.06 \times 10^{4}}{4}=0.515 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~N}$  $\Rightarrow T_{2}=5.15 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Speed of a transverse wave on a straight wire (mass 6.0 g , length 60 cm and area of cross-section $1.0 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$ ) is 90 $\mathrm{ms}^{-1}$. If the Young's modulus of wire is $16 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$ the extension of wire over its natural length is:

\\
solution: Given, $l=60 \mathrm{~cm}, m=6 \mathrm{~g}, A=1 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}, v=90 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and $Y$ $=16 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}$\\ Using, $v=\sqrt{\frac{T}{m} \times l} \Rightarrow T=\frac{m v^{2}}{I}$  Again from, $Y=\frac{T}{A} \Delta L / L_{0}$  $\Delta L=\frac{T l}{Y A}=\frac{m v^{2} \times l}{l(\mathrm{YA})}$  $=\frac{6 \times 10^{-3} \times 90^{2}}{16 \times 10^{11} \times 10^{-6}}=3 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}$\\ $=0.03 \mathrm{~mm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Equation of travelling wave on a stretched string of linear density $5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{m}$ is $\mathrm{y}=0.03 \sin (450 \mathrm{t}-9 \mathrm{x})$ where distance and time are measured in SI units. The tension in the string is:

$\\
solution: We have given,  $y=0.03 \sin (450 t-9 x)$  Comparing it with standard equation of wave, we get $\omega=$ $450 \mathrm{k}=9$  $\therefore \mathrm{v}=\frac{\omega}{\mathrm{k}}=\frac{450}{9}=50 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Velocity of travelling wave on a stretched string is given by  $\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{T}}{\mu}} \Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{T}}{\mu}=2500$  $\mu=$ linear mass density  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}=2500 \times 5 \times 10^{-3}$  $\Rightarrow 12.5 \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A heavy ball of mass $M$ is suspended from the ceiling of a car by a light string of mass $\mathrm{m}(\mathrm{m}<<\mathrm{M})$. When the car is at rest, the speeed of transverse waves in the string is 60 $\mathrm{ms}^{-1}$. when the car has acceleration a, the wave-speed increases to $60.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$. The value of a , in terms of gravitational acceleration g, is closest to: \\
solution: Wave speed $V=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}$  when car is at rest $\mathrm{a}=0$  $\therefore 60=\sqrt{\frac{M g}{\mu}}$  Similarly when the car is moving with acceleration a,  $60.5=\sqrt{\frac{M\left(\mathrm{~g}^{2}+\mathrm{a}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}{\mu}}$  $\frac{60.5}{60}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{g}^{2}+\mathrm{a}^{2}}{\mathrm{~g}^{2}}}$  $\left(1+\frac{0.5}{60}\right)^{4}=\frac{\mathrm{g}^{2}+\mathrm{a}^{2}}{\mathrm{~g}^{2}}=1+\frac{2}{60}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{g}^{2}+\mathrm{a}^{2}=\mathrm{g}^{2}+\mathrm{g}^{2} \times \frac{2}{60}$  $\mathrm{a}=\mathrm{g} \sqrt{\frac{2}{60}}=\frac{\mathrm{g}}{\sqrt{30}}$  [which is closest to $g / 5$ ]  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A wire of length $L$ and mass per unit length $6.0 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{kgm}^{-1}$ is put under tension of 540 N . Two consecutive frequencies that it resonates at are: 420 Hz and 490 Hz . Then L in meters is:


\\
solution: Fundamental frequency, $f=70 \mathrm{~Hz}$.  The fundamental frequency of wire vibrating under tension $T$ is given by  $f=\frac{1}{2 L} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}$  Here, $\mu=$ mass per unit length of the wire $L=$ length of wire  $70=\frac{1}{2 L} \sqrt{\frac{540}{6 \times 10^{-3}}}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{L} \approx 2.14 \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A tuning fork of frequency 480 Hz is used in an experiment for measuring speed of sound $(v)$ in air by resonance tube method. Resonance is observed to occur at two successive lengths of the air column, $l_{1}=30 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $l_{2}=70$ cm . Then, $v$ is equal to :

$\\
solution: $V=f \lambda=f \times 2\left(\ell_{2}-\ell_{1}\right)$  $=480 \times 2(0.70-0.30)$  $=384 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A string 2.0 m long and fixed at its ends is driven by a 240 Hz vibrator. The string vibrates in its third harmonic mode. The speed of the wave and its fundamental frequency is:

\\
solution: $\frac{3 \lambda}{2}=2$ or $\lambda=\frac{4}{3} m$  Velocity, $v=f_{\lambda}=240 \times \frac{4}{3}=320 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$  Also $f_{1}=\frac{240}{3}=80 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A string is clamped at both the ends and it is vibrating in its $4^{\text {th }}$ harmonic. The equation of the stationary wave is Y $=0.3 \sin (0.157 \mathrm{x}) \cos (200 \mathrm{At})$. The length of the string is: (All quantities are in SI units.)

\\
solution: Given, $\mathrm{y}=3 \sin (157 x) \cos (200 \pi \mathrm{t})$  So $\mathrm{k}=0.157$ and $\mathrm{w}=200 \pi$  or $\mathrm{f}=100 \mathrm{~Hz}, v=\frac{w}{k}=\frac{200 \pi}{0.157}=4000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Now, using $f=\frac{n v}{2 l}=\frac{4 v}{2 l}=\frac{2 v}{l}$  $\therefore l=\frac{2 v}{f}=\frac{2 \times 4000}{100}=80 \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A wire of length $2 L$, is made by joining two wires $A$ and $B$ of same length but different radii $r$ and $2 r$ and made of the same material. It is vibrating at a frequency such that the joint of the two wires forms a node. If the number of antinodes in wire A is $p$ and that in B is $q$ then the ratio $p: q$ is :



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-53}\\
solution: As there must be node at both ends and at the joint of the wire $A$ and $B$ so  $\frac{V_{A}}{V_{B}}=\sqrt{\frac{u_{B}}{u_{A}}}=\frac{r_{B}}{r_{A}}=2=\frac{\lambda_{A}}{\lambda_{B}}$  $\Rightarrow \lambda_{A}=2 \lambda_{B}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{P}{q}=\frac{1}{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A closed organ pipe has a fundamental frequency of 1.5 kHz . The number of overtones that can be distinctly heard by a person with this organ pipe will be: (Assume that the highest frequency a person can hear is $20,000 \mathrm{~Hz}$ )\\





$\\
solution: If a closed pipe vibration in $\mathrm{N}^{\text {th }}$ mode then frequency of vibration $\mathrm{n}=\frac{(2 \mathrm{~N}-1) \mathrm{v}}{4 l}=(2 \mathrm{~N}-1) \mathrm{n}_{1}$  (where $\mathrm{n}_{1}=$ fundamental frequency of vibration)  Hence $20,000=(2 \mathrm{~N}-1) \times 1500$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{N}=7.1 \approx 7$  $\therefore$ Number of over tones $=$ (No. of mode of vibration) -1 $=7-1=6$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A string of length 1 m and mass 5 g is fixed at both ends. The tension in the string is 8.0 N . The string is set into vibration using an external vibrator of frequency 100 Hz . The separation between successive nodes on the string is close to:

\\
solution: Velocity of wave on string  $\mathrm{V}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{T}}{\mu}}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{5} \times 1000}=40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Here, $\mathrm{T}=$ tension and $\mu=$ mass/length  Wavelength of wave $\lambda=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{\mathrm{n}}=\frac{40}{100} \mathrm{~m}$  Separation $b / w$ successive nodes,  $\frac{\lambda}{2}=\frac{40}{2 \times 100}=\frac{20}{100} \mathrm{~m}=20 \mathrm{~cm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A granite rod of 60 cm length is clamped at its middle point and is set into longitudinal vibrations. The density of granite is $2.7 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$ and its Young's modulus is $9.27 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~Pa}$.

What will be the fundamental frequency of the longitudinal vibrations?

\\
solution: In solids, Velocity of wave  $V=\sqrt{\frac{Y}{\rho}}=\sqrt{\frac{9.27 \times 10^{10}}{2.7 \times 10^{3}}}$  $\mathrm{v}=5.85 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$\\ Since rod is clamped at middle fundamental wave shape is as follow  $\frac{\lambda}{2}=\mathrm{L} \Rightarrow \lambda=2 \mathrm{~L} \quad \mathrm{~A}$  $\lambda=1.2 \mathrm{~m}(\because \mathrm{L}=60 \mathrm{~cm}=0.6 \mathrm{~m}$ (given)  Using $\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{f} \lambda$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{f}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{\lambda}=\frac{5.85 \times 10^{3}}{1.2}$  $=4.88 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~Hz} \simeq 5 \mathrm{KHz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The end correction of a resonance column is 1 cm . If the shortest length resonating with the tuning fork is 10 cm , the next resonating length should be

\\
solution: For first resonance, $\frac{\lambda}{4}=\ell_{1}+\mathrm{e}=11 \mathrm{~cm}$  ( $\because$ end correction $\mathrm{e}=1 \mathrm{~cm}$ given)  For second resonance, $\frac{3 \lambda}{4}=\ell_{2}+\mathrm{e}$  $\Rightarrow \ell_{2}=3 \times 11-1=32 \mathrm{~cm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two wires $\mathrm{W}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{W}_{2}$ have the same radius r and respective densities $\rho_{1}$ and $\rho_{2}$ such that $\rho_{2}=4 \rho_{1}$. They are joined together at the point O , as shown in the figure. The combination is used as a sonometer wire and kept under tension T. The point O is midway between the two bridges. When a stationary waves is set up in the composite wire, the joint is found to be a node. The ratio of the number of antinodes formed in $\mathrm{W}_{1}$ to $\mathrm{W}_{2}$ is :



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-53(1)}\\
solution: $\mathrm{n}_{1}=\mathrm{n}_{2}$  $\mathrm{T} \rightarrow$ Same  $\mathrm{r} \rightarrow$ Same  $l \rightarrow$ Same  Frequency of vibration  $\mathrm{n}=\frac{\mathrm{p}}{2 l} \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{T}}{\pi \mathrm{r}^{2} \rho}}$  As T, r, and $l$ are same for both the wires  $\mathrm{n}_{1}=\mathrm{n}_{2}$  $\frac{\mathrm{p}_{1}}{\sqrt{\rho_{1}}}=\frac{\mathrm{p}_{2}}{\sqrt{\rho_{2}}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{p}_{1}}{\mathrm{p}_{2}}=\frac{1}{2} \quad \because \rho_{2}=4 \rho_{1}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A uniform string of length 20 m is suspended from a rigid support. A short wave pulse is introduced at its lowest end. It starts moving up the string. The time taken to reach the supports is :

 (take $\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$ )\\
solution: We know that velocity in string is given by  $v=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{T}}{\mu}}$  where $\mu=\frac{\mathrm{m}}{1}=\frac{\text { mass of string }}{\text { length of string }}$  The tension $\mathrm{T}=\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\ell} \times \mathrm{x} \times \mathrm{g}$  From (1) and (2)   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-61}   $\frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\sqrt{\mathrm{gx}}$  $x^{-1 / 2} d x=\sqrt{g} d t$  $\therefore \int_{0}^{\ell} \mathrm{x}^{-1 / 2} \mathrm{dx}-\sqrt{\mathrm{g}} \int_{0}^{\ell} \mathrm{dt}$  $\Rightarrow 2 \sqrt{1}$\\ $=\sqrt{g} \times \mathrm{t} \quad \therefore \mathrm{t}=2 \sqrt{\frac{\ell}{\mathrm{g}}}=2 \sqrt{\frac{20}{10}}=2 \sqrt{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A pipe open at both ends has a fundamental frequency $f$ in air. The pipe is dipped vertically in water so that half of it is in water. The fundamental frequency of the air column is now :

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-62}   The fundamental frequency in case (a) is $\mathrm{f}=\frac{\mathrm{V}}{2 \ell}$  The fundamental frequency in case $(\mathrm{b})$ is  $f^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{4(\ell / 2)}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2 \ell}=\mathrm{f}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A pipe of length 85 cm is closed from one end. Find the number of possible natural oscillations of air column in the pipe whose frequencies lie below 1250 Hz . The velocity of sound in air is $340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.

\\
solution: Length of pipe $=85 \mathrm{~cm}=85 \mathrm{~m}$  Frequency of oscillations of air column in closed organ pipe is given by,  $f=\frac{(2 n-1) v}{4 L}$  $f=\frac{(2 n-1) v}{4 L} \leq 1250$  $\Rightarrow \frac{(2 \mathrm{n}-1) \times 340}{0.85 \times 4} \leq 1250$  $\Rightarrow 2 n-1<12.5 \approx 6$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The total length of a sonometer wire between fixed ends is 110 cm . Two bridges are placed to divide the length of wire in ratio $6: 3: 2$. The tension in the wire is 400 N and the mass per unit length is $0.01 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}$. What is the minimum common frequency with which three parts can vibrate?

\\
solution: Total length of sonometer wire, $l=110 \mathrm{~cm}=1 \mathrm{~m}$ Length of wire is in ratio, $6: 3: 2$ i.e. $60 \mathrm{~cm}, 30 \mathrm{~cm}, 20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Tension in the wire, $\mathrm{T}=400 \mathrm{~N}$  Mass per unit length, $\mathrm{m}=0.01 \mathrm{~kg}$  Minimum common frequency $=$ ?  As we know,  Frequency, $v=\frac{1}{21} \sqrt{\frac{T}{m}}=\frac{1000}{11} \mathrm{~Hz}$  Similarly, $v_{1}=\frac{1000}{6} \mathrm{~Hz}$  $v_{2}=\frac{1000}{3} \mathrm{~Hz}$  $v_{3}=\frac{1000}{2} \mathrm{~Hz}$  Hence common frequency $=1000 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A sonometer wire of length 1.5 m is made of steel. The tension in it produces an elastic strain of $1 \%$. What is the fundamental frequency of steel if density and elasticity of steel are $7.7 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$ and $2.2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ respectively?\\
solution: Fundamental frequency,  $f=\frac{v}{2 \ell}=\frac{1}{2 \ell} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}=\frac{1}{2 \ell} \sqrt{\frac{T}{A \rho}} \quad\left[\because v=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}\right.$ and $\left.\mu=\frac{m}{\ell}\right]$  Also, $Y=\frac{T \ell}{A \Delta \ell} \Rightarrow \frac{T}{A}=\frac{Y \Delta \ell}{\ell}$  $\Rightarrow f=\frac{1}{2 \ell} \sqrt{\frac{y \Delta \ell}{\ell}}$  $\ell=1.5 \mathrm{~m}, \frac{\Delta \ell}{\ell}=0.01$,  $\rho=7.7 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$ (given)  $y=2.2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ (given)  Putting the value of $\ell, \frac{\Delta \ell}{\ell}, \rho$ and $y$ in eq. ${ }^{\mathrm{n}}$. (i) we get, $f=\sqrt{\frac{2}{7}} \times \frac{10^{3}}{3}$ or $f \approx 178.2 \mathrm{~Hz}$\\

question: A sonometer wire of length 114 cm is fixed at both the ends. Where should the two bridges be placed so as to divide the wire into three segments whose fundamental frequencies are in the ratio $1: 3: 4$ ?
options: a) At 36 cm and 84 cm from one end
b) At 24 cm and 72 cm from one end
c) At 48 cm and 96 cm from one end
d) At 72 cm and 96 cm from one end
solution: Total length of the wire, $\mathrm{L}=114 \mathrm{~cm}$  $\mathrm{n}_{1}: \mathrm{n}_{2}: \mathrm{n}_{3}=1: 3: 4$  Let $\mathrm{L}_{1}^{2}, \mathrm{~L}_{2}^{3}$ and $\mathrm{L}_{3}$ be the lengths of the three parts  As $\mathrm{n} \propto \frac{1}{\mathrm{~L}}$  $\therefore \quad \mathrm{L}_{1}: \mathrm{L}_{2}: \mathrm{L}_{3}=\frac{1}{1}: \frac{1}{3}: \frac{1}{4}=12: 4: 3$  $\therefore \quad \mathrm{L}_{1}=\left(\frac{12}{12+4+3} \times 114\right)=72 \mathrm{~cm}$  $\mathrm{L}_{2}=\left(\frac{4}{19} \times 114\right)=24 \mathrm{~cm}$  and $\mathrm{L}_{3}=\left(\frac{3}{19} \times 114\right)=18 \mathrm{~cm}$  Hence the bridges should be placed at 72 cm and $72+24$ $=96 \mathrm{~cm}$ from one end.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A cylindrical tube, open at both ends, has a fundamental frequency $f$ in air. The tube is dipped vertically in water so that half of it is in water. The fundamental frequency of the air-column is now :

\\
solution: Initially for open organ pipe, fundamental frequency  $v_{0}=\frac{v}{2 l_{0}}$  where $l_{0}$ is the length of the tube  $v=$ speed of sound  But when it is half dipped in water, it becomes closed organ  pipe of length $\frac{\ell_{0}}{2}$.  Fundamental frequency of closed organ pipe  $v_{c}=\frac{v}{4 l_{c}}$  New length, $l_{c}=\frac{l_{0}}{2}$  Thus $v_{c}=\frac{v}{4 l_{0} / 2} \Rightarrow v_{c}=\frac{v}{2 l}$  From equations (i) and (iii)  $$ v_{0}=v_{c} $$  Thus, $v_{c}=f\left(\because v_{0}=f\right.$ is given $)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An air column in a pipe, which is closed at one end, will be in resonance wtih a vibrating tuning fork of frequency 264 Hz if the length of the column in cm is (velocity of sound $=330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ )

\\
solution: Given : Frequency of tuning fork, $n=264 \mathrm{~Hz}$ Length of column $L=$ ?  For closed organ pipe  $n=\frac{v}{4 l}$  $\Rightarrow l=\frac{v}{4 n}=\frac{330}{4 \times 264}=0.3125$  or, $l=0.3125 \times 100=31.25 \mathrm{~cm}$  In case of closed organ pipe only odd harmonics are possible.  Therefore value of $l$ will be $(2 n-1) l$  Hence option (b) i.e. $3 \times 31.25=93.75 \mathrm{~cm}$ is correct.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A uniform tube of length 60.5 cm is held vertically with its lower end dipped in water. A sound source of frequency 500 Hz sends sound waves into the tube. When the length of tube above water is 16 cm and again when it is 50 cm , the tube resonates with the source of sound. Two lowest frequencies (in Hz ), to which tube will resonate when it is taken out of water, are (approximately).

\\
solution: Two lowest frequencies to which tube will resonates are 272 Hz and 544 Hz .

question:
The equation of a wave on a string of linear mass density $0.04 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}$ is given by

$y=0.02(\mathrm{~m}) \sin \left$.

The tension in the string is

$[2010]$\\
solution: y=02(m) \sin \left[2 \pi\left(\frac{t}{04(s)}\right)-\frac{x}{50(m)}\right] $$  Comparing it with the standard wave equation  $y=a \sin (\omega t-k x)$  we get  $\omega=\frac{2 \pi}{0.04} \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1}$\\ and $k=\frac{2 \pi}{0.50}$  Wave velocity, $\mathrm{v}=\frac{w}{k}$  $\Rightarrow v=\frac{2 \pi / 0.04}{2 \pi / 0.5}=12.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Velocity on a string is given by  $v=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}$  $\therefore T=\mathrm{v}^{2} \times \mu=(12.5)^{2} \times 0.04=6.25 \mathrm{~N}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
While measuring the speed of sound by performing a resonance column experiment, a student gets the first resonance condition at a column length of 18 cm during winter. Repeating the same experiment during summer, she measures the column length to be x cm for the second resonance. Then

\\
solution: Fundamental frequency for first resonant length  $v=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{4 \ell_{1}}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{4 \times 18}$ (in winter)  Fundamental frequency for second resonant length  $v^{\prime}=\frac{3 v^{\prime}}{4 \ell_{2}}=\frac{3 v^{\prime}}{4 x}$ (in summer)  According to questions,  $\therefore \frac{\mathrm{v}}{4 \times 18}=\frac{3 \mathrm{v}^{\prime}}{4 \times \mathrm{x}}$  $\therefore \mathrm{x}=3 \times 18 \times \frac{\mathrm{v}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{v}}$  $\therefore \mathrm{x}=54 \times \frac{\mathrm{v}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{v}} \mathrm{cm}$  $\mathrm{v}^{\prime}>\mathrm{v}$ because velocity of light is greater in summer as compared to winter $(\mathrm{v} \propto \sqrt{\mathrm{T}})$  $\therefore \mathrm{x}>54 \mathrm{~cm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A string is stretched between fixed points separated by 75.0 cm . It is observed to have resonant frequencies of 420 Hz and 315 Hz . There are no other resonant frequencies between these two. Then, the lowest resonant frequency for this string is

\\
solution: It is given that 315 Hz and 420 Hz are two resonant frequencies, let these be $\mathrm{n}^{\text {th }}$ and $(n+1)^{\text {th }}$ harmonies, then  we have $\frac{\mathrm{nv}}{2 \ell}=315$  and $(\mathrm{n}+1) \frac{\mathrm{v}}{2 \ell}=420$  $\Rightarrow \frac{n+1}{n}=\frac{420}{315}$  $\Rightarrow n=3$  Hence $3 \times \frac{v}{2 \ell}=315 \Rightarrow \frac{v}{2 \ell}=105 \mathrm{~Hz}$  The lowest resonant frequency is when  $\mathrm{n}=1$  Therefore lowest resonant frequency $=105 \mathrm{~Hz}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Tube $A$ has both ends open while tube $B$ has one end closed, otherwise they are identical. The ratio of fundamental frequency of tube $A$ and $B$ is

\\
solution: The fundamental frequency for tube B closed at one end is given by  $v_{\mathrm{B}}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{4 \ell}$  $$ \left[\because \ell=\frac{\lambda}{4}\right] $$  Where $\ell=$ length of the tube and v is the velocity of sound in air.  The fundamental frequency for tube A open with both ends is given by  $v_{\mathrm{A}}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2 \ell}$  $$ \left[\because \ell=\frac{\lambda}{2}\right] $$  $\therefore \frac{v_{\mathrm{A}}}{v_{\mathrm{B}}}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2 \ell} \times \frac{4 \ell}{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{2}{1}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A wave $y=a \sin (\omega t-k x)$ on a string meets with another wave producing a node at $x=0$. Then the equation of the unknown wave is
solution: To form a node there should be superposition of this wave with the reflected wave. The reflected wave should travel in opposite direction with a phase change of $\pi$. The equation of the reflected wave will be  $\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{a} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t}+\mathrm{kx}+\pi)$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{y}=-\mathrm{a} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t}+\mathrm{kx})$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
There harmonic waves having equal frequency $v$ and same intensity $\mathrm{I}_{0}$, have phase angles $0, \frac{\pi}{4}$ and $-\frac{\pi}{4}$ respectively. When they are superimposed the intensity of the resultant wave is close to:

\\
The correct figure that shows, schematically, the wave pattern produced by superposition of two waves of frequencies 9 Hz and 11 Hz is :
solution: Beat frequency   $=$ difference in frequencies of two waves $=11-9=2 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A resonance tube is old and has jagged end. It is still used in the laboratory to determine velocity of sound in air. A tuning fork of frequency 512 Hz produces first resonance when the tube is filled with water to a mark 11 cm below a reference mark, near the open end of the tube. The experiment is repeated with another fork of frequency 256 Hz which produces first resonance when water\\
reaches a mark 27 cm below the reference mark. The velocity of sound in air, obtained in the experiment, is close to:

\\

A tuning fork vibrates with frequency 256 Hz and gives one beat per second with the third normal mode of vibration of an open pipe. What is the length of the pipe? (Speed of sound of air is $340 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$ )

\\
solution: According to question, tuning fork gives 1 beat/second with $(\mathrm{N}) 3^{\text {rd }}$ normal mode. Therefore, organ pipe will have frequency $(256 \pm 1) \mathrm{Hz}$. In open organ pipe, frequency   $\mathrm{n}=\frac{\mathrm{NV}}{2 \ell}$  or, $255=\frac{3 \times 340}{2 \times \ell} \Rightarrow \ell=2 \mathrm{~m}=200 \mathrm{~cm}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
5 beats/ second are heard when a turning fork is sounded with a sonometer wire under tension, when the length of the sonometer wire is either 0.95 m or 1 m . The frequency of the fork will be:

\\
solution: Probable frequencies of tuning fork be $n \pm 5$  Frequency of sonometer wire, $n \propto \frac{1}{l}$  $\therefore \quad \frac{n+5}{n-5}=\frac{100}{95} \Rightarrow 95(n+5)=100(n-5)$  or, $95 n+475=100 n-500$  or, $5 n=975$  or, $n=\frac{975}{5}=195 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A standing wave is formed by the superposition of two waves travelling in opposite directions. The transverse displacement is given by

$\mathrm{y}(x, t)=0.5 \sin \left(\frac{5 \pi}{4} x\right) \cos (200 \pi \mathrm{t})$.

What is the speed of the travelling wave moving in the positive $x$ direction?

( $x$ and $t$ are in meter and second, respectively.)

\\



$\mathrm{s}(\mathrm{d}) 120 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$
solution: Given, $\mathrm{y}(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{t})=5 \sin \left(\frac{5 \pi}{4} \mathrm{x}\right) \cos (200 \pi \mathrm{t})$,  comparing with equation $-\mathrm{y}(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{t})=2 \mathrm{a} \sin \mathrm{kx} \cos \omega \mathrm{t}$ $\omega=200 \pi, k=\frac{5 \pi}{4}$  speed of travelling wave $\mathrm{v}=\frac{\omega}{\mathrm{k}}=\frac{200 \pi}{5 \pi / 4}=160 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A wave represented by the equation $y_{1}=a \cos (k x-\omega t)$ is superimposed with another wave to form a stationary wave such that the point $x-0$ is node. The equation for the other wave is

\\
solution: Since the point $x=0$ is a node and reflection is taking place from point $x=0$. This means that reflection must be taking place from the fixed end and hence the reflected ray must suffer an additional phase change of $\pi$ or a path change of $\frac{\lambda}{2}$.  So, if $y_{\text {incident }}=a \cos (k x-\omega t)$  $\Rightarrow y_{\text {incident }}=a \cos (-k x-\omega t+\pi)$  Hence equation for the other wave  $y=a \cos (k x+\omega t+\pi)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Following are expressions for four plane simple harmonic waves



(i) $y_{1}=A \cos 2 \pi\left(n_{1} t+\frac{x}{\lambda_{1}}\right)$

(ii) $y_{2}=A \cos 2 \pi\left(n_{1} t+\frac{x}{\lambda_{1}}+\pi\right)$

(iii) $y_{3}=A \cos 2 \pi\left(n_{2} t+\frac{x}{\lambda_{2}}\right)$

(iv) $y_{4}=A \cos 2 \pi\left(n_{2} t-\frac{x}{\lambda_{2}}\right)$

The pairs of waves which will produce destructive interference and stationary waves respectively in a medium, are\\
solution: In case of destructive interference  Phase difference $\phi=180^{\circ}$ or $\pi$  So wave pair (i) and (ii) will produce destructive interference.  Stationary or standing waves will produce by equations (iii) \& (iv) as two waves travelling along the same line but in opposite direction.  $n^{\prime}=n+x$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A travelling wave represented by

$y=A \sin (\omega t-k x)$ is superimposed on another wave represented by $y=A \sin (\omega t+k x)$. The resultant is
options: a) A wave travelling along $+x$ direction
b) A wave travelling along -x direction
c) A standing wave having nodes a $x=\frac{n \lambda}{2}, n=0,1,2 \ldots$
d) A standing wave having nodes at $x=\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \frac{\lambda}{2} ; n=0,1,2 \ldots$
solution: $y=A \sin (\omega t-k x)+A \sin (\omega t+k x)$  $y=2 A \sin \omega t \cos k x$  This is an equation of standing wave. For position of nodes  $\cos k x=0$  $\Rightarrow \frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot x=(2 n+1) \frac{\pi}{2}$  $\Rightarrow x=\frac{(2 n+1) \lambda}{4}, n=0,1,2,3, \ldots \ldots \ldots$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Statement - 1 : Two longitudinal waves given by equations : $y_{1}(x, t)=2 a \sin (\omega t-k x)$ and $y_{2}(x, t)=a$ $\sin (2 \omega t-2 k x)$ will have equal intensity. 

Statement - 2: Intensity of waves of given frequency in same medium is proportional to square of amplitude only.
options: a) Statement-1 is true, statement-2 is false.
b) Statement-1 is true, statement-2 is true, statement2 is the correct explanation of statement-1
c) Statement-1 is true, statement-2 is true, statement2 is not the correct explanation of statement-1
d) Statement-1 is false, statement-2 is true.
solution: Intensity of a wave  $I=\frac{1}{2} p w^{2} A^{2} v$  Since, $I \propto A^{2} \omega^{2}$  $\therefore \quad I_{1} \propto(2 a)^{2} \omega^{2}$  and $I_{2} \propto a^{2}(2 \omega)^{2}$  $I_{1}=I_{2}$  In the same medium, $p$ and $v$ are same.  Intensity depends on amplitude and frequency.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Three sound waves of equal amplitudes have frequencies $(v-1), v,(v+1)$. They superpose to give beats. The number of beats produced per second will be :

\\
solution: Maximum number of beats  $=$ Maximum frequency-Minimum frequency  $=(v+1)-(v-1)=2$ Beats per second  \begin{enumerate}

question:
When two tuning forks (fork 1 and fork 2 ) are sounded simultaneously, 4 beats per second are heard. Now, some tape is attached on the prong of the fork 2 . When the tuning forks are sounded again, 6 beats per second are heard. If the frequency of fork 1 is 200 Hz , then what was the original frequency of fork 2 ?

\\
solution: Frequency of fork 1 , no $=200 \mathrm{~Hz}$  No. of beats heard when fork 2 is sounded with fork $1=\Delta n=$ 4  Now on loading (attaching tape) on unknown fork, the mass of tuning fork increases, So the beat frequency increases (from 4 to 6 in this case) then the frequency of the unknown fork 2 is given by,  $\mathrm{n}=\mathrm{n}_{0}-\Delta \mathrm{n}=200-4=196 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A tuning fork of known frequency 256 Hz makes 5 beats per second with the vibrating string of a piano. The beat frequency decreases to 2 beats per second when the tension in the piano string is slightly increased. The frequency of the piano string before increasing the tension was

\\
solution: It is given that tuning fork of frequency 256 Hz makes 5 beats/second with the vibrating string of a piano. Therefore, possible frequency of the piano are $(256 \pm 5)$ Hz . i.e., either 261 Hz or 251 Hz . When the tension in the piano string increases, its frequency will increases. As the original frequency was 261 Hz , the beat frequency should decreases, we can conclude that the frequency of piano string is 251 Hz

question:
A tuning fork arrangement (pair) produces 4 beats/sec with one fork of frequency 288 cps . A little wax is placed on the unknown fork and it then produces 2 beats $/ \mathrm{sec}$. The frequency of the unknown fork is

\\



d) 288 cps
solution: Frequency of unknown fork $=$ known frequency $\pm$ Beat frequency $=288+4 \mathrm{cps}$ or $288-4 \mathrm{cps}$ i.e. 292 cps or 284 cps. When a little wax is placed on the unknown fork, it produces 2 beats $/ \mathrm{sec}$. When a little wax is placed on the unknown fork, its frequency decreases and simultaneously the beat frequency decreases confirming that the frequency of the unknown fork is 292 cps .   Note : Had the frequency of unknown fork been 284 cps , then on placing wax its frequency would have decreased thereby increasing the gap between its frequency and the frequency of known fork. This would produce high beat frequency.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A sound source $S$ is moving along a straight track with speed $v$, and is emitting sound of frequency $v_{0}$ (see figure). An observer is standing at a finite distance, at the point $O$, from the track. The time variation of frequency heard by the observer is best represented by:



( $t_{0}$ represents the instant when the distance between the source and observer is minimum)\\
solution: Frequency heard by the observer  $$ v_{\text {observed }}=\left(\frac{v_{\text {sound }}}{\mathrm{v}_{\text {sound }}-v \cos \theta}\right) v_{0} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-64}   Initially $\theta$ will be less so $\cos \theta$ more. $\therefore v_{\text {observed }}$ more, then it will decrease.\\

question:
A driver in a car, approaching a vertical wall notices that the frequency of his car horn, has changed from 440 Hz to 480 Hz , when it gets reflected from the wall. If the speed of sound in air is $345 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, then the speed of the car is :

\\
solution: Let $f_{1}$ be the frequency heard by wall, $f_{1}=\left(\frac{v}{v-v_{c}}\right) f_{0}$  Here, $v=$ Velocity of sound,  $v_{v}=$ Velocity of Car,  $f_{0}=$ actual frequency of car horn  Let $f_{2}$ be the frequency heard by driver after reflection from wall.  $f_{2}=\left(\frac{v+v_{c}}{v}\right) f_{1}=\left(\frac{v+v_{c}}{v-v_{c}}\right) f_{0}$  $\Rightarrow 480=\left[\frac{345+v_{c}}{345-v_{c}}\right] 440 \Rightarrow \frac{12}{11}=\frac{345+v_{c}}{345-v_{c}}$  $\Rightarrow v_{c}=54 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The driver of a bus approaching a big wall notices that the frequency of his bus's horn changes from 420 Hz to 490 Hz when he hears it after it gets reflected from the wall. Find the speed of the bus if speed of the sound is $330 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$.

\\
solution: From the Doppler's effect of sound, frequency appeared at wall   \begin{equation*} f_{w}=\frac{330}{330-v} \cdot f \tag{i} \end{equation*}   Here, $v=$ speed of bus,  $f=$ actual frequency of source  Frequency heard after reflection from wall $\left(f^{\prime}\right)$ is  $f^{\prime}=\frac{330+v}{330} \cdot f_{w}=\frac{330+v}{330-v} \cdot f$  $\Rightarrow 490=\frac{330+v}{330-v} \cdot 420$  $\Rightarrow v=\frac{330 \times 7}{91} \approx 25.38 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}=91 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Magnetic materials used for making permanent magnets (P) and magnets in a transformer (T) have different properties of the following, which property best matches for the type of magnet required?

$
options: a) T : Large retentivity, small coercivity
b) P: Small retentivity, large coercivity
c) T : Large retentivity, large coercivity
d) P: Large retentivity, large coercivity
solution: Permanent magnets $(P)$ are made of materials with large retentivity and large coercivity. Transformer cores $(T)$ are made of materials with low retentivity and low coercivity.

question:
A stationary observer receives sound from two identical tuning forks, one of which approaches and the other one recedes with the same speed (much less than the speed of sound). The observer hears 2 beats/sec. The oscillation frequency of each tuning fork is $v_{0}=1400 \mathrm{~Hz}$ and the velocity of sound in air is $350 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The speed of each tuning fork is close to:

$\\
solution: From Doppler's effect, frequency of sound heard $\left(f_{1}\right)$ when source is approaching   $f_{1}=f_{0} \frac{c}{c-v}$  Here, $c=$ velocity of sound  $v=$ velocity of source  Frequency of sound heard $\left(f_{2}\right)$ when source is receding  $f_{2}=f_{0} \frac{c}{c+v}$  Beat frequency $=f_{1}-f_{2}$  $\Rightarrow 2=f_{1}-f_{2}=f_{0} c\left[\frac{1}{c-v}-\frac{1}{c+v}\right]$  $=f_{0} c \frac{2 v}{c^{2}\left[1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right]}$  For $c>>v$  $\Rightarrow v=\frac{2 c}{2 f_{0}}=\frac{c}{f_{0}}=\frac{350}{1400}=\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$

question:
A submarine (A) travelling at $18 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$ is being chased along the line of its velocity by another submarine (B) travelling at $27 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$. B sends a sonar signal of 500 Hz to detect A and receives a reflected sound of frequency $v$. The value of $v$ is close to :



(Speed of sound in water $=1500 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$ )\\
solution: f_{1}=f\left(\frac{v-v_{o}}{v-v_{s}}\right)=f\left(\frac{1500-5}{1500-5}\right)  No reflected signal,\\ $f_{2}=f_{1}\left(\frac{v+v_{o}}{v+v_{s}}\right)=f_{1}\left(\frac{1500+7.5}{1500+5}\right)$  $f_{2}=500\left(\frac{1500-5}{1500-7.5}\right)\left(\frac{1500+7.5}{1500+5}\right)$  502 Hz  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two sources of sound $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ produce sound waves of same frequency 660 Hz . A listener is moving from source $\mathrm{S}_{1}$ towards $\mathrm{S}_{2}$ with a constant speed $u \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and he hears\\
10 beats $/ \mathrm{s}$. The velocity of sound is $330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. Then $u$ equals:

\\
solution: $f_{1}=f \frac{v-v_{0}}{v}$ and $f_{2}=f \frac{v+v_{0}}{v}$  $S_{1} \xrightarrow{u} S_{2}$  But frequency,  $f_{2}-f_{1}=f \times \frac{2 v_{0}}{v}$  or $10=660 \times \frac{2 u}{330}$  $\therefore u=2.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A stationary source emits sounds waves of frequency 500 Hz . Two observers moving along a line passing through the source detect sound to be of frequencies 4801 Hz and 530 Hz . Their respective speeds are, in $\mathrm{ms}^{-1}$,

(Given speed of sound $=300 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ ) \\
solution: Frequency of sound source $\left(\mathrm{f}_{0}\right)=500 \mathrm{~Hz}$  When observer is moving away from the source  Apparent frequency $\mathrm{f}_{1}=480=\mathrm{f}_{0}\left(\frac{v-v_{0}^{\prime}}{v}\right)$  And when observer is moving towards the source  $f_{2}=530=f_{0}\left(\frac{v-v_{0}^{\prime \prime}}{v}\right)$  From equation (i)  $480=500\left(\frac{300-v_{0}^{\prime}}{300}\right)$  $\mathrm{v}^{\prime}=12 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  From equation (ii)  $530=500\left(1+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{0}^{\prime \prime}}{\mathrm{v}}\right)$  $\therefore \mathrm{V}^{\prime \prime}=18 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A source of sound S is moving with a velocity of $50 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ towards a stationary observer. The observer measures the frequency of the source as 1000 Hz . What will be the apparent frequency of the source when it is moving away from the observer after crossing him? (Take velocity of sound in air $350 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ )

\\
solution: When source is moving towards a stationary observer,  $f_{\text {app }}=f_{\text {source }}\left(\frac{V-0}{V-50}\right)$  $1000=f_{\text {source }}\left(\frac{350}{300}\right)$  When source is moving away from observer  $f^{\prime}=f_{\text {source }}\left(\frac{350}{350+50}\right)$  $f^{\prime}=\frac{1000 \times 300}{350} \times \frac{350}{400}$  $f^{\prime} \approx 750 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two cars A and B are moving away from each other in opposite directions. Both the cars are moving with a speed of $20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$ with respect to the ground. If an observer in car A detects a frequency 2000 Hz of the sound coming from car B , what is the natural frequency of the sound source in car B ? (speed of sound in air $=340 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$ )

\\
solution: $f^{\prime}=f \frac{v-v_{0}}{v+v_{s}}$  or $2000=f \frac{340-20}{340+20}$  $$ \therefore f=2250 \mathrm{~Hz} \text {. } $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A train moves towards a stationary observer with speed $34 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The train sounds a whistle and its frequency registered by the observer is $f_{1}$ If the speed of the train is reduced to $17 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the frequency registered is $f_{2}$ If speed of sound is $340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, then the ratio $f_{1} / f_{2}$ is:

\\
solution: According to Doppler's effect, when source is moving but observer at rest $\mathrm{f}_{\text {app }}=\mathrm{f}_{0}\left[\frac{V}{V-V_{s}}\right] \Rightarrow \mathrm{f}_{1}=\mathrm{f}_{0}\left[\frac{340}{340-34}\right]$  and, $\mathrm{f}_{2}=\mathrm{f}_{0}\left[\frac{340}{340-17}\right]$  $\therefore \frac{\mathrm{f}_{1}}{\mathrm{f}_{2}}=\frac{340-17}{340-34}=\frac{323}{306}$ or, $\frac{\mathrm{f}_{1}}{\mathrm{f}_{2}}=\frac{19}{18}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A musician using an open flute of length 50 cm produces second harmonic sound waves. A person runs towards the musician from another end of a hall at a speed of $10 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. If the wave speed is $330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the frequency heard by the running person shall be close to:

\\
solution: Frequency of the sound produced by open flute.  $f=2\left(\frac{v}{2 \ell}\right)=\frac{2 \times 330}{2 \times 0.5}=660 \mathrm{~Hz}$  Velocity of observer, $\mathrm{v}_{0}=10 \times \frac{5}{18}=\frac{25}{9} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  As the source is moving towards the observer therefore, according to Doppler's effect  $\therefore$ Frequency detected by observer,  $\mathrm{f}^{\prime}=\left[\frac{v+v_{0}}{v}\right] f=\left[\frac{\frac{25}{9}+330}{330}\right] 660$  $=\frac{2995}{9 \times 330} \times 660$ or, $\mathrm{f}^{\prime}=665.55 \simeq 666 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two sitar strings, A and B, playing the note 'Dha' are slightly out of tune and produce beats and frequency 5 Hz . The tension of the string B is slightly increased and the beat frequency is found to decrease by 3 Hz . If the frequency of A is 425 Hz , the original frequency of B is

\\
solution: $\mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{A}}=425 \mathrm{~Hz}, \mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{B}}=$ ?  Beat frequency $x=5 \mathrm{~Hz}$ which is decreasing $(5 \rightarrow 3)$ after increasing the tension of the string B .  Also tension of string B increasing so  $\mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{B}} \uparrow(\because \mathrm{n} \propto \sqrt{\mathrm{T}})$  Hence $\mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{A}}-\mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{B}} \uparrow=\mathrm{x} \downarrow \longrightarrow$ correct  $\mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{B}} \uparrow-\mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{x} \downarrow \longrightarrow$ incorrect  $\therefore \mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{B}}=\mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{A}}-\mathrm{x}=425-5=420 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A toy-car, blowing its horm, is moving with a steady speed of $5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, away from a wall. An observer, towards whom the toy car is moving, is able to hear 5 beats per second. If the velocity of sound in air is $340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the frequency of the horn of the toy car is close to : \\
