solution: From Doppler's effect  $\mathrm{f}($ direct $)=\mathrm{f}\left(\frac{340}{340-5}\right)=\mathrm{f}_{1}$  $\mathrm{f}($ by wall $)=\mathrm{f}\left(\frac{340}{340+5}\right)=\mathrm{f}_{2}$  Beats $=\left(f_{1}-f_{2}\right)$  $5=\mathrm{f}\left(\frac{340}{340-5}-\frac{340}{340+5}\right)$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{f}=170 \mathrm{~Hz}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two engines pass each other moving in opposite directions with uniform speed of $30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. One of them is blowing a whistle of frequency 540 Hz . Calculate the\\
frequency heard by driver of second engine before they pass each other. Speed of sound is $330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$ :


\\
solution: We know that the apperent frequency  $f^{\prime}=\left(\frac{v-v_{0}}{v-v_{S}}\right) f$ from Doppler's effect  where $v_{0}=v_{\mathrm{s}}=30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, velocity of observer and source  Speed of sound $v=330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  $\therefore \mathrm{f}^{\prime}=\frac{330+30}{330-30} \times 540=648 \mathrm{~Hz}$.  $\because$ Frequency of whistle (f) $=540 \mathrm{~Hz}$.

question:
A train is moving on a straight track with speed $20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$. It is blowing its whistle at the frequency of 1000 Hz . The percentage change in the frequency heard by a person standing near the track as the train passes him is (speed of sound $=320 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$ ) close to :

\\
solution: $f_{1}=f\left[\frac{v}{v-v_{s}}\right]=f \times \frac{320}{300} \mathrm{~Hz}$  $f_{2}=f\left[\frac{v}{v+v_{s}}\right]=f \times \frac{320}{340} \mathrm{~Hz}$  $$ \left(\frac{f_{2}}{f_{1}}-1\right) \times 100=\left(\frac{300}{340}-1\right) \times 100 \simeq 12 \% $$  \begin{enumerate}

According to Doppler's effect,  Apparent, frequency $f=\left(\frac{V+V_{0}}{V-V_{S}}\right) f_{0}$  Now, $f=\left(\frac{f_{0}}{V-V_{S}}\right) V_{0}+\frac{V f_{0}}{V-V_{s}}$  So, slope $=\frac{f_{0}}{V-V_{S}}$  Hence, option (c) is the correct answer.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A bat moving at $10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$ towards a wall sends a sound signal of 8000 Hz towards it. On reflection it hears a sound of frequency $f$. The value of $f$ in Hz is close to (speed of sound $=320 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$ )

\\
solution: Reflected frequency of sound reaching bat  $=\left[\frac{V-\left(-V_{0}\right)}{V-V_{s}}\right] f=\left[\frac{V+V_{0}}{V-V_{s}}\right] f=\frac{V+10}{V-10} f$  $=\left(\frac{320+10}{320-10}\right) \times 8000=8516 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A source of sound A emitting waves of frequency 1800 Hz is falling towards ground with a terminal speed $v$. The observer B on the ground directly beneath the source receives waves of frequency 2150 Hz . The source A receives waves, reflected from ground of frequency nearly: (Speed of sound $=343 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ )

\\
solution: Given $\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{A}}=1800 \mathrm{~Hz}$  $v_{\mathrm{t}}=\mathrm{v}$  $\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{B}}=2150 \mathrm{~Hz}$  Reflected wave frequency received by $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{A}}{ }^{\prime}=$ ?  Applying doppler's effect of sound,  $\mathrm{f}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{S}} \mathrm{f}}{\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{s}}-\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{t}}}$  here, $v_{t}=v_{S}\left(1-\frac{f_{A}}{f_{B}}\right)$  $$ =343\left(1-\frac{1800}{2150}\right) $$  $\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{t}}=55.8372 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Now, for the reflected wave,  $\therefore \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{A}}{ }^{\prime}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{s}}+\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{t}}}{\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{s}}-\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{t}}}\right) \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{A}}$  $=\left(\frac{343+55.83}{343-55.83}\right) \times 1800$  $=2499.44 \approx 2500 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two factories are sounding their sirens at 800 Hz . A man goes from one factory to other at a speed of $2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The velocity of sound is $320 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The number of beats heard by the person in one second will be:

\\
solution: Given: Frequency of sound produced by siren, $f=$ 800 Hz  Speed of observer, $u=2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  Velocity of sound, $v=320 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  No. of beats heard per second $=$ ?  No. of extra waves received by the observer per second $= \pm 4 \lambda$  $\therefore$ No. of beats/ sec  $=\frac{2}{\lambda}-\left(-\frac{2}{\lambda}\right)=\frac{4}{\lambda}$  $=\frac{2 \times 2}{\frac{320}{800}} \quad\left(\because \lambda=\frac{V}{f}\right)$  $=\frac{2 \times 2 \times 800}{320}=10$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A and B are two sources generating sound waves. A listener is situated at C . The frequency of the source at A is 500 Hz . A, now, moves towards C with a speed $4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The number of beats heard at C is 6 . When A moves away from C with speed $4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the number of beats heard at C is 18. The speed of sound is $340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The frequency of the source at B is :



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-57}\\
solution: $\mathrm{f}=500 \mathrm{~Hz}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-66(2)}   Case 1 : When source is moving towards stationary listener apparent frequency $\eta^{\prime}=\eta\left(\frac{v}{v-v_{s}}\right)=500\left(\frac{340}{336}\right)=506$  Hz  Case 2 : When source is moving away from the stationary listener  $\eta^{\prime \prime}=\eta\left(\frac{v}{v+v_{s}}\right)=500\left(\frac{340}{344}\right)=494 \mathrm{~Hz}$  In case 1 number of beats heard is 6 and in case 2 number of beats heard is 18 therefore frequency of the source at $\mathrm{B}=512 \mathrm{~Hz}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An engine approaches a hill with a constant speed. When it is at a distance of 0.9 km , it blows a whistle whose echo is heard by the driver after 5 seconds. If the speed of sound in air is $330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, then the speed of the engine is :

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-66(1)}   Let after 5 sec engine at point C  $\mathrm{t}=\frac{\mathrm{AB}}{330}+\frac{\mathrm{BC}}{330} \quad 5=\frac{0.9 \times 1000}{330}+\frac{\mathrm{BC}}{330}$  $\therefore \mathrm{BC}=750 \mathrm{~m}$  Distance travelled by engine in 5 sec  $=900 \mathrm{~m}-750 \mathrm{~m}=150 \mathrm{~m}$  Therefore velocity of engine  $=\frac{150 \mathrm{~m}}{5 \mathrm{sec}}=30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
This question has Statement 1 and Statement 2. Of the four choices given after the Statements, choose the one that best describes the two Statements.

Statement 1: Bats emitting ultrasonic waves can detect the location of a prey by hearing the waves reflected from it. Statement 2: When the source and the detector are moving, the frequency of reflected waves is changed.
options: a) Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true.
b) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false.
c) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is not the correct explanation of Statement 1.
d) Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is the correct explanation of Statement 1.
solution: Bats catch the prey by hearing reflected ultrasonic waves.  When the source and the detector (observer) are moving, frequency of reflected waves change. This is according to Doppler's effect.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A motor cycle starts from rest and accelerates along a straight path at $2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$. At the starting point of the motor cycle there is a stationary electric siren. How far has the motor cycle gone when the driver hears the frequency of the siren at $94 \%$ of its value when the motor cycle was at rest? (Speed of sound $=330 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$ )

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_14_aa0c6488ea5729570a14g-66}   Let the motorcycle has travelled a distances, its velocity at that point  $\mathrm{v}_{m}^{2}-u^{2}=2 a s \therefore \mathrm{v}_{m}^{2}=2 \times 2 \times s$  $\therefore \mathrm{V}_{m}=2 \sqrt{s}$  The observed frequency will be  $v^{\prime}=v\left[\frac{\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{v}_{m}}{\mathrm{v}}\right]$  $0.94 v=v\left[\frac{330-2 \sqrt{s}}{330}\right] \Rightarrow s=98.01 \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A whistle producing sound waves of frequencies 9500 HZ and above is approaching a stationary person with speed $\mathrm{v} \mathrm{ms}^{-1}$. The velocity of sound in air is $300 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$. If the person can hear frequencies upto a maximum of $10,000 \mathrm{HZ}$, the maximum value of v upto which he can hear whistle is

\\
solution: Apparent frequency $v^{\prime}=v\left[\frac{v}{v-v_{s}}\right]$  $\Rightarrow 10000=9500\left[\frac{300}{300-v}\right] \Rightarrow 300-\mathrm{v}=300 \times 0.95$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{v}=300-285=15 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: An observer moves towards a stationary source of sound, with a velocity one-fifth of the velocity of sound. What is the percentage increase in the apparent frequency? \\
solution: Apparent frequency  $n^{\prime}=n\left[\frac{v+v_{0}}{v}\right]=n\left[\frac{v+\frac{v}{5}}{v}\right]=n\left[\frac{6}{5}\right] \frac{n^{\prime}}{n}=\frac{6}{5}$  The percentage increase in apparent  frequency $\frac{n^{\prime}-n}{n}=\frac{6-5}{5} \times 100=20 \%$   \end{document}

question:
Three charges $+\mathrm{Q}, \mathrm{q},+\mathrm{Q}$ are placed respectively, at distance, $\mathrm{d} / 2$ and d from the origin, on the $x$-axis. If the net force experienced by +Q , placed at $x=0$, is zero, then value of $q$ is:

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-86(1)}   Force due to charge $+Q$,  $\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{\mathrm{KQQ}}{\mathrm{d}^{2}}$  Force due to charge q ,  $\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{b}}=\frac{\mathrm{KQq}}{\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}}{2}\right)^{2}}$  For equilibrium,  $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}_{\mathrm{a}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}_{\mathrm{b}}=0$  $\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{kQQ}}{\mathrm{d}^{2}}+\frac{\mathrm{kQq}}{(\mathrm{d} / 2)^{2}}=0 \quad \therefore \mathrm{q}=-\frac{\mathrm{Q}}{4}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Charge is distributed within a sphere of radius $R$ with a volume charge density $p(r)=\frac{A}{r^{2}} e^{-2 r / a}$ where $A$ and a are constants. If Q is the total charge of this charge distribution, the radius R is:

\\
solution: (b) $\mathrm{Q}=\int \rho \mathrm{dv}=\int_{0}^{\mathrm{R}} \frac{\mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}} \mathrm{e}^{-2 r / a}\left(4 \pi \mathrm{r}^{2} \mathrm{dr}\right)$  $=4 \pi \mathrm{A} \int_{0}^{\mathrm{R}} \mathrm{e}^{-2 \mathrm{r} / \mathrm{a}} \mathrm{dr}=4 \pi \mathrm{A}\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{-2 \mathrm{r} / a}}{-\frac{2}{\mathrm{a}}}\right)_{0}^{\mathrm{R}}$  $=4 \pi \mathrm{A}\left(-\frac{\mathrm{a}}{2}\right)\left(\mathrm{e}^{-2 \mathrm{R} / \mathrm{a}}-1\right)$  $\mathrm{Q}=2 \pi \mathrm{aA}\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{-2 \mathrm{R} / \mathrm{a}}\right)$  $\mathrm{R}=\frac{\mathrm{a}}{2} \log \left(\frac{1}{1-\frac{\mathrm{Q}}{2 \pi \mathrm{aA}}}\right)$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-86(2)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two identical conducting spheres A and B , carry equal charge. They are separated by a distance much larger than their diameter, and the force between them is F. A third identical conducting sphere, C , is uncharged. Sphere C is first touched to A , then to B , and then removed. As a result, the force between A and B would be equal to

\\
solution: Spheres A and B carry equal charge say 'q'  $\therefore \quad$ Force between them, $\mathrm{F}=\frac{\mathrm{kqq}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}$  When A and C are touched, charge on both $\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{C}}=\frac{\mathrm{q}}{2}$  Then when B and C are touched, charge on B  $\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{B}}=\frac{\frac{\mathrm{q}}{2}+\mathrm{q}}{2}=\frac{3 \mathrm{q}}{4}$  Now, the force between charge $\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{A}}$ and $\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{B}}$  $\mathrm{F}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{kq}_{\mathrm{A}} \mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{B}}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{k} \times \frac{\mathrm{q}}{2} \times \frac{3 \mathrm{q}}{4}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}=\frac{3}{8} \frac{\mathrm{kq}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}=\frac{3}{8} \mathrm{~F}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Shown in the figure are two point charges +Q and -Q inside the cavity of a spherical shell. The charges are kept near the surface of the cavity on opposite sides of the centre of the shell. If $\sigma_{1}$ is the surface charge on the inner surface and $\mathrm{Q}_{1}$ net charge on it and $\sigma_{2}$ the surface charge on the outer surface and $\mathrm{Q}_{2}$ net charge on it then :



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-78}\\
solution: Inside the cavity net charge is zero.  $\therefore \quad Q_{1}=0$ and $\sigma_{1}=0$  There is no effect of point charges $+Q,-Q$ and induced charge on inner surface on the outer surface.  $\therefore \quad Q_{2}=0$ and $\sigma_{2}=0$\\

question:
Two charges, each equal to $q$, are kept at $x=-a$ and $x=a$ on the $x$-axis. A particle of mass $m$ and charge $q_{0}=\frac{\mathrm{q}}{2}$ is placed at the origin. If charge $\mathrm{q}_{0}$ is given a small displacement $(\mathrm{y}<<\mathrm{a}$ ) along the y -axis, the net force acting on the particle is proportional to

\\
solution: \\ \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-86(3)}  $\Rightarrow F_{\text {net }}=2 F \cos \theta$  $F_{\text {net }}=\frac{2 k q\left(\frac{q}{2}\right)}{\left(\sqrt{y^{2}+a^{2}}\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{y}{\sqrt{y^{2}+a^{2}}}$  $F_{\text {net }}=\frac{2 k q\left(\frac{q}{2}\right) y}{\left(y^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}$  $(\because y<<a)$  $\Rightarrow \frac{k q^{2} y}{a^{3}} \quad$ So, $F \propto y$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two balls of same mass and carrying equal charge are hung from a fixed support of length $l$. At electrostatic equilibrium, assuming that angles made by each thread is small, the separation, $x$ between the balls is proportional to

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-86}   In equilibrium, $\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{e}}=\mathrm{T} \sin \theta$  $\mathrm{mg}=\mathrm{T} \cos \theta$  $\tan \theta=\frac{\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{e}}}{\mathrm{mg}}=\frac{\mathrm{q}^{2}}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} \mathrm{x}^{2} \times \mathrm{mg}}$  also $\tan \theta \approx \sin =\frac{\mathrm{x} / 2}{\ell}$  Hence, $\frac{\mathrm{x}}{2 \ell}=\frac{\mathrm{q}^{2}}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} \mathrm{x}^{2} \times \mathrm{mg}}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{x}^{3}=\frac{2 \mathrm{q}^{2} \ell}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} \mathrm{mg}}$  $\therefore \mathrm{x}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{q}^{2} \ell}{2 \pi \epsilon_{0} \mathrm{mg}}\right)^{1 / 3}$  Therefore $\mathrm{x} \propto \ell^{1 / 3}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two identical charged spheres suspended from a common point by two massless strings of length $l$ are initially a distance $d(d \ll l)$ apart because of their mutual repulsion. The charge begins to leak from both the spheres at a constant rate. As a result charges approach each other with a velocity $\nu$. Then as a function of distance $x$ between them,

\\
solution: From figure  $T \cos \theta=\mathrm{mg}$  $T \sin \theta=F_{e}$  Dividing equation (ii) by (i), we get  $\Rightarrow \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}=\frac{F_{e}}{m g} \quad \Rightarrow F_{e}=\mathrm{mg} \tan \theta$  $\Rightarrow \frac{k q^{2}}{x^{2}}=\mathrm{mg} \tan \theta \quad \Rightarrow q^{2}=\frac{x^{2} m g \tan \theta}{k}$  Since $\theta$ is small  $\therefore \tan \theta \approx \sin \theta=\frac{x}{2 l}$  $\therefore q^{2}=\frac{x^{3} m g}{2 k l} \Rightarrow q^{2} \propto x^{3 / 2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-87(4)}   $\Rightarrow \frac{d q}{d t} \alpha \frac{3}{2} \sqrt{x} \frac{d x}{d t}=\frac{3}{2} \sqrt{x} V$  Since $\frac{d q}{d t}=$ const.  $\Rightarrow v \propto x^{-1 / 2}$  $\left[\because q^{2} \propto x^{3}\right]$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A charge $Q$ is placed at each of the opposite corners of a square. A charge $q$ is placed at each of the other two corners. If the net electrical force on $Q$ is zero, then $Q / q$ equals:

\\
solution: Let $F$ be the force between $Q$ and $Q$. The force between $q$ and $Q$ should be attractive for net force on $Q$ to be zero. Let $F^{\prime}$ be the force between $Q$ and $q$. The resultant of $F^{\prime}$ and $F^{\prime}$ is $R$. For equilibrium   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-87(5)}   Net force on $Q$ at $C$ is zero.  $\therefore \vec{R}+\vec{F}=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{2} F^{\prime}=-F$  $\Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{2} \times k \frac{Q q}{\ell^{2}}=-k \frac{Q^{2}}{(\sqrt{2} \ell)^{2}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{Q}{q}=-2 \sqrt{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If $g_{E}$ and $g_{M}$ are the accelerations due to gravity on the surfaces of the earth and the moon respectively and if Millikan's oil drop experiment could be performed on the\\
two surfaces, one will find the ratio

$$

$\frac{\text { electronic charge on the moon }}{\text { electronic charge on the earth }}$ to be\\
solution: It is obvious that by charge conservaiton law, electronic charge does not depend on acceleration due to gravity as it is a universal constant.  So, electronic charge on earth  $=$ electronic charge on moon  $\therefore$ Required ratio $=1$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two spherical conductors $B$ and $C$ having equal radii and carrying equal charges on them repel each other with a force $F$ when kept apart at some distance. A third spherical conductor having same radius as that $B$ but uncharged is brought in contact with $B$, then brought in contact with $C$ and finally removed away from both. The new force of repulsion between $B$ and $C$ is

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-87(2)}   Initial force, $F=K \frac{Q_{B} Q_{C}}{x^{2}}$ $x$ is distance between the spheres. When third spherical conductor comes in contact with $B$ charge on $B$ is halved i.e., $\frac{Q}{2}$ and charge on third sphere becomes $\frac{Q}{2}$. Now it is touched to $C$, charge then equally distributes themselves to make potential same, hence charge on $C$ becomes $\left(Q+\frac{Q}{2}\right) \frac{1}{2}=\frac{3 Q}{4}$.  $\therefore F_{\text {new }}=k \frac{Q_{C}^{\prime} Q_{B}^{\prime}}{x^{2}}=k \frac{\left(\frac{3 Q}{4}\right)\left(\frac{Q}{2}\right)}{x^{2}}=k \frac{3}{8} \frac{Q^{2}}{x^{2}}$  or $F_{\text {new }}=\frac{3}{8} F$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Three charges $-q_{1},+q_{2}$ and $-q_{3}$ are place as shown in the figure. The $x$ - component of the force on $-q_{1}$ is proportional to



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-79(4)}\\
solution: Force applied by charge $q_{2}$ on $q_{1}$  $F_{12}=k \frac{q_{1} q_{2}}{b^{2}}$  Force applied by charge $q_{3}$ on $q_{1}$  $F_{13}=k \frac{q_{1} q_{3}}{a^{2}}$  The $X$-component of net force $\left(F_{x}\right)$ on  $q_{1}$ is $F_{12}^{x}+F_{13} \sin \theta$  $\therefore F_{x}=k \frac{q_{1} q_{2}}{b^{2}}+k \frac{q_{1} q_{2}}{a^{2}} \sin \theta$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-87}   $\therefore F_{x} \propto \frac{q_{2}}{b^{2}}+\frac{q_{3}}{a^{2}} \sin \theta$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If a charge $q$ is placed at the centre of the line joining two equal charges $Q$ such that the system is in equilibrium then the value of $q$ is

\\
solution: At equilibrium net force is zero,  $\therefore k \frac{Q \times Q}{(2 x)^{2}}+k \frac{Q q}{x^{2}}=0$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-87(1)}   $\Rightarrow q=-\frac{Q}{4}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Charges $Q_{1}$ and $Q_{2}$ are at points A and B of a right angle triangle OAB (see figure). The resultant electric field at point O is perpendicular to the hypotenuse, then $Q_{1} / Q_{2}$ is proportional to



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-79(1)}\\
solution: Electric field due charge $Q_{2}, E_{2}=\frac{k Q_{2}}{x_{2}^{2}}$  Electric field due charge $Q_{1}, E_{1}=\frac{k Q_{1}}{x_{1}^{2}}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-87(3)}   From figure,  $\tan \theta=\frac{E_{2}}{E_{1}}=\frac{x_{1}}{x_{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{k Q_{2}}{x_{2}^{2} \times \frac{k Q_{1}}{x_{1}^{2}}}=\frac{x_{1}}{x_{2}}$\\ $\Rightarrow \frac{Q_{2} x_{1}^{2}}{Q_{1} x_{2}^{2}}=\frac{x_{1}}{x_{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=\frac{x_{2}}{x_{1}}$ or, $\frac{Q_{1}}{Q_{2}}=\frac{x_{1}}{x_{2}}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Consider the force F on a charge ' $q$ ' due to a uniformly charged spherical shell of radius $R$ carrying charge $Q$ distributed uniformly over it. Which one of the following statements is true for F , if ' $q$ ' is placed at distance $r$ from the centre of the shell?

\\
solution: For spherical shell  $$ \begin{aligned} E & =\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{Q}{r^{2}} & & \text { (if } r \geq R) \\ & =0 & & \text { (if } r<R \text { ) } \end{aligned} $$  Force on charge in electried field, $F=q E$  $\therefore F=0$  (For $r<R$ )  $F=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{Q q}{r^{2}}$  (For $r>R$ )  \begin{enumerate}

question: Two charged thin infinite plane sheets of uniform surface charge density $\sigma_{+}$and $\sigma_{-}$, where $\left|\sigma_{+}\right|>\left|\sigma_{-}\right|$, intersect at right angle. Which of the following best represents the electric field lines for this system?
solution: The electric field produced due to uniformly charged infinite plane is uniform. So option (b) and (d) are wrong. And + ve charge density $\sigma_{+}$is bigger in magnitude so its field along $Y$ direction will be bigger than field of-ve charge density $\sigma_{-}$in $X$ direction. Hence option  is correct.\\ \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-88(2)}

question:
A particle of charge $q$ and mass $m$ is subjected to an electric field $E=E_{0}\left(1-a x^{2}\right)$ in the $x$-direction, where $a$ and $E_{0}$ are constants. Initially the particle was at rest at $x=0$. Other than the initial position the kinetic energy of the particle becomes zero when the distance of the particle from the origin is :

$\\
solution: Given,   Electric field, $E=E_{0}\left(1-x^{2}\right)$  $\therefore$ Force, $F=q E=q E_{0}\left(1-x^{2}\right)$  Also, $F=m a=m v \frac{d v}{d x} \quad\left(\because a=v \frac{d v}{d x}\right)$  $\therefore m v \frac{d v}{d x}=q E_{0}\left(1-x^{2}\right)$  $\Rightarrow v d v=\frac{q E_{0}\left(1-x^{2}\right) d x}{m}$  Integrating both sides we get,  $\Rightarrow \int_{0}^{v} v d v=\int_{0}^{x} \frac{q E_{0}\left(1-x^{2}\right) d x}{m}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{v^{2}}{2}=\frac{q E_{0}}{m}\left(x-\frac{9 x^{3}}{3}\right)=0$  $\Rightarrow x=\sqrt{\frac{3}{a}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A charged particle (mass $m$ and charge $q$ ) moves along $X$ axis with velocity $V_{0}$. When it passes through the origin it enters a region having uniform electric field $\vec{E}=-E \hat{j}$ which extends upto $x=d$. Equation of path of electron in the region $x>d$ is :



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-80(6)}\\
solution: $F_{x}=0, a_{x}=0,(v)_{x}=$ constant  Time taken to reach at ' $P$ ' $=\frac{d}{v_{0}}=t_{0}$ (let)  (Along $-y), y_{0}=0+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{q E}{m} \cdot t_{0}^{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-88(1)}   $\tan \theta=\frac{v_{y}}{v_{x}}=\frac{q E t_{0}}{m \cdot v_{0}},\left(t=\frac{d}{v_{0}}\right)$  $\tan \theta=\frac{q E d}{m \cdot v_{0}^{2}}$, Slope $=\frac{-q E d}{m v_{0}^{2}}$  No electric field $\Rightarrow F_{\text {net }}=0, \vec{v}=$ const.  $y=m x+c,\left\{\begin{array}{l}m=\frac{q E d}{m v_{0}^{2}} \\ \left(d,-y_{0}\right)\end{array}\right\}$  $-y_{0}=\frac{-q E d}{m v_{0}^{2}}, d+c \Rightarrow c=-y_{0}+\frac{q E d^{2}}{m v_{0}^{2}}$  $y=\frac{-q E d}{m v_{0}^{2}} x-y_{0}+\frac{q E d^{2}}{m v_{0}^{2}}$  $y_{0}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{q E}{m}\left(\frac{d}{v_{0}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{q E d^{2}}{m v_{0}^{2}}$  $y=\frac{-q E d x}{m v_{0}^{2}}-\frac{1}{2} \frac{q E d^{2}}{m v_{0}^{2}}+\frac{q E d^{2}}{m v_{0}^{2}}$  $y=\frac{-q E d}{m v_{0}^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{q E d^{2}}{m v_{0}^{2}} \Rightarrow y=\frac{\mathrm{qEd}}{\mathrm{mv}_{0}^{2}}\left(\frac{d}{2}-x\right)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A small point mass carrying some positive charge on it, is released from the edge of a table. There is a uniform electric field in this region in the horizontal direction. Which of the following options then correctly describe the trajectory of the mass? (Curves are drawn schematically and are not to scale).

$

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-80(5)}\\
solution: Net force acting on the particle,  $$ \vec{F}=q E \hat{i}+m g \hat{j} $$  Net acceleration of particle is constant, initial velocity is zero therefore path is straight line.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-88(3)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
Consider a sphere of radius R which carries a uniform charge density $\rho$. If a sphere of radius $\frac{R}{2}$ is carved out of it, as shown, the ratio $\frac{\left|\vec{E}_{A}\right|}{\left|\vec{E}_{B}\right|}$ of magnitude of electric field $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}_{\mathrm{A}}$ and $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}_{\mathrm{B}}$, respectively, at points A and B due to the remaining portion is:



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-80(8)}\\
solution: Electric field at $\mathrm{A}\left(R^{\prime}=\frac{R}{2}\right)$  $E_{A} \cdot d s=\frac{q}{\varepsilon_{0}}$  $\Rightarrow \vec{E}_{A}=\frac{\rho \times \frac{4}{3} \pi\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{3}}{\varepsilon_{0} \cdot 4 \pi\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{2}}$  \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-88}\\ $\Rightarrow \vec{E}_{A}=\frac{\sigma(R / 2)}{3 \varepsilon_{0}}=\left(\frac{\sigma R}{6 \varepsilon_{0}}\right)$  Electric fields at ' $B$ '  $\vec{E}_{B}=\frac{k \times \rho \times \frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}}{R^{2}}-\frac{k \times \rho \times \frac{4}{3} \pi\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{3}}{\left(\frac{3 R}{2}\right)^{2}}$  $\Rightarrow \vec{E}_{B}=\frac{\sigma R}{3 \varepsilon_{0}}-\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\right) \frac{(\sigma)}{\left(\frac{3 R}{2}\right)^{2}} \frac{4 \pi}{3}\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{3}$  $\Rightarrow \vec{E}_{B}=\frac{\sigma R}{3 \varepsilon_{0}}-\frac{\sigma R}{54 \varepsilon_{0}}$  $\Rightarrow E_{B}=\frac{17}{54}\left(\frac{\sigma R}{\varepsilon_{0}}\right)$  $\left|\frac{E_{A}}{E_{B}}\right|=\frac{1 \times 54}{6 \times 17}=\left(\frac{9}{17}\right)=\frac{9}{17} \times \frac{2}{2}=\frac{18}{34}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An electric dipole of moment $\vec{p}=(\hat{i}-3 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}) \times 10^{-29}$ C.m is at the origin $(0,0,0)$. The electric field due to this dipole at $\vec{r}=+\hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+5 \hat{k}$ (note that $\vec{r} \cdot \vec{p}=0$ ) is parallel to:

$\\
solution: Since $\vec{r} \cdot \vec{p}=0$  $\vec{E}$ must be antiparallel to $\vec{p}$  $\therefore \hat{E}$ is parallel to $(\hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-2 \hat{k})$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A charged particle of mass ' $m$ ' and charge ' q ' moving under the influence of uniform electric field $E \hat{i}$ and a uniform magnetic field $B \vec{k}$ follows a trajectory from point P to Q as shown in figure. The velocities at P and Q are respectively, $v \vec{i}$ and $-2 v \vec{j}$. Then which of the following statements (A, B, C, D) are the correct? (Trajectory shown is schematic and not to scale)



 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-80(3)}
 

(A) $\mathrm{E}=\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{m v^{2}}{q a}\right)$

(B) Rate of work done by the electric field at P is $\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{m v^{2}}{a}\right)$

(C) Rate of work done by both the fields at Q is zero

(D) The difference between the magnitude of angular momentum of the particle at P and Q is 2 mav.\\
solution: (A) By work energy theorem  $W_{m g}+W_{\text {ele }}=\frac{1}{2} m(2 v)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m(v)^{2}$  $0+q E_{0} 2 a=\frac{3}{2} m v^{2} \quad \Rightarrow E_{0}=\frac{3}{4} \frac{m v^{2}}{q a}$  (B) Rate of work done at $P=$ power of electric force  $=q E_{0} V=\frac{3}{4} \frac{m v^{3}}{a}$  (C) At, $\mathrm{Q}, \frac{d w}{d t}=0$ for both the fields  (D) The difference of magnitude of angular momentum of the particle at P and Q ,  $\Delta \vec{L}=(-m 2 v 2 a \hat{k})-(-m v a \hat{k})$  $|\Delta \vec{L}|=3 m v a$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Three charged particles

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-80(7)}
 

$A, B$ and $C$ with charges $-4 q, 2 q$ and $-2 q$ are present on the circumference of a circle of radius $d$. The charged particles $A, C$ and centre $O$ of the circle formed an equilateral triangle as shown in figure. Electric field at $O$ along $x$-direction is:

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-89(1)}   Electric field due to charge $+2 q$ at centre $O$  $$ \vec{E}_{1}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \times \frac{2 q}{d^{2}}\left[\frac{\sqrt{3} \hat{i}-\hat{j}}{2}\right] $$  Electric field due to charge $-2 q$ at centre $O$  $$ \vec{E}_{2}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \times \frac{2 q}{d^{2}}\left[\frac{\sqrt{3} \hat{i}-\hat{j}}{2}\right] $$  Electric field due to charge $-4 q$ at centre $O$  $\vec{E}_{3}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \times \frac{4 q}{d^{2}}\left[\frac{\sqrt{3} \hat{i}+\hat{j}}{2}\right]$  $\therefore$ Net electric field at point $O$  $\vec{E}_{0}=\vec{E}_{1}+\vec{E}_{2}+\vec{E}_{3}=\frac{\sqrt{3} q}{\pi \varepsilon_{0} d^{2}} \hat{i}$   \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two infinite planes each with uniform surface charge density $+\sigma$ are kept in such a way that the angle between them is $30^{\circ}$. The electric field in the region shown between them is given by:

$\\
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-81}\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-89(3)}   From figure,  $\vec{E}_{1}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}} \hat{y} \quad$ and $\vec{E}_{2}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left(-\cos 60^{\circ} \hat{x}-\sin 60^{\circ} \hat{y}\right)$  $=\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left(-\frac{1}{2} \hat{x}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \hat{y}\right)$  Electric field in the region shown in figure (P)  $\vec{E}_{P}=\vec{E}_{1}+\vec{E}_{2}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left[-\frac{1}{2} \hat{x}+\left(1-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) \hat{y}\right]$  or, $\vec{E}_{P}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left[\left(1-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) \hat{y}-\frac{\hat{x}}{2}\right]$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A particle of mass $m$ and charge $q$ has an initial velocity $\vec{v}=v_{0} \oint$. If an electric field $\stackrel{1}{E}=E_{0} \stackrel{1}{i}$ and magnetic field ${ }_{B}^{1}=B_{0} \hat{i}$ act on the particle, its speed will double after a time:

\\
solution: In the x direction  $$ \begin{aligned} & F_{x}=q E \\ & \Rightarrow \quad m a_{x}=q E \\ & \Rightarrow \quad a_{x}=\frac{E_{0} q}{m} \end{aligned} $$  For speed to be double,   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-89(2)}   $$ \begin{aligned} & v_{0}^{2}+v_{x}^{2}=\left(2 v_{0}\right)^{2} \\ & \Rightarrow v_{x}=\sqrt{3} v_{0}=a_{x} t \\ & \Rightarrow \sqrt{3} v_{0}=0+\frac{q E_{0} t}{m} \Rightarrow t=\frac{\sqrt{3} v_{0} m}{E_{0} q} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A simple pendulum of length $L$ is placed between the plates of a parallel plate capacitor having electric field E , as shown in figure. Its bob has mass $m$ and charge $q$. The time period of the pendulum is given by :

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-81(1)}\\
$\\
solution: Time period of the pendulum (T) is given by  $T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{L}{g_{\text {eff }}}}$  $g_{\text {eff }}=\frac{\sqrt{(m g)^{2}+(q E)^{2}}}{m}$  $\Rightarrow g_{\text {eff }}=\sqrt{g^{2}+\left(\frac{g E}{m}\right)^{2}} \Rightarrow T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{L}{\sqrt{g^{2}+\left(\frac{q E}{m}\right)^{2}}}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Four point charges $-q,+q,+q$ and $-q$ are placed on $y$-axis at $y=-2 d, y=-d, y=+d$ and $y=+2 d$, respectively. The magnitude of the electric field E at a point on the $x$-axis at $x=\mathrm{D}$, with $\mathrm{D}>>$, will behave as:

\\
solution: $\vec{E}=\left(\overrightarrow{E_{1}}+\overrightarrow{E_{2}}\right)+\left(\overrightarrow{E_{3}}+\overrightarrow{E_{4}}\right)$  or $E=2 E \cos \alpha-2 E \cos \beta$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-90(3)}   $$ =\frac{2 k q}{\left(D^{2}+d^{2}\right)} \times \frac{D}{\sqrt{D^{2}+d^{2}}}-\frac{2 k q}{\left(D^{2}+(2 d)^{2}\right.} \times \frac{D}{\sqrt{D^{2}+(2 d)^{2}}} $$  $$ =\frac{2 k q D}{\left(D^{2}+d^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}-\frac{2 k q D}{\left[D^{2}+(2 d)^{2}\right]^{3 / 2}} $$  For $\mathrm{d}<<\mathrm{D}$  $E \propto \frac{D}{D^{3}} \propto \frac{1}{D^{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The bob of a simple pendulum has mass 2 g and a charge of $5.01 / 4 \mathrm{C}$. It is at rest in a uniform horizontal electric field of intensity $2000 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}$. At equilibrium, the angle that the pendulum makes with the vertical is :\\
 (take $g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ )\\
solution: At equilibrium resultant force on bob must be zero, so  $$ T \cos \theta=m g $$  $T \sin \theta=q E$  Solving (i) and (ii) we get  $\tan \theta=\frac{q E}{m g}$  $\tan \theta=\frac{5 \times 10^{-6} \times 2000}{2 \times 10^{-3} \times 10}=\frac{1}{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-90}   $\left[\right.$ Here, $q=5 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{C}$, $\left.\mathrm{E}=2000 \mathrm{v} / \mathrm{m}, \mathrm{m}=2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~kg}\right]$  $\Rightarrow \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)$\\

question:
For a uniformly charged ring of radius $R$, the electric field on its axis has the largest magnitude at a distance $h$ from its centre. Then value of $h$ is:


\\
solution: Electric field on the axis of a ring of radius R at a distance $h$ from the centre,  $\mathrm{E}=\frac{\mathrm{kQh}}{\left(\mathrm{h}^{2}+\mathrm{R}^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}$  Condition: for maximum electric field $\frac{\mathrm{dE}}{\mathrm{dh}}=0$  $\Rightarrow \frac{d}{d h}\left[\frac{k Q h}{\left(R^{2}+h^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}\right]=0$  By using the concept of maxima and minima we get, $\mathrm{h}=\frac{\mathrm{R}}{\sqrt{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two point charges $q_{1}(\sqrt{10} \mu \mathrm{C})$ and $\mathrm{q}_{2}(-25 \mu \mathrm{C})$ are placed on the $x$-axis at $x=1 \mathrm{~m}$ and $x=4 \mathrm{~m}$ respectively. The electric field (in $\mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m}$ ) at a point $y=3 \mathrm{~m}$ on $y$-axis is,

$$
\left
$$

[9 Jan 2019, II]
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-90(1)}   Let $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}_{1}$ and $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}_{2}$ are the vaues of electric field due to charge, $\mathrm{q}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{q}_{2}$ respectively  magnitude of $E_{1}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \frac{q_{1}}{r_{1}^{2}}$  $=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \frac{\sqrt{10} \times 10^{-6}}{\left(1^{2}+3^{2}\right)}$  $=\left(9 \times 10^{9}\right) \times \sqrt{10} \times 10^{-7}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-90(2)}   $=9 \sqrt{10} \times 10^{2}$  $\therefore \vec{E}_{1}=9 \sqrt{10} \times 10^{2}\left[\cos \theta_{1}(-\vec{i})+\sin \theta_{1} \vec{j}\right]$  $\Rightarrow E_{1}=9 \times \sqrt{10} \times 10^{2}\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}(-\hat{i})+\frac{3}{\sqrt{10}} \hat{j}\right]$  $\Rightarrow E_{1}=9 \times 10^{2}[-\hat{i}+3 \hat{j}]=[-9 \hat{i}+27 \hat{j}] 10^{2}$  Similarly, $\mathrm{E}_{2}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \frac{q_{2}}{r^{2}}$  $\mathrm{E}_{2}=\frac{9 \times 10^{9} \times(25) \times 10^{-6}}{\left(4^{2}+3^{2}\right)} \mathrm{E}_{2}=9 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}$  $$ \therefore \vec{E}_{2}=9 \times 10^{3}\left(\cos \theta_{2} \hat{i}-\sin \theta_{2} \hat{j}\right) \because \tan \theta_{2}=\frac{3}{4} $$  $\therefore \vec{E}_{2}=9 \times 10^{3}\left(\frac{4}{5} \hat{i}-\frac{3}{5} \hat{j}\right)=(72 \hat{i}-54 \hat{j}) \times 10^{2}$  $\therefore \vec{E}=\vec{E}_{1}+\vec{E}_{2}=(63 \hat{i}-27 \hat{j}) \times 10^{2} \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: A body of mass $M$ and charge $q$ is connected to a spring of spring constant $k$. It is oscillating along x -direction about its equilibrium position, taken to be at $x=0$, with an amplitude $A$. An electric field $E$ is applied along the x -direction. Which of the following statements is correct?
options: a) The total energy of the system is $\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} A^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{q^{2} E^{2}}{k}$
b) The new equilibrium position is at a distance: $\frac{2 q E}{k}$ from $x=0$
c) The new equilibrium position is at a distance: $\frac{q E}{2 k}$ from $x=0$
d) The total energy of the system is $\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} A^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \frac{q^{2} E^{2}}{k}$
solution: Equilibrium position will shift to point where resultant force $=0$  $\mathrm{kx}_{\mathrm{eq}}=\mathrm{qE} \Rightarrow \mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{\mathrm{qE}}{\mathrm{k}}$  Total energy $=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m} \omega^{2} \mathrm{~A}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{kx}_{\mathrm{eq}}^{2}$  Total energy $=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m} \omega^{2} \mathrm{~A}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{q}^{2} \mathrm{E}^{2}}{\mathrm{k}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A solid ball of radius R has a charge density $\rho$ given by\\
  $\rho=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{r}{R}\right)$ for $0 \leq r \leq R$. The electric field outside the ball is:

\\
solution: Charge density, $\rho=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{r}{R}\right)$  $$ \begin{aligned} & d q=\rho d v \\ & q_{i n}=\int d q=\rho d v \\ &=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{r}{R}\right) 4 \pi r^{2} d r \quad\left(\because d v=4 \pi \mathrm{r}^{2} \mathrm{dr}\right) \\ &=4 \pi \rho_{0} \int_{0}^{R}\left(1-\frac{r}{R}\right) r^{2} d r \\ &=4 \pi \rho_{0} \int_{0}^{R} r^{2} d r-\frac{r^{2}}{R} d r \\ &=4 \pi \rho_{0}\left[\left[\frac{r^{3}}{3}\right]_{0}^{R}-\left[\frac{r^{4}}{4 R}\right]_{0}^{R}\right]=4 \pi \rho_{0}\left[\frac{R^{3}}{3}-\frac{R^{4}}{4 R}\right] \\ &=4 \pi \rho_{0}\left[\frac{R^{3}}{3}-\frac{R^{3}}{4}\right]=4 \pi \rho_{0}\left[\frac{R^{3}}{12}\right] \\ & q=\frac{\pi \rho_{0} R^{3}}{3} \\ & E .4 \pi r^{2}=\left(\frac{\pi \rho_{0} R^{3}}{3 \epsilon_{0}}\right) \end{aligned} $$  $\therefore \quad$ Electric field outside the ball, $E=\frac{\rho_{0} R^{3}}{12 \epsilon_{0} r^{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A long cylindrical shell carries positive surface charge $\sigma$ in the upper half and negative surface charge - $\sigma$ in the lower half. The electric field lines around the cylinder will look like figure given in : (figures are schematic and not drawn to scale)

\\
solution: Field lines originate perpendicular from positive charge and terminate perpendicular at negative charge. Further this system can be treated as an electric dipole.

question:
A wire of length $L(=20 \mathrm{~cm})$, is bent into a semicircular arc. If the two equal halves of the arc were each to be uniformly charged with charges $\pm \mathrm{Q},\left the net electric field at the centre O of the semicircular arc would be : [Online April 11, 2015]

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-82(12)}\\
reference: |\mathrm{Q}|=10^{3} \varepsilon_{0}\right.$ Coulomb where $\varepsilon_{0}$ is the permittivity (in SI units) of free space
solution: Given: Length of wire $L=20 \mathrm{~cm}$ charge $Q=10^{3} \varepsilon_{0}$   We know, electric field at the centre of the semicircular arc $E=\frac{2 K \lambda}{r}$  or, $E=\frac{2 K\left(\frac{2 Q}{\pi r}\right)}{r}\left[A s \lambda=\frac{2 Q}{\pi r}\right]$  $=\frac{4 K Q}{\pi r^{2}}=\frac{4 K Q \pi^{2}}{\pi L^{2}}=\frac{4 \pi K Q}{L^{2}}=25 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{Ci}$\\

question:
A thin disc of radius $b=2 a$ has a concentric hole of radius ' $a$ ' in it (see figure). It carries uniform surface charge ' $\sigma$ ' on it. If the electric field on its axis at height ' $h$ ' $(h \ll<a)$ from its centre is given as ' Ch ' then value of ' C ' is :

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-82(10)}
solution: Electric field due to complete disc $(R=2 a)$ at a distance $x$ and on its axis  $$ \begin{aligned} & E_{1}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left[1-\frac{x}{\sqrt{R^{2}+x^{2}}}\right] \quad E_{1}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left[1-\frac{h}{\sqrt{4 a^{2}+h^{2}}}\right] \\ & =\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left[1-\frac{h}{2 a}\right] \quad\left[\begin{array}{l} \text { here } x=h \\ \text { and, } R=2 a \end{array}\right] \end{aligned} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-91(1)}   Similarly, electric field due to disc $(R=a)$  $E_{2}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left(1-\frac{h}{a}\right)$  Electric field due to given disc  $E=E_{1}-E_{2}$  $\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left[1-\frac{h}{2 a}\right]-\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left[1-\frac{h}{a}\right]=\frac{\sigma h}{4 \varepsilon_{0} a}$  Hence, $c=\frac{\sigma}{4 a \varepsilon_{0}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A spherically symmetric charge distribution is characterised by a charge density having the following variations:

$\rho(r)=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{r}{R}\right)$ for $r<R$

$\rho(r)=0$ for $r \geq R$

Where $r$ is the distance from the centre of the charge distribution $\rho_{\mathrm{o}}$ is a constant. The electric field at an internal point $(r<R)$ is:

\\
solution: Let us consider a spherical shell of radius $x$ and thickness dx.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-91}   Charge on this shell  $\mathrm{dq}=\rho \cdot 4 \pi \mathrm{x}^{2} \mathrm{dx}=\rho_{0}\left(1-\frac{\mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{R}}\right) \cdot 4 \pi \mathrm{x}^{2} \mathrm{dx}$  $\therefore$ Total charge in the spherical region from centre to $r(r<R)$ is  $q=\int d q=4 \pi \rho_{0} \int_{0}^{r}\left(1-\frac{x}{R}\right) x^{2} d x$  $=4 \pi \rho_{0}\left[\frac{x^{3}}{3}-\frac{x^{4}}{4 R}\right]_{0}^{r}=4 \pi \rho_{0}\left[\frac{r^{3}}{3}-\frac{r^{4}}{4 R}\right]=4 \pi \rho_{0} r^{3}\left[\frac{1}{3}-\frac{r}{4 R}\right]$  $\therefore$ Electric field at $\mathrm{r}, \mathrm{E}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{q}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}$  $=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{4 \pi \rho_{0} \mathrm{r}^{3}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}\left[\frac{1}{3}-\frac{\mathrm{r}}{4 \mathrm{R}}\right]=\frac{\rho_{0}}{\varepsilon_{0}}\left[\frac{\mathrm{r}}{3}-\frac{\mathrm{r}^{2}}{4 \mathrm{R}}\right]$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The magnitude of the average electric field normally present in the atmosphere just above the surface of the Earth is about 150 N/C, directed inward towards the center of the Earth. This gives the total net surface charge carried by the Earth to be:

 [Given $\varepsilon_{\mathrm{o}}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{C}^{2} / \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m}^{2}, \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{E}}=6.37 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}$ ]\\
solution: Given,  Electric field $\mathrm{E}=150 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{C}$  Total surface charge carried by earth $\mathrm{q}=$ ?  or, $\mathrm{q}=\epsilon_{0} \mathrm{EA}$  $=\epsilon_{0} \mathrm{E} \pi \mathrm{r}^{2}$.  $=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 150 \times\left(6.37 \times 10^{6}\right)^{2}$  $\simeq 680 \mathrm{Kc}$  As electric field directed inward hence  $\mathrm{q}=-680 \mathrm{Kc}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The surface charge density of a thin charged disc of radius $R$ is $\sigma$. The value of the electric field at the centre of the disc is $\frac{\sigma}{2 \epsilon_{0}}$. With respect to the field at the centre, the electric field along the axis at a distance R from the centre of the disc :

\\
solution: Electric field intensity at the centre of the disc.  $\mathrm{E}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \epsilon_{0}}$ (given)  Electric field along the axis at any distance x from the centre of the disc  $$ \mathrm{E}^{\prime}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \epsilon_{0}}\left(1-\frac{\mathrm{x}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{x}^{2}+\mathrm{R}^{2}}}\right) $$  From question, $x=R$ (radius of disc)  $\therefore \mathrm{E}^{\prime}=\frac{\sigma}{2 \epsilon_{0}}\left(1-\frac{\mathrm{R}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{R}^{2}+\mathrm{R}^{2}}}\right)$  $=\frac{\sigma}{2 \epsilon_{0}}\left(\frac{\sqrt{2} R-R}{\sqrt{2} R}\right)$  $=\frac{4}{14} \mathrm{E}$  $\therefore \%$ reduction in the value of electric field  $=\frac{\left(E-\frac{4}{14} E\right) \times 100}{E}=\frac{1000}{14} \% \simeq 70.7 \%$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A liquid drop having 6 excess electrons is kept stationary under a uniform electric field of $25.5 \mathrm{kVm}^{-1}$. The density of liquid is $1.26 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. The radius of the drop is (neglect buoyancy).

\\
solution: $\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{qE}=\mathrm{mg}\left(\mathrm{q}=6 \mathrm{e}=6 \times 6 \times 10^{-19}\right)$  $\operatorname{Density}(\mathrm{d})=\frac{\text { mass }}{\text { volume }}=\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\frac{4}{3} \pi \mathrm{r}^{3}}$  or $\mathrm{r}^{3}=\frac{\mathrm{m}}{\frac{4}{3} \pi \mathrm{d}}$  Putting the value of d and $\mathrm{m}\left(=\frac{\mathrm{qE}}{\mathrm{g}}\right)$ and solving we get r $=7.8 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~m}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
In a uniformly charged sphere of total charge $Q$ and radius $R$, the electric field $E$ is plotted as function of distance from the centre, The graph which would correspond to the above will be:

\\
solution: Let us consider a spherical shell of radius $x$ and thickness $d x$.  Charge on this shell  $d q=\rho \cdot 4 \pi x^{2} d x=\rho_{0}\left(\frac{5}{4}-\frac{x}{R}\right) \cdot 4 \pi x^{2} d x$  $\therefore$ Total charge in the spherical region from centre to $r(r<R)$ is  $q=\int d q=4 \pi \rho_{0} \int_{0}^{r}\left(\frac{5}{4}-\frac{x}{R}\right) x^{2} d x$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-92}   $=4 \pi \rho_{0}\left[\frac{5}{4} \cdot \frac{r^{3}}{3}-\frac{1}{R} \cdot \frac{r^{4}}{4}\right]=\pi \rho_{0} r^{3}\left(\frac{5}{3}-\frac{r}{R}\right)$  $\therefore \quad$ Electric field at $r$,  $$ \begin{aligned} & E=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{q}{r^{2}} \\ & =\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{\pi \rho_{0} r^{3}}{r^{2}}\left(\frac{5}{3}-\frac{r}{R}\right)=\frac{\rho_{0} r}{4 \epsilon_{0}}\left(\frac{5}{3}-\frac{r}{R}\right) \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Three positive charges of equal value $q$ are placed at vertices of an equilateral triangle. The resulting lines of force should be sketched as in

\\
solution: Electric lines of force due to a positive charge is spherically symmetric  All the charges are positive and equal in magnitude. So repulsion takes place. Due to which no lines of force are present inside the equilateral triangle and the resulting lines of force obtained as shown:   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-92(2)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
A thin semi-circular ring of radius $r$ has a positive charge $q$ distributed uniformly over it. The net field $\vec{E}$ at the centre $O$ is



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-83(4)}\\
solution: Let us consider a differential element $d$ l subtending at angle $d Q$ at the centre $Q$ as shown in the figure. Linear charge density $\lambda=\frac{q}{Q r}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-92(1)}   Charge on the element, $d q=\left(\frac{q}{\pi r}\right) d l$  $=\frac{q}{\pi r}(r d \theta)$  $(\because d l=r d \theta)$  $=\left(\frac{q}{\pi}\right) d \theta$  Electric field at the center $O$ due to $d q$ is  $$ d E=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{d q}{r^{2}}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{q}{\pi r^{2}} d \theta $$  Resolving $d E$ into two rectangular component, we find the component $d E \cos \theta$ will be counter balanced by another element on left portion. Hence resultant field at $O$ is the resultant of the component $d E \sin \theta$ only.  $\therefore E=\int d E \sin \theta=\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{q}{4 \pi^{2} r^{2} \epsilon_{0}} \sin \theta d \theta$  $=\frac{q}{4 \pi^{2} r^{2} \epsilon_{0}}[-\cos \theta]_{0}^{\pi}$  $=\frac{q}{4 \pi^{2} r^{2} \epsilon_{0}}(+1+1)=\frac{q}{2 \pi^{2} r^{2} \epsilon_{0}}$  The direction of $E$ is towards negative $y$-axis.  $\therefore \vec{E}=-\frac{q}{2 \pi^{2} r^{2} \epsilon_{0}} \hat{j}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Let there be a spherically symmetric charge distribution with charge density varying as $\rho(r)=\rho_{0}\left(\frac{5}{4}-\frac{r}{R}\right)$ upto $r$ $=R$, and $\rho(r)=0$ for $r>R$, where r is the distance from the origin. The electric field at a distance $r(r<R)$ from the origin is given by

\\
solution: Let us consider a spherical shell of radius $x$ and thickness $d x$  Due to shpherically symmetric charge distribution, the chrge on the spherical surface of radius $x$ is  $d q=d V \rho \cdot 4 \pi x^{2} d x=\rho_{0}\left(\frac{5}{4}-\frac{x}{R}\right) \cdot 4 \pi x^{2} d x$  $\therefore$ Total charge in the spherical region from centre to $r(r<R)$ is  $q=\int d q=4 \pi \rho_{0} \int_{0}^{r}\left(\frac{5}{4}-\frac{x}{R}\right) x^{2} d x$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-93(2)}   $=4 \pi \rho_{0}\left[\frac{5}{4} \cdot \frac{r^{3}}{3}-\frac{1}{R} \cdot \frac{r^{4}}{4}\right]=\pi \rho_{0} r^{3}\left(\frac{5}{3}-\frac{r}{R}\right)$  $\therefore$ Electric field intensity at a point on this spherical surface $E=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{q}{r^{2}}$  $=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{\pi \rho_{0} r^{3}}{r^{2}}\left(\frac{5}{3}-\frac{r}{R}\right)=\frac{\rho_{0} r}{4 \epsilon_{0}}\left(\frac{5}{3}-\frac{r}{R}\right)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
This question contains Statement-1 and Statement-2. Of the four choices given after the statements, choose the one that best describes the two statements.

Statement-1 : For a charged particle moving from point $P$ to point $Q$, the net work done by an electrostatic field on the particle is independent of the path connecting point $P$ to point $Q$.

Statement-2 : The net work done by a conservative force on an object moving along a closed loop is zero.
options: a) Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is the correct explanation of Statement-1.
b) Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is not the correct explanation of Statement-1.
c) Statement-1 is false, Statement-2 is true.
d) Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is false.

question:
Let $\rho(r)=\frac{Q}{\pi R^{4}} r$ be the charge density distribution for a solid sphere of radius $R$ and total charge $Q$. For a point ' $P$ ' inside the sphere at distance $r_{1}$ from the centre of the sphere, the magnitude of electric field is :

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-93(3)}   Let us consider a spherical shell of thickness $d x$ and radius $x$. The area of this spherical shell $=4 \pi x^{2}$.  The volume of this spherical shell $=4 \pi x^{2} d x$. The charge enclosed within shell  $d q=\left[\frac{Q . x}{\pi R^{4}}\right]\left[4 \pi x^{2} d x\right]=\frac{4 Q}{R^{4}} x^{3} d x$  The charge enclosed in a sphere of radius $r_{1}$ can be calculated by  $Q=\int d q=\frac{4 Q}{R^{4}} \int_{0}^{r_{1}} x^{3} d x=\frac{4 Q}{R^{4}}\left[\frac{x^{4}}{4}\right]_{0}^{r_{1}}=\frac{Q}{R^{4}} r_{1}^{4}$  $\therefore$ The electric field at point $P$ inside the sphere at a distance $r_{1}$ from the centre of the sphere is  $E=\frac{1}{4 \pi E} \frac{Q}{r_{1}^{2}}$  $\Rightarrow E=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \frac{\left[\frac{Q}{R^{4}} r_{1}^{4}\right]}{r_{1}^{2}}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \frac{Q}{R^{4}} r_{1}^{2}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A thin spherical shell of radus $R$ has charge $Q$ spread uniformly over its surface. Which of the following graphs most closely represents the electric field $E(r)$ produced by the shell in the range $0 \leq r<\infty$, where $r$ is the distance from the centre of the shell?

\\
solution: The electric field inside a thin spherical shell of radius $R$ has charge $Q$ spread uniformly over its surface is zero.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-93(1)}   Outside the shell the electric field is $E=k \frac{Q}{r^{2}}$. These characteristics are represented by graph (a)  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two spherical conductors $A$ and $B$ of radii 1 mm and 2 mm are separated by a distance of 5 cm and are uniformly charged. If the spheres are connected by a conducting wire then in equilibrium condition, the ratio of the magnitude of the electric fields at the surfaces of spheres $A$ and $B$ is

\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-93}   When the two conducting spheres are connected by a conducting wire, charge will flow from one to other till both acquire same potential.  $\therefore$ After connection, $V_{1}=V_{2}$  $\Rightarrow k \frac{Q_{1}}{r_{1}}=k \frac{Q_{2}}{r_{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{Q_{1}}{r_{1}}=\frac{Q_{2}}{r_{2}}$  The ratio of electric fields  $\frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}=\frac{k \frac{r_{1}}{r_{1}^{2}}}{k \frac{Q_{2}}{r_{2}^{2}}} \Rightarrow \frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}=\frac{Q_{1}}{r_{1}^{2}} \times \frac{r_{2}^{2}}{Q_{2}}$  $\Rightarrow \frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}=\frac{r_{1} \times r_{2}^{2}}{r_{1}^{2} \times r_{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}}=\frac{r_{2}}{r_{1}}=\frac{2}{1}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two point charges $+8 q$ and $-2 q$ are located at $x=0$ and $x=L$ respectively. The location of a point on the $x$ axis at which the net electric field due to these two point charges is zero is

\\
solution: At $P \frac{-K 2 q}{(x-L)^{2}}+\frac{K 8 q}{x^{2}}=0$  $\Rightarrow \frac{1}{(x-L)^{2}}=\frac{4}{x^{2}}$  or $\frac{1}{x-L}=\frac{2}{x}$  $\Rightarrow x=2 x-2 L$ or $x=2 L$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-94(1)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
A charged ball $B$ hangs from a silk thread $S$, which makes an angle $\theta$ with a large charged conducting sheet $P$, as shown in the figure. The surface charge density $\sigma$ of the sheet is proportional to



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-83}\\
solution: P   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-94(2)}   $T \sin \theta=q E$  $T \cos \theta=m g$  Dividing (i) by (ii),  $\tan \theta=\frac{q E}{m g}=\frac{q}{m g}\left(\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0} K}\right) \frac{\sigma q}{\varepsilon_{0} K \cdot m g}$  $\therefore \sigma \propto \tan \theta$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Four charges equal to $-Q$ are placed at the four corners of a square and a charge $q$ is at its centre. If the system is in equilibrium the value of $q$ is

\\
solution: For the system to be equilibrium, net field at $A$ should be zero  $$ \begin{aligned} & \sqrt{2} E_{1}+E_{2}=E_{3} \\ & \therefore \frac{k Q \times \sqrt{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{k Q}{(\sqrt{2} a)^{2}}=\frac{k q}{\left(\frac{a}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}} \end{aligned} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-94}   $\Rightarrow \frac{Q \sqrt{2}}{1}+\frac{Q}{2}=2 q \Rightarrow q=\frac{Q}{4}(2 \sqrt{2}+1)$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A charged oil drop is suspended in a uniform field of $3 \times 10^{4}$ $\mathrm{v} / \mathrm{m}$ so that it neither falls nor rises. The charge on the drop will be (Take the mass of the charge $=9.9 \times 10^{-15} \mathrm{~kg}$ and $g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$ )

\\
solution: Given, Electric field, $E=3 \times 10^{4}$  Mass of the drop, $m=9.9 \times 10^{-15} \mathrm{~kg}$  At equilibrium, coulomb force on drop balances weight of drop. $q E=m g$  $\Rightarrow q=\frac{m g}{E} \Rightarrow q=\frac{9.9 \times 10^{-15} \times 10}{3 \times 10^{4}}=3.3 \times 10^{-18} \mathrm{C}$\\

question: Two identical electric point dipoles have dipole moments $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{1}}=\mathrm{P} \hat{i}$ and $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{2}}=-\mathrm{P} \hat{i}$ and are held on the $x$ axis at distance ' $a$ ' from each other. When released, they move along $x$ axis with the direction of their dipole moments remaining unchanged. If the mass of each dipole is ' m ', their speed when they are infinitely far apart is : $\quad$ \\
solution: Let $v$ be the speed of dipole.  Using energy conservation  $K_{i}+U_{i}=K_{f}+U_{f}$  $\Rightarrow 0-\frac{2 k \cdot p_{1}}{r^{3}} p_{2} \cos \left(180^{\circ}\right)=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+0$  $(\because$ Potential energy of interaction between dipole  $$ \left.=\frac{-2 p_{1} p_{2} \cos \theta}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} r^{3}}\right) $$  $\Rightarrow m v^{2}=\frac{2 k p_{1} p_{2}}{r^{3}} \Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{2 k p_{1} p_{2}}{m r^{3}}}$  When $p_{1}=p_{2}=p$ and $r=\mathrm{a}$  $v=\frac{p}{a} \sqrt{\frac{1}{2 \pi \epsilon_{0} m a}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An electric field $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=4 x \hat{i}-\left(y^{2}+1\right) \hat{j} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{C}$ passes through the box shown in figure. The flux of the electric field through surfaces ABCD and BCGF are marked as $\phi_{1}$ and $\phi_{11}$ respectively. The difference between ( $\phi_{1}-\phi_{11}$ ) is (in $\mathrm{Nm}^{2} / \mathrm{C}$ ) $\qquad$ .




 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-84}
solution: Flux of electric field $\vec{E}$ through any area $\vec{A}$ is defined as $\phi=\int E . A \cos \theta$  Here, $\theta=$ angle between electric field and area vector of a surface  For surface $A B C D$ Angle, $\theta=90^{\circ}$  $\therefore \phi_{1}=\int E . A \cos 90^{\circ}=0$  For surface $B C G F \phi_{n}=\int \vec{E} \cdot \overrightarrow{d A}$  $\therefore \quad \phi_{11}=\left[4 \times \hat{i}-\left(y^{2}+1\right) \hat{j}\right] \cdot 4 \hat{i}=16 x$  $$ \phi_{11}=48 \frac{N m^{2}}{C} $$  $\phi_{1}-\phi_{11}=-48$  \begin{enumerate}

question: In finding the electric field using Gauss law the formula $|\vec{E}|=\frac{q_{\text {enc }}}{\epsilon_{0}|A|}$ is applicable. In the formula $\epsilon_{0}$ is permittivity of free space, $A$ is the area of Gaussian surface and $q_{\text {enc }}$ is charge enclosed by the Gaussian surface. This equation can be used in which of the following situation?
options: a) Only when the Gaussian surface is an equipotential surface.
b) Only when the Gaussian surface is anequipotential surface and $|\vec{E}|$ is constant on the surface.
c) Only when $|\vec{E}|=$ constant on the surface.
d) For any choice of Gaussian surface.

question:
Shown in the figure is a shell made of a conductor. It has inner radius $a$ and outer radius $b$, and carries charge Q . At its centre is a dipole $\vec{p}$ as shown. In this case :

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-84(1)}
options: a) surface change density on the inner surface is uniform and equal to $\frac{\mathrm{Q} / 2}{4 \pi \mathrm{a}^{2}}$
b) electric field outside the shell is the same as that of a point charge at the centre of the shell.
c) surface charge density on the outer surface depends on $|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}}|$
d) surface charge density on the inner surface of the shell is zero everywhere.-
solution: Surface charge density depends only due to $Q$. Also   $$ \begin{aligned} & \oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{A}=\frac{q_{1} \lambda}{\varepsilon_{0}} \\ & \text { or } E \times 4 \pi r^{2}=\frac{Q}{\varepsilon_{0}} \Rightarrow E=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{Q}{r^{2}}, r \geq R \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Let a total charge 2 Q be distributed in a sphere of radius R , with the charge density given by $\rho(r)=k r$, where r is the distance from the centre. Two charges A and B , of -Q each, are placed on diametrically opposite points, at equal distance, a , from the centre. If A and B do not experience any force, then.

\\
solution: $\oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{A}=\frac{q_{i n}}{\varepsilon_{0}}$  \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-94(3)}\\ or $E \times 4 \pi \mathrm{r}^{2}=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}} \int S\left(4 \pi r^{2}\right) d r$  or $\mathrm{E} \times 4 \pi \mathrm{r}^{2}=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}} \int_{0}^{r}(k r)\left(4 \pi r^{2}\right) d r$  or $E \times 4 \pi \mathrm{r}^{2}=\frac{4 \pi k}{\varepsilon_{0}}\left(\frac{r^{4}}{4}\right)$  $\therefore \quad E=\frac{k}{4 \varepsilon_{0}} r^{2}$  Also $2 Q=\int_{0}^{R}(k r)\left(4 \pi r^{2}\right) d r=4 \pi k\left|\frac{r^{4}}{4}\right|_{0}^{R}$   \begin{equation*} Q=\frac{\pi k R^{4}}{2} \tag{ii} \end{equation*}   From above equations,   \begin{equation*} E=\frac{Q r^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{4}} \tag{iii} \end{equation*}   According to given condition   \begin{equation*} =E Q \frac{Q^{4}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}(20)^{2}} \tag{iv} \end{equation*}   From equations (iii) and (iv), we have $\mathrm{a}=8^{-1 / 4} \mathrm{R}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
An electric dipole is formed by two equal and opposite charges $q$ with separation $d$. The charges have same mass $m$. It is kept in a uniform electric field $E$. If it is slightly rotated from its equilibrium orientation, then its angular frequency $\omega$ is :

\\
solution: $\tau=-P E \sin \theta$  or $I \alpha=-P E(\theta)$  $$ \alpha=\frac{P E}{I}(-\theta) $$  On comparing with  $$ \alpha=-\omega^{2} \theta $$  $$ \omega=\sqrt{\frac{P E}{I}}=\sqrt{\frac{q d E}{2 m\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 q E}{m d}} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question: An electric field of $1000 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}$ is applied to an electric dipole at angle of $45^{\circ}$. The value of electric dipole moment is $10^{-29}$ C.m. What is the potential energy of the electric dipole?\\
solution: Potential energy of a dipole is given by  $\mathrm{U}=-\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} . \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}$  $=-\mathrm{PE} \cos \theta$  [Where $\theta=$ angle between dipole and perpendicular to the field]  $=-\left(10^{-29}\right)\left(10^{3}\right) \cos 45^{\circ}$  $=-0.707 \times 10^{-26} \mathrm{~J}=-7 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~J}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: Charges -q and +q located at A and B , respectively, constitute an electric dipole. Distance $\mathrm{AB}=2 \mathrm{a}, \mathrm{O}$ is the mid point of the dipole and OP is perpendicular to AB . A charge Q is placed at P where $\mathrm{OP}=y$ and $y>2 \mathrm{a}$. The charge Q experiences an electrostatic force F . If Q is now moved along the equatorial line to $\mathrm{P}^{\prime}$ such that $\mathrm{OP}^{\prime}$ $=\left(\frac{y}{3}\right)$, the force on Q will be close to: $\left(\frac{y}{3}>2 \mathrm{a}\right)$\\
solution: Electric field of equitorial plane of dipole $=-\frac{K \vec{P}}{r^{3}}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-95}   $\therefore$ At point $\mathrm{P},=+\frac{\mathrm{KP}}{\mathrm{y}^{3}} \mathrm{Q}$  At Point $\mathrm{P}^{1}, \mathrm{~F}^{1}=+\frac{\mathrm{KPQ}}{(\mathrm{y} / 3)^{3}}=27 \mathrm{~F}$.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A charge $Q$ is placed at a distance $\mathrm{a} / 2$ above the centre of the square surface of edge a as shown in the figure. The electric flux through the square surface is:\\
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-85(4)}\\
solution: When cube is of side a and point charge Q is at the center of the cube then the total electric flux due to this charge will pass evenly through the six faces of the cube. So, the electric flux through one face will be equal to $1 / 6$ of the total electric flux due to this charge.  Flux through 6 faces $=\frac{\mathrm{Q}}{\epsilon_{0}}$  $\therefore$ Flux through 1 face, $=\frac{\mathrm{Q}}{6 \epsilon_{\mathrm{o}}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: An electric dipole has a fixed dipole moment $\vec{p}$, which makes angle $\theta$ with respect to $x$-axis. When subjected to an electric field $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}_{1}}=\mathrm{E} \hat{i}$, it experiences a torque $\vec{T}_{1}=\tau \hat{i}$. When subjected to another electric field $\overrightarrow{E_{2}}=\sqrt{3 E_{1}} \hat{j}$ it experiences torque $\vec{T}_{2}=-\vec{T}_{1}$. The angle $\theta$ is: \\
solution: $T=\mathrm{PE} \sin \theta$ Torque experienced by the dipole in an electric field, $\vec{T}=\vec{P} \times \vec{E}$  $\vec{p}=p \cos \theta \hat{i}+p \sin \theta \hat{j}$  $\vec{E}_{1}=E \vec{i}$  $\vec{T}_{1}=\vec{p} \times \vec{E}_{1}=(p \cos \theta \hat{i}+p \sin \theta \hat{j}) \times E(\hat{i})$  $\tau \hat{k}=p E \sin \theta(-\hat{k})$  $\vec{E}_{2}=\sqrt{3} E_{1} \hat{j}$  $\left.\vec{T}_{2}=p \cos \theta \hat{i}+p \sin \theta \hat{j}\right) \times \sqrt{3} E_{1} \hat{j}$  $\tau \hat{k}=\sqrt{3} p E_{1} \cos \theta \hat{k}$  From eqns. (i) and (ii)  $p E \sin \theta=\sqrt{3} p E \cos \theta$  $\tan \theta=\sqrt{3} \quad \therefore \quad \theta=60^{\circ}$  \begin{enumerate}

The net flux linked with closed surfaces $\mathrm{S}_{1}, \mathrm{~S}_{2}, \mathrm{~S}_{3} \& \mathrm{~S}_{4}$ are  For surface $S_{1}, \phi_{1}=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}}(2 q)$  For surface $\mathrm{S}_{2}, \phi_{2}=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}}(\mathrm{q}+\mathrm{q}+\mathrm{q}-\mathrm{q})=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}} 2 \mathrm{q}$  For surface $S_{3}, \phi_{3}=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}}(q+q)=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}}(2 q)$  For surface $S_{4}, \phi_{4}=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}}(8 q-2 q-4 q)=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}}(2 q)$  Hence, $\phi_{1}=\phi_{2}=\phi_{3}=\phi_{4}$ i.e. net electric flux is same for all surfaces.  Keep in mind, the electric field due to a charge outside ( $\mathrm{S}_{3}$ and $\mathrm{S}_{4}$ ), the Gaussian surface contributes zero net flux through the surface, because as many lines due to that charge enter the surface as leave it.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The region between two concentric spheres of radii 'a' and ' $b$ ', respectively (see figure), have volume charge density $\rho=\frac{A}{r}$, where A is a constant and r is the distance from the centre. At the centre of the spheres is a point charge Q . The value of A such that the electric field in the region between the spheres will be constant, is:



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-85(1)}\\
solution: Applying Gauss's law  $$ \begin{aligned} & \oint_{S} \vec{E} \cdot \overrightarrow{d s}=\frac{Q}{\epsilon_{0}} \\ & \therefore E \times 4 \pi r^{2}=\frac{Q+2 \pi A r^{2}-2 \pi A a^{2}}{\epsilon_{0}} \end{aligned} $$  $\rho=\frac{d r}{d V}$  $Q=\rho 4 \pi r^{2}$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-96(3)}   $Q=\int_{a}^{r} \frac{A}{r} 4 \pi r^{2} d r=2 \pi A\left[r^{2}-a^{2}\right]$  $E=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}\left[\frac{\mathrm{Q}-2 \pi \mathrm{Aa}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}+2 \pi \mathrm{A}\right]$  For $E$ to be independent of ' $r$ '  $Q-2 \pi A a^{2}=0$  $$ \therefore A=\frac{Q}{2 \pi a^{2}} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The electric field in a region of space is given by, $\vec{E}=E_{0} \hat{i}+2 E_{o} \hat{j}$ where $E_{o}=100 \mathrm{~N} / C$. The flux of the field through a circular surface of radius 0.02 m parallel to the Y -\\
Z plane is nearly:\\
solution: $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=\mathrm{E}_{0} \hat{\mathrm{i}}+2 \mathrm{E}_{0} \hat{\mathrm{j}}$  Given, $\mathrm{E}_{0}=100 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{c}$  So, $\vec{E}=100 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+200 \hat{\mathrm{j}}$  Radius of circular surface $=0.02 \mathrm{~m}$  Area $=\pi \mathrm{r}^{2}=\frac{22}{7} \times 0.02 \times 0.02$  $=1.25 \times 10^{-3} \hat{\mathrm{i}} \mathrm{m}^{2} \quad$ [Loop is parallel to Y-Z plane]  Now, flux $(\phi)=$ EA $\cos \theta$  $=(100 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+200 \hat{\mathrm{j}}) \cdot 1.25 \times 10^{-3} \hat{\mathrm{i}} \cos \theta^{\circ}\left[\theta=0^{\circ}\right]$  $=125 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} / \mathrm{c}$  $=0.125 \mathrm{Nm}^{2} / \mathrm{c}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two point dipoles of dipole moment $\vec{p}_{1}$ and $\vec{p}_{2}$ are at a distance $x$ from each other and $\vec{p}_{1} \| \vec{p}_{2}$. The force between the dipoles is :

\\
solution: Force of interaction   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-96}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
The flat base of a hemisphere of radius a with no charge inside it lies in a horizontal plane. A uniform electric field $\vec{E}$ is applied at an angle $\frac{\pi}{4}$ with the vertical direction. The electric flux through the curved surface of the hemisphere is



\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-85(3)}\\
solution: We know that,  $\phi=\oint E . d S=E \oint d S \cos 45^{\circ}$  In case of hemisphere  $\phi_{\text {curved }}=\phi_{\text {circular }}$  Therefore, $\phi_{\text {curved }}=E \pi a^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=\frac{E \pi a^{2}}{\sqrt{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question: An electric dipole is placed at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ to a nonuniform electric field. The dipole will experience
options: a) a translational force only in the direction of the field
b) a translational force only in a direction normal to the direction of the field
c) a torque as well as a translational force
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-96(1)}   As the dipole is placed in non-uniform field, so the force acting on the dipole will not cancel each other. This will result in a force as well as torque.  \begin{enumerate}

question:
If the electric flux entering and leaving an enclosed surface respectively is $\phi_{1}$ and $\phi_{2}$, the electric charge inside the surface will be

\\
solution: The electric flux $\phi_{1}$ entering an enclosed surface is taken as negative and the electric flux $\phi_{2}$ leaving the surface is taken as positive, by convention. Therefore the net flux leaving the enclosed surface, $\phi=\phi_{2}-\phi_{1}$  According to Gauss theorem  $$ \phi=\frac{q}{\epsilon_{0}} \quad \Rightarrow q=\epsilon_{0} \phi=\epsilon_{0}\left(\phi_{2}-\phi_{1}\right) $$  \begin{enumerate}

Electric flux due to charge placed outside is zero. But for the charge inside the cube, flux due to each face is  $\frac{1}{6}\left[\frac{q}{\epsilon_{0}}\right]$ which is not in option.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_12ca6e8d0caf0402ea9bg-96(2)}    \end{document}

question:
Ten charges are placed on the circumference of a circle of radius $R$ with constant angular separation between successive charges. Alternate charges 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 have charge $(+q)$ each, while $2,4,6,8,10$ have charge $(-q)$ each. The potential $V$ and the electric field $E$ at the centre of the circle are respectively :

(Take $V=0$ at infinity)
options: d) $V=\frac{10 q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R} ; E=\frac{10 q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2}}$
solution: Potential at the centre, $V_{C}=\frac{K Q_{\text {net }}}{\mathrm{R}}$  $\because Q_{\text {net }}=0$  $\therefore V_{C}=0$  Let $E$ be electric field produced by each charge at the centre, then resultant electric field will be $E_{C}=0$, since equal electric field vectors are acting at equal angle so their resultant is equal to zero.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_06f9eecddb573a703badg-113(3)}   \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two isolated conducting spheres $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ of radius $\frac{2}{3} R$ and $\frac{1}{3} R$ have $12 \mu \mathrm{C}$ and $-3 \mu \mathrm{C}$ charges, respectively, and are at a large distance from each other. They are now connected by a conducting wire. A long time after this is done the charges on $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ are respectively :

\\
solution: Total charge $Q_{1}+Q_{2}=Q_{1}^{\prime}+Q_{2}^{\prime}$  $$ =12 \mu C-3 \mu C=9 \mu C $$  Two isolated conducting sphres $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ are now connected by a conducting wire.  $\therefore V_{1}=V_{2}=\frac{K Q_{1}^{\prime}}{\frac{2}{3} R}=\frac{K Q_{2}^{\prime}}{\frac{R}{3}}=12-3=9 \mu \mathrm{C}$  $Q_{1}^{\prime}=2 Q_{2}^{\prime} \Rightarrow 2 Q_{2}^{\prime}+Q_{2}^{\prime}=9 \mu C$  $\therefore Q_{1}^{\prime}=6 \mu C$ and $Q_{2}^{\prime}=3 \mu C$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Concentric metallic hollow spheres of radii $R$ and $4 R$ hold charges $Q_{1}$ and $Q_{2}$ respectively. Given that surface charge densities of the concentric spheres are equal, the potential difference $V(R)-V(4 R)$ is :

\\
solution: We have given two metallic hollow spheres of radii $R$ and $4 R$ having charges $Q_{1}$ and $Q_{2}$ respectively.  Potential on the surface of inner sphere (at $A$ )  $V_{A}=\frac{k Q_{1}}{R}+\frac{k Q_{2}}{4 R}$  Potential on the surface of outer sphere (at $B$ )  $V_{B}=\frac{k Q_{1}}{4 R}+\frac{k Q_{2}}{4 R}$  $$ \left(\text { Here, } \mathrm{k}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\right) $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_06f9eecddb573a703badg-113}   Potential difference,  $$ \Delta V=V_{A}-V_{B}=\frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{k Q_{1}}{R}=\frac{3}{16 \pi \epsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{Q_{1}}{R} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A charge $Q$ is distributed over two concentric conducting thin spherical shells radii $r$ and $R(R>r)$. If the surface charge densities on the two shells are equal, the electric potential at the common centre is : 

\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_06f9eecddb573a703badg-101}\\
solution: Let $\sigma$ be the surface charge density of the shells.   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_06f9eecddb573a703badg-113(2)}   Charge on the inner shell, $Q_{1}=\sigma 4 \pi r^{2}$  Charge on the outer shell, $Q_{2}=\sigma 4 \pi R^{2}$  $\therefore$ Total charge, $Q=\sigma 4 \pi\left(r^{2}+R^{2}\right)$  $\Rightarrow \sigma=\frac{Q}{4 \pi\left(r^{2}+R^{2}\right)}$  Potential at the common centre,  $$ \begin{aligned} V_{C} & =\frac{K Q_{1}}{r}+\frac{K Q_{2}}{R} \quad\left(\text { where } K=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\right) \\ & =\frac{K \sigma 4 \pi r^{2}}{r}+\frac{K \sigma 4 \pi R^{2}}{R} \\ & =K \sigma 4 \pi(r+R) \\ & =\frac{K Q 4 \pi(r+R)}{4 \pi\left(r^{2}+R^{2}\right)} \\ & =\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{(r+R) Q}{\left(r^{2}+R^{2}\right)} \end{aligned} $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A point dipole $=\vec{p}-p_{o} \hat{x}$ kept at the origin. The potential and electric field due to this dipole on the $y$-axis at a distance $d$ are, respectively : (Take $\mathrm{V}=0$ at infinity)

\\
solution: The electric potential at the bisector is zero and electric field is antiparallel to the dipole moment.  $$ \therefore V=0 \text { and } \vec{E}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\left(\frac{-\vec{P}}{d^{3}}\right) $$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A uniformly charged ring of radius 3 a and total charge q is placed in xy-plane centred at origin. A point charge $q$ is moving towards the ring along the z -axis and has speed v at $z=4 a$. The minimum value of $v$ such that it crosses the origin is :

\\
solution: Potential at any point of the charged ring  $$ \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{p}}=\frac{\mathrm{Kq}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{R}^{2}+\mathrm{Z}^{2}}} $$   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_06f9eecddb573a703badg-113(1)}   $\mathrm{R}=3 \mathrm{a}$  $\mathrm{Z}=4 \mathrm{a}$\\ $\ell=\sqrt{\mathrm{R}^{2}+\mathrm{Z}^{2}}=5 \mathrm{a}$  The minimum velocity $\left(\mathrm{v}_{0}\right)$ should just sufficient to reach the point charge at the center, therefore  $\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}_{0}^{2}=\mathrm{q}\left[\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{C}}-\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{P}}\right]$  $=\mathrm{q}\left[\frac{\mathrm{Kq}}{3 \mathrm{a}}-\frac{\mathrm{Kq}}{5 \mathrm{a}}\right]$  $v_{0}^{2}=\frac{4 \mathrm{Kq}^{2}}{15 \mathrm{ma}}=\frac{4}{15} \frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{\mathrm{q}^{2}}{\mathrm{ma}}$  $\Rightarrow \mathrm{v}_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\mathrm{~m}}}\left(\frac{2 \mathrm{q}^{2}}{15 \times 4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \mathrm{a}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
A solid conducting sphere, having a charge Q , is surrounded by an uncharged conducting hollow spherical shell. Let the potential difference between the surface of the solid sphere and that of the outer surface of the hollow shell be V . If the shell is now given a charge of -4 Q , the new potential difference between the same two surfaces is :

\\
solution: When charge Q is on inner solid conducting sphere   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_06f9eecddb573a703badg-114}   Electric field between spherical surface  $\vec{E}=\frac{K Q}{r^{2}}$ So $\int \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{r}=V$ given  Now when a charge -4 Q is given to hollow shell   \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_06f9eecddb573a703badg-114(1)}   Electric field between surface remain unchanged.  $\vec{E}=\frac{K Q}{r^{2}}$  as, field inside the hollow spherical shell $=0$  $\therefore$ Potential difference between them remain unchanged  i.e. $\int \vec{E} . d \vec{r}=V$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
The electric field in a region is given by $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=(\mathrm{A} x+\mathrm{B}) \hat{i}$, where E is in $\mathrm{NC}^{-1}$ and $x$ is in metres. The values of constants are $\mathrm{A}=20$ SI unit and $\mathrm{B}=10$ SI unit. If the potential at $x=1$ is $\mathrm{V}_{1}$ and that at $x=-5$ is $\mathrm{V}_{2}$, then $\mathrm{V}_{1}-\mathrm{V}_{2}$ is:

\\
solution: Given, $\vec{E}=(A x+B) \hat{i}$  or $E=20 x+10$  Using $V=\int E d x$, we have  $V_{2}-V_{1}=\int_{-5}^{1}(20 x+10) d x=-180 \mathrm{~V}$  or $V_{1}-V_{2}=180 \mathrm{~V}$  \begin{enumerate}

options: a) Electric field of a uniformly charged sphere
b) Potential of a uniformly charged spherical shell
c) Potential of a uniformly charged sphere
d) Electric field of a uniformly charged spherical shell
solution: Electric potential is constant inside a charged spherical shell.

question:
A charge Q is distributed over three concentric spherical shells of radii a, b, c $(\mathrm{a}<\mathrm{b}<\mathrm{c})$ such that their surface charge densities are equal to one another.

The total potential at a point at distance r from their common centre, where $\mathrm{r}<\mathrm{a}$, would be:

$\\
solution: \includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_06f9eecddb573a703badg-114(3)}   Potential at point $\mathrm{P}, \mathrm{V}=\frac{\mathrm{kQ}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\mathrm{a}}+\frac{\mathrm{kQ}_{\mathrm{b}}}{\mathrm{b}}+\frac{\mathrm{kQ}_{\mathrm{c}}}{\mathrm{c}}$  Since surface charge densities are equal to one another  i.e., $\sigma_{a}=\sigma_{b}=\sigma_{c}$  $\therefore \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{a}}: \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{b}}: \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{c}}:: \mathrm{a}^{2}: \mathrm{b}^{2}: \mathrm{c}^{2}$  $\therefore Q_{a}=\left[\frac{a^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}+\mathrm{c}^{2}}\right] Q$  $\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{b}}=\left[\frac{\mathrm{b}^{2}}{\mathrm{a}^{2}+\mathrm{b}^{2}+\mathrm{c}^{2}}\right] \mathrm{Q}$  $\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{c}}=\left[\frac{\mathrm{c}^{2}}{\mathrm{a}^{2}+\mathrm{b}^{2}+\mathrm{c}^{2}}\right] \mathrm{Q}$  $\therefore V=\frac{Q}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}\left[\frac{(\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b}+\mathrm{c})}{\mathrm{a}^{2}+\mathrm{b}^{2}+\mathrm{c}^{2}}\right]$  \begin{enumerate}

question:
Two electric dipoles, $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}$ with respective dipole moments $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}_{\mathrm{A}}=-4$ qa $\hat{i}$ and $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}_{\mathrm{B}}=-2$ qa $\hat{i}$ are placed on the $x$-axis with a separation R , as shown in the figure

 
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_15_06f9eecddb573a703badg-102(1)}
 

The distance from A at which both of them produce the same potential is:

$\\
